webTitle: Widow, 88, takes Barclays big boss to task

fields.headline: Widow, 88, takes Barclays big boss to task
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: In a reverse of Barclays expensive new advertising campaign, little got much the better of big yesterday as frail 88-year-old widow, Jessie Bonner-Thomas, took on Matt Barrett, the vigorous Irish-Canadian chief executive of Barclays bank.
fields.body:
In a reverse of Barclays expensive new advertising campaign, little got much the better of big yesterday as frail 88-year-old widow, Jessie Bonner-Thomas, took on Matt Barrett, the vigorous Irish-Canadian chief executive of Barclays bank.

By the end of the exchange Mr Barrett was hiding his head in his hands, ducking under a long table to shield himself from her tongue.

Mr Barrett's theatrics at the bank's annual meeting came amid accusations that he was causing a "stigma of shame" at Barclays.

Mrs Bonner-Thomas accused the bank of "big brother" tactics, an ill-thought out £15m advertising campaign and dubbed Mr Barrett himself "the Montreal mauler".

"Last September I received a letter stating that circumstances beyond your control only allowed you to increase my widow's pension by £1 a week. My husband died of a heart attack at the age of 57 in 1966 and I am in my 89th year," she said. "But circumstances within your control allowed you to give Mr Barrett a £1.3m hello".

Blame the chancellor for keeping inflation in check, replied Sir Peter Middleton, the former Treasury mandarin who is now chairman of the bank, for what she described as a "scrooge" rise in her pension.

Mr Barrett's pay, Sir Peter explained, was in line with industry standards, particularly those in north America where the chief executive was hired.

The 171 branch closures, predominately in rural areas, caused other shareholders to ask Barclays to explain its role in the "destruction" of many communities and its failure to communicate branch closures with staff and customers.

One shareholder asked: "Why is the bank spending millions on a grotesque advertising campaign when it should be telling its customers what it is up to?"

The bank's £15 advertising campaign proclaiming it is a "big bank for a big world" and featuring film stars such as Sir Anthony Hopkins, failed to win any applause. Neither did its stance over charging from cash machines which caused such a storm earlier this year.

Outside the conference centre, the protests were more colourful. Mafia, the mutual assistance for investors and account holders, hung poorly treated customers on a cross to demonstrate how they had been "crucified" by the bank.

Yet there was some positive reaction. For instance, to the bank's £20m investment in community schemes and Mr Barrett's pledge to look at the possibility of setting up community banks and helping credit unions develop.

webTitle: Tesco adds mortgages to its website array

fields.headline: Tesco adds mortgages to its website array
fields.standfirst:
Money Unlimited
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Tesco yesterday moved to grab a slice of the £115bn mortgage market by linking up with broker John Charcol in an online home loans venture.
fields.body:
Tesco yesterday moved to grab a slice of the £115bn mortgage market by linking up with broker John Charcol in an online home loans venture.

Tesco Personal Finance is joining forces with Charcolonline to create a "mortgage supermarket" on the net. The move represented the retailer's first venture into the mortgage market and formed a main plank in its "aggressive e-commerce strategy", a spokesman said.

The Tesco Mortgage Finder service goes live next month and will allow people to view details of and apply for hundreds of products, some of them Tesco-branded deals available only through the website.

It will negotiate with major mortgage lenders on these Tesco "Special" products.

Tesco Personal Finance is a joint venture between the supermarket chain and Royal Bank of Scotland. It began business in July 1997 and offers instant access savings accounts and Isas, credit cards, personal loans and general insurance policies.

However, while rival Sainsbury has been selling mortgages for almost three years, Tesco Personal Finance has until now steered clear of them. The spokesman said Tesco had been keen to do something different, and the new service "will help cus tomers save money and speed up the process of finding the right mortgage".

The retailer already claims to operate the world's largest online grocery service and has been keen to expand its online personal finance division. In November Tesco Personal Finance started an internet service for its instant access savings customers, and it offers personal loans on the net. It claims to be attracting 100,000 visitors a month to its financial web pages.

The new mortgage service is likely to resemble the existing Charcolonline facility, with Tesco Personal Finance branding. Charcolonline went live five months ago and offers 482 products from 46 lenders.

fields.headline: Skipton claims poll victory
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Skipton building society last night declared it had beaten off the carpetbaggers - despite a ballot in which members appeared to vote in favour of it converting to a bank. Nine out of 10 of the 168,369 members who voted backed the carpetbaggers' resolution.
fields.body:
Skipton building society last night declared it had beaten off the carpetbaggers - despite a ballot in which members appeared to vote in favour of it converting to a bank. Nine out of 10 of the 168,369 members who voted backed the carpetbaggers' resolution.

But before the ballot began the Skipton board recommended that members should back the resolution, because the wording called on the board only to "consider" abandoning mutuality rather than forcing a conversion.

The directors therefore claimed the result as a victory for the board - a view contested by the carpetbaggers.

"This vote signals the end of carpetbagging at Skipton building society," said chairman Richard Robinson. Skipton members also voted 77.4% against a proposal for one-tenth of the proceeds from any demutualisation to be handed to charity.

The move comes one day after Standard Life, the biggest mutual, agreed to hold a vote on conversion to plc status.

Meanwhile, the assault on mutual life offices gathered pace yesterday with a carpetbaggers' attack on Friends Provident with a target of £5,000 windfalls.

A new internet site, fpvote.co.uk, opened to collect 100 signatures of policyholders needed to force Friends Provident to ballot its 750,000 members on converting to a company.

Analysts say that Friends Provident, the third-largest mutual, could float for around £4bn - compared to £7bn which Lloyds TSB paid for Scottish Widows last year.

Friends Provident said it was not standing by mutuality as an act of faith. Director and company secretary Brian Sweetland said: "There is no question of us being immutably wedded to mutuality and we will adapt our status as necessary."

But many windfall hunters will be disappointed. Less than half of Friends Provident's 2m policyholders will be eligible for payouts.

fields.headline: Win over a jealous colleague
fields.trailText: 27 April: My boss and his secretary were having an affair for a while. It is now all out in the open but the secretary is really funny with me - she snipes and says I am not doing my work right and flirt with other men in the office. Is it because I now work with her partner.
fields.body:
The problem

My boss and his secretary were having an affair for a while. It is now all out in the open but the secretary is really funny with me - she snipes and says I am not doing my work right and flirt with other men in the office. Neither is true, I work hard and I am happily engaged to a wonderful man.

Half the time she is nice as pie but I hear she makes comments behind my back. I am so tired of it all. People in the office say she is jealous because I get on really well with my boss, who is now her partner. What should I do?
Caroline

The solution

There are three possible strategies open to you. The first is to befriend this woman - really go out of your way to be nice as pie to her. She will find it much harder to snipe about someone who is being so incredibly nice to her!

The second approach is to talk at every opportunity about your man and how happy you are with him. Wax lyrical about how wonderful and romantic he is, and the plans you have together. This may reassure her that you are not after her man (or any other bloke in the office).

Finally, you could talk to her and explain how you feel. Offer to take her out for coffee (or lunch if your budget allows) and tell her that you are concerned that she may be unhappy about something you have done or said. Don't start telling her about the comments you know she makes (she will only want to know who has been grassing on her), but just say that you feel she is often unduly critical of you or that you sometimes feel put down by her. Ask her if there is anything you are doing to upset her or that she doesn't like. Chances are, she will struggle to find anything or simply deny any problem - which will make it much harder for her to snipe at you in the future.

Try all three strategies, rather than picking one, and you may find that your enemy becomes your ally.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't

fields.headline: Hate diary dilemma
fields.standfirst:
Burning Issues
Hampstead Theatre, London
**
fields.trailText: I am all for plays about moral issues. The problem with Ron Hutchinson's new work, however, is that the central dilemma carries little conviction. Should a publisher circulate or incinerate the racist journals of one of its best-selling authors? In the real world you feel that, if the journals were any good, they would publish and be damned: the one thing they wouldn't do is destroy them.
fields.body:
I am all for plays about moral issues. The problem with Ron Hutchinson's new work, however, is that the central dilemma carries little conviction. Should a publisher circulate or incinerate the racist journals of one of its best-selling authors? In the real world you feel that, if the journals were any good, they would publish and be damned: the one thing they wouldn't do is destroy them.

All Hutchinson's premises seem a little shaky. He posits the idea of a writer, Edward Mallowan, who has created a twelve-novel sequence exploring the moral issues of the modern world; not least what to do with the paintings the Nazis labelled degenerate.

The man is a potential Nobel candidate, attracts correspondence from the world's greatest writers and is a northern recluse who has kept his private journals hidden from his tame academic biographer. Suddenly, for no clear reason, Mallowan not only wants his journals published but threatens to take his new novel elsewhere if they're not.

Think Philip Larkin, whose name is naturally invoked, and you begin to see the falsity of the dilemmas. The Little Englandism of Larkin's letters, which were of course published, is deducible from his poetry and journalism; in Mallowan's case there seems a ludicrous chasm between the sensitivity of his fiction and the banal racism of his journals. As the play proceeds, the false choices proliferate.

At one point Neil, a pragmatic Scot who wants to destroy the diaries, asks Richter, the publishing house's brash American owner, what he would have done if in 1925 he had possessed the sole copy of Mein Kampf: the implication is that, by destroying it, he could have saved the lives of 6m Jews. The reality is that the book was so turgidly written it was scarcely read even by dedicated Nazis.

Even Mallowan's frontal attack on his biographer, though amusingly written, seems wide of the mark. You can argue, as Scott Fitzgerald did, that a biography of a novelist is inherently impossible: "he's too many people if he's any good". But Mallowan's line that biography is generally conceived in sullen hate just seems sour grapes.

Where Hutchinson comes closer to truth is in his portrayal of the fractious nature of modern publishing. In Denis Lawson's production, roving between London, Manchester and Tuscany, there are sparky exchanges between John Gordon-Sinclair's incendiary Neil, Miranda Pleasence's author-defending editor and Rob Spendlove's wiry American owner. Kenneth Colley also has the right solitary grumpiness as the morose Mallowan. But it seems a pity that this unfocused debate about literary ethics has been given London exposure at the expense of Ben Brown's Larkin with Women, seen in Scarborough last year, which examined a real writer's life with exemplary sensitivity.

Until June 3. Box office: 020-7722 9301.

fields.headline: BoS plans leave investors cool
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Bank of Scotland put on a brave face yesterday after its "opportunistic" but failed bid for NatWest, pledging to grow organically via the internet and joint ventures.
fields.body:
Bank of Scotland put on a brave face yesterday after its "opportunistic" but failed bid for NatWest, pledging to grow organically via the internet and joint ventures.

But its strategy, which includes rejigging the board and a new fund management operation, failed to impress the City, which hammered its shares down 8% to 587p.

The failed five-month bid and the bank's aborted US venture with evangelist Pat Robertson cost £54m - the equivalent of 5% of the bank's profits, but £30m less than it might have been if success fees had been paid to its investment banking advisers.

Peter Burt, chief executive of BoS, said as the bank announced its results yesterday, that the bid battle, which was won by Royal Bank of Scotland, had not been a waste of money. "In terms of advertising we got quite a lot back and picked up commercial business from people who didn't realise there were two banks in Scotland," he said.

As part of its strategy to find new distribution channels for its products, BoS said it was in talks about a joint venture with "another major household name".

It already has ventures with Sainsbury's, BT, Sony and Airtours, and Mr Burt hinted that Sainsbury's bank might soon go online.

The bank has set a target of 1m internet customers by February 2001, up from 350,000 now. It said its Eubos internet venture in the Netherlands was doing better than expected and would be rolled out in other European countries.

The bank excluded provisions for the cost of the NatWest bid and other items, to show a 14% rise in pre-tax profits to £965m for the year. It will pay a 13.5p dividend.

It has also appointed three executives to its board for the first time: Gordon McQueen, finance director, Colin Matthew, chief executive of business banking, and George Mitchell, the former retail bank head who now runs corporate banking.

webTitle: Robin Houston's top 10 books on programming

fields.headline: Robin Houston's top 10 books on programming
fields.trailText: Robin Houston is a technical architect.
fields.body:
Robin Houston is a technical architect.

1. Philip and Alex's Guide to Web Publishing by Philip Greenspun
Fittingly, available on the web in its entirety. Witty, readable and opinionated: I didn't put it down until I'd finished it, when I thrust it into the hands of the person nearest me and insisted that he read it immediately.

2. Design Patterns by Gamma, Helm, Johnson and Vlissides
Drawing on the ideas of the architect Christopher Alexander (especially his classic A Pattern Language), the gang of four, as they have become known, applied the idea of a pattern, or re-usable technique, to the process of building object-oriented software. Depending on your experience, it either gives you a language to describe techniques you already knew, or puts the methods of the masters at your disposal. <

3. Inner Loops by Rick Booth
The perfect antidote to an overdose of joyless structured programming or excessively abstract code, this book masquerades as a guide to writing highly optimised assembly for Intel processors. Though it performs that function admirably, it's really a paean to the joys of speed-freak take-no-prisoners code. Booth knows he's at odds with conventional wisdom, and grins gleefully as he races past.

4. UNIX Network Programming by W Richard Stevens
All of Stevens's books are good: this one is my favourite because it combines two of my favourite things, UNIX and TCP/IP. Encyclopaedic in its scope - Stevens knows his topic inside out and explains it to perfection.

5. The Mythical Man-Month by Frederick P Brooks Jr
Written in 1975, this is the software engineering classic. Apart from some of the examples, it is still as fresh and relevant today. Nobody should be allowed near a software project (and yes, a large website is a software project) until they've read this book at least twice.

6. Mastering Regular Expressions by Jeffrey Friedl
Regular expressions look like this - /("[^"]*"|[^])*>/ - and Jeffrey Friedl knows the score. Clearly the work of an obsessed man, he claims that regexes are "one of the few outlets for the artist in me". Meticulous and definitive.

7. Riddley Walker by Russell Hoban
OK, not really a programming book, but truly great - the only post-apocalyptic novel that need ever be written. From Punch & Judy to nuclear war via the Littl Shyning Man. Written not in English but in a worn down, broken-up vernacular, Riddley Walker evokes a fragile, mysterious world.

8. The Waves by Virginia Woolf
Arguably her greatest novel, this is ostensibly the intertwined first-person stories of six friends, from childhood into old age. The monologues are extraordinarily poetic, written in language which is not and has never been spoken. Possibly the single most beautiful thing in existence.

9. Godel, Escher, Bach by Douglas Hofstadter
A genuine masterpiece, though perhaps a predictable choice. Its most astonishing facet for me is that Hofstadter's explains Godel's world-changing incompleteness theorem in a fairly comprehensible (and very comprehensive) way via Bach & Lewis Carroll.

10. Through the Looking Glass by Lewis Carroll
Probably the funniest book I've ever read, suffused throughout with surreal humour and fantastic rhymes. Dated only by occasional reference to mutton pies, the humour is as fresh as ever.

fields.headline: Drab ecstasy
fields.standfirst:
Jacques
The Spitz, London
***
fields.trailText: Side-projects and offshoots are traditionally creative outlets which serve as reactions to and frivolous breathers from the Day Job, but Jacques, the alter ego of London's premier bedsit rock band Jack, are different. Where Jack are bedsit, Jacques are bedstand. Where Jack lever out the last remaining romance from the digital age, Jacques do the same thing, but in the process get even more detritus under their fingernails.
fields.body:
Side-projects and offshoots are traditionally creative outlets which serve as reactions to and frivolous breathers from the Day Job, but Jacques, the alter ego of London's premier bedsit rock band Jack, are different. Where Jack are bedsit, Jacques are bedstand. Where Jack lever out the last remaining romance from the digital age, Jacques do the same thing, but in the process get even more detritus under their fingernails.

The chief difference between the two is that Jack feel like the saviours of Brit noir, while Jacques feel, intrinsically, like a captivatingly grubby diversion. Leader Anthony Reynolds does the Scott Walker thing, and quivers on the high notes in a way that Suede's Brett Anderson can only delude himself about, while the odd bit of violin and Will Johnson's Yamaha keyboard add highbrow-meets-everything-for-a-pound ambience. Stories are told evoking well-to-do-folks adrift in nothing-to-do places (This is What you Do), faded glamour (London Loves You) and glorious tat (To Stars).

Reynolds is one of those performers who seems to stalk the stage shadowed by his teenage self. He introduces a song "written when I was young and depressed" that starts with the line "Let's not talk about killing ourselves tonight", and you can see his previous incarnation haunting second-hand book shops in a big coat, consumed with self-loathing, the sort of troubled soul who probably found Morrissey a bit shallow and turned to Bergman, Brel and Kafka for solace.

But Reynolds' residual angst isn't a burden; it is actually an asset, something from which he seems to have emerged more confident, more self-deprecating (unlike Tindersticks' Stuart Staples, he's aware that he's a moody sod), with a clear-eyed view of the world. There's a touch of masochism about the whole thing - the sense of someone dreaming about glamourous surroundings from the discomfort of drab ones, but only because they can't be arsed to get off the public lavatory floor - and the squalid, existential, Bukowskian world that Jacques create is something which only exists, if at all, between the cracks of modern London. But you know that Reynolds must have done his research to make it sound this real.

fields.headline: Producers fear recession
fields.standfirst:
CBI urges government action as survey shows business confidence falling
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Business leaders warned yesterday that the strong pound is crushing investment plans and threatening to send manufacturing back into recession.
fields.body:
Business leaders warned yesterday that the strong pound is crushing investment plans and threatening to send manufacturing back into recession.

In the wake of complaints from car manufacturers about the damage inflicted by sterling, the Confederation of British Industry said the chancellor should dig into his coffers to reduce the corporate tax burden and that the Bank of England should signal no further rises in interest rates.

"There are serious signs that manufacturing is heading back into recession," said Nick Reilly, chairman and managing director of Vauxhall Motors, who heads the CBI's economic affairs committee. His comments followed publication of the CBI's quarterly industrial trends survey which showed business confidence falling for the first time in a year due to shrinking order books, stagnating output and a build up of unsold stocks, which may depress production in the months ahead.

Describing the survey's results as depressing, Mr Reilly highlighted a collapse in investment intentions which he said was particularly worrying because it undermined industry's ability to respond to a pick-up in future demand.

"You can't just turn on investment like a tap," he said.

According to the survey, carried out before the pound's renewed climb, the proportion of firms planning to invest in new plant and machinery, minus those who were not, was minus 21%, compared to a long term average of minus 1%. The equivalent balance for investment in new buildings was minus 30%, against the long term average of minus 18%.

The value of the euro against sterling averaged about 62p during the survey but slumped to a record low of 58p on Tuesday. Yesterday, the euro was trading within a quarter per cent of its new low, and sterling was at a 14-year high on a trade-weighted basis.

Firms said the most important constraint was an inadequate net return on investment followed by uncertainty about demand.

While acknowledging that the weakness of investment intentions may reflect unrealistically high expectations of profits, Mr Reilly said there were also strong external pressures on manufacturers.

"It is hard to justify long term investment in an environment where manufacturers' efforts to improve productivity are easily outweighed by an increasing tax burden, higher interest rates and higher exchange rates.

"This reluctance to invest is worrying for the future of our manufacturing base, even if sterling falls from recent highs. Everyone who has an impact on manufacturing must take account of the strong messages in this survey and take appropriate action to help get through this difficult period.

"There is now an opportunity for the Bank of England to leave interest rates on hold, indicating that they peaked and encouraging a decline in the exchange rate. With few signs of inflation across the economy in general, the MPC has little justification for doing anything else."

He said the government should look at ways of reducing the corporate tax burden and consider investment allowances for large firms.

A Treasury spokeswoman said: "We are concerned if there is evidence that confidence is falling but it's important to get these issues into perspective. We have macro economic stability, low inflation and total business investment is very high - it's an excellent environment for growth."

fields.headline: Rescue package
fields.standfirst:
Rover suppliers are offered £10m in aid
Money Unlimited
Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: The government yesterday made an additional £10m available to help suppliers most likely to be hit by the scaling down of Rover car making operations.
fields.body:
The government yesterday made an additional £10m available to help suppliers most likely to be hit by the scaling down of Rover car making operations.

A government task force, in an interim report, said the supply chain was "in the most exposed position" and needed immediate help. Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, said the suppliers could use money to modernise, retrain workers, retool and diversify.

The report came as rival bids for Rover neared their climax and Ray Eagan took his protest to the gates of the threatened Longbridge plant.

Alchemy, the venture capital firm aiming to buy the bulk of Rover including Longbridge, hopes to complete its deal within days.

John Towers, the former Rover chief executive heading the Phoenix consortium's counterbid, yesterday tried to persuade BMW executives to give him more time to secure financial backing.

A BMW spokesman said Mr Towers had clarified some aspects of his bid but these would have to be checked. BMW needed to be sure Mr Towers had sufficient financial backing to allow Rover "to go on in an appropriate way".

Alex Stephenson, chairman of the Rover task force, said 24,000 people were directly or indirectly dependent upon car making at Longbridge, which is due to be scaled down under both the Alchemy and Phoenix plans.

The task force admits that the West Midlands economy is at its most buoyant for for 10 years and able to create new jobs but says £27.5m of short term funding is needed.

In the longer term, a high-technology corridor should be created along the A38 from central Birmingham into Worcestershire, with Longbridge as its focal point.

fields.headline: A harrowing century
fields.standfirst:
The Greek Passion
Royal Opera House, London
****
fields.trailText: The Royal Opera's new production of Martinu's The Greek Passion is harrowing stuff, though to an extent it represents the triumph of great musicianship and compelling theatricality over uneven substance. The piece aims to encapsulate the 20th century's political and spiritual failure, and inevitably it hits raw nerves.
fields.body:
The Royal Opera's new production of Martinu's The Greek Passion is harrowing stuff, though to an extent it represents the triumph of great musicianship and compelling theatricality over uneven substance. The piece aims to encapsulate the 20th century's political and spiritual failure, and inevitably it hits raw nerves.

It is set at the end of the first world war. A group of Greek villagers, cast as Christ and the apostles in a local passion play, begin to live out their roles in reality when refugees from some unspecified atrocity stream into their neighbourhood. Tensions flare. The shepherd-preacher cast as Christ is recrucified. The refugees, having buried his body, are forced to move on. There's little question of resurrection. It's a desperately bleak work.

The score is problematic. Martinu, confusingly, produced two versions of it: the second is perhaps the more coherent, though the Royal Opera have opted for the more daring original version, which was rejected by Covent Garden when Martinu submitted it in 1957. One can understand why. Experimental and aphoristic, it seems like a patchwork of fragments which are gradually blended together to produce the whole. Operatic intensity jolts into Brechtian alienation. It is unfailingly impressive, but it takes ages to coalesce and it only becomes overwhelming halfway through.

Nevertheless, this is an astonishing achievement. David Pountney's production melds lyrical symbolism with unflinching realism to unforgettable effect. Stefanos Lazaridis's set spirals upwards towards a murky heaven. At the end, it becomes a denuded winter landscape as the dispossessed begin their travels once more.

The performance, conducted with fiery nobility by Charles Mackerras, is fantastic too. It is flawlessly sung by a tremendous ensemble, though Jorma Silvasti as the Christ-like shepherd Manolios and Marie McLaughin as the local tart cast as Mary Magdalene are particularly outstanding. It demands to be seen, whatever one's qualms about the work.

In rep until May 8. Box office: 020-7304 4000.

A version of this review appeared in some editions of yesterday's paper.

webTitle: Injury leaves Van Nistelrooy in limbo

fields.headline: Injury leaves Van Nistelrooy in limbo
fields.trailText: United ask for second opinion on £18.5m Dutch striker's right knee.
fields.body:
Ruud van Nistelrooy's proposed British-record £18.5m transfer to Manchester United was teetering on the brink of collapse last night amid farcical scenes at Old Trafford.

The signing of European football's most sought-after striker on a five-year contract at £42,000 a week was left hanging in the balance as the press conference to signal his arrival went ahead with the Dutchman conspicuous only by his absence and his prospective new employers announcing that he had failed his medical.

Van Nistelrooy had been scheduled to arrive at 4.30pm for an audience with media from around the world after having a medical at a private hospital in Cheadle, Cheshire. When he failed to put in an appearance the official line was that he was on his way with the assistant manager Steve McClaren but had been held up in rush-hour traffic.

Shortly before 6pm the club's finance director David Gill filed into the Europa suite with the director Maurice Watkin and United's official spokesman Ken Ramsden. To a somewhat bewildered 100-strong audience Gill apologised for the delay before reading out a hastily prepared statement.

"As you will be aware, Ruud van Nistelrooy has had a knee injury and has not been able to play for the last six to eight weeks," he said. "The key focus of our tests has been on the injured knee and we have been unable to complete all the necessary tests to our satisfaction. We will continue to conduct the tests with the cooperation of PSV Eindhoven and will communicate the position as soon as possible.

"I am pleased to announce we have concluded negotiations with both PSV and Ruud and will complete the transfer as soon as the tests have been satisfactorily concluded."

However, there must be suspicion that the deal will not be concluded at all. Van Nistelrooy strained the medial ligaments in his right knee during a friendly against Silkeborg of Denmark on March 6. He returned to training last week and no problems were envisaged by either the club or the player. Indeed, the 23-year-old spoke at his press conference in the Netherlands on Friday as though the transfer was a fait accompli.

A PSV spokesman said: "We have agreed to let Ruud stay in Manchester for another day to do more tests. If the deal is not completed on Wednesday he will have to come back to Holland for further treatment with his physiotherapists. We hope everything will be cleared up in the next 24 hours."

Asked whether the transfer was "a done deal", Gill said: "I am not prepared to say any more. Manchester United have no further comment at this time. Thank you for your patience."

At roughly the same time Van Nistelrooy was being driven away from Old Trafford, having arrived a few minutes earlier expecting to put pen to paper and seemingly oblivious to the medical diagnosis. It is believed the bad news was passed on to him in an adjoining suite.

Sir Alex Ferguson missed the debacle, which was being screened live on satellite television across the world. The United manager had flown to Spain on Monday, and his chairman Martin Edwards was said to be away on club business.

Ferguson had been unhappy about news of the deal being leaked last week and his caution now appears to have been justified. The manner in which the news was relayed will not have helped his mood on what was supposed to be a short break to celebrate the successful defence of the Premiership.

To confuse matters further, a potentially acrimonious sub-plot was brewing. Edwards had stated earlier in the day that Ferguson "was obviously keen to buy Van Nistelrooy. Now he has to decide which of his other strikers he feels he can get by without".

He went on to emphasise that there would be no more transfer deals unless Ferguson recouped some of the Van Nistelrooy money by trimming a squad of 67 professionals.

Ferguson now has more pressing concerns than the possibility of another spat with his chairman. As Marc Vivien Foe discovered last season, United will not risk signing a player unless they are 100% certain about his fitness.

fields.headline: Alessandro and Ronaldo earn large
fields.trailText: Footballers that see more money than you can shake a stick at.
fields.body:
Italy's Alessandro del Piero has overtaken Ronaldo as the world's best-paid player, according to a new survey by France Football magazine.

Del Piero has earned $11m (£7m) a year in salary, bonuses and advertising revenue since he signed a new deal with Juventus last year. Ronaldo earns $9.2m, while David Beckham, who earns $6m, is fourth.

 The French side Lyon have expressed an interest in signing Chelsea's Frank Leboeuf.

 Tickets for Wales' match against Brazil at the Millennium stadium on May 23 sold out in nine hours yesterday.

webTitle: Taggart finds new lease of life under McIlroy

fields.headline: Taggart finds new lease of life under McIlroy
fields.trailText: Gerry Taggart, the Leicester City centre-back, returns from a two-year exile to captain Northern Ireland in tonight's friendly against Hungary at Windsor Park.
fields.body:
Gerry Taggart, the Leicester City centre-back, returns from a two-year exile to captain Northern Ireland in tonight's friendly against Hungary at Windsor Park.

"He is a winner, possesses the correct attitude and hopefully the enthusiasm and drive will rub off on the younger players," said Sammy McIlroy, facing his first home fixture since his appointment as manager four months ago.

Lawrie McMenemy, McIlroy's predecessor, omitted Taggart for disciplinary reasons after the friendly with Spain in Santander in June 1998. "It would be naive to say nothing happened but football is all about learning and I appreciate the lessons," said Taggart, 29. "However, it was frustrating missing out for so long. Indeed, if Sammy McIlroy had not been appointed my international career might have ended. The choice would have been mine."

Northern Ireland (probable, 4-4-2): Taylor (Fulham); Griffin (St Johnstone), A Hughes (Newcastle), Taggart (Leicester), Nolan (Sheffield Wednesday); Gillespie (Blackburn) or Johnson (Blackburn), Lennon (Leicester), Sonner (Sheffield Wednesday), M Hughes (Wimbledon); Kirk (Hearts), Healy (Manchester United).

Hungary (probable, 4-3-3): Kiraly; Feher, Sedok, Hrutka, Matyus; Peto, Halmai, Lendvai; Lisztes, Illes, Derdai.

Referee: C Richards (Wales).

fields.headline: McCarthy patches up Irish
fields.trailText: The Republic of Ireland manager Mick McCarthy had to make five late call-ups yesterday to fill the places on the substitutes' bench after losing nine of his original 22-man squad.
fields.body:
The Republic of Ireland manager Mick McCarthy had to make five late call-ups yesterday to fill the places on the substitutes' bench after losing nine of his original 22-man squad.

The Manchester City winger Mark Kennedy was released for the promotion game against Birmingham City at Maine Road on Friday night and injuries or viral infections to Roy Keane, Stephen Carr, Ian Harte, Gary Kelly, Stephen McPhail, Jason McAteer, Damien Duff and Niall Quinn left McCarthy with only 10 outfield players and three goalkeepers to play Greece in tonight's friendly at Lansdowne Road.

Those 10 outfield men will all start against the Greeks, with the late call-ups Alan Maybury (Leeds), Paul Butler (Sunderland), Barry Quinn (Coventry), Alan Mahon (Tranmere) and Gary Doherty, Tottenham's £1m signing from Luton, on the bench.

"With all the club fixtures over the Easter weekend I thought there might be a few drop-outs because of injuries but I never expected the squad to be depleted on this scale," said McCarthy.

The wisdom of the Football Association of Ireland in organising the fixture must be called into question, with McCarthy struggling just to make up the numbers. "But the game does give an unexpected opportunity to several players and it would be my wish to see all our substitutes used at some stage."

Greece are likely to rely on the side that defeated Romania 2-0 in Athens in March, with a 40th cap for the Newcastle defender Nikos Dabizas.

Republic of Ireland: Kiely (Charlton); Cunningham (Wimbledon), Dunne (Everton), Breen (Coventry), Staunton (Liverpool); Finnan (Fulham), Delap (Derby), Kinsella (Charlton), Kilbane (Sunderland); Connolly (Excelsior), Keane (Coventry).
Substitutes: Maybury (Leeds), Doherty (Tottenham), Quinn (Coventry), Mahon (Tranmere), Butler (Sunderland).

Greece (probable): Nikopolidis; Mavrogenidis, Dabizas, Georgatos, Ouzounidis; Poursanidis, Amanatidis, Georgiadis, Kiparissis; Tsartas, Niniadis.

Referee: H Dallas (Scotland).

webTitle: Hull turn to Little in search of big rewards

fields.headline: Hull turn to Little in search of big rewards
fields.trailText: Brian Little has signed a three-year contract with the Third Division club.
fields.body:
Hull City have put their faith in the experience of Brian Little to guide them to the First Division after confirming the former Aston Villa manager as their replacement for Warren Joyce who was sacked last week.

Little has signed a three-year contract with the Third Division club and will begin work next week. "I am looking forward to the opportunity to join a big club which has the desire and potential to play at the highest level," he said.

"We are delighted that we have secured the services of such a well-respected and experienced manager with an enviable record," said Hull's chairman Nick Buchanan.

fields.headline: Durrant eager to deflate Dutch
fields.trailText: Veteran midfielder Ian Durrant is set to take on Edgar Davids in the friendly against the Euro 2000 favourites Holland here tonight.
fields.body:
The veteran midfielder Ian Durrant is set to make his 19th appearance for Scotland in the friendly against the Euro 2000 favourites Holland here tonight.

Durrant, who won the first cap of an injury-plagued career 13 years ago, will not be daunted at the prospect of pitting his wits against Edgar Davids and says that, at 33 and now with Kilmarnock, "I've been playing my best stuff".

He owes his return largely to other players' injuries, and another yesterday denied Scotland's coach Craig Brown the services of the Leicester defender Matt Elliott, who suffered a recurrence of a back injury.

Although for the Dutch this match is primarily a warm-up for the European championship, their manager Frank Rijkaard is keen to improve a record of only two wins in his 14 games in charge and is treating Scotland with respect.

Arthur Numan, the Dutch full-back who plays for Rangers, said: "We are not taking them lightly. Those who play have their Euro 2000 places to fight for."

Rijkaard echoed the last sentiment when he said: "I need to decide quickly on my final 22 players. Without naming names, I will be giving the opportunity to certain players to make their mark."

Holland will be without Jaap Stam, who is injured, Clarence Seedorf and Patrick Kluivert. But Scotland will need to be on their toes to repel an attack of Dennis Bergkamp and the former Leeds player Jimmy-Floyd Hasselbaink.

However, they relish the challenge of taking on the giants of the international game, an attitude exemplified by Don Hutchison, who in eight games for his adopted country has scored four times, two of them the winning goals in Germany and England.

Despite his difficulties in putting a side together Brown remains optimistic. "We have done well in the last three big games away," he said, "not just in England and Germany but for an hour against the Czechs. We were two up and Hutchison's scored in that match as well."

Holland (probable, 4-4-2): Sar; Ooijer, Konterman, F de Boer, Numan; Makaay, Davids, Bosvelt, Overmars; Hasselbaink, Bergkamp.

webTitle: Let down when they didn't turn up with the cup

fields.headline: Let down when they didn't turn up with the cup
fields.trailText: This morning, for the first time, I feel a little sorry for the supporters of Manchester United.
fields.body:
There are prize winners in life. And there are those who look on wistfully, clutching a fistful of Silvo Tarnish Guard, a soft dry cloth and a dogged yearning.

In sport it is not the taking part which is important, nor even the winning. It is about waving a lump of silverware, a shiny piece of Ag, over your head with a contemptuous cackle, while your opponent slinks away abjectly in the direction of oblivion. Somehow it makes everything worthwhile.

Most of us, alas, win our prizes vicariously and taste only second-hand glories. But the next best thing to wearing a gaudy gong and a manic grin is to see it done by someone to whom you have attached emotional jump-leads: your hero, friend, family, pet moggy or favourite marrow. Or your team.

So this morning, for the first time, I feel a little sorry for the supporters of Manchester United.

On Saturday United's wonderful players won the Premiership when they dismantled Southampton at the Dell. On Monday they returned to Old Trafford and a land fit for heroes for a cantering celebration of their success and a victory over Chelsea. At the end they even did a lap of honour before their jubilant supporters. But where was the prize? Where was the trophy for which this magnificent team had toiled so long?

The Premier League said yesterday that it would give United their pot after their final home game of the season, against Tottenham on Saturday week.

Imagine, if you can, Kevin Spacey or Michael Caine making their Oscar acceptance speech and then leaving the dais empty-handed. "Oh Michael, darling, please pop back in a couple of weeks and we will have the trophy ready for you then."

Can you see the battered, bloody figure of Henry Cooper having his winning fist held aloft by the referee only to be told to come back later for his Lonsdale belt? Can you envisage Bobby Moore leading his England players to World Cup triumph only to be told to return to Wembley for his Jules Rimet at a more convenient moment?

At Old Trafford on Monday young fans waved pieces of cardboard, cut out in the shape of the Premiership trophy and covered with silver paper. You only do that when you expect to see the real thing. They were cruelly disappointed.

The moment must be seized and trophies firmly gripped. Emotion, like a fizzing glass of champagne, does not necessarily last. It is difficult to put euphoria on hold.

Yesterday one newspaper attempted to cheer up everyone by mocking up a picture of the goalscorer Dwight Yorke clutching the championship prize.

Nice try. But we all agreed with Sir Alex Ferguson when he said: "It would have been nice to have got the trophy at Southampton on Saturday or after this game." And the former United player Mark Hughes observed glumly: "It was a bit of an anticlimax without the trophy."

I phoned the Premier League for an explanation yesterday and was told: "We always present the trophy at the end of the season. It's traditional."

The Premiership started in 1992. Now, there are many things we can learn from eight-year-old children but when they start lecturing us about tradition it is hard to take.

Tradition is about celebrating triumph at the time and not a week or two down the line. It is about officials racing around the country with the pot in the boot of the car, or, as in the days of John Player cricket, having a helicopter careering from one potential winner to another.

Personally, I have given up on the Big One. The carefully preserved gap on the bookshelf, between the Wisden Cricketers' Almanacks and the Rothmans Football Yearbooks, which would have been set off nicely by some trifling acknowledgment from Joseph Pulitzer or Alfred Bernhard Nobel, has long since been filled by Playfairs, dog-eared dictionaries and other aids to troubled hackery.

I have also given up on the Premier League. United will probably have a wonderful party in Manchester on Saturday week. But it will be a sham. A faked orgasm.

The real Manchester United supporter was there when it happened, at the Dell on Saturday and at Old Trafford on Monday, feeling a little heady, ecstatic - and robbed.

webTitle: Johnson keeps nervy Ipswich in automatic promotion hunt

fields.headline: Johnson keeps nervy Ipswich in automatic promotion hunt
fields.trailText: Ipswich 1 - 0 Crystal Palace
fields.body:
There is a local condition known as play-off-itis and the Suffolk medical authorities are bracing themselves for a rash of new complaints should Ipswich have to endure the end-of-season lottery for a fourth successive year.

Victory last night, as David Johnson moved to 20 goals for the campaign, improved their chances of taking the automatic promotion place behind Charlton, but Portman Road senses that they are going to have to try and do it the hard way once again.

The failure to build on Johnson's 26th-minute drive added to the anxiety because sporadically Crystal Palace were able to demonstrate pace on the break to worry George Burley's defence. The London club still need one more win to guarantee their safety, but it looks assured.

Defeat against QPR had severely damaged Ipswich's cause and left them looking to Manchester City to show their fallibility. Maybe City's generosity in allowing Portsmouth to retrieve a two-goal deficit on Monday could yet prove crucial because Joe Royle's team have a harder two games with which to finish.

Ipswich needed something to happen early if Portman Road's April neurosis was not to take hold again. A couple of headers softened up Palace for a long night on the retreat. Johnson, off-balance, then got under his shot after James Scowcroft had nipped in ahead of Matt Gregg.

Burley had restored the Dutch midfielder Martijn Reuser to his side after impressing in the second half at Loftus Road and he added some quality touches to the central areas. From there Matt Holland shot high after 20 minutes, failing to worry the goalkeeper as Jim Magilton had done earlier with a drive that just cleared the angle of post and bar.

A glorious diagonal pass hit from deep inside his own half by Wayne Brown gave Johnson the chance to put Ipswich in front. The leading scorer used his chest to shepherd the ball away from Jamie Smith before striking a hard shot through the defender's legs and inside the near post.

Ipswich kept up the pressure with both Magilton and Johnson coming close, though their own goalmouth was to come under attack itself as Palace strung a handful of moves together. The chance which Ashley Cole put into the side netting was difficult but there was a genuine escape when Clinton Morrison got the better of Brown and left himself only Richard Wright to beat. His effort slipped wide of the upright.

There was a let-off for Smith just before the break when Scowcroft's dash into the penalty area was halted by a lunging tackle. Although Smith won the ball his challenge was from behind and reckless and warranted sanction. Manuel Thetis then let Palace know what he was about with a couple of heavy tackles at the start of the second half.

Ipswich knew they could not afford to let these points slip away and continued to drive forward in search of a second goal. Andy Linighan's experience helped keep Palace together and he kept close tabs on Scowcroft.

Ipswich run-in: Apr 29 Charlton (a); May 7 Walsall (h)

webTitle: Shane and Shoaib top bill at new county show

fields.headline: Shane and Shoaib top bill at new county show
fields.trailText: The first-class cricket season gets properly under way today in a blizzard of rumour, suspicion and black-humoured innuendo. A sprinkling of exotic new players, notably Shane Warne, Rahul Dravid, Sourav Ganguly, Glenn McGrath and Shoaib Akhtar, will at least distract attention from less savoury matters.
fields.body:
The first-class cricket season, which started almost three weeks ago amid snow showers, gets properly under way today in a blizzard of rumour, suspicion and black-humoured innuendo.

Since the Hansie Cronje affair and other allegations of betting in cricket, the game has felt like a case of "never mind the quality, feel the spread". Happily, the betting culture that exists in county dressing rooms consists, mostly, of telling the callow 12th man to nip down to the bookies and put a tenner on the three o'clock at Newmarket.

Today, when the new-look county championship starts, the most urgent topic of conversation will be the consequences of the two divisions and the designer names to be found in most teams.

Promotion and relegation and a sprinkling of exotic new players, notably Shane Warne, Rahul Dravid, Sourav Ganguly, Glenn McGrath and Shoaib Akhtar, will at least distract attention from less savoury matters.

Surrey, who begin the defence of their championship against Somerset at Taunton, look even more formidable and it is difficult to see this richly gifted bunch of cricketers failing to prevail again.

They are a little tired of being reminded of the fact that the most important contribution last season came from their overseas player Saqlain Mushtaq, who in fact played in only seven games. But in those the unorthodox Pakistan off-spinner took 58 wickets at 11.37 and this season, though not available until June, he will play more matches.

Perhaps the most interesting game today is that at Canterbury between two of the pretenders to the crown, Kent and Lancashire. Lancashire were runners-up last year, as they had been the year before, and despite all their one-day glories there are many members who would prefer to see the side win the championship, outright, for the first time since 1934.

In this respect their decision to sign Ganguly is an odd one. The India captain is one of the world's finest one-day batsmen but their real need was a bowler, a spin bowler, to replace Muthiah Muralitharan. Their leg-spinner Chris Schofield, of course, is centrally contracted to England.

For this season at least, interest in the Second Division will be equally high. Here can be found some of the world's greatest fast bowlers: Shoaib, Allan Donald and McGrath, who will make his championship debut for Worcestershire today in the noble shadow of the cathedral. As if nothing had changed.

webTitle: Nervous, worried... but here to stay

fields.headline: Nervous, worried... but here to stay
fields.trailText: Zimbabwe vow to complete tour no matter what happens at home.
fields.body:
Some felt on compassionate grounds that it would not be wise to send them to England. Others thought it would be inappropriate to have the national flag fluttering gaily atop the Lord's pavilion while blood was being spilled in their homeland.

Indeed the Zimbabwe vice-captain Heath Streak has wondered aloud whether all hell will break loose on the family farm to the north of Bulawayo during the tour, and whether he and the others in the squad with farming connections will be packing up their kit halfway into the itinerary and going home to something more serious than a game of cricket.

But for now almost all of the 16-man squad and the back-room staff are in London and are glad to be there.

Arriving tomorrow to complete the party are Streak, who has been in Bulawayo with his family, and the new stand-in coach Andy Pycroft. Dave Houghton, their former captain and coach during the last World Cup here, is now a Sky commentator and so Pycroft, former test batsman and now head of selectors, is filling in.

Tomorrow too the squad begin their preparations for the first test at Lord's on May 18 with a four-day game against a Warne-less Hampshire. It will, their impressively stoical captain Andy Flower said at yesterday's official kick-off at Lord's, serve to take their minds off things.

Clad in training gear, the Zimbabweans' tour manager Dan Stannard looked uncannily like a shell-suited tourist off for a week in Spain and was suitably upbeat. "The tour was never in doubt, never has been," he declared. "We had the go-ahead from the Zimbabwe Cricket Union and the England and Wales Cricket Board, and at this moment in time there are no thoughts whatsoever about going back."

The ECB has not been quite so sanguine, however, despite appearances to the contrary. It has been taking advice from the Foreign Office as it considered contingency plans to salvage a two-test series and the triangular one-day tournament in case Zimbabwe had to cancel.

Even now the ECB must be mindful that an escalation of the situation in Africa could disrupt its summer. Yesterday the Zimbabwe manager paused at length before deciding that he could not envisage any situation in which the tour might be cut short.

Stannard, though, has a son who is a farm manager. "He has been affected already. Many farmers have, and it's a question of not highlighting it in case those who have not been [affected] consequently are. We would like to keep clear of that."

He must be anxious, though, along with the other squad members from farming stock: besides Streak there are Guy Whittall, Gary Brent, Dirk Viljoen and the former captain Alistair Campbell as well as Andy Blignaut, who may yet join the team for the limited-overs tournament in June.

"Everyone in the side is bound to be worried about what is happening back home," said Flower. "It is not ideal. When we were in the West Indies recently it was frustrating being thousands of miles away.

"But if anyone is looking to interpret this as an additional pressure, they are wrong. When you are playing sport at this level you always get dis tractions and this is another. Certainly it is not an excuse or reason for underperformance on the field. We should be able to refocus or compartmentalise sufficiently well.

"Anyway, if it's a choice between being at home or touring England then there isn't any choice at all. Everyone is determined to do well and enjoy it."

The truth is that Zimbabwean cricket treads a fine line for survival, and the consequences of this tour not taking place could have been devastating for its future.

"Ever since England came out in 1996 and cricket was televised live for the first time, the game has taken off at home," Stannard explained. "The more it is played and the more success we have, the more money comes in, so the more can be invested in development and the more players we will get.

"Our development programme is going very well in the high-density areas and throughout the country in general, so for us to do well here would be a big boost."

The touring party contains four black cricketers, all selected on merit alone, of whom Henry Olonga has the highest profile having made quite a splash here during the World Cup with his fast bowling and bouncing dreadlocks. Perhaps the most promising is the 16-year-old batsman-wicketkeeper Tatenda Taibu.

Flower believes that Olonga is underused as an evangelist for the game, but all four are seen as role models for the future. "It is absolutely vital for Zimbabwean cricket that this tour goes ahead" was Stannard's last word yesterday. He was not exaggerating.

 Jeff Thomson is standing in as Zimbabwe's bowling coach until June 20 when his fellow former Australia fast bowler Carl Rackemann will resume the post he has filled for the tourists' last two series.

Others thought it would be inappropriate to have the national flag fluttering gaily atop the Lord's pavilion while blood was being spilled in their homeland. Indeed the Zimbabwe vice-captain Heath Streak has wondered aloud whether all hell will break loose on the family farm to the north of Bulawayo during the tour, and whether he and the others in the squad with farming connections will be packing up their kit halfway into the itinerary and going home to something more serious than a game of cricket. But for now almost all of the 16-man squad and the back-room staff are in London and are glad to be there. Arriving tomorrow to complete the party are Streak, who has been in Bulawayo with his family, and the new stand-in coach Andy Pycroft. Dave Houghton, their former captain and coach during the last World Cup here, is now a Sky commentator and so Pycroft, former test batsman and now head of selectors, is filling in. Tomorrow too the squad begin their preparations for the first test at Lord's on May 18 with a four-day game against a Warne-less Hampshire. It will, their impressively stoical captain Andy Flower said at yesterday's official kick-off at Lord's, serve to take their minds off things. Clad in training gear, the Zimbabweans' tour manager Dan Stannard looked uncannily like a shell-suited tourist off for a week in Spain and was suitably upbeat. "The tour was never in doubt, never has been," he declared. "We had the go-ahead from the Zimbabwe Cricket Union and the England and Wales Cricket Board, and at this moment in time there are no thoughts whatsoever about going back." It has been taking advice from the Foreign Office as it considered contingency plans to salvage a two-test series and the triangular one-day tournament in case Zimbabwe had to cancel. When we were in the West Indies recently it was frustrating being thousands of miles away. "But if anyone is looking to interpret this as an additional pressure, they are wrong. When you are playing sport at this level you always get dis tractions and this is another. Certainly it is not an excuse or reason for underperformance on the field. We should be able to refocus or compartmentalise sufficiently well. "Anyway, if it's a choice between being at home or touring England then there isn't any choice at all. Everyone is determined to do well and enjoy it." "Ever since England came out in 1996 and cricket was televised live for the first time, the game has taken off at home," Stannard explained. "The more it is played and the more success we have, the more money comes in, so the more can be invested in development and the more players we will get. webTitle: Hat-trick hero Brandes faces grim reality back on the farm

fields.headline: Hat-trick hero Brandes faces grim reality back on the farm
fields.trailText: As the Zimbabwe team arrived yesterday for their first tour of Britain, Telford Vice meets Eddo Brandes, the chicken farmer who found fame by taking a one-day international hat-trick against England, was back at home on his farm 15 miles from Harare, caught in the crossfire of what threatens to be a bloody civil war.
fields.body:
As the Zimbabwe team arrived yesterday for their first tour of Britain, Eddo Brandes, the chicken farmer who found fame by taking a one-day international hat-trick against England, was back at home on his farm 15 miles from Harare, caught in the crossfire of what threatens to be a bloody civil war.

Brandes pricked the pomposity of English cricket three years ago. After the first two tests between the countries had been drawn, and after England's coach David Lloyd had uttered his infamous "we flippin' murdered 'em" line, Zimbabwe swept to a 3-0 win in the one-day series, with Brandes taking his hat-trick and knocking over the entire England top five in the third match.

He is now 37, but though he may be gone from international cricket he is far from forgotten. "Yeah, I'm still here: can't you hear the chickens?" he said in that strangely cheerful tone the human voice defaults to when adversity strikes.

The boast on a T-shirt worn as a badge of honour by Zimbabwean cricket folk is "This is what we call murder". It features a caricature of Brandes gleefully holding aloft a plucked chicken in each hand. One of the chickens has a picture of Michael Atherton as its head and the other an image of Lloyd.

Then came the violent farm invasions by self-styled veterans of Zimbabwe's liberation struggle and the words on the T-shirt took on an ominous significance.

Would Brandes be abandoning his farm to the invaders, like many other farmers? "Nah, I don't think so," he said. "You know, you can't just up sticks when you're talking about a business.

"We haven't had any real trouble yet but it has been a bit scary at times. But we're all in this together and we have to find a solution, which we have started negotiating towards."

He added, less confidently, that he "really can't talk about this" in case his comments are seen as anti-patriotic by the Zimbabwean authorities. Merely attending an opposition party meeting is regarded as treasonous by Robert Mugabe's police. "They're blaming everyone now, and safety is of paramount importance," Brandes added.

From his cattle and game ranch 45 miles north of Bulawayo the gentlemanly Denis Streak, the ever restrained father of the strapping perennial spearhead of the Zimbabwean attack Heath Streak, is also cagey. "It hasn't been very pleasant, you feel defenceless, but we've got a very good police force here," he said hopefully, adding that he had managed to placate the "20 or so" invaders who had arrived at his gates last week.

That said, Streak Jr's departure for England was delayed by the crisis. "We needed to sort things out in case something goes drastically wrong while he is away," said his father. "I want his mind to be on cricket, not on what's happening at home."

fields.headline: Buzz words
fields.standfirst: TV's University Challenge is the model for an innovative scheme enabling high-dependency psychiatric patients to have a voice. Judy Hirst reports
fields.trailText: TV's University Challenge is the model for an innovative scheme enabling high-dependency psychiatric patients to have a voice. Judy Hirst reports
fields.body:
Right, here's your starter for 10: name a game involving lots of shouting and pressing of buzzers that could transform the way mental health services are delivered.

The answer "Userversity Challenge" is probably not what ministers had in mind when they made user involvement a key objective of the new mental health national service framework. But then they didn't reckon with a bunch of service-users with some very novel ideas about what real empowerment means.

Userversity Challenge is the brainchild of the User Q project, a user-led initiative in East Sussex. Its purpose is simple: to open up a dialogue with people "including long-term in-patients and others with severe mental health problems", about what they think of their services.

Not, you may think, an easy task when many of the people being consulted are on heavy-duty medication, unable to concentrate and in other ways intellectually impaired. Yet the quiz game is already going down a storm with just such a group of service-users, much to the amazement of their care staff.

The User Q team has been piloting it with high-dependency patients at a former psychiatric hospital. Staff there said they wouldn't get anyone to participate for more than a few minutes. But the group went in and set up the game, complete with buzzers, touch pads and team names, with one of them playing Jeremy Paxman. One and half hours later everyone - staff, patients, even managers - was still shouting out the answers.

It sounds like good fun. But what does it have to do with monitoring the quality of services? Everything, according to User Q coordinator Paddi Mobbs. "We use it as an ice-breaker, keeping the questions very simple and non-threatening. Answers to questions like "Where's your nearest fire-escape?" or "What did you do on your birthday?" tell us a lot about a place." The whole exercise reveals more about the staff's interaction with users than umpteen questionnaires could, she says.

Not that the group rejects more formal methods. They just know that other approaches often work better, particularly when delivered by people who've been through the system themselves. So, included in the User Q "toolbox" are board games, flash cards, think bubbles, jigsaws and crossword puzzles that test users' recognition of things they should be informed about - such as complaints procedures - and their degree of satisfaction with services.

"A lot of it is about how to open up a relationship," says Glen, a User Q member who only recently was an in-patient himself. "Instead of going in with a clip-board, we'll sit and have a fag with them. It doesn't bother us if somebody dozes off during a game because of their medication. We just wait for them to wake up and join in."

The User Q project emerged two years ago, after East Sussex Brighton & Hove health authority approached Mind, Insight and other organisations to develop user involvement in monitoring local services. What happened next was a real education, according to mental health strategy manager David Fordham. "It soon became obvious that the users wanted to go way beyond the traditional quality monitoring model, which basically consists of a few professionals visiting a service and reporting back on users' views," he says.

The user organisations turned this process on its head, winning health authority support for an extensive trawl of the largely rural area to dig out the service-users, followed by a series of loosely structured events that brought hundreds of them together to draw up their own quality standards.

The project has since developed a menu of games and other monitoring devices, and these are being worked up into modules for training "user-monitors" and care staff. An input into NVQs, the local community care plan and the health improvement programme is planned. Even a social firm to market User Q - with users as stakeholders - is on the cards. "It's like a playful puppy has been let loose," says Mobbs.

For the people who volunteered to join User Q, it has been a life-changing experience. When Diana, who has been in and out of hospital with manic depression, first joined the group she was withdrawn and agitated in meetings. "Now I'm out addressing meetings, sitting on the User Q steering group and making a real contribution," she says. "We all still have relapses, but the group allows for that."

Robin, who has suffered for years from agoraphobia and panic attacks, now organises expenses for the group's weekly meetings. One member, a lone parent, describes the kick she got out of sitting alongside her former community psychiatric nurse and social worker at a professional conference, and being taken seriously for her views.

The therapeutic value for User Q members is obvious. But once it's up and running, what long-term impact will it have on services? This is not the first time user involvement in quality monitoring has been mooted. The Sainsbury Centre and a number of other agencies have been developing models for some time. However, Fordham believes the innovative tools and training potential of User Q are unique - along with its success at getting health, social services and a growing band of enthusiastic professionals on board.

The risk, though, is whether they can they meet the expectations that are being raised. Users are starting to tell the health authority what they want: 24-hour services, better out-reach and sanctuary services, opportunities to be with each other in normal settings.

Fordham says: "We've got these things in some places, but not in others. User Q means we're going to be severely challenged if we say, for whatever reason, the investment can't be made."

webTitle: Van Nistelrooy flies home but tests to continue

fields.headline: Van Nistelrooy flies home but tests to continue
fields.trailText: 8.30pm update Ruud van Nistelrooy has flown back to Holland after a second day of tests on his injured knee. PSV remain confident that van Nistelrooy will prove his fitness and that the deal will be completed.
fields.body:
Ruud van Nistelrooy has flown back to Holland after a second day of tests on his injured knee. Van Nistelrooy checked out of his Cheshire hotel and returned home this evening with Manchester United insisting that they have not finished their assessment of his injury.

United's financial director David Gill, who announced yesterday that the £19million deal had been put on hold, said: "The player has returned to Holland, but the tests are continuing."

United ordered the extra checks after van Nistelrooy failed a fitness test on the knee yesterday. United are worried about the medial ligament injury he suffered seven weeks ago and want to test his fitness before finalising the deal.

United have said that they will announce in due course if they will press ahead with the transfer, which would be the biggest in British football.

PSV spokesman Pedro Salazar Hewitt claimed it was down to United to make the next move. "I'd heard that he was coming back today, although I didn't know at what time," he said. "It's now up to Manchester United to come out with the information and say what happens next. We are not the ones who have to say."

PSV remain confident that van Nistelrooy will prove his fitness and that the deal will be completed. Just to make sure the Dutch club sent their doctor Cees Rein van der Hoogenband to Manchester this morning.

Van der Hoogenband has been supervising van Nistelrooy's recovery since the Dutch international damaged his medial ligament attempting an overhead kick during a friendly match on March 6.

PSV remain positive that the 23-year-old will be back in action next month as planned before the end of the Dutch league.

The club have also ruled out the possibility of renegotiating the fee because of the injury. Salazar Hewitt said: "We're confident everything is going to be OK because van Nistelrooy is fine. "He didn't have an operation on his knee so the injury is not very bad. "He is recovering on schedule and he has been training for one week already without any reaction and so we don't expect any more problems.

"We've also been in the same situation in the past with buying players and sometimes you can't test everything in one day. So we're confident about the whole thing because he has been recovering here perfectly. Of course he has an injury and that's why Manchester United wanted to have a complete and clear picture of it and that's normal."

"I don't know how long they will take, but the deal is done and the conditions are the same as they were before the medical as far as we're concerned. "Now we're just waiting until everything is cleared up."

fields.headline: New home for Wembley towers
fields.trailText: Wembley's twin towers are to be dismantled to make way for a new national stadium and moved 200 miles away, it was announced today.
fields.body:
Wembley's twin towers are to be dismantled to make way for a new national stadium and moved 200 miles away, it was announced today.

Halton borough council said it will use the towers, which were due to be demolished, as part of its planned £5m national rugby league museum.

Council officials have negotiated for the nine-storey buildings to be given as a gift to the borough and have until December to remove them to the Cheshire town of Widnes.

Another one of the capital's famous landmarks, the old London Bridge, was thus dismantled and reassembled stone by stone in Arizona.

Although Wembley is usually associated with football, the rugby league cup final has been staged there for many years.

A team of architects will begin a £1m operation to move the structures from their north London home to a plot of derelict land on the banks of the Mersey, next to the Runcorn bridge.

Plans for the new museum, which are still being negotiated with the rugby league, include relocating the twin towers on either side of a manicured lawn with rugby league goal posts as a centrepiece.

The leader of Halton council, Tony McDermott, said: "This is a wonderful opportunity to put Halton on the map."

fields.headline: Chelsea ponder 'failure' insurance
fields.trailText: Chelsea are considering taking out insurance worth more than £10million if they failed to qualify for the Champions League in future seasons.
fields.body:
Chelsea are considering taking out insurance worth more than £10million if they failed to qualify for the Champions League in future seasons.

Boss Gianluca Vialli has already conceded that his team have no realistic chance of finishing in the top three of the Premiership this season, meaning that the UEFA Cup is the best they can now aspire to. Even then they would still have to finish above Leeds in fourth spot or win the FA Cup final against Aston Villa, or take their chances in the pre-season InterToto Cup.

The club have raked in at least £12.5million from this season's Champions League run through a qualifying round, two group stages and a quarter-final defeat over two legs against Barcelona as television revenues are shared out from a centralised pool.

Although actually winning the UEFA Cup could raise up to £10million, there is not the guaranteed income from the group stages, while revenues are largely dependent upon being given high-profile ties as TV companies bid for the rights to games.

The premium on an insurance policy to cover the loss of prospective Champions League income would be sizeable, possibly more than £1million, but such a move is understood to be the subject of much discussion among the European elite.

Chelsea managing director Colin Hutchinson confirmed: "It is something we are investigating. You can also insure the other side of the coin, if you like.

"That is, insure against being successful so that all the bonuses and so forth are paid for you if you win trophies."

He told the Evening Standard: "Some of the premiums do not make it viable. But it is an interesting concept and we will be exploring it for the future."

It is of course too late for Chelsea to take out an insurance policy this season but reports indicate that Arsenal are also looking at the concept for possible future use.
