fields.headline: Hague accused of mob mentality
fields.trailText: Conservative leader William Hague was today accused of encouraging a "lynch mob mentality" after demanding a change in the law to give greater protection to people who defend their homes against intruders.
fields.body:
Conservative leader William Hague was today accused of encouraging a "lynch mob mentality" after demanding a change in the law to give greater protection to people who defend their homes against intruders.

Following the public outcry over Norfolk farmer Tony Martin's conviction for the murder of 16-year-old burglar Fred Barras, Mr Hague promised that a Conservative government would introduce a "strong presumption" in favour of the likes of Martin, in a speech at a campaign meeting in Alcester, Warwickshire.

"What has happened to our courts system when career burglars and muggers get a few dozen hours community service while people defending their homes against the very same criminals risk long prison sentences?" he asked.

His comments drew a hail of criticism today from political opponents, who accused him of jumping on a populist bandwagon to boost his party's chances in next week's local elections.

Peter Bradley, head of the rural group of Labour MPs, accused Mr Hague of political opportunism. "I'm not quite sure what reform William Hague is promoting unless it is a move to a gun law that we are of course very familiar with in the USA," he said. "We are glad we don't have that kind of lynch mob mentality that they have there."

Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman Simon Hughes said the Tory leader was guilty of ill-considered populism. "Any hint of what the Tories are suggesting - more people taking more of the law into their own hands - is not just foolish but almost certainly dangerous."

Crispian Strachan, chief constable of Northumbria Police, added his voice to the politicians and warned that any shift in the legal position over use of reasonable force in favour of the public would lead to a "serious increase in violent crime". He said he would not want to see Britain become like the United States, with high rates of murder and violent crime. "The definition of reasonable force has, I think, been in place since 1967, and it has stood the test for virtually every case since for the public and for police officers," he added.

In his campaign speech, Mr Hague insisted that while there is no place in a civilised society for vigilantes the law must meet the demands of "natural justice".

"Politicians aren't doing their job if they don't listen and respond to the unprecedented public outcry which has greeted the murder conviction for this Norfolk farmer who was defending his home against burglars," he said. "I understand that outcry and I share it."

The prime minister, visiting Watford, Hertfordshire, as part of the local election campaign, refused today to make any direct comment on Mr Hague's proposal or on the Martin case.

"I remind the Conservatives that when they were in power, crime doubled and in all their 18 years in office they never once introduced the rather vague measures they are now proposing," he told an audience of local councillors.

At the weekend, government sources more resources could be made available for policing isolated rural areas in chancellor Gordon Brown's July spending review.

fields.headline: The plot thickens...
fields.trailText: In the beginning there was one man, one plot. And that plot had one purpose: cultivation by the occupier for himself and his family, as the 1922 Allotments Act put it. With their neat rows of vegetables, forests of beanpoles and rusting, corrugated huts, little plots in their thousands fed generations of Britain's urban poor.
fields.body:
In the beginning there was one man, one plot. And that plot had one purpose: cultivation by the occupier for himself and his family, as the 1922 Allotments Act put it. With their neat rows of vegetables, forests of beanpoles and rusting, corrugated huts, little plots in their thousands fed generations of Britain's urban poor.

But those old certainties are gone, and allotments are now under threat as never before. They are vanishing fast as councils sell off sites to developers; allotment land has halved in the past 30 years. Urgently needed laws to protect them have not materialised. And the allotment culture itself is split by infighting, as the traditionalists clash with newcomers, for whom allotments are not just a food source but a new way of living.

Fewer and fewer people are growing their own food. The National Society of Allotment and Leisure Gardeners has lost 27,000 members - more than a quarter - since 1995. Sites lie derelict everywhere, though some places have long waiting lists, and allotments have a poor image. The movement is not dead, but it is ailing.

The new political gardeners see themselves as its salvation. For them, allotments - with their roots in the anti-enclosure movement - need to be re-politicised to meet the needs of communities. Organic gardening, permaculture, shared plots, new, exotic crops often grown by ethnic minorities, and alternative uses such as community gardens could reconnect urban people to the land. But the activists say an ageing establishment resists these ideas, hiding behind archaic rules.

"This generation are re-learning gardening, informed by hippie culture, which includes permaculture and organic gardening," says Sophie Andrews, allotments spokesperson for Friends of the Earth. "The old guard don't understand us activists, because we're middle class and they're not. It's the red/green split."

There have been cases of organic gardeners and permaculturists being resented by their neighbours, having their plots vandalised or being driven out altogether. There has been resistance to community use by older tenants, whom newcomers accuse of being individualistic and selfish.

"The national society is increasingly unrepresentative of allotment holders," Andrews says. "It wants to hold on to power without knowing what to do with it."

"Absolutely not," says Alan Rees, chair of the national society. "We are not afraid of change. We want allotments used for community use. Whether people garden organically is up to individuals, not the national society. We are desperately trying to protect land so people who want to garden can do so, yet people say nasty things about us." In 1998, part of the society broke away and formed the United Community Horticultural Association.

Where activists and the society part company is over direct action to protect allotments. When the direct action organisation The Land is Ours wanted to occupy threatened allotment sites, the society refused to take part. "These people break the law," Rees says. "We cannot be associated with them. Personally, I have stood in front of a JCB, but the national society could not be seen to do something illegal."

B oth sides agree new laws are needed. The government has not acted on the recommendations of a 1988 all-party committee which called for action to protect sites and an overhaul of laws dating back to the early part of the last century.

Into this vacuum has stepped Shell, which, through its Better Britain campaign, is working with the government and local authorities to foster dialogue and produce a good practice guide. But Shell's involvement - which it sees as neutral - is anathema to activists. "It doesn't understand activists, has no links to local communities and is excluding key people," Andrews says.

But the allotment movement may die if it doesn't adapt. "Without broader ideas about the uses that can be made of allotments, people won't want to use them," says Ian Egginton-Metters, director of the National Federation of City Farms and Community Gardens. "Then people will get more and more divorced from the land and know even less about where their food comes from."

Useful websites

National Society of Allotment and Leisure Gardeners
Shell Better Britain
The Land is Ours
Friends of the Earth

fields.headline: Victims of circumstance
fields.standfirst: Chris Johnston on new research indicating dangerous links between child psychiatric problems and class, gender and family instability
fields.trailText: Chris Johnston on new research indicating dangerous links between child psychiatric problems and class, gender and family instability
fields.body:
One in 10 British children had a mental disorder last year, according to the most comp- rehensive survey of adolescent mental health ever undertaken.

Conduct disorders (aggression or antisocial behaviour) affected 5%, while 4% had emotional disorders such as anxiety and depression and 1% were considered hyperkinetic (inattention and overactivity). More boys than girls suffered from problems - 10% of five to 10 year olds and 13% of 11 to 15 year olds. The figures for girls were 6% and 10%.

The research involved more than 10,000 face-to-face interviews with parents of children aged five to 15 years and 4,500 with young people aged 11 to 15, as well as a questionnaire to the children's teachers.

Prof Robert Goodman - who headed a team that involved the Office for National Statistics, the Institute of Psychiatry and Maud sley Hospital - said the one in 10 figure was extremely high. "It's a very serious problem; you can't find physical disorders that are that common," he said.

Although higher figures had been produced by other research, Goodman said very strict criteria had been used so only children with serious symptoms were included.

The finding needed to be taken seriously, he said, not least because these children were suffering and their lives, as well as those of their families, were being disrupted.

"But beyond that, part of the interest and importance of child mental health is that it does predict many problems in adult life. This 10% are at much greater risk of abusing drugs, having health problems, being involved in criminal activity and being long-term unemployed," Goodman says.

One of the most striking findings of the research was the relationship between social class and mental health. Disorders were more likely among children in families where neither parent worked (20%) than those in which both were employed (8%).

The difference was almost as large when measured by gross weekly household income of less than £200 compared with £500 or more - 16% as against 6%. Similarly, 14% of children with mental disorders came from families in social class V (unskilled occupations), while the figure for those from professional families (social class I) was just 5%.

Mental disorders in children were twice as likely in lone parent families, compared with those with two parents (16% and 8%). Similarly, incidences were much more common when the primary care giver, usually the mother, had no educational qualifications (15%) compared with those that had been to university (6%).

Twice as many children with a mental health problem had a parent with a similar problem, such as anxiety or depression (47% and 23%), and affected children were also twice as likely to come from broken families.

Goodman says the research had not tried to determine the causes of mental illness in children, and this would require a different type of study. Rather, he says, the Department of Health commissioned the study to help it design services for children with serious mental health problems. "Inner city areas with a high number of poor single parent families in social housing need a lot more money for services, because there will be more chil dren needing help," he says. "In the recent past, money has been moved away from, for instance, inner London and out into more rural areas probably more than was justified, because inner city areas have much more deprived populations."

He hoped that the findings would lead to the government providing more funding to areas that needed better mental health services and said its commit- ment to tackling social exclusion suggested action would be taken. Further analysis of the findings will take place, and Goodman hopes funding will be made available to allow follow-up studies of participants.

 Mental Health and Adolescents in Great Britain (£35; ISBN 011 621373 6) is available from the Stationery Office (tel: 020-7242 6393). Office for National Statistics release: www.statistics.gov.uk/pdfdir/mhc0300.pdf
fields.bodyText: One in 10 British children had a mental disorder last year, according to the most comp- rehensive survey of adolescent mental health ever undertaken. Conduct disorders (aggression or antisocial behaviour) affected 5%, while 4% had emotional disorders such as anxiety and depression and 1% were considered hyperkinetic (inattention and overactivity). More boys than girls suffered from problems - 10% of five to 10 year olds and 13% of 11 to 15 year olds. The figures for girls were 6% and 10%. The research involved more than 10,000 face-to-face interviews with parents of children aged five to 15 years and 4,500 with young people aged 11 to 15, as well as a questionnaire to the children's teachers. Prof Robert Goodman - who headed a team that involved the Office for National Statistics, the Institute of Psychiatry and Maud sley Hospital - said the one in 10 figure was extremely high. "It's a very serious problem; you can't find physical disorders that are that common," he said. Although higher figures had been produced by other research, Goodman said very strict criteria had been used so only children with serious symptoms were included. The finding needed to be taken seriously, he said, not least because these children were suffering and their lives, as well as those of their families, were being disrupted. "But beyond that, part of the interest and importance of child mental health is that it does predict many problems in adult life. This 10% are at much greater risk of abusing drugs, having health problems, being involved in criminal activity and being long-term unemployed," Goodman says. One of the most striking findings of the research was the relationship between social class and mental health. Disorders were more likely among children in families where neither parent worked (20%) than those in which both were employed (8%). The difference was almost as large when measured by gross weekly household income of less than £200 compared with £500 or more - 16% as against 6%. Similarly, 14% of children with mental disorders came from families in social class V (unskilled occupations), while the figure for those from professional families (social class I) was just 5%. Mental disorders in children were twice as likely in lone parent families, compared with those with two parents (16% and 8%). Similarly, incidences were much more common when the primary care giver, usually the mother, had no educational qualifications (15%) compared with those that had been to university (6%). Twice as many children with a mental health problem had a parent with a similar problem, such as anxiety or depression (47% and 23%), and affected children were also twice as likely to come from broken families. Goodman says the research had not tried to determine the causes of mental illness in children, and this would require a different type of study. Rather, he says, the Department of Health commissioned the study to help it design services for children with serious mental health problems. "Inner city areas with a high number of poor single parent families in social housing need a lot more money for services, because there will be more chil dren needing help," he says. "In the recent past, money has been moved away from, for instance, inner London and out into more rural areas probably more than was justified, because inner city areas have much more deprived populations." He hoped that the findings would lead to the government providing more funding to areas that needed better mental health services and said its commit- ment to tackling social exclusion suggested action would be taken. Further analysis of the findings will take place, and Goodman hopes funding will be made available to allow follow-up studies of participants.  Mental Health and Adolescents in Great Britain (£35; ISBN 011 621373 6) is available from the Stationery Office (tel: 020-7242 6393). fields.headline: Open all hours
fields.standfirst: Appointments made to suit the patient were once the preserve of private medicine. But times are changing, reports David Brindle
fields.trailText: Appointments made to suit the patient were once the preserve of private medicine. But times are changing, reports David Brindle
fields.body:
Things are ticking over smoothly in the MRI scanning unit at Queen Mary's hospital in Sidcup, Kent. Patients are coming and going, family and friends are waiting, staff are busying themselves with the routine. The difference is, this is 9pm.

As ministers prod and cajole the NHS to become more customer friendly, the issue of clinic hours is certain to become central to the modernisation process. Why should people have to take a morning off work to have a routine test? What other services today insist on, at best, a nine-to-five schedule?

At the Queen Mary's MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) unit, such questions have already been addressed. The scanner is operating from 8am to 10pm three days a week and to 8pm on a fourth. And there is no shortage of evening patients.

"We've found very high interest in the evenings because it means no time off work," says Patrick Byrne, managing director of the company running the unit in partnership with the NHS trust. "People say that their partners can look after the children and, interestingly, they can park. If you are driving to a hospital during normal clinic hours, it's just a nightmare."

The company, Lodestone Patient Care, runs all seven of its MRI units at health service hospitals until 8pm most days. The success of the later hours piloted at Sidcup means it is considering following suit elsewhere. In a recent survey, more than half the 724 patients questioned at four units said they would be willing to attend between 8pm and midnight.

There is, of course, an extra incentive for an MRI unit to operate long hours: the high cost of the equipment, and its limited life, make it prudent to get as much out of it as possible.

Peter Barker, the lead consultant radiologist at Sidcup, says: "There are key advantages to this approach. The whole set-up probably costs £2m and the machine itself £800,000. It's a lot of money for an NHS trust to find if you cannot guarantee to use it 10 sessions or more a week."

Then there is the question of the unit's semi-private status. Could such "out of hours" working be replicated in the mainstream NHS, or is it something achievable only outside the restrictions of health service labour agreements?

Lodestone began life when Byrne, who was something in the City, was asked by his brother - a consultant neuro-radiologist at Atkinson Morley's hospital in Wimbledon, south London - to help raise money to buy a scanner. Byrne found venture funding on the basis that the MRI unit, opened in 1992, would be sited at the hospital, and would contract to it, but would also see private patients. Across the now seven units,74% of patients are NHS and 26% private.

"Patient care is fundamental to what we do and we didn't like the way patients were being treated generally," says Byrne. "We said we would take the risk, put the kit in, but come up with a better service."

Part of this commitment is the extended hours arrangement at Sidcup - a response in itself to findings from the company's annual patient survey. The unit initially offered appointments through to midnight, but experience showed that demand tailed off in the last two hours. The 10pm finish has now been made permanent.

Lesley Harmes, a radiographer who manages the unit, says: "We started off thinking it would be mainly private patients who would want the flexibility of a later appointment. But we've found it popular across the board: the last two or three tonight will be private, but that's not always the case."

Patients attend for scanning of everything from a sports injury to the potential for brain surgery. Although there is always a "crash" team on hand in the hospital, Harmes admits that evening work tends to the routine and that more complex cases are usually dealt with during the day, when the unit is more fully staffed.

Working to 10pm is now reflected modestly in staff pay, says Harmes. But of more importance is a flexibility of attitude that could prove difficult to establish in the NHS itself. "This week I have worked a few extra hours," she says, "so I will finish at about 2pm on Friday so that I get the time back."

Lodestone argues that being more customer friendly pays dividends. It says the average waiting time for a non-urgent NHS scan at its units is between eight and 12 weeks, compared to between eight and 12 months in some other areas, and it points to a failure rate - where the patient refuses to go into the scanner or panics and demands to come out - of less than 0.5%, compared to up to 5% elsewhere.

According to the company's latest survey, 85% of patients classed their appointment as better than other hospital visits. Yet, fascinatingly, 44% were unaware that the unit is privately run.

webTitle: Living in the shadows of evil

fields.headline: Living in the shadows of evil
fields.standfirst: Sarah Ebner on the idological shift that has left some children even more vulnerable to abuse
fields.trailText: Sarah Ebner on the idological shift that has left some children even more vulnerable to abuse
fields.body:
Leigh was 10 when he was taken from the care home where he lived and told he had been found a new family. "I thought it would be nice," he says now, puffing nervously on a cigarette and twisting the rings on his fingers over and over. "I thought I'd have my own bedroom, that I'd be able to do my own thing, instead of hanging round on street corners like I had been."

For the first three weeks, everything was fine. Leigh didn't have to wait for 15 other boys to use the bathroom before him and he was able to leave his possessions lying about without worrying they might be stolen. Then, one evening, as his foster father was reading him a story, he started massaging Leigh's stomach.

"He started doing things to me from that day on," says Leigh softly, "and it got worse. He did more things to me and made me do more things to him. I was staying awake, waiting, thinking 'Here we go again.' I'd be up by the window, looking at the stars, wanting it to go away and be somewhere else."

Leigh was told not to tell anyone about "Daddy's little secret". In any case, he was confused because he had never had a father figure before. "I thought this was what they did," he says, his voice low and tinged with shame. "I thought this was showing affection, so I just lived with it." In any case, Leigh had no idea who to tell.

Unfortunately, that sense of isolation, of having no one to talk to, is typical of many foster children. But it can be dangerous. In recent years, it has become accepted that children in care are better off in "family units" than larger care homes. Two-thirds are now looked after in foster placements, and this ideological shift has been exacerbated by reports of abuse in residential care, most recently in various children's homes in north Wales. Those jailed include Roger Saint, who was also a foster carer.

"Detection of abuse in foster care is likely to be at least as difficult as it is in any residential home," Sir Ronald Waterhouse, who carried out an extensive inquiry into the north Wales abuse, has said. "The disincentive to complain is just as strong, if not stronger."

Janet knows about that disincentive. She was six when the son of her foster parents began sexually abusing her. It continued for years, but she didn't tell anybody. "I had such a fear of being taken away," she says now. "If I told, it would have meant choosing to say goodbye to everything that I knew and everyone I knew. You don't know what's going to happen to you. You might end up in a worse situation. In a care home, there would be other people to talk to."

Janet wishes she could have spoken to somebody independent, but that wasn't a possibility. The other option, her social worker, only ever saw her with her foster parents.

Jo Williams, president of the Association of the Directors of Social Services, says that would not happen now. In most local authorities, she says, child and foster carers have different social workers, while the government's Quality Protects programme and the Waterhouse inquiry have highlighted the need for more rigour when it comes to children in public care. Yet that has clearly not filtered through to the whole of the care system.

There is also the issue of cost. Foster care is far cheaper than residential care. (In 1998-99, the average price per week for a child in residential care was £1,793; in a foster placement it was £165.) Williams says cost is not the cause of children moving from residential to foster care. However, there's little doubt the money released by closing down children's homes is not all being pumped into fostering.

Malcolm Phillips, of the National Foster Care Association, says abuse in foster care does happen but that it's incredibly difficult to quantify because of the isolation of the children and their routes to the outside world.

H e is keen to point out that sufficient safeguards do exist, but are not all being enforced. "There's a national shortage of social workers," he says. "If they have too many children to see, especially if some of the children are placed a great distance from the authority where the social workers come from, that makes it extremely difficult to visit at the regularity required."

Leigh, who is now 19, says he will never get over what happened. After years of drug taking and general rebellion - he was, he says, trying to signal to his social worker that something was wrong - he told the police, and was returned to his original care home. He still gets flashbacks and he continues to lock his bedroom door.

"I know lots of people like me," he says. "And the worst thing is no one actually believing them or taking action for them. The whole system could do with changing."

 Sarah Ebner is a producer on BBC Newsnight. Her film on abuse in foster care will be screened on tonight's Newsnight. Voices from Care: 01222 398 214; The Who Cares? Trust: 020-7251 3117; The National Foster Care Association: 020-7620 6400.

fields.headline: Off cuts
fields.trailText: Laurie Taylor
fields.body:
There are few more moving moments in recent cinema than the long scene in Mike Leigh's Secrets and Lies where Hortense (Marianne Jean-Baptiste) and Cynthia (Brenda Blethyn) slowly, ever so slowly, come to terms with the knowledge that they are mother and daughter. A good part of the tension is generated by our sense that it might have been better for both of them if Hortense had never initiated the search. How will her life be improved by the discovery that her birth mother is a sad, inadequate and lonely woman?

Even though Leigh brings an enormous subtlety to bear upon the anxieties aroused for both parties by the meeting, he is dealing with a set of questions that have become almost commonplace in novels and soap operas. What happens when adopted children meet parents from whom they have been separated for most of their lives? Will nature always triumph over nurture?

Until now there has always been one missing element in this debate: an almost complete lack of information about those adopted children who consciously choose not to conduct such a search.

This gap has been remedied by David Howe and Julia Feast in their new book, Adoption, Search and Reunion. A grant from the Nuffield Foundation to the Children's Society allowed Howe and Feast to interview 472 adopted people and compare the experiences of both "searchers" and "non-searchers".

Perhaps their most startling finding was that nearly half of the "non-searchers" had no curiosity at all about their origins or background. They were not overcome, as were many of the "searchers", by an inner compulsion to find somebody who looked and laughed and acted like they did, someone who would provide them with a sense of completeness.

Members of this group said that they did not feel different from their adoptive family. They belonged in their present home and, in some cases, even resented birth relatives trying to make contact. This was, they felt, an intrusion of privacy against which they had no defence.

But what about those who found their birth mothers? Was this the beginning of new family life? Hardly. In many cases, contact ceased after a few years, enabling Howe and Feast to say that, for most adopted people, relationships established in childhood are more enduring that those restored with birth parents in adulthood: a technical victory, one might say, for nurture.

 Laurie Taylor talks to David Howe and Julia Feast about adoption and reunion in Radio 4's Thinking Allowed at 4pm today.

fields.headline: Proceeding with caution
fields.standfirst: Elisabeth Hoodless  wants to see true democratisation of the police service
fields.trailText: Elisabeth Hoodless wants to see true democratisation of the police service
fields.body:
Recent reports of rising crime and plummeting trust in the police prompt the question: why are our police so reluctant to involve ordinary citizens in maintaining law and order? Apart from requests to "rat on a rat", the only time most constabularies invite citizens to help is when a child is missing - and they respond in droves.

The prime minister has called for Britain's public services to increase volunteer involvement - but the number of volunteer special constables has dropped over the last few years to 16,500.

Of course Neighbourhood Watch schemes have an impact in some areas and lay visitors to police custody areas have been welcomed by police and detainees alike. But the potential is infinitely greater, as our American cousins demonstrate: in Redding, California, 20% of the police service person power comes from volunteers who daily check empty property, map crime to predict future problems, welcome front desk callers and help trace missing persons, thus releasing officers for front line duties.

In Tempe, Arizona, an urban community adjoining Phoenix, over 600 volunteers steward public events, organise summer activities with teenagers (reducing crime), build partnerships with minority groups, provide interpreter services and drive police trucks emblazoned with "volunteers in policing" to rescue stranded motorists.

So why do US police involve volunteers? First, because their impact far exceeds the cost of organising them. Second, because they are an excellent source of police recruits - the volunteers know the realities of the job and the police know their capabilities. It is an especially positive pathway to increasing ethnic minority participation. Third, volunteers are powerful advocates; they speak from knowledge and their personal commitment speaks volumes to friends, neighbours and colleagues.

The Lawrence report's revelations of the Metropolitan police's canteen culture underlines the potential value of citizen involvement in the task of upholding the peace. This is particularly so in urban areas; increasingly police officers have moved out of the areas they serve to leafier climes. They are increasingly perceived as an army of occupation.

Some constabularies have made a start: in Gloucester and Sussex, rural police stations have been saved from closure by teams of volunteers in telephone contact with HQ. They pick up lost dogs, record crime reports and strengthen community links - a key ingredient in reducing crime. Thames Valley and Bedford have both launched volunteer involvement ventures but, ironically, budget cuts have hampered progress. In South Wales, young volunteers have been harnessed to work with young offenders and those at risk of offending, with very encouraging results. Vulnerable older victims of crime in Bexhill are receiving practical care and repair for their door locks and windows thanks to Action 1066 - a CSV Millennium Volunteers initiative involving 30 people, aged 16 to 24, in community safety based in the Bexhill police station.

So why are so many constabularies ignoring this growing resource, despite the prime minister's exhortations?

Naturally the Police Federation is cautious - but not against the approach. They recognise volunteers are not after their jobs - they just want to help their communities by investing their time and skills.

Many police chiefs welcome the concept but lack the knowledge and experience of how best to attract and involve volunteers - the basic nuts and bolts.

And at a time when budgets are tight, finding the initial resources to recruit, train and match volunteers is a challenge, even though a small investment brings returns 10 times over.

As English schools introduce citizenship into their curriculum, they will increasingly look to the police for opportunities to involve their pupils in active learning - a win-win pathway if the answer is welcoming.

Change is never easy, especially when money is tight. The home secretary should persuade the chancellor to give him a challenge fund to enable the pioneers to pilot new approaches. And just as he has set targets for women and ethnic minority involvement, so too there should be targets for volunteers from the community.

Nothing less will achieve true democratisation of this key service. Police committees, citizen's review boards and inspections all have a part to play, but if ordinary citizens are to know that the police truly serve and give "best value" then we must end the exclusion of those who ask for a chance to serve, and still wait to be asked.

 Elisabeth Hoodless is executive director of Community Service Volunteers. For further information, visit the CSV website.

Some constabularies have made a start: in Gloucester and Sussex, rural police stations have been saved from closure by teams of volunteers in telephone contact with HQ. They pick up lost dogs, record crime reports and strengthen community links - a key ingredient in reducing crime. Thames Valley and Bedford have both launched volunteer involvement ventures but, ironically, budget cuts have hampered progress. In South Wales, young volunteers have been harnessed to work with young offenders and those at risk of offending, with very encouraging results. Vulnerable older victims of crime in Bexhill are receiving practical care and repair for their door locks and windows thanks to Action 1066 - a CSV Millennium Volunteers initiative involving 30 people, aged 16 to 24, in community safety based in the Bexhill police station. So why are so many constabularies ignoring this growing resource, despite the prime minister's exhortations? Naturally the Police Federation is cautious - but not against the approach. They recognise volunteers are not after their jobs - they just want to help their communities by investing their time and skills. Many police chiefs welcome the concept but lack the knowledge and experience of how best to attract and involve volunteers - the basic nuts and bolts. And at a time when budgets are tight, finding the initial resources to recruit, train and match volunteers is a challenge, even though a small investment brings returns 10 times over. As English schools introduce citizenship into their curriculum, they will increasingly look to the police for opportunities to involve their pupils in active learning - a win-win pathway if the answer is welcoming. Change is never easy, especially when money is tight. The home secretary should persuade the chancellor to give him a challenge fund to enable the pioneers to pilot new approaches. And just as he has set targets for women and ethnic minority involvement, so too there should be targets for volunteers from the community. Nothing less will achieve true democratisation of this key service. Police committees, citizen's review boards and inspections all have a part to play, but if ordinary citizens are to know that the police truly serve and give "best value" then we must end the exclusion of those who ask for a chance to serve, and still wait to be asked.  Elisabeth Hoodless is executive director of Community Service Volunteers. For further information, visit the CSV website.

fields.headline: London calling
fields.standfirst: The mayoralty is better than nothing, argues Roger White, but it's only a start in reclaiming the streets
fields.trailText: The mayoralty is better than nothing, argues Roger White, but it's only a start in reclaiming the streets
fields.body:
London government has always been a mess. The current contortions over the mayoralty are another poor show in a long run of confusion, gerrymandering, political vitriol and strife. Londoners themselves must take some of the blame - for the unforgiving ferocity of local politics, for instance, and for abandoning the needs of London as a whole to the local interests of its constituent towns and villages.

But those twin big brothers of Westminster and Whitehall have never liked the idea of Londoners running their city. London has been just too important to state and nation to be left to its own devices. So, uniquely, the Metropolitan police were accountable to the home secretary rather than a local police authority; so, its public transport arrangements were the first to be nationalised, accountable to the minister of transport from 1931; so, the interminable fiddling with London government, with new structures imposed in 1900, 1965, 1986 and 2000, sometimes in the teeth of vociferous opposition from Londoners themselves.

The notorious changes of 1986, when the Greater London Council was disbanded, wiped out any notion of Londoners having a say in how their city - as distinct from their parish - was run. And London was left, alone among the great capitals of western democracy, with no city-wide government at all except that provided by parliament and civil servants.

Now we have a new democratic settlement for London. It is in many ways a massive step forward. For the first time in history a London police authority, made up mainly of local representatives, will be able to appoint a commissioner and question the internal management arrangements of a peculiarly troubled force. The scandalous failures of successive home secretaries to ensure the Met adapted to a multi-cultural London - unremarked upon in the Macpherson inquiry report - should now be a thing of the past.

Now, too, the mayor and assembly will have greater control than ever before over public transport, traffic and roads. Even so, London self-government in the 21st century is an impoverished article compared to its heyday between 1930 and 1948. It may then have been a muddle of functions and areas, and hereditary fiefdoms had already begun to embed themselves in London's Labour "heartlands", but self-government was markedly more vital in two ways in particular.

First, its institutions were closer to Londoners. Authorities generally governed smaller populations. Of the 100 or so borough and district councils in Greater London, over 60 had fewer than 100,000 people. So elected representatives had smaller constituencies - around one to 2,000 people compared to one to 3,700 in London boroughs now. Even in the upper tier of councils running services such as education, fire brigades and health services, the giant LCC had 124 councillors for a population of 4.4m. Now just 25 assembly members and a mayor will represent the city-wide interests of 7m Londoners.

There will be an interstellar distance between the citizen and a mayor with personal patronage equalled only by the prime minister and even greater personal financial responsibilities for the huge budgets of London Transport and the Metropolitan police.

Second, London self-government was responsible for far more functions of importance to the citizen than even the new arrangements will put in place. The greatest gap is health. Before the nationalisation of the hospitals in 1948, local government ran some three-quarters of hospital beds and all the mental and public health services.

Frank Dobson, well placed to recognise this particular democratic deficit, has promised to appoint a medical officer of health for London, but power will continue to reside elsewhere. And in addition to health, local government also ran 70% of London's electricity supply and all its water and sewerage, issued vehicle and driving licences, provided income support for the poorest families and raised 75% of its expenditure from the rates.

Much of that, of course, is irrecoverable. It was spirited away by those self-defeating big ideas of nationalisation and privatisation, one ironically paving the way for the other. But in the absence of another big idea - local democracy and a larger place for it in the British constitution - the new London government, for all its radical scope and immense promise, is fated to be like the Millennium Dome: just one more temporary structure.

 Jerry White was the chief executive of Hackney and is the local government ombudsman for England.

fields.headline: Earthy delights
fields.standfirst: Jay Griffiths on why May Day events have always been seen as a threat to the status quo
fields.trailText: Jay Griffiths on why May Day events have always been seen as a threat to the status quo
fields.body:
In its pagan beginnings, May Day was a festival of fertility and the maypole, one stonking erection plunged into the wet mother earth, was its key symbol. May Day - or Beltane - was the calendar's most permissive day, the one festival the Christian church and other authorities could never quite control. Traditionally, young people went to the woods the night before May Day, to "bring in the may" and to find a maypole; grooving the dark earthy groves, vicarless and knickerless. "Scarcely a third of maidens going to the woods returned home undefiled", wrote one disapproving puritan.

May Day is personification of spring and the Green Man gives a green light to revelry with his huge "horn" full of wine and suggestiveness. It was a day of reversal, the topsy-turvy whirligig of carnival time turning work-time to play- time. The status quo was overturned and a Queen of the May was crowned from the common people. The festivities were led by the Lord of Misrule, the King of Unreason and the Abbot of Disobedience.

It was also a day for the common people to celebrate common time on common land. They celebrated their rites on the land and also celebrated their rights to that land.

First came the enclosures. Hundreds of folk festivals and carnivals disappeared with these acts of parliament which robbed people of their rights, and their sites of carnival. Then came the puritans. Hating the social reversal of carnival and sniffing the rank sexuality of the day (they decried the maypole as "this stinking idol"), the puritans banned May Day in 1644.

Over the following centuries, just as land was literally enclosed so the spirit of carnival time was metaphorically enclosed: no drinking, no bawdiness, no sex. For carnival was vulgar in two senses; it was rude, for sure, and it was also vulgar in a class context because it was of the common people. Nothing irritated the Victorian rising middle classes more than seeing commoners having a jovial pie-eating, procreating piss-up in public.

For the factories and mills of the industrial revolution, "time off" was disastrous, so holidays were massively reduced and working hours dramatically increased. May Day then became a focus for campaigns to reduce working hours. A general strike was held across the US and Canada on May Day 1886. After a rally on May 4, eight anarchists were hanged for calling for an eight-hour working day. In 1889, May Day was declared International Workers Day in their memory.

This year, there will be two celebrations of May Day which could not be more different, or more politically expressive. The one fawned on by the media and the authorities is a travesty of tradition and May Day's meaning - such as the dawn choir at Magdalen Tower in Oxford. The other, frowned on by the media and the authorities, is a profound upholding of tradition - such as Reclaim The Streets doing some guerrilla gardening in Parliament Square. The traditional Mayday is all about the sexy, earthy, horizontal plane of copulation, not about virginal choristers in a vertical tower.

The quality of universality of May Day - from the commoners celebrating common time on common land, to the internationalism of May Day in labour terms - is represented today in the People's Global Action and in focusing protests against organisations like the WTO, IMF and the World Bank which traduce the rights of common people across the world.

Protesting against corporations which destroy the natural environment looks back to Beltane's pagan roots. The word "pagan" etymologically means "of the countryside". Most of all, the RTS guerrilla gardening honours the spirit of May Day: fertile, anarchic and pleasure-seeking, coming up like shoots from the earth itself, irrepressible in its vulgar, laughing, streamer-fluttering, transformative character, but, true to the spirit of carnival, a gusto coupled with an implacably serious political intent.

 Jay Griffiths is the author of Pip Pip: A Sideways Look At Time (Flamingo; £12.99).

fields.headline: Fertile minds
fields.standfirst: 'We must do it creatively enough that we cannot be labelled as terrorists, and militantly enough that we cannot be ignored'. Simon Jones on the 'guerrilla gardeners' sowing the seeds of a revolution
fields.trailText: 'We must do it creatively enough that we cannot be labelled as terrorists, and militantly enough that we cannot be ignored'. Simon Jones on the 'guerrilla gardeners' sowing the seeds of a revolution
fields.body:
Mike's fruit trees are coming up nicely, but not so as you'd notice. That's because they are hidden - all 30 of them - behind a wall of brambles on a derelict allotment in Bristol. He hacked through the undergrowth to plant them, in soil so heavy that people had given up trying to grow vegetables on it.

Along a cycle path, his friend Bethan has harvested some chives, which may or may not be those she planted a year or two ago. The cherries and plums that thrive along the path end up as jam. And all over the city, derelict land is sprouting, where people like Mike and Bethan have planted everything from apple trees to strawberries.

The same is happening in many British cities - including Brighton, Bradford, Manchester, Sheffield and London - and in cities the world over. Wherever derelict urban land can be brought back to life as green space, the guerrilla gardeners can work.

"People go out and plant stuff where there are no trees," said Ben, another Bristol activist. "Willows are simple to do on a large scale: you push willow sticks in the ground and you can get a 40% success rate. Some people just drift through, plant and then move on."

Mike, who has taught permaculture for 20 years, says: "The idea of doing something on someone else's land takes vast amounts of control out of people's hands, but it's perfectly natural that you should want to improve your environment. People around the world manage their resources without having ownership of them, so it's strange that guerrilla gardening is seen as subversive."

Guerrilla gardening - so named after the Green Guerrillas, who pioneered it in New York in the 1980s - is not a new idea. Gypsies have practised it for generations, planting potatoes by a roadside, moving on, and returning to collect their crop. But now it has become politicised. Gardening is direct action: it can reassert people's rights over their land, revive urban communities, and seize back control of the food supply from multinationals.

As a movement, it is vague and made up of many disparate groups. But its aims are clear: to reconnect people to their land and produce food from it, using local resources and a minimum of energy. Rather than buying apples flown from Chile, you can grow your own where you live. In place of individual gardens, community ones; in place of monoculture, diversity; and in place of consumption, production. A conventional garden consumes energy, chemicals and fertilisers made from fossil fuels, but an organic one recycles everything.

Guerrilla gardening has grown naturally from other environmental direct action, such as anti-roads protests, and involves many of the same people. "Some activists decided it was better to come down off the trees and grow vegetables," says Sophie Andrews, of Bristol Friends of the Earth. "They have moved round to more positive actions rather than just saying no."

Now the guerrilla gardeners have gone global. On May Day, the direct action group Reclaim the Streets, under the slogan "Resistance is Fertile", will hold planting events in London, Manchester, Belfast, Bristol and Brighton as part of a global day of action against capitalism. Earlier this month, similar actions took place in Washington, at the International Monetary Fund and World Bank summit. As one US instruction leaflet said: "We must do it creatively enough that they cannot credibly label us as terrorists, and militantly enough that we cannot be ignored."

This has taken guerrilla gardening beyond the local context and into the arena of challenging capitalism and consumption. Jack Tann, of Reclaim the Streets, says: "It is not just green; it is also symbolic of taking back the land under people's feet - land they have to buy or rent - and breaking up the alienating cycle of producers and consumers. It represents the idea that people have the power and right to decide how they live. We do not have to live in this ugly and constrained way under capitalism."

It all started in New York, where, in the blighted, brownish landscape of Manhattan's lower east side, a group called the Green Guerrillas began to plant gardens among the burnt-out slum tenements. What began as squats by activists and poor residents eventually became full-blown community gardens.

Local traditions and ethnic minorities flourished. In some gardens, central American immigrants reproduced the conditions of their home villages, keeping chickens, building huts and drinking beer with their friends on hot days. Thus communities were given the power to control their environment, even though, under the zero tolerance regime of the city's Republican mayor, Rudolph Giuliani, many of their activities were criminalised.

Puerto Ricans, Anglo-Saxons, Dominicans, Colombians, Poles and many other groups planted and worked together, painted murals, secured grants. They held poetry readings and jazz concerts.

The gardens spread throughout Manhattan and up to the Bronx, until they numbered close to 1,000 in the city as a whole. But they were victims of their own success. As areas were improved so they became safer and, eventually, gentrified. Once the land underneath a garden had become attractive to build on, the garden was threatened. A series of planning battles followed in the late 1990s, and a number of gardens were bulldozed and destroyed. Nevertheless, New York's guerrilla gardening movement has demonstrated what can be achieved. Many hundreds of gardens survive, and many have sprung up in other cities, including San Francisco and Vancouver.

The US experience helped inspire the growth of community gardens in Britain. As in New York, many began with squatting, or a local community fighting to keep green waste land. Among the earliest were the Calthorpe Street project on a derelict site near King's Cross, a deprived area of inner London, and the Windmill Hill city farm in Bristol. Here and in many other places what was started by activists brought lasting benefits to a whole community.

Community gardens - and city farms, which are similar but with livestock - are booming in Britain, unlike allotments, which are declining as interest wanes. There are now 518 community gardens, run by volunteers, and 68 farms. Tellingly, more than a third are in the 33 most deprived districts in England. Of the remainder, many are in deprived pockets in more affluent areas.

Between them, they provide green space for more than 300,000 people. But like those in New York, they may also be threatened by development. As the government tries to find space for millions of extra homes on "brownfield" sites within cities, the gardens are soft targets for developers. Judging from experience, even the most dedicated activists may be powerless to stop the bulldozers.

Guerrilla Gardens and Urban Ecology
Avant Gardening

fields.headline: Fighting talk
fields.standfirst: Alison Smith on how drama can prevent crisis leading to violence
fields.trailText: Alison Smith on how drama can prevent crisis leading to violence
fields.body:
"A few weeks ago, one parent was outside threatening people with a machete." We're about to start a teacher training session on conflict resolution, and I'm talking to Harriet, a classroom assistant at a Norfolk middle school.

The training is led by Tiebreak, a touring theatre company based in Norwich, and complements a series of drama workshops for 11 to 12 year olds. The workshops look at issues related to domestic violence and use drama, improvisation and role-play to encourage young people to solve problems without resorting to aggression.

The session is well-attended and we begin with feedback from the two teachers whose classes have been directly involved in the workshops. Claire's children thought the workshops were fun and were keen to join in. They were attentive throughout, and she was particularly pleased to see children from the learning support centre taking a full part in all the activities. Everyone worked together co-operatively, and she was impressed by how willing children were to talk about their experiences. Some children in Brian's class were hesitant at first. They lacked confidence and were self-conscious about joining in the role-playing activities. But, as the workshops progressed, he noticed they gained confidence and began to voice their opinions.

For Brian, the most successful element was the "image theatre" - a drama technique where participants form frozen images representing an emotion or situation. In this case, the theme was bullying and the whole class was involved in building up a story about an incident in the park. Brian thought it was important for the children to see how easily a situation can escalate into violence and to consider the events leading up to it.

Next it's time for some practical work. Each school has been given a resource pack with suggestions on how the project might be used as a springboard for further work on resolving conflict. The pack covers themes such as relationships, feelings, self-esteem, gender stereotypes and violent images - all of which can be linked to domestic violence. To help staff get the most from the pack, we want to try out some drama activities.

Everyone gets into pairs. Each pair is asked to make two frozen images: one showing a conflict situation and the other, a move towards resolution. When they are touched on the shoulder they must say what they are thinking at that moment.

Claire and Brian's first image is of an argument. It looks ferocious. For their second, Brian is shrugging his shoulders - he has a look of resignation. When tapped on the shoulder, he says: "What's the point? I give up."

Afterwards, Brian confesses to finding this task quite difficult because he hates confrontation and always tries to avoid arguments. In fact, his wife cited his inability to argue in their divorce proceedings.

Harriet and Bob's is about money: Bob is hopeless with it, and Harriet has had enough. Their attempt at resolution is somewhat extreme - Harriet is going to take responsibility for her own finances, leaving Bob to do what he likes. I can't help thinking this one will run and run. Next, everyone is asked to imagine they are about 10 years old. They can hear their parents arguing downstairs. The row is getting heated and could turn violent. What should they do? The exercise provokes discussion about how children cope with domestic violence. How do they deal with the myriad of feelings they experience? Are these feelings manifested in bad behaviour and poor achievement?

The training was developed in collaboration with Relate Norfolk and Norwich: and to end, we look at some Relate information about managing conflict. As we pass round leaflets on stress, depression, relationships and divorce, we're conscious that it's not just children who need to learn about conflict resolution.

fields.headline: New citizens on the block
fields.standfirst: Neighbourhood Watch is coming out from behind the net curtains and on to the streets. Volunteers are working publicly with the police both here and in the US. But is it only the prosperous middle classes who take part and benefit? Chris Arnot reports
fields.trailText: Neighbourhood Watch is coming out from behind the net curtains and on to the streets. Volunteers are working publicly with the police both here and in the US. But is it only the prosperous middle classes who take part and benefit? Chris Arnot reports
fields.body:
The briefing from Sergeant Kevin Pearson, of Rose Road police station, ends with the sort of message we came to expect from Hill Street Blues. "Be careful out there," is what it amounts to, although what Pearson actually says is: "We don't expect you to put yourselves at risk." Risks are not immediately evident from our gathering point outside a sub-post office and close to some tennis courts in leafy Harborne, a prosperous suburb of Birmingham.

All looks peaceful at two o'clock on a Friday afternoon. But appearances can be deceptive. The sarge goes on to tell us that, earlier this week, there have been six burglaries here in 48 hours. What's more, most of them have happened in the afternoon while the majority of local householders have been out earning an honest living.

"This is high-visibility policing," he says, glancing at our eye-wateringly lurid yellow jackets. "Should the villains revisit this area, they'll see these jackets and think twice about it."

Let's hope so, because the majority of those patrolling the beat this afternoon are not hardened cops: they're just law-abiding citizens who have volunteered their services for an hour or so. Neighbourhood Watch is coming out from behind the curtains and on to the streets. It was Pearson's idea. "When I've been to Neighbourhood Watch meetings," he says, "I've detected a lot of untapped enthusiasm for doing a bit more than just watching. There are a lot of very public-spirited people out there and the public generally has always hankered for more bobbies on the beat.

"In fact, the chances of a beat bobby catching a burglar in the act are fairly remote, unless he's acting on prior information. A scheme like this puts a visible presence on the street, which reassures the neighbours while letting the criminals know that they're being watched."

There are around 30 regular volunteers. A number are women or pensioners, sometimes both. A few are young professionals in their twenties. They go out in shifts, usually three or four at a time and always in the company of a police officer. For the most part, they go after dark. Today's afternoon promenade is in response to a specific outbreak of daylight robberies. This is the fifth such patrol, so it's too early to draw any conclusions about the likely deterrent effect. Perhaps it's a coincidence that the figures for domestic burglaries in Harborne are down from 256 to175 - a drop of 32%. But that's since last April. The volunteers' initiative only started in December. The effects of deterrence, unlike detection, are impossible to gauge. Who knows how many burglars have been put off by the busy-bodies in yellow jackets, or simply moved their activities elsewhere?

Nationwide, the home secretary has set a target of a 26% reduction in burglaries by the year 2005. So at the very least, Pearson's patch is off to a flying start in the context of a West Midlands force where the overall drop in burglaries over the same period is 5%. But he's well aware that this is a marathon, not a sprint, and his neighbourhood patrols are more likely to be effective in prosperous middle-class suburbs than in the inner city. "It probably wouldn't work in areas where the public is not so solidly behind the police," he concedes. "The volunteers might be victimised and harassed by criminals."

Yet the government is keen to involve local residents in crime prevention in more deprived areas. Last month final proposals were released for neighbourhood wardens to patrol housing estates and inner-city streets. "These schemes can complement local services by improving communication between residents and local authorities or the police, and mediate in minor incidents of anti-social behaviour," says Home Office minister Charles Clarke. In fact, the notion of the public giving up time voluntarily to help the police has been growing for some time, irrespective of government

South Wales has "street watch" schemes in Cardiff, Swansea and Bridgend, where residents walk around their areas in pairs and ring in to their local stations to report any suspicious activity. In forces such as Gloucestershire and Thames Valley, volunteers are taking on clerical tasks or manning front desks in country stations in order to free uniformed officers for more visible police work.

Elisabeth Hoodless, executive director of Community Service Volunteers, is enthusiastic. "I think it's very important," she says, "that citizens are involved in upholding the police. It's also good for the police - who, in some areas, are like an army of occupation- to see that there are just as many citizens who want to keep the peace."

In the US, she points out, many police forces recruit 10% of their "people from volunteers. "Retired people in Long Beach, California, are out on bikes patrolling the homes of those in the neighbourhood who are away on holiday," she says. "In Tempe, Arizona, volunteers are out in trucks, looking for people stranded on the motorway."

Back in Harborne in Birmingham, our six-strong patrol is being split into two. The three milddle-aged women present are going with PC Rex Couch, a bulkily reassuring copper of the old school with a bristling moustache. "I've got my mobile so I can call 999," trills one of his charges. "That won't be necessary; Rex can radio for back-up if he needs it," Pearson assures her before setting off in the opposite direction with myself and two stalwarts of the Harborne and West Edgbaston Neighbourhood Watch.

The chairman, Ron Hill, 63, now takes Friday afternoons off from his engineering company. His deputy, Richard Rawsthorne, 62, is a retired banker whose home was recently burgled while he and his wife were away at a conference. "In Harborne, we've got more to nick than some," Hill admits as we pound the pavements. "We're surrounded by areas less fortunate than we are and this is an easy place to slip in and out of."

Having stood up to be counted in the fight against crime, he is determined to give evidence if ever he's called upon. "I'm not going to be intimidated," he says. "You've got to have the courage of your convictions." "Absolutely," Rawsthorne concurs.

Both men have already witnessed rather more than they bargained for. On their second patrol, on an otherwise quiet midweek evening, they stumbled across a spirited fight between two young men in a pub car park. Pearson managed to pull the combatants apart and calm them down. "We had to stand and watch," Hill recalls, ruefully. "But if they'd turned on him, we wouldn't have stood idly by."

Thankfully, there's not the remotest threat of violence this afternoon. Nor, indeed, any sign of criminal activity whatsoever. The only ones to accost us are a group of mothers walking their children home from school and curious to know what we're up to. Judging by the twitching curtains and slowing cars on every street, they're not the only ones. High-visibility policing is evidently causing a bit of a stir in the neighbourhood - which is exactly what it's intended to do.

Back at the sub-post office an hour after we left, PC Couch and his "ladies" have nothing untoward to report. Meanwhile, the next patrol is being briefed. Six hours from now it will be time to be careful out there. The pubs on nearby Hagley Road will be packed with revellers and Rose Road police station will be gearing up for a busy Friday night. By that time, many of the Neighbourhood Watch patrollers will be back behind the curtains.

fields.headline: Cover stories
fields.trailText: Police in Nottingham have asked church congregations to direct their prayers at a suburb where there is a high level of youth crime
fields.body:
God squad: Police in Nottingham have asked church congregations to direct their prayers at a suburb where there is a high level of youth crime.

Inside job? Thieves stole a painting that was part of an exhibition of prison inmates' art at a gallery in Stockton-on-Tees.

Dogged determination: Staff at a veterinary centre in Newcastle upon Tyne treated a dog which limped in on its own after being hit by a car.

Job lot: A host of job vacancies have arisen on the Hebridean island of Gigha following the retirement of a man who held 14 positions, ranging from policeman and fireman to pier master and undertaker.

Parental concern: The parents of a woman who had phoned to say she was going into labour arrived at the hospital in Whiston, Merseyside, in an ambulance after the mother fell downstairs and the father suffered a panic attack.

Living dangerously: An endangered species of shrimp is thriving on Salisbury Plain army training area, Wiltshire, in water- filled ruts carved out by tanks.

Heady brew: A further education college in Plymouth is soon to have its own brewery for students on a course in beer making.

Mass appeal: Health and safety officials at Manchester city council have warned the priest of a church in Chorlton-cum-Hardy to restrict the size of his congregations for mass because of the danger of overcrowding.

Tall order: A builder who created a 43-foot obelisk at his home in Great Rissington, Gloucestershire, in memory of his late wife has been ordered to scale it down following complaints by neighbours.

Morris major: A group of Morris dancers formed the guard of honour at the wedding in Colchester, Essex, of a Morris Minor restorer named Morris.

Harry's shame: The head of a primary school in Chatham, Kent, has banned pupils from reading J K Rowling's Harry Potter books because she claims they go against the Bible's teaching.

Hot ticket: Residents of a home for elderly people in Handforth, Cheshire, had to be evacuated when a fire-eater at an entertainment night set off the smoke alarms.

One.God: A competition organised by the rector of a church in Lewes, East Sussex, to invent an email address for God received only one entry.

Aerial struggle: Firefighters had to rescue a football fan from the roof of his home in Middlesbrough after he got stuck while trying to adjust the aerial so he could watch a match on TV.

webTitle: In his own words: Tony Martin's story

fields.headline: In his own words: Tony Martin's story
fields.standfirst: Two weeks before Martin's murder trial started, he gave his story to Norfolk's Eastern Daily Press. What follows is an extract from his five-hour interview. You can read the whole transcript on Norfolk Now, the Eastern Daily Press website.
fields.trailText: "Look, I don't agree with shooting people.                   It's not something I take lightly. On the night                   of the burglary I was a terrified man alone in                   the house...
fields.body:
"Look, I don't agree with shooting people. It's not something I take lightly. On the night of the burglary I was a terrified man alone in the house...

"I heard this murmuring and had this light shone in my eyes. All these things happened in a flash. I couldn't stand it any longer and then I just let the gun off.

"When you resort to using a gun you are desperate. I've never used that shotgun before. I'm not really interested in shooting rabbits round the house. I didn't even know if it worked. I discharged the gun and then ran upstairs. Nobody followed me."

fields.headline: Steven Norris, live online
fields.standfirst: The Conservative candidate for London mayor answers your questions
fields.trailText: The Conservative candidate for London mayor answers your questions
fields.body:
Steven, you seem like a decent bloke. Surely, especially given your recent utterances, it's time for you to leave the Conservative party?
Angela
No, I still have every intention of working hard to make the Conservative party as attractive to ethnic minorities as I believe it should be. I have a very good relationship with William Hague. He is a decent, fair minded man and I know he believes as I do that equality is indivisible. If I ever thought the Tories were either racist or homophobic I would leave the party. Sadly, every political party has its share of bigots but I don't believe the Conservatives are particularly over represented in that category! If you couldn't control transport, still less control your trousers, how are you going to control one of the biggest cities in the world?
Paul King
Do you really expect a serious answer to such a pathetically sniggering 14-year-old question. My strong advice is to get outdoors more and find a girlfriend. Mind you, could take you some time. How will Steven accommodate or facilitate for the growing business demands in the City? Particularly in terms of building heights and floorplate sizes. Can we expect Manhattan?
Ben Wrighton
I have no problem with tall buildings in appropriate locations and broadly, I do see the City accommodating increasing densities. It may not be Manhattan but over the next 10 years we have to keep pace with the demands of business and Docklands will not be able to absorb all the capacity we are likely to generate. On a related issue I do believe we have to look at residential densities if we are going to increase the amount of affordable housing in this city. It is an irony that Georgian terraces are far more dense than modern two storey semis. With good design we can raise heights, increase density and make the city more attractive at the same time. 1. You say you will increase the London weighting. Good. But by how much? Clearly if it's going to allow public sector workers to buy home sit will need to be a very substantial rise.

2. Brownfield development; high density housing; protection of green belt. Fine words indeed. Will you support the policy of the Empty homes agency to reduce VAT on refurbishment from 17.5% and equalise it vis a vis new homes? I'm not asking if you agree in principle with this but whether you will promise to do it?

3. You seem to be opposed to all social housing and your desire for an audit of council housing sounds suspiciously like a plan for a sell-off. This feeling is strengthened by your commitment to a right-to-buy drive. Can you explain in greater detail how your plan of PPP will provide the necessary affordable houses?
Michael O'Flynn
1.London weighting needs to be increased to a maximum of £6,000 as compared to the current ceiling of £3,000. To do this for police officers (post Sheehey) teachers and other public sector workers in London will cost around £820m. This represents a tiny proportion of the funds London is currently denied by the Barnett formula - around £3.5bn. There is no short cut here. The Home Office accepts the problem exists and that something urgent must be done. 2. Yes. 3. You are quite wrong. I perfectly accept the value of social housing. I have no plans to campaign to sell any of it off. I don't know where you get this idea of "my committment to a right to buy drive" but it is news to me. Working with the housing corporation and the existing housing associations in London and putting them together with public sector employers and private sector funders can fund tied accomodation for example for key workers. Steve, do you support William Hague and the Conservative party's policy of immediate detention of all asylum seekers?
Cedric
I certainly think we have to have a serious look at how the current policy is working. Is it reasonable to suggest that in a number of cases, whilst the motives of those applying are perfectly understandable, their claim to asylum status does not stand examination? Are there any circumstances in which those who do not qualify should be returned to whence they came? And if the answer to the above questions is yes, then is it not reasonable to deal with all applicants quickly and then ensure that the decisions are implemented? I think the answer to all three questions is yes. Every applicant is entitled to their dignity and to a fair and prompt hearing. It may be that in order to process applications efficiently applicants need to be directed to reception centres. If that is logistically necessary I would not shrink from it. What is very worrying to me is that the current position does appear to be damaging good community relations in London. When many boroughs are spending more on the problem than they are on their own elderly population, and when housing waiting lists applicants see accomodation being allocated ahead of them they resent the burden. It is not the fault of the asylum seeker but it is most certainly an issue the government has to address urgently. Do you not think that opposing the euro outright is unhelpful for the City's balancing act of maintaining importance while staying outside?
Brian Wolfe
No. You will be aware that the London Chamber of Commerce research has satisfied them, and many others, that there are no adverse consequences for the City deriving from our not joining the euro. My objections are economic and constitutional. They are most certainly not anti-european.
Can you let me know what your thoughts are on people who email questions to you when they should be working? Would you lock them all up in one of Mr Hagues camps?
Jonathan
Ha ha. Yeah. Actually I can't answer all the questions coming in but I am really impressed by the quality. There are some very bright Guardian readers out there.

What is the mayor actually going to be able to do? You all talk sensibly about crime, transport, jobs and free sweets for everyone. What makes you think you'll have any effect as mayor when your party so signally failed in government to implement any of these improvements for Londoners?
Simon Paley
There is a real difference between what a junior minister can do (very little in reality) and what a mayor can do with real executive authority. It is not about money alone. As a minister you advise organisations like LT, you answer for them when things go wrong and you try to take the credit when things go right, but ultimately it's their call. As mayor if you don't like what LT management is doing, you change them. Get it wrong and you alone are to blame. Get it right and you deserve to get the credit.

How is Mr Norris going to deal with spiralling house RENTAL prices in the capital?
Rory Cook
Not easy but I believe that you can make progress in at least two ways. First, we have to review London weighting to allow public servants to keep pace with the massive increase in freehold values and rents. Second, we have to make more affordable housing available, both tied to key public sector workers (teachers, nurses, police) and for more general consumption. Steve.

fields.headline: Spacey: the new Clouseau?
fields.standfirst: • Would Spacey make a good Clouseau? In case negotiations fail, we've come up with a few alternatives. Click here to see our suggestions.
fields.trailText: Kevin Spacey's move into more mainstream, user-friendly comedy continues today with the news that the double Oscar-winning actor is currently in negotiations to star in MGM's long-planned remake of The Pink Panther. The 40-year-old star would play the blundering, self-conscious French cop Inspector Clouseau - a role made famous by the great Peter Sellers.
fields.body:
Kevin Spacey's move into more mainstream, user-friendly comedy continues today with the news that the double Oscar-winning actor is currently in negotiations to star in MGM's long-planned remake of The Pink Panther. The 40-year-old star would play the blundering, self-conscious French cop Inspector Clouseau - a role made famous by the great Peter Sellers.

But MGM vice-president Chris McGurk hastens to put out that these negotiations are still at a fledgling stage. "Currently he is not attached," McGurk admits. "But we are in discussions with Kevin Spacey."

The Pink Panther remake will be produced by Ivan Reitman and will begin shooting at the end of year. However, it looks set to struggle to find a window in Spacey's increasingly hectic schedule, which includes a starring role in the adaptation of E Annie Proulx's The Shipping News and an as yet untitled romantic comedy that he will also produce.

The original Pink Panther picture was filmed back in 1963 and followed the fortunes of Clouseau as he hunted a debonair cat burglar (David Niven) who had swiped a priceless jewel. The film was so successful that it inspired a long-running TV cartoon and seven sequels.

Even Sellers, who succumbed to a heart attack in 1980, found that death was no barrier to further adventures. The last Pink Panther film - 1982's The Trail of the Pink Panther - was pieced together with out-takes from his previous pictures.

 Would Spacey make a good Clouseau? In case negotiations fail, we've come up with a few alternatives. Click here to see our suggestions.
