webTitle: The superstars came in two by two

fields.headline: The superstars came in two by two
fields.trailText: When Shane Warne and Glenn McGrath signed their six-figure contracts for this summer, they probably weren't thinking in terms of having to bowl a two-over spell in a ten-over thrash on a puddle-strewn ground in the April twilight. But that's what both of them found themselves doing on Monday.
fields.body:
When Shane Warne and Glenn McGrath signed their six-figure contracts for this summer, they probably weren't thinking in terms of having to bowl a two-over spell in a ten-over thrash on a puddle-strewn ground in the April twilight. But that's what both of them found themselves doing on Monday.

And it was interesting to see how they coped. Warne came on to bowl when Surrey were, if not cruising, then splashing towards victory over Hampshire at The Oval, and turned the match. On a day when the typical over went for eight and a half runs, Warne's two went for three apiece, and he also took two big wickets. Graham Thorpe top-edged a sweep off what was reported in the Telegraph as a googly - the one legspinner's weapon that Warne doesn't normally have in his armoury. Then poor old Adam Hollioake was bowled by Warne, just as he was (playing no stroke) at the same ground, the last time either of them played in a Test in this country, in August 1997. Result: Hampshire squelched through by two runs.

Warne has one advantage in underwater cricket: he has the shortest, slowest run-up in the world. This is just one of the differences between him and Glenn McGrath, whose debut for Worcestershire at Edgbaston turned into another 10-over job. His new team-mates couldn't have done much more to help him with the bat, piling up 91 for 4 in their 10 overs. But then McGrath took none for 21 in his two overs and his opening partner, Kabir Ali, fresh from a four-wicket debut, did even worse, with none for 31. Nick Knight belted 30 off 18 balls and Warwickshire romped home with a ball to spare.

Don't write McGrath off yet, though. Last time he bowled badly at Edgbaston, in the first Test of 1997, he hung around at the end of the game for extra practice on the square, located the right length for English conditions, and proceeded to take 8 for 38 at Lord's. If the rain ever stops, someone will be made to pay.

Tim de Lisle is editor of wisden.com and Wisden Cricket Monthly.

fields.headline: Soundbites and fury
fields.standfirst: William Hague's headline-grabbing call to strengthen the law on self-defence mimics the style of New Labour in opposition but not the substance, writes political correspondent Nicholas Watt
fields.trailText: William Hague's headline-grabbing call to strengthen the law on self-defence mimics the style of New Labour in opposition but not the substance, writes political correspondent Nicholas Watt.
fields.body:
William Hague is so obsessed with Labour's mastery of the media that he has deluded himself into thinking that elections are won by the number of banner headlines he can seize.

His aides have therefore been preening themselves this morning as they survey the front pages which are all dominated by Mr Hague's pledge to change the law to give greater protection to people who are forced to defend themselves against burglars.

Tony Blair grabbed the headlines with policy announcements while in opposition and we are just following his example, goes the thinking among members of the Hague inner circle.

Unfortunately for Mr Hague there are two crucial differences between the Labour party in the run-up to the general election of 1997 and today's Conservative party.

All of New Labour's major policy changes were announced after a lengthy period of work in which they were tested on countless focus groups and subjected to rigorous tests to assess how much they would cost. The policies were also designed to reach out to voters in the centre ground where Mr Blair knew the election would be won.

Mr Hague's speech today, which follows hard on the heels of his pledge to lock up all asylum seekers, appears to be a knee-jerk reaction to the outcry over the jailing of Tony Martin. The farmer has barely been in jail for a week and the Tory leader has announced a major change in the law which would introduce a "strong presumption" in favour of people forced to defend their homes.

Unlike Labour's efforts to reach out to new voters, Mr Hague's speech appears to have been inspired by an outcry in the rightwing press and among his own backbenchers.

Labour and the Liberal Democrats wasted little time in condemning the speech, with one Labour MP accusing the Tory leader of fostering a "lynch mob mentality".

But in a sign of how far Mr Hague has lurched to the right, a chief constable was also moved to criticise his plans. Northumbria's Crispian Strachan said that Mr Hague's proposed change in the law would lead to a "serious increase in violent crime".

The Hague inner circle will be unmoved by such remarks. They have privately given up on the next general election. They are just attempting to shore up their core support, which will mean lots of headline-grabbing speeches to appeal to the right with little effort to appeal to the broader electorate.

fields.headline: A high-class hundred
fields.standfirst: Mark Lawson reviews Wisden Cricketers' Almanack 2000
fields.trailText: Among the thousands of products marking the Millennium, this special edition of Wisden takes the risk of walking in last with the crowd looking dangerously bored. The cultural celebrations of the date-change became tedious in about June 1999 but a millennial Wisden is more appropriate than most, cricket being the area of life - apart perhaps from the Stock Exchange which most depends on watching zeros clicking round.
fields.body:
Among the thousands of products marking the Millennium, this special edition of Wisden takes the risk of walking in last with the crowd looking dangerously bored. The cultural celebrations of the date-change became tedious in about June 1999 but a millennial Wisden is more appropriate than most, cricket being the area of life - apart perhaps from the Stock Exchange which most depends on watching zeros clicking round.

Of the timed-in innovations, the most intriguing (showing editor Matthew Engel's talent for publicity) is the inclusion alongside the usual Five Cricketers of the Year of a quintet from across the century. This has started a debate which could fill those rain-breaks for the rest of the summer.

A good game before the five became widely publicised was to ask another obsessive to guess one. Everyone was allowed Bradman as one off the mark - the equivalent of that one about the capital of France which settles the contestant's nerves on Who Wants to be a Millionaire? - but after that there were no easy scores.

Few will argue with Hobbs, Sobers and Viv Richards, but the undoubted surprise is Shane Warne, the only one of the five either unknighted or still playing. It's a startling achievement for a player who was only active in the final decade of the century. You assume that the selectors are rewarding a haul of Test wickets achieved with a form of bowling which until Warne came along was unfashionable and typically very hittable. The panel have omitted any quick bowlers, a breed which dominated the second half of the cricket century. A talking point for the rain-breaks is whether they are making a deliberate point. "Fast bowling is the easy option." Discuss.

The effect of this provocative millennial addition - there are also sections on the images of the century, the cricket-writing of the last 100 years and a separate free paperback containing extracts from every Wisden between 1900 and 1999 - is to overshadow the traditional annual five players. This may be a good thing, because this section increasingly seems to me one of the few rough edges in the Wisden game. The rule that no player can be selected twice surely needs changing.

Denied the repetitively brilliant, the editor has achieved a thoughtful connoisseur's selection: Lance Klusener, Chris Cairns, Rahul Dravid, Tom Moody, Saqlain Mushtaq. But I find that my own mind is still filled with the batting of Steve Waugh, dragging his team back from the check-in desk with an innings which kept them in the World Cup and gave them the impetus to win it. But Waugh has been chosen before. Even political systems with term-limits allow their leaders to appear twice, and it seems wrong that the Wisden honours system is unable to celebrate the endurance or recovery of talent when these are such an element of the theatre of the game.

That this fat and imaginative edition is not an entirely happy read is not the fault of the editor. Fittingly - but wrenchingly - the Millennium Wisden carries more than any previous edition a sense of endings.

It still seems like a terrible printing error to be reading of the death of Malcolm Marshall, aged 41. Apart from the traditional death notice way down the order of pages, Engel also gives proper prominence to Mark Nicholas's ex-captain's panegyric, delivered in Barbados at Marshall's funeral. Nicholas's image of him still bowling accurately and passionately in the nets on the eve of the operation which failed to catch the cancer chasing him makes your eyes look like Dickie Bird's on the morning of his final Test appearance.

The only displeasure of this edition is that there are just too many deaths: Sylvester Clarke (only 44) and Conrad Hunte complete an unwanted Bajan hat-trick with Marshall. At least EW Swanton and Godfrey Evans - remembered here by their friends John Woodcock and Colin Cowdrey respectively - lived sufficiently long that you smile at the tributes to them. Swanton, at 92, had the distinction of having also written a piece (on Wisden's editors of the century) which appears in the same edition as the posthumous appreciation of him.

Amid these saddening dismissals, the one consolation is that the fine playwright Peter Tinniswood - who added to cricket literature with the Brigadier - recovered sufficiently from his recent grave illnesses to contribute an entertaining book review in which he dares, among other things, to criticise Dickens.

The edition which takes leave of the century also announces another departure. Matthew Engel - who has brought more mischief, literary merit and marketing zeal to Wisden than it has ever had - leaves his post for at least a year, his predecessor Graeme Wright coming in as a runner.

Engel's editor's notes for 2000 contain the usual mixture of high-class polemic (cricket in schools, the use of painkillers by bowlers, the amount of driving required of players) and good jokes: the sloppy nostalgia of a Lord MacLaurin speech is lethally deconstructed.

The rules allow Engel to return - there is an asterisk beside his score of eight - and we must hope he does. Retired tired. But also, on this evidence, triumphant.

Mark Lawson is a columnist on the Guardian and the presenter of BBC2's Review and Radio 4's Front Row

Amid these saddening dismissals, the one consolation is that the fine playwright Peter Tinniswood - who added to cricket literature with the Brigadier - recovered sufficiently from his recent grave illnesses to contribute an entertaining book review in which he dares, among other things, to criticise Dickens. The edition which takes leave of the century also announces another departure. Matthew Engel - who has brought more mischief, literary merit and marketing zeal to Wisden than it has ever had - leaves his post for at least a year, his predecessor Graeme Wright coming in as a runner. Engel's editor's notes for 2000 contain the usual mixture of high-class polemic (cricket in schools, the use of painkillers by bowlers, the amount of driving required of players) and good jokes: the sloppy nostalgia of a Lord MacLaurin speech is lethally deconstructed. The rules allow Engel to return - there is an asterisk beside his score of eight - and we must hope he does. Retired tired. But also, on this evidence, triumphant. Mark Lawson is a columnist on the Guardian and the presenter of BBC2's Review and Radio 4's Front Row

fields.headline: £10m to ease Rover fallout
fields.trailText: The government today announced £10m worth of aid for firms hit by the sale of Rover after a report warned of a "major shock" to the economy caused by redundancies at the car giant.
fields.body:
The government today announced £10m worth of aid for firms hit by the sale of Rover after a report warned of a "major shock" to the economy caused by redundancies at the car giant.

The taskforce set up to examine the impact of the shock sale by German owners BMW warned that up to 20,000 jobs could be lost if car production ends at the Longbridge plant. It asked for £27.5m to retrain workers, help firms enter new markets and improve local roads.

Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers said the report identified the supply chain as being in the most exposed position. "I will therefore make up to £10m available to help companies in the supply chain to modernise, retrain their workers, retool and diversify," he said.

"If there are good projects coming forward which will create jobs and ensure economic regeneration, we will look at offering more money."

As the report was published, former Rover executive John Towers prepared to meet BMW officials to discuss a rival bid for the car company. Venture capitalists Alchemy however remain confident that its proposed deal to buy Rover will be completed by the weekend.

Mr Towers is pressing BMW to extend the Friday deadline for his Phoenix consortium to submit its bid for Rover Group. The group has pleaded for more time to finalise its offer as it can only round up the necessary loans once all financial checks have been completed.

Mr Byers admitted that whoever bought Rover, there would be "difficult times ahead", adding that the government needed to put in place measures to help the region through the next few months.

The taskforce's final report will be published at the end of June when the group will have a better indication of the likely scale of job losses and the impact on the area.

webTitle: Norris distances himself from 'racist Tories' remark

fields.headline: Norris distances himself from 'racist Tories' remark
fields.standfirst: Tory core is racist says Norris team
fields.trailText: Steven Norris today attempted to distance himself from remarks by his most senior aide suggesting that the Tory candidate for London mayor believed the core of the Conservative party is racist, sexist and homophobic.
fields.body:
Steven Norris today attempted to distance himself from remarks by his most senior aide suggesting that the Tory candidate for London mayor believed the core of the Conservative party is racist, sexist and homophobic.

Ceri Evans, who handles Mr Norris's media relations, told the Asian television company Zee TV that Mr Norris's campaign was feeling "increasingly detached" from the "rather unpleasant core" of the Tory party.

But Mr Norris today said that he had "never encountered racism in the Conservative party in nearly 30 years of my membership of it" and praised William Hague's determination "to root out racism".

He did, however, acknowledge that his "more liberal agenda" may have upset some people within the party ranks.

Mr Evans's comments were taped by the London-based TV company as he was explaining why Mr Norris was not prepared to make an election broadcast specifically for the channel.

They are likely to have angered and embarrassed the Tory leader, William Hague, whose recent hardline comments on asylum seekers have led to accusations that he is creating a climate in which racism can flourish.

webTitle: No way back for Lewis now

fields.headline: No way back for Lewis now
fields.standfirst: Orin Gordon assesses how Guyana-born Chris Lewis has emerged from the match-fixing affair
fields.trailText: The question I am most frequently asked about Cronjegate is whether any West Indian players were ever approached by bookies or took money from them. So far my inquiries have yielded nothing, but one West Indian is emerging as a central figure in the latest round of accusations and counter-allegations: a man from Guyana named Chris Lewis. He has been badly - perhaps terminally - damaged by the storm over his allegations that three England players may have been involved in match-fixing. The weight of the evidence seems to be that the ECB mishandled the affair by apparently disregarding the accusations when he first made them nearly a year ago. Even if that is the case, Lewis looks bad for reheating the stuff when the Cronje affair hit the headlines. But my fellow columnist Kamran Abbasi argued last week, the way he was hung out to dry by the cricketing establishment was disgraceful.
fields.body:
The question I am most frequently asked about Cronjegate is whether any West Indian players were ever approached by bookies or took money from them. So far my inquiries have yielded nothing, but one West Indian is emerging as a central figure in the latest round of accusations and counter-allegations: a man from Guyana named Chris Lewis. He has been badly - perhaps terminally - damaged by the storm over his allegations that three England players may have been involved in match-fixing. The weight of the evidence seems to be that the ECB mishandled the affair by apparently disregarding the accusations when he first made them nearly a year ago. Even if that is the case, Lewis looks bad for reheating the stuff when the Cronje affair hit the headlines. But my fellow columnist Kamran Abbasi argued last week, the way he was hung out to dry by the cricketing establishment was disgraceful.

If he thought his goose was cooked after his angry denunciation of ECB administrators last year, itÕs been well and truly digested after the ECB's stern summons and apparent cold-shouldering. There's surely no way back to the England team now for Lewis, who got a taste of how low his stock had sunk when he was booed from the field after being run out for 0 for Leicestershire against Lancashire on Monday. The two-division County Championship, which starts today, should have been his chance to remind the selectors and the public that he is not a spent force, but in fact a better all rounder than Craig White, who has been given an England contract. I wonder about LewisÕs state of mind, especially given his short and ill-advised strike to protest his treatment by Lord MacLaurin and co. For Clairmonte Christopher Lewis, the season looks over before it's properly begun.

Lewis has been accused time and again of not delivering the goods for England. It's a cruel irony that, as he tells it, a bent bookie asked him literally to deliver. The ECB should take a leaf out of the book of the South Africans, who acted swiftly in the case of Hansie Cronje. The three players should immediately be summoned to a hearing along with Lewis. The board should then clear up the question of whether he did make the same allegations last year. If the evidence he presents is credible, they should consider suspending the players pending a full investigation. This in turn should be part of a wider inquiry by the ICC into a) the extent to which bookies pay players for information on pitch conditions and the like, and b) the extent of real match-fixing. We know match-fixing is illegal and players who are found guilty should be banned for life. Tough, uniform new penalties should be introduced for taking payment from bookmakers. It's not criminal, but it tarnishes the sport.

The way it looks, for the moment anyway, is that West Indies appear to be the only one of the major cricketing nations untouched by the whole affair. But it's unlikely that the bookies would have approached the likes of Cronje, Shane Warne, Mark Waugh and, apparently, several Pakistanis and not done the same to West Indies players. When I spoke with Clive Lloyd shortly after the Cronje story broke, he told me that to his knowledge none of his players was approached while he was captain or manager (a job he held until a few months ago). He was sure the players would have told him and in any case, he told me confidently, he was sure such approaches would have been dismissed out of hand. Lloyd is certain the drip-drip of allegations and revelations "is destroying the game of cricket", and is in favour of the ICC holding a full and wide-ranging investigation.

How might a player get tapped? Functions such as sponsors' parties and receptions are now important off-field activities for the players, and Lloyd believes it is not that hard to get their mobile phone numbers. Journalists routinely get the their numbers that way. Unfortunately, it seems we're not the only ones who can. I'm less confident than Clive that everyone who might have approached a player would have been shooed away. Cricketers earn very little compared to other professional sportsmen. Shane Warne will take home £750,000 after his season with Hampshire, but most of that will be in sponsorship. Footballers at the low end of the pay scale in the English Premiership can earn close to half-a-million a year. A footballer who has as much stature as Warne in his game can expect to earn at least five times that. And let's not even talk about what basketball players earn in the NBA. The point is that cricketers are sensitive to issues of pay, as the Windies players showed when they almost wrecked their tour of South Africa before it started 18 months ago, with their Heathrow stand-off. When they finally did face Cronje's men, they lost the Test series 5-0 and the one-day series 6-1. Yeah, I know what you'd be thinking now: how did they win that one match when they were so mind-numbingly awful throughout the tour? I thought and still think Cronje's captaincy was a great example of ruthlessly, even chillingly, professional leadership. His opponents had even begun to inspire pity, but he never let up. As Indian investigators compile their dossier on him, Cronje can point to those matches in his defence.

Orin Gordon, born and brought up in Guyana, has lived in London for five years and currently works as a broadcast journalist. His Anglo-Caribbean View appears fortnightly on wisden.com.

Next Wednesday you can read Kamran AbbasiÕs Anglo-Asian View.

fields.headline: China's irrational disaster
fields.standfirst: Persecution of the Falun Gong has backfired on Beijing
fields.trailText: In the year that has passed since 10,000 Falun Gong devotees surrounded the vermilion walls of the Chinese leadership's headquarters next to the Forbidden City in Beijing and demanded an end to official persecution of their sect, two things have happened: Falun Gong has demonstrated that it has both a tenacious organisation worldwide and deep roots in China, and the Chinese government has made itself look ridiculous.
fields.body:
In the year that has passed since 10,000 Falun Gong devotees surrounded the vermilion walls of the Chinese leadership's headquarters next to the Forbidden City in Beijing and demanded an end to official persecution of their sect, two things have happened: Falun Gong has demonstrated that it has both a tenacious organisation worldwide and deep roots in China, and the Chinese government has made itself look ridiculous.

On July 22 last year, the persecution that Falun Gong had complained of became an article of faith at the highest level of the state as police raided the homes of practitioners across the country and arrested such leaders as they could get their hands on. Falun Gong reacted with demonstrations in 30 cities. The government responded with more arrests. Yesterday the group succeeded in pulling off another demonstration in Tiananmen Square, despite a large police presence dedicated to preventing it.

Twelve months after resolving publicly to eliminate Falun Gong, the Chinese government has an embarrassing failure on its hands. According to the movement's own figures, 35,000 followers have been arrested and 5,000 sent to labour camps - a form of detention that the Chinese authorities call "administrative" and which does not, therefore, require a court trial. These figures are not verifiable, but the minority who have been tried in formal courts have received sentences of up to 18 years in prison. Falun Gong practitioners also risk losing their jobs and now their university places.

What is the point of all this? According to government propaganda, Falun Gong is a politically motivated movement that has as its aim the overthrow of the Chinese government. Yet the government has failed to produce a scrap of evidence of any such conspiracy.

It is worth remembering that, just 10 years ago, the same government was going out of its way to promote belief in the kind of qigong practice that is now condemned as superstitious. Casting around for some diversion for a nation stunned by the Tiananmen massacre, the Communist party fell upon qigong because they saw it as apolitical, autochthonous and good for health. These were qualities that appealed strongly to a government that had no political message beyond the promise that it would always be in power and was prepared to shoot anyone who said otherwise.

But what the Falun Gong affair demonstrates is that, to a morally and ideologically bankrupt government, there is no safe activity. The threat did not even lie in the message that those 10,000 protesters who encircled Zhongnanhai a year ago were delivering, but in the fact that they were there at all. They were not the usual suspects - the political activists and dissidents whose names figure on China's police computers and whose movements and contacts are constantly watched. These were ordinary citizens: pensioners, housewives, small time clerks, party members, a cross section of Chinese society with only their passion for Falun Gong in common.

Falun Gong followers, of course, supported last week's attempt by the United States to censure China in the UN commission on human rights. The Chinese government promptly accused Falun Gong of being "a new tool for anti-China elements in the United States". The idea that even the most fervent of such "anti-China elements" could conjure tens of thousands of demonstrators out of the air in China is simply laughable.

Falun Gong is the most dramatic and widely publicised case of repression in the past year, but it is not the only one. At least five other qigong movements have been targeted in the same period, among them Zhong Gong, a group that last year claimed 38m followers in China and had centres across the country. Zhong Gong representatives complain that 600 of its followers have been detained, that group assets worth £50m (810m yuan) have been seized and that 400,000 workers have lost their jobs after the government closed down more than 3,000 Zhong Gong centres. The government has not tried to suggest that Zhong Gong is trying to overthrow it, but like Falun Gong, it is entirely too appealing.

Last week's human rights resolution failed, as have all attempts to censure China in that forum, because too many governments, including the British one, believe in chasing crocks of gold at the end of Chinese rainbows.

But those governments that will do anything to do business with China might care to reflect on why the Chinese government is so scared of qigong. The men who run China understand that their people think that a faith in deep breathing and visiting aliens is at least as good a bet as believing any of the promises made by the government and the Communist party. If they can see it, why can't we?

webTitle: Take Three: Nasa hopes Wednesday's the day to launch Atlantis

fields.headline: Take Three: Nasa hopes Wednesday's the day to launch Atlantis
fields.standfirst:
Nasa Human Spaceflight
Kennedy Space Centre: launch countdown
Mission STS-101: the crew
fields.trailText: After being whipped by the wind, Nasa tried for the third time in as many days to launch space shuttle Atlantis on a mission to fix the international space station.
fields.body:
After being whipped by the wind, Nasa tried for the third time in as many days to launch space shuttle Atlantis on a mission to fix the international space station.

The Florida weather was expected to cooperate, finally, for Wednesday afternoon's lift-off. Forecasters were keeping an eye on the emergency landing sites in Spain and Morocco: At least one must be clear in order for Atlantis to take off.

Nasa is in a hurry to get Atlantis and its crew of seven to the space station.

The station is slipping in orbit nearly two miles a week because of increased solar activity, and is down to four functioning batteries, close to the limit.

Commander James Halsell Jr. and his crew will use the shuttle to boost the station as much as 27 miles and replace the batteries. They also will replace a broken antenna and fix a loose crane.

Because of the urgent nature of the mission, Nasa decided to attempt a launch three days in a row - a first in 19 years of space shuttle flight.

Nasa usually limits the number of consecutive launch attempts to two to give the astronauts and launch team a rest. Managers decided to go for three in a row this time, given the convenient afternoon launch time and the fact that no shuttle problems have cropped up during the countdown.

Besides, Wednesday may be Atlantis' last launch opportunity for a while, because of all the unmanned rocket launches and other operations scheduled over the next few weeks. Unless the schedule is rearranged, the next launch attempt for Atlantis will be around May 11.

Nasa called off Tuesday's launch attempt with 40 minutes remaining in the countdown, as gale-force gusts of 39mph swept the pad, well above the launch safety limit. The wind was so strong it ripped off the lower tie of the American flag next to the countdown clock. It flapped back and forth on the flagpole until workers took it down. On Monday, the wind wasn't nearly as fierce. But it was still strong enough to force a delay.

The 10-day mission is already running late because of Russia's repeated delays in launching a crucial service module to the space station, and the commander's sprained ankle. Halsell twisted his left ankle during training last month, which resulted in a one-week delay.

fields.headline: 15-year-old arrested over zoo shootings
fields.trailText: US police have arrested a 15-year-old youth in connection with a shooting that wounded seven children at Washington's national zoo, a crime described by Bill Clinton as a "devastating act of violence".
fields.body:
US police have arrested a 15-year-old youth in connection with a shooting that wounded seven children at Washington's national zoo, a crime described by Bill Clinton as a "devastating act of violence".

Police chief Charles Ramsey said Antoine Jones was arrested without incident at a home in north-east Washington on Tuesday after a 24-hour manhunt, and was charged with assault with intent to kill while armed.

Channing Phillips, a spokesman for the US attorney's office, said Mr Jones would be charged as an adult for his alleged role in Monday's shootings at the popular tourist attraction. The charges against him could be changed to second-degree murder if one of the victims dies.

fields.trailText: As a young kid I remember the Brazilian striker Mirandinha wooing the St James' faithful. How successful was he - and where is he now? asks Michael Jacobs
fields.body:
As a young kid I remember the Brazilian striker Mirandinha wooing the St James' faithful. How successful was he - and where is he now? asks Michael Jacobs

The signing of Mirandinha from Palmeiras in 1987 was a huge coup for Newcastle, who were then a struggling side in the old First Division (funny how things change). The Brazilian made a scintillating start and was a major factor in the Toon finishing 8th in the 1987/1988 season (they'd been 17th the year before).

But injury, and the bitterly cold North East weather took its toll on the mercurial Brazilian and soon the plaudits from Barry Davies - and more importantly the goals - dried up. The following season, Newcastle finished 20th and were relegated.

Despite a not unimpressive scoring record for Newcastle, 23 goals in 55 first team appearances, Mirandinha increasingly became a bit-part figure at the club and in 1990 he packed his bags and headed back to Palmeiras. A short while later he went to Japan. He was last heard of - according to the Newcastle website www.nufc.com - coaching Al Hajer in Saudia Arabia.

How many players have scored 100 or more Premier League goals? asks Michele Matonti

Six players have achieved the 100 goal milestone. They are Matt Le Tissier (100 goals), Robbie Fowler (109 goals), Les Ferdinand and Ian Wright (113 goals), Andy Cole (125 goals) and Alan Shearer (172 goals)

My mate reckons that Stoke are the only team to have appeared in at least three Cup Finals at Wembley since World War II and not been beaten. Tell me it isn't true and let me embarrass him at his wedding during my best man's speech begs Francis O'Brien.

You'll be pleased to know that you have the right to quip freely at the groom's expense. Stoke are indeed unbeaten in all three of their post-war Wembley cup finals, winning the 1972 League Cup and the 1992 and 2000 finals of the Auto Windscreen Shield. However, Wolves have gone one better, winning Wembley showpieces in 1949 and 1960 (FA Cup) as well as 1974 and 1980 (League Cup).

West Ham have also arguably trumped the Potters' post-war Wembley record. The Hammers contested and won the 1964, 1975 and 1980 FA Cup finals and held Liverpool to a 1-1 draw under the twin towers in the League Cup final of 1981. They did lose the replay 2-1, but that was at Villa Park.

Just for the record, seven other teams are unbeaten at Wembley in the major finals since 1946 - Derby, Blackpool, Swindon, Ipswich, Oxford, Coventry and Wimbledon.

What is the lowest amount of points any team in the Premiership has stayed up on and what is the highest amount they've been relegated with? asks Gary Hall.

Southampton and Coventry both had 38 points and an identical goal difference in the 1995-6 season. Usually this would have been enough to send these two seemingly relegation-proof sides down - but good old Manchester City managed an even worse record so off they went instead.

Poor Crystal Palace, meanwhile, keep getting relegated with points totals which almost match their current debts. In the season before Saints and Coventry escaped with 38 points, Palace surrendered their top-flight status with 45. Four were relegated that season and there were two more clubs in the league, which goes some way to explaining the difference in luck - but the fact that the same club dropped out of the first Premiership two seasons earlier with a mammoth 49 points suggests Selhurst Park may be in fact cursed.

Let's hope Gary's not a nervous Wimbledon fan...

Last week we asked the question: "Which three players have played in the Liverpool, Manchester and North London derbies?" We knew two of the names - Paul Walsh and Paul Stewart - but we were stumped on the identity of third player.

Thanks to everyone who emailed in with the answer: Brian Kidd. We now need help with the following conundrum: three Manchester United players have captained England in the same international match. Simon Poole believes he knows who the trio are, do you?

fields.headline: Crime, race and equality
fields.standfirst: The main London mayoral candidates' promises and policies
fields.trailText: Frank Dobson, Labour
fields.body:
Frank Dobson, Labour

Crime
Frank Dobson has made a "crackdown" on crime his priority, suggesting that police are soft on drug users and offering tough words demanding they confront drug use and drug dealers. More specifically, he promises that every Londoner will have a named police officer in their local area "just as everyone has their own GP". He also wants more "community-based wardens", the removal of racist graffiti within one day and use of "anti-social behaviour orders" to combat nuisance neighbours.

Racism and the police
"It is imperative that the mayor and the police work in partnership with the black and ethnic minority communities to build trust and confidence and recruit more black and Asian police," Labour's candidate says. Mr Dobson's running mate, black broadcaster Trevor Phillips, will chair the Metropolitan Police Authority.

Equality issues
Mr Phillips will also head a task force on black and Asian unemployment, aiming to promote public sector jobs and training for young black and Asian people and encourage black and Asian-led businesses.

Steven Norris, Conservative

Crime
As in almost all policy areas, Steven Norris's declared position is markedly to the left of official Conservative party policy. He says he will "not prosecute those who use cannabis for medicinal purposes", although he is on more traditional territory with his promises to "rid London of the scourge of drug pushers and lobby for tougher sentences from the courts".

Racism and the police
Mr Norris also promises to reverse the fall in police numbers in the capital since 1997 and increase the number of special constables and other civilian volunteers in the Met. Police racism will be tackled through a new complaints and disciplinary unit and targets will be set for recruitment from each London community. Daily crime figures will also be published.

Equality issues
With a massive ethnic vote and a reported 500,000 gay and lesbian voters in London, Mr Norris's manifesto is much more liberal than the position of his party on questions of race and sexuality. He supports the repeal of section 28, banning the "promotion" of homosexuality in schools, and his manifesto includes a pledge to work with the police to deliver "an absolute commitment to equality and respect for every Londoner regardless of their age, gender, race, religion and sexual orientation". He also enraged the Daily Telegraph by suggesting that police should turn a blind eye to homosexual "cruising" and sex in public.

Susan Kramer, Liberal Democrat

Crime
The creation of a community police force is the Liberal Democrat candidate's key pledge to help combat crime. "Local community constables" would carry out the duties of public service officials such as housing estate wardens, parks superintendents, bus lane enforcement officers, traffic wardens and school crossing patrol officers. Working in partnership with the police, they would also report crime, provide "a reassuring street presence to help reduce the fear of crime" and combat anti-social behaviour, such as excess noise and vandalism.

Racism and the police
Susan Kramer will establish a new scheme in every borough in London so that senior black and Asian business people are seconded into the senior ranks of the Met "to end the canteen culture of institutionalised racism".

Equality issues
With her deputy, Baroness Sally Hamwee, Ms Kramer has published an "agenda for women", denouncing the "macho, yah-boo style" of the mayoral contest and promising a raft of women-friendly policies, including improving CCTV on public transport, enforcing the ban on unlicensed mini-cabs and coordinating refuge provision for the victims of domestic violence across London.

Ken Livingstone, independent

Crime
Ken Livingstone proposes to instigate a London-wide programme of "crime mapping and crime prevention" and increase investment in the latest anti-crime technology, including DNA testing and new generation CCTV cameras. He also proposes to give local communities an incentive to report drug dealers by ploughing money confiscated from drug dealers back into local youth facilities.

Racism and the police
Like his fellow candidates, Mr Livingstone wants to shift resources within the police to increase street patrols. He wants a recruitment drive for 2,000 more police officers, ensuring recruitment "reflects every part of the community". Mr Livingstone promises to work with the home secretary, Jack Straw, to get more black and Asian faces into the police force and weed out a corrupt and racist minority in the force.

Equality issues
His recent promise to recognise gay marriages in the capital attracted the kind of rash of adverse publicity once associated with his GLC regime in the 1980s. He has also vowed that the Greater London Authority (GLA) will boycott homophobic companies, which could threaten Stagecoach's multi-million-pound bus contracts, as the company is owned by pro-section 28 campaigner Brian Souter. Mr Livingstone's gay rights credentials are also bolstered by the backing of the Green party's openly gay candidate, Darren Johnson, who has professed a willingness to become Mr Livingstone's deputy.

fields.headline: County championship latest
fields.trailText: On a day billed as a historic new beginning for the two-division county championship, the English weather took the opportunity to display typically impressive early-season timing.
fields.body:
On a day billed as a historic new beginning for the two-division county championship, the English weather took the opportunity to display typically impressive early-season timing.

The game's oldest enemy arrived right on cue to prevent a single ball being bowled before lunch in this country and to raise the prospect of a total washout at all venues.

The Division One clash between Indian Test players Rahul Dravid and Saurav Ganguly and their respective teams Kent and Lancashire was put on hold by morning rain at Canterbury.

Even wetter conditions at Trent Bridge saw Division Two hopefuls Nottinghamshire and Northamptonshire abandon day one of their championship season almost two hours before the scheduled start of play.

It was the same story between Gloucestershire and Sussex at Bristol, where the decision to call off play for the day came at 10.15am.

A 1pm inspection was planned at New Road - venue for Worcestershire's clash with Glamorgan - while back in Division One Derbyshire and Leicestershire were still clinging to the hope of an afternoon start if the rains relented at the Racecourse Ground.

The day's remaining championship fixture between Somerset and county title-holders Surrey hinged on a 2pm inspection at Taunton.

Oxford University and Warwickshire were in the same boat in the Parks - play abandoned by 11am - while Cambridge University and Essex were also unable to start but awaiting an improvement in the weather after lunch at Fenner's.

Taunton: Somerset v Surrey No play before lunch, Inspection at 2pm.

Trent Bridge: Nottinghamshire v Northamptonshire No play Wednesday due to rain.

Canterbury: Kent v Lancashire No play before lunch, rain.

Fenner's: Cambridge University v Essex No play Wednesday due to rain.

webTitle: Dobson warns voters off his rival

fields.headline: Dobson warns voters off his rival
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Frank Dobson is to launch an 11th hour bid to scare voters away from Ken Livingstone by plastering London with posters which will declare: "Beware the costs of Livingstone."
fields.body:
Frank Dobson is to launch an 11th hour bid to scare voters away from Ken Livingstone by plastering London with posters which will declare: "Beware the costs of Livingstone."

With just over a week until polling, Labour's candidate for mayor still believes he can swing Londoners away from Mr Livingstone if Labour issues dire warnings of how his "reckless" ideas would hit voters' pockets.

The posters will warn voters that Mr Livingstone's plans to levy congestion charges would cost motorists living in outer London £300 a month to drive into the capital.

Mr Dobson, who finally launched his manifesto yesterday, said: "Increasingly, Londoners are recognising that poking a stick at the government may not be a cost-free activity."

Labour has attempted to highlight the costs of Mr Livingstone's congestion charges. It claims Mr Livingstone would have to set up three zones around London, with motorists being charged more the closer they get to central London.

A motorist from Croydon, Labour claims, would have to pay £5 a day to enter the first zone, a further £5 once they cross the south circular, and another £5 to enter central London.

Mr Livingstone, who described Mr Dobson's campaign as "increasingly desperate", responded: "The claim that I would increase the tax burden by £300 a month does not have the slightest basis in any policy I have proposed. My manifesto clearly states that I would consult widely about the best possible congestion charge scheme."

Labour believes that scare stories about Mr Livingstone's independent campaign are paying off, with Labour supporters flocking back to Mr Dobson, particularly in the suburbs.

However, Labour has privately given up any hope of a Dobson victory and is fighting to ensure that Labour is not beaten into second place by the Tory candidate, Steve Norris.

Mr Dobson attempted to reach out to floating voters yesterday by pledging to rein in his spending plans to ensure that he would not be responsible for any increases in council taxes.

Mr Dobson also outlined populist measures, including plans to "name and shame" London's worst loan sharks. This could include placing posters of the most serious offenders throughout the capital.

Mr Dobson's manifesto rejects Tube privatisation, promises there will be no congestion charges and pledges to reverse the rise in the capital's street crime within two years by recruiting more police officers.

The manifesto: no tube sell-off and pledges to boost jobs

No tube privatisation, which Mr Dobson describes as "wrong in principle and wrong in practice". Day-to-day running and safety of the tube would be left in public hands. But Mr Dobson would turn to private companies to modernise the tube through an £8bn public-private partnership. He believes this is the best system because it would leave the private sector to carry the risks and would be £2.3bn cheaper than Ken Livingstone's bonds system.

No congestion charges in first term. Mr Dobson believes that it is better to improve the tube and buses before charging motorists to drive into London. He also wants to wait for a "proper electronic scheme" for congestion charging, which would take at least four years to introduce.

Creation of 100,000 new jobs by working with business to attract more inward investment. Mr Dobson would work closely with the businessman Sir John Egan, his choice to head the London development agency, which will have a £300m budget for economic regeneration. He would also set up a black and Asian skills taskforce to tackle the "scandal of ethnic minority unemployment".

Pressurise the government to increase the number of police officers, with a named officer for everyone. His deputy, Trevor Phillips, who is Mr Dobson's nominee to chair the new metropolitan police authority, would make the "battle against street crime" his top priority. The manifesto also echoes Mr Livingstone with a pledge to "root out corruption and racism within the police".

Name and shame London's loan sharks, who Mr Dobson describes as the "lowest of the low".

Limit spending to ensure the mayor is not responsible for an increase in council tax bills.

fields.headline: In brief, and casting couch
fields.trailText: Another Hollywood couple splits up, and Anne Heche and Michelle Williams are on the casting couch
fields.body:
 After a week of fevered tabloid speculation, Winona Ryder and Matt Damon have officially ended their two-year relationship. The New York Daily News reports that the pair has split up and cites the reason as Damon's rumoured dalliance with Spanish actress Penelope Cruz, his co-star on the Mexican-set Western All the Pretty Horses. But this gossip runs counter to last week's gossip, which put the blame squarely on the elfin shoulders of Ryder who it was alleged had hooked up with Boogie Nights star Mark Wahlberg. With such a storm of speculation in the air, no one (perhaps not even the parties involved) appear quite sure who did what to whom, and why. Such is the love life of your average Hollywood superstar.

Casting couch

 Anne Heche and Michelle Williams are the last principal names to commit to the big-screen adaptation of Prozac Nation. They join star Christina Ricci (who also produces) and Jason Biggs in the independently financed film version of Elizabeth Wurtzel's book about a school prodigy turned manic-depressive in media Manhattan. Heche will play Ricci's shrink, and Williams (a graduate of TV's Dawson's Creek) her supportive best buddy. The film will be directed by Norwegian film-maker Erik Skjoldbjaerg.

The New York Daily News reports that the pair has split up and cites the reason as Damon's rumoured dalliance with Spanish actress Penelope Cruz, his co-star on the Mexican-set Western All the Pretty Horses. fields.standfirst: Tittle-tattle tied up and tamed
fields.trailText: Daily Mail
fields.body:
Daily Mail

Frank Leboeuf is a target for French side Lyon. Club president Jean-Michel Aulas has confessed an interest in the 32-year-old, although the player himself wants to play for Real Madrid.

Eidur Gudjohnsen remains a top target for Newcastle. Bobby Robson watched the 21-year-old Icelandic international again at the weekend and is ready to offer Bolton £5m for his services.

Middlesbrough have denied an interest in Newcastle's Duncan Ferguson. The injury-prone striker is tipped to leave St James' Park this summer, but Bryan Robson is instead concentrating his attentions on German striker Oliver Neuville and Norwich youngster Craig Bellamy.

The Sun

Martin O'Neill is hoping to sign Bradford's Dean Windass this summer. O'Neill first tried to sign the former Hull man in 1995 when he was manager of Norwich City.

Planet Football

webTitle: Trouble in paradise for Charlie's Angels

fields.headline: Trouble in paradise for Charlie's Angels
fields.trailText: Officially, the Charlie's Angels movie is proceeding nicely and remains set for a release in November this year. Unofficially, the picture is rumoured to be building into a disaster of near biblical proportions. While the stars of the Columbia film - Cameron Diaz, Drew Barrymore and Lucy Liu - were all smiles when presenting an award at last month's Oscars, the project is reported to be in deep trouble.
fields.body:
Officially, the Charlie's Angels movie is proceeding nicely and remains set for a release in November this year. Unofficially, the picture is rumoured to be building into a disaster of near biblical proportions. While the stars of the Columbia film - Cameron Diaz, Drew Barrymore and Lucy Liu - were all smiles when presenting an award at last month's Oscars, the project is reported to be in deep trouble.

The New York Post this week claimed to be in possession of the current film treatment, which is on its 30th rewrite and bearing the thumbprints of dozens of writers.

In addition, the production is whispered to be plagued with problems. Barrymore is apparently pole-axed by personal difficulties, while a heated row between Liu (best known for her role in Ally McBeal) and co-star Bill Murray is said to have shut down filming for an entire day.

If there's a lesson to be taken from all this, it would be that Hollywood adapts retro TV shows about wacky crime fighters at its peril. Did Columbia bosses learn nothing from making The Avengers?

webTitle: Donald Duck lands hacks in hot water

fields.headline: Donald Duck lands hacks in hot water
fields.trailText: The arts supplement of the daily Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung is to German high culture what the Times Literary Supplement is to English letters: sober, authoritative, demanding and not a little po-faced.
fields.body:
The arts supplement of the daily Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung is to German high culture what the Times Literary Supplement is to English letters: sober, authoritative, demanding and not a little po-faced.

So the reaction can be imagined to the news that for years the leading conservative newspaper has been purveying the Weltanschauung of Donald Duck. A recent edition was found to contain no fewer than 10 headlines and captions taken from the bubble captions of Donald Duck comic strips.

Confronted with overwhelming evidence by reporters from the weekly news magazine, Der Spiegel, two FAZ journalists owned up last week. Patrick Bahners, 33, and Andreas Platthaus, 34, admitted to having slipped "Donaldisms" into captions and headlines about everything from classical Greek theatre to Chopin.

One recent heading, taken from a cartoon strip, ran above a critique of a book on advertising: "Sparkling water, duck's wine, costs little and tastes fine". They even slipped some extracts into the texts of their own articles.

The two journalists are members of a society called Donald that promotes the cartoon character.

"We regard ourselves as scientists," Mr Platthaus said yesterday. "We study life in Duckburg in much the same way that normal scientists deal with our world."

Members of Donald have an annual "Day of Struggle" on April 1 and, in keeping with the conventions of the comic strip world, they do not applaud but shout: "Clap. Clap. Clap."

Mr Platthaus said his colleague had been slipping Donaldisms into the newspaper for 10 years. "When I joined the paper, three and a half years ago, we combined our efforts and the number of Donaldisms increased. It has been really intense in the last two years".

So intense, in fact, that a reader of the rival Süddeutsche Zeitung remarked in a letter on the similarity between the cartoon duck's utterances and some material in Germany's most respected daily. Mr Platthaus said he thought that it was that letter that had aroused the interest of Der Spiegel's investigators.

Asked about the reaction at FAZ, he said: "Up to now, there has been no reaction." But he added: "Because the editor is on holiday."

webTitle: How poet's secret love defended her virtue

fields.headline: How poet's secret love defended her virtue
fields.trailText: The secret lover Rupert Brooke romped naked with through Grantchester meadows was not a bohemian wild child as she has been portrayed, her defenders claim
fields.body:
The secret lover Rupert Brooke romped naked with through Grantchester meadows was not a bohemian wild child as she has been portrayed, her defenders claim.

Phyllis Gardner, the young artist whose tempestuous affair with the patriot poet Churchill idolised as "one of England's noblest sons" only came to light when her 90-page memoirs were unearthed in the British Library, was an innocent who doggedly clung to her virginity.

Brooke became so frustrated with her defence of her virtue that during an erotic encounter he pretended to strangle her, an experience she later confessed she had quite enjoyed.

The discovery of the papers, locked away for 50 years at the request of Gardner's sister Delphis, confirmed the growing impression that Brooke was far from the noble martyr of myth but could be a cruel and manipulative cad, whose charisma and beauty allowed him to get away with murder.

With poems such as the The Soldier, Brooke became the laureate of the generation lost in the first world war, his sanctity confirmed by his early death on the way to Gallipoli. Biographies and memoirs by his friends Eddie Marsh and Geoffrey Keynes cultivated this image of a pure and ethereal young man who sacrificed himself for his country.

What they failed to mention was that Brooke was a lothario who at one stage, according to his most recent biographer, Nigel Jones, kept four relationships on the go at one time, was bisexual in his youth, and also managed to conduct affairs with two sisters simultaneously, without either of them knowing the full story.

Nor was there any mention of Phyllis, although Marsh met the artist several times and allowed Brooke to use his London flat as their love nest.

Lorna Beckett, an artist herself, became convinced five years ago that there had been a love affair when she found a copy of a woodcut showing Gardner grieving over Brooke's grave on the Greek island of Skyros. Gardner fell for Brooke after she spotted him on November 11 1911, when he sat opposite her on the Cambridge train and she started to sketch him.

The spark of attraction was mutual but it did not combust until he invited her to his home, the Old Vicarage in Grantchester.

After they stripped to wade across the Cam, she threw his boots into the river and he chased her, bringing her down in the meadow. Brooke's mood suddenly turned. He said: "Supposing I were to kill you?" He then gripped her around the neck. "I was in a sort of heaven although once he made me choke," she wrote later.

Brooke left for Berlin soon afterwards, where he wrote his most sexually charged poem for her, Beauty and Beauty.

But Beckett believes the couple never slept together. She said Brooke had wanted them to have sex and it was his pressuring of her which broke up the relationship.

"He had no intention of marrying her and that is what she most wanted. She wanted to save herself. She sacrificed the love of her life for her principles. That is why I feel so sorry now for Phyllis that she is being portrayed as some kind of loose woman."

The news of Brooke's death from septicaemia in 1915 seemed to unhinge Gardner. Eventually she dedicated her life to breeding Irish wolfhounds and working as an illustrator.

Nigel Jones, whose new biography of Brooke, Life, Death and Myth, revealed that the poet had gone on to father and disown a child by a Tahitian woman, said Gardner - like many of Brooke's lovers - was prepared to overlook his vain, neurotic side.

"He overwhelmed people. You just have to look at his letters to see that. He is probably the greatest literary letter writer since Byron."

webTitle: American History X lawsuit tossed out of court

fields.headline: American History X lawsuit tossed out of court
fields.trailText: The lawsuit filed by American History X director Tony Kaye against the film's backers, New Line Cinema, and the Directors Guild of America was effectively killed last night by a federal judge in California. US district court Judge Dean D Pregerson dismissed the 1998 action "with prejudice" - a tough verdict which implies that the suit will not be filed again.
fields.body:
The lawsuit filed by American History X director Tony Kaye against the film's backers, New Line Cinema, and the Directors Guild of America was effectively killed last night by a federal judge in California. US district court Judge Dean D Pregerson dismissed the 1998 action "with prejudice" - a tough verdict which implies that the suit will not be filed again.

The explosive spat between British-born Kaye and the American film industry proved almost as fascinating as the content of the film it concerned. Released last year, American History X rustled up an explosive exposé of neo-Nazi groups inside the US and was anchored by an Oscar-nominated performance from Edward Norton as a reformed racist skinhead.

But Kaye was incensed by what he regarded as post-production meddling by New Line Cinema and Norton himself, who was reputed to have had a hand in the film's editing. Alleging that Norton recut the film to give himself a more meaty role, Kaye demanded to have his name removed from the project and to have the director credited as one "Humpty Dumpty". When New Line and the DGA refused to grant his wishes, Kaye filed the suit, demanding a reported $200m in damages.

Throughout the 80s and 90s, Kaye proved himself to be one of the most respected commercials directors in the business, filming eye-catching adverts for the likes of Nike and Michelin. In attempting to crack Hollywood, he provocatively hyped himself in paid advertisements as "the best British director since Hitchcock".

Now, the American History X farrago looks to have irreparably damaged his reputation among America's money-men. Responding to the judge's verdict, DGA attorney Ernie Getto remarked: "This is a case that should not have been allowed to move forward on its merits." Where Kaye goes from here, however, is anyone's guess.

fields.headline: Jury nobbling claims rejected
fields.standfirst: 'I'm glad the case got a bloody good airing,' says publicist as row breaks out over media coverage of the killings at Bleak House
fields.trailText: The jury in the highly controversial trial of Tony Martin was yesterday found not to have been intimidated into finding the farmer guilty, despite the massive public outcry against the verdict.
fields.body:
The jury in the highly controversial trial of Tony Martin was yesterday found not to have been intimidated into finding the farmer guilty, despite the massive public outcry against the verdict.

An inquiry into claims that the jury's six men and six women were "nobbled" found no evidence to substantiate the allegations, and concluded that there would be no further investigation. A spokesman for the Lord Chancellor's Office said: "There has been no formal complaint from jurors of any intimidation. There is nothing to investigate at present."

The case of the farmer who shot two burglars in his own home, killing a 16-year-old youth, touched a raw nerve across rural Britain. The jury nobbling allegations stirred yet further the debate about the rights of householders to defend their property.

Last night questions were being raised about the level of hype surrounding the case. Dr George Turner, the Labour MP for Norfolk North West, condemned the hysteria and the involvement of the publicist Max Clifford, who took up the case of the farmer for free. He said: "It hasn't helped that the whole thing has been handled by a professional publicist rather than professional lawyers. There's a feeling there's more than one agenda and I am very worried by what's been going on."

Dr Turner said that people were "seeking to exploit the tragic events at Bleak House" and were in danger of encouraging people to take the law into their own hands. "To an extent there may be an attempt to manipulate public opinion for different ends than looking after the public's best interests," he said.

Mr Clifford admitted yesterday that he had been stirring up the public outcry against Martin's conviction by supplying newspaper editors and journalists with stories and information about his client to ensure that the story "had got a bloody good airing".

But he denied that he was behind the call to a local Norfolk radio station last week by a woman who claimed to have been a jury member.

The caller - who did not go on air - spoke of how the trial had "changed her life", and how she felt "frightened to leave her house". The radio station, Broadland 102.4fm, insisted that the woman - it is still unclear whether she was genuine or a hoax caller - did not say she was intimidated or nobbled.

Front pages

But immediately Martin's lawyers and Mr Clifford himself started using those phrases and by the next morning they were splashed over the front pages of the tabloids.

Mr Clifford said: "In terms of the hype and media coverage I am very happy to put my hands up. I have done everything I can to encourage the vast media coverage and I wish I could say it was all down to Max Clifford, but it is down to the vast support shown by the British public. I have tried to do everything I know, including getting [Martin's] mother to do interviews. Max Clifford fortunately has helped to get the message out there that this is going on across the country."

Martin's team have been carefully noting down any signs of interference with the jury or any hint that there could have been a threat. First there was the juror who phoned 999 over a weekend, having been warned by the judge to do so if anyone approached them about the case. It is believed that the woman thought she was being stalked, but the worry was unfounded when investigated by police.

Then there was the presence in court of the man the tabloids have dubbed "the king of the gypsies". Eli Frankham, a 21-stone, 6ft8in former bare-knuckle prize fighter was given a police escort out of the courtroom after just 20 minutes.

Court officials said that Mr Frankham and a friend had cadged tickets for the courtroom from a Gypsy woman who had queued for hours for entrance. But despite claims that he glowered at the jury, there has been no proof that he intimidated them.

He has denied the allegation, saying that he turned up out of interest.

Pointing to these incidents, Mr Clifford added: "I have other reports of intimidation. Somebody saw someone running their finger across their throat. I didn't make that up. This guy of 6ft8in, I didn't make him up - he was escorted out of court by police. It's not Max Clifford hype. It could be that the message that Max Clifford is trying to get across is true."

Nick Makin, a solicitor for Martin, said he had gathered evidence that should be investigated. He had taken a very helpful call after putting out an appeal for infor mation. He said: "I am absolutely certain that I spoke to a woman who was a member of the jury. She was the same woman who spoke to the radio station. There is no doubt about it, it was not a hoax."

Last night, Norfolk acting deputy chief constable John Bligh said: "The crown prosecution service and Norfolk constabulary are keen to have this matter resolved as quickly as possible in order to confirm or negate what has been said in some areas of the press."

Privately, some police sources have been angered by press stories and have been "concerned about the nebulous nature of these allegations and the lack of firm information or evidence".

Isolated house

The sentencing to life imprisonment of Martin after the shooting at his isolated Norfolk farmhouse has become the talking point in pubs and at dinner tables across the country.

Martin, 55, was found guilty by a majority verdict of murdering 16-year-old Fred Barras and of attempting to murder Brendon Fearon, another burglar, with intent to cause bodily harm.

The farmer had been the subject of threats and it emerged in court that a £60,000 bounty was alleged to have been put on his head. For reasons of safety, jury members were identified by number and not name in court.

Martin's lawyers will now lodge an appeal against his conviction on Friday and will ask for a number of documents from the trial relating to jury intimidation. Mr Makin said: "We hope it will be dealt with as quickly as possible."

webTitle: Hague joins outcry over jailed farmer

fields.headline: Hague joins outcry over jailed farmer
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague will today attempt to exploit the public outcry over the jailing of the farmer Tony Martin by pledging to change the law to give greater protection to people who are forced to defend their homes against intruders.
fields.body:
William Hague will today attempt to exploit the public outcry over the jailing of the farmer Tony Martin by pledging to change the law to give greater protection to people who are forced to defend their homes against intruders.

In one of his most populist moves since taking over as Tory leader, Mr Hague will promise that a Conservative government would introduce into the law a "strong presumption" in favour of the likes of Martin, who was convicted last week of the murder of a teenage burglar.

Speaking on the local election campaign trail, the Tory leader will say: "The Tony Martin case lit a touch paper that has led to an explosion of anger among the millions of law-abiding British people who no longer feel the state is on their side.

"Politicians aren't doing their job if they don't listen and respond to the unprecedented public outcry which has greeted the murder conviction for this Norfolk farmer who was defending his home against burglars. I understand that outcry and I share it."

Mr Hague will qualify his remarks by insisting that there is no place in a civilised society for vigilantes. But he will say that the law had to distinguish between hardened criminals and people forced to defend their property.

"There is all the difference in the world between the career criminal who sets out deliberately to burgle a house and the terrified homeowner who acts to protect himself and his home," he will say in a campaign speech in Alcester, Warwickshire.

"Unless our laws reflect natural justice, then they fall into disrepute. The next Conservative government will overhaul the law with a strong presumption that, in future, the state will be on the side of people who protect their homes and their families against criminals."

Mr Hague's speech will delight Tory backbenchers, including the former cabinet minister and Norfolk MP Gillian Shephard, who have expressed deep anger at the jailing of Martin for the shooting dead a burglar who broke into his Norfolk farm.

However, Mr Hague's speech will once again confirm the fears of moderates in the party that the Tory leader seems determined to reach out to a small rightwing core of hardline Tory supporters. To announce such a major policy within days of a court case will also lead to criticism that Mr Hague's circle have few ideas of their own and are happy to follow the latest fad.

Labour immediately accused Mr Hague of "knee-jerk opportunism". A spokesman said: "He is trying to latch on to a well-publicised case but he has no coherent policy to offer."

The Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman Simon Hughes accused the Tory leader of "ill-considered populism". Despite Labour's criticism of Mr Hague, the government has itself responded to the outcry over the Martin case. Over the weekend, government sources let it be known that they were planning to make more resources available for policing isolated rural areas in the chancellor's comprehensive spending review in July. Officials were quoted as saying that the case had a "strongly political dimension".

In an attempt to drum up Tory support ahead of next week's local elections, he will also spell out other Tory policies to act tough on crime, including reversing the fall in police numbers, ending the automatic early release of prisoners on licence and extending the "two-strikes-and-you're out" regime.

"What is the point of having a police service and prisons when three criminals, with 114 convictions between them, are allowed to wander about free to terrorise rural communities," he will say. "What has happened when career burglars and muggers get a few dozen hours community service, or a couple of months in prison if they're unlucky, while people defending their homes risk long prison sentences?"

webTitle: Teachers vote to hold strike ballot

fields.headline: Teachers vote to hold strike ballot
fields.standfirst: Vote for one-day schools strike ballot
fields.trailText: The largest teaching union voted decisively yesterday to ballot for the first national one-day strike in schools in England and Wales since 1969 in an attempt to put pressure on the government to abandon plans for performance pay linked to pupils' results.
fields.body:
The largest teaching union voted decisively yesterday to ballot for the first national one-day strike in schools in England and Wales since 1969 in an attempt to put pressure on the government to abandon plans for performance pay linked to pupils' results.

Delegates at the National Union of Teachers' annual conference, instructed their leaders to ballot for a stoppage "at the earliest possible opportunity in the summer term", to win a £2,000 pay increase for all teachers, with no strings.

The decision, on the last day of the Harrogate conference, was a victory for leftwingers against Doug McAvoy, the general secretary, who pleaded for more limited action, including a work to rule in which teachers would boycott non-contractual duties such as sports coaching and school trips.

He said he would not try to thwart the will of the conference by failing to call a ballot, as union activists complained he did after losing votes in previous years. But he would refuse to obey an instruction from delegates to "campaign vigorously to ensure a positive yes vote for strike action".

Mr McAvoy said: "I am not prepared to campaign for a yes vote because to do so would be dishonest. It would imply that I support a national one-day strike and believe it would be effective." Such action would alienate parents. They would see it as an attempt by militants to let off steam without any realistic hope that the government would drop its plans. The next steps will be decided by the union's national executive, on which moderates supporting Mr McAvoy normally have a majority of 24 to 18. The outcome is likely to be a ballot during the summer term, with the executive campaigning for a work to rule and presenting teachers with the arguments for and against a one-day strike, without making a recommendation.

David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, said: "This is the first time in history that a trade union conference has called for a strike against its members being offered promotion and extra pay simply for doing their job well."

The conference voted for a strike by 105,208 to 82,114 after a heated debate spread over three days. Delegates were united against the government's pay scheme, despite the attraction of a £2,000 performance bonus in September for most of the 240,000 experienced teachers who are currently stuck at the £24,000 maximum for classroom staff.

Mr McAvoy said the system for assessing which teachers deserved the increase was "flawed, unjust, misguided and educationally unsound". But he said the fight was a long-term struggle.

Although leaders of the other unions are going along with the scheme, a survey of NUT members showed that 60% of members wanted a one-day national stoppage.

John Lockwood, of the union's mid-Warwickshire branch, said: "There is not a teacher in the land who does not know the £2,000 is a bribe offered to break our conditions of service."

Liz Rattue, an Islington teacher, said: "If we want to protect our members from being catapulted back to Victorian times, we must embark on a serious programme of industrial action and do it now."

In a speech to the conference before the result of the strike motion was declared, Mr McAvoy said: "The friendship and teamwork of teachers - the very glue that holds schools together - will be blown apart by this pay system."

He later questioned the legitimacy of the conference decision. The first vote on an amendment to include a one-day stoppage in the main motion was passed by a majority of 5,000, thanks to the block votes of big delegations. But there were more individual delegates voting against a strike than voting for.

"The amendment was carried by the smallest of majorities, not because of the arguments and the facts used in the debate, but because of the pre-determined political posturing of some delegates," Mr McAvoy complained.

fields.headline: Comments from Germany sink euro
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: The pound and the dollar soared to new record highs against the euro yesterday as European investors returned to work after the Easter break and immediately dumped the ailing single currency.
fields.body:
The pound and the dollar soared to new record highs against the euro yesterday as European investors returned to work after the Easter break and immediately dumped the ailing single currency.

The latest plunge took the euro to 92.5 cents against the dollar and 58.62p against the pound.

The pound's strength against the euro will pile the pressure on manufacturing industry, struggling to win business in export markets and facing a flood of cheap import competition at home.

Today's quarterly survey from the Confederation of British Industry is likely to emphasise the pain manufacturers are suffering.

Analysts said the euro's fall was triggered by comments from the chairman of Germany's five wise men Jürgen Donges, who said the German public was losing confidence in the currency, and remarks by the new German economics minister, Werner Müller, who suggested the euro's fall on the foreign exchanges had not eroded its domestic purchasing power.

Tony Norfield, head of global currency research at ABN-Amro in London, said the latest drop in the euro could prove to be the last straw for fund managers still holding the currency in the expectation of a recovery.

If they decided to sell the euro, it could fall "at least several more per cent".

However, some traders believe that jitters in the American stock market could soon undermine the dollar and herald a rapid recovery of the euro.
