webTitle: Elian moves home to avoid media circus

fields.headline: Elian moves home to avoid media circus
fields.trailText: Elian Gonzalez and his father have been moved from the Andrews air force base to a conference centre in Maryland to shield them from the intense media attention focused on the Cuban shipwreck survivor.
fields.body:
Elian Gonzalez and his father have been moved from the Andrews air force base to a conference centre in Maryland to shield them from the intense media attention focused on the Cuban shipwreck survivor.

Cuban officials in Havana, hoping to strengthen their case that the six-year-old boy belongs with his father rather than with the Miami relatives who cared for him after he was rescued from the Straits of Florida, have issued lengthy descriptions of Elian romping with dogs and playing with his little brother since he was reunited with his father.

"The boy was loving, above all with his father and little brother," said a report from the Cuban interests section in Washington broadcast yesterday on Cuban state television. "On several occasions he carried Hianny [his brother] and put him down, repeating with affection, 'I love you very much'." The report was compiled by Cuban diplomats who visited the family at the weekend at Andrews, in the Maryland suburbs.

Cuban President Fidel Castro was in the audience but did not speak during the 2 1/2-hour broadcast dedicated to the boy at the centre of a custody battle since he was rescued in late November after a shipwreck that killed his mother.

Cuban psychologist Patricia Ares said the interests section report, along with photos released earlier of a smiling Elian hugging his father, removed any doubt that "there exists an intense bond" between the boy and his father "that never was interrupted", despite the five months Elian spent with Cuban relatives exiled in Miami. Last night's programme also showed clips of a US television broadcast in which psychiatrists discussed the emotional stability of Marisleysis Gonzalez, who cared for Elian in Miami and who had been in hospital with stress-related illnesses several times since his rescue. Ms Ares said the young woman was "disturbed" and claimed she could cause emotional harm to the boy. Cuban officials have supported the US government raid on Saturday that removed Elian from the house of Lazaro Gonzalez, the great-uncle who is fighting to keep the child in the US against his father's expressed wish to return the boy to Cuba. A federal appeals court in Atlanta has ordered Elian to be kept in the US until the Miami relatives' attempt to win political asylum for him is resolved. The weekend raid came after the Miami relatives refused to give Elian's father unrestricted custody of the child despite an order by the Immigration and Naturalisation Service stripping them of custody. Last night's television programme, one of scores broadcast by Cuban TV in the four months since Elian was brought to Miami, repeated a call to turn next week's May Day celebrations into a huge rally for the boy's return. Mass rallies calling for the boy to be brought home have been organised almost daily in Havana and elsewhere.

The raid to snatch Elian, although broadly welcomed by much of the American public, has incensed Cuban-Americans, some of whom have severed their ties with the Democratic party in protest. About 60 people switched party affiliations at the Latin chamber of commerce in Miami's Little Havana district.

"The worst was them putting a machine gun in Elian's face," said Marta Acosta, who along with her husband switched to the Republican party on Monday.

Cuban-Americans in Florida, unlike a majority of Hispanics elsewhere in the country, tend to vote Republican. Their unified bloc attracts the attention of congress and presidential candidates seeking Florida's 25 electoral votes.

fields.headline: What the papers say
fields.trailText:
An honourable solution
We should not forget for one minute that there is still a legal process pending in the United States, imposed by the authorities of that country along with many other arbitrary measures throughout the course of this case involving a boy who was the victim of a shipwreck resulting from an absurd law, and of a great tragedy in which his mother lost her life before his eyes, when he had to float for over 30 hours on an inner tube, followed by a prolonged period of manipulation and abuse for almost five months... The turnover of the boy to his father is a favourable step toward a just, honourable and correct solution to the problem.
Granma Internacional, Cuba
fields.body:
An honourable solution

The turnover of the boy to his father is a favourable step toward a just, honourable and correct solution to the problem. Granma Internacional, Cuba

A shocking raid, a call for calm
The evidence clearly suggests that the Miami relatives were at last prepared to voluntarily deliver Elian to his father within a very short time. A full and independent investigation of this matter is warranted. We have supported Juan Miguel Gonzalez's desire to be reunited with his son since he arrived in the United States. But achieving that goal yesterday does not justify the trauma that was inflicted on our community.
Miami Herald

A hard decision
Reno made a hard decision and made it stick. Elian is where he should be - in his father's arms. To say there should have been an easier solution is to ignore the political fever that leaders of the Cuban-American community in Miami had fuelled around the issue.
LA Times, 23 April (registration required)

Seizing Elian: The ends cannot justify these excessive means
By acting as it has this weekend, the Clinton White House has only revived old suspicions - easily tapped in the US - of an arrogant and over-mighty central authority. These are dangerous emotions to stir.
The Sunday Times

Three minutes that shook America
Bill Clinton, freed from the need to grub for votes among the virulent leaders of Miami's anti-Castro Cubans, could use the Elian affair to normalise relations with Havana. And if Elian's too-eventful life could contribute to the ending of America's counter-productive isolation of Cuba, the shock he endured at five o'clock last Saturday morning may have heralded a larger accomplishment.
The Independent

Villains not victims
If the federal authorities can be criticised, it is over their delay in removing Elian... Too many politicians have been pusillanimous in the face of the exile vote and the crucial role Florida could play in this year's federal elections. The economic blockade, introduced four decades ago, is not going to end this side of the election, but once Castro goes, stand by for change. The Guardian

webTitle: Cuban exiles' strike passes Miami by

fields.headline: Cuban exiles' strike passes Miami by
fields.standfirst: The Elian Gonzalez case: special report
fields.trailText: Miami's Cuban exiles plunged deeper into isolation yesterday when a strike called to protest Saturday's forcible reunion of Elian Gonzalez with his father failed to paralyse the city.
fields.body:
Miami's Cuban exiles plunged deeper into isolation yesterday when a strike called to protest Saturday's forcible reunion of Elian Gonzalez with his father failed to paralyse the city.

In the working class Cuban district of Little Havana, the strike was observed in full. Its restaurants, shops and cigar stores were all locked up and plastered with signs explaining the cause. One insurance company had rigged its electronic hoarding to read: "Support Elian. Shame on Clinton."

Along the normally bustling main thoroughfare, the loudest sounds were the horns of cars decorated in Cuban flags honking their support.

The rest of Miami, however, functioned more or less as normal, highlighting the city's deep ethnic divide and the failure of its 800,000 Cubans to win the sympathy of its 1.3m Anglophone whites and blacks.

The police force reported an almost 100% turnout for work, while the municipal and county governments said their services would not be seriously affected.

The Cuban-American singer Gloria Estefan closed her recording studio for the day, and six Cuban members of the Florida Marlins baseball team announced they would not play last night, but no leading non-Cuban figures offered any gesture of support.

A nationwide poll found that a majority, 57%, of Americans supported the government's police action - a slight increase over the past two days.

Meanwhile Elian, his father, Juan Miguel Gonzalez, and their immediate family were moved from their temporary home at Andrews air force base outside Washington to Carmichael farm at the Wye River plantation in Maryland, where the late King Hussein stayed during recent Middle East talks.

Mr Gonzalez asked the state department yesterday to grant visas for some of Elian's classmates and parents so that they could join him in the US and provide some degree of normality while the family waits for a court hearing on the boy's fate, due to start on May 11.

The state department spokesman, James Rubin, said that once the visa applications arrived at the US interests section in Havana, they would be processed within 24 hours.

Meanwhile, in Congress, the attorney general, Janet Reno, appeared before a bipartisan group of senators to account for her decision to send armed federal agents into the home of Elian's Miami relatives to seize the six-year-old boy.

The Miami relatives, Cuban-American political groups and their Republican allies have accused Ms Reno of using excessive force at a time when negotiations were still under way.

The attorney general argued that on the night, the Miami relatives continually played for time and showed no signs of being ready to hand over Elian.

But Republicans repeated their call for a congressional investigation. "I'm going to recommend to the majority leader that the Senate engage in a hearing or a set of hearings into the use of force," the Florida senator, Connie Mack, said, declaring himself "horrified" by the raid.

But Democratic senators argued that the public appeared to be tired of the issue. Vermont senator Patrick Leahy said the Miami relatives' intention to damage the Cuban communist regime had backfired. "They helped Castro and they hurt Elian," he said.

Mr Gonzalez asked the state department yesterday to grant visas for some of Elian's classmates and parents so that they could join him in the US and provide some degree of normality while the family waits for a court hearing on the boy's fate, due to start on May 11. The state department spokesman, James Rubin, said that once the visa applications arrived at the US interests section in Havana, they would be processed within 24 hours. "They helped Castro and they hurt Elian," he said. Useful links: Liberty for Elian Let Elian Gonzalez Go Home US Immigration and Naturalisation Service

fields.headline: The photo war
fields.standfirst: The struggle over custody of Elian Gonzalez is over for the moment but the battle of images rages on: the instantly famous photograph of a gun-toting agent removing the Cuban child swiftly countered with a volley of snaps of a joyous father and son reunion. Julian Borger on how an international incident was played out through the camera lensThe Elian Gonzalez case: special report
fields.trailText: The struggle over custody of Elian Gonzalez is over for the moment  but the battle of images rages on. Julian Borger  on how an international incident was played out through the camera lens.
fields.body:
The street outside the little house in Miami is almost deserted now. The barricades have gone and the protest placards have been swept up. But the battle for Elian continues this week in its most emotive and fiercely contested form - the struggle for the visual high ground.

From the moment when Elian Gonzalez was brought, exhausted and semi-conscious, onto dry land on November 25, the conflict over his fate was fought out with a succession of images. As soon as Amando Gutierrez, a political wheeler-dealer in the Miami Cuban-American community, saw that first photograph, he said: "I knew there was something special about that child." He rushed over to see him, bringing a couple of his political clients with him, and an icon was born.

The first pictures were being printed on posters within hours. The first T-shirt followed soon after. Within a couple of days his face appeared on Cuban government posters in Havana, where he was portrayed as an anguished prisoner of the Cuban exiles. It was an old-fashioned cold war propaganda battle, pitting one fixed image against another, recalling an era before television was king.

As the fight intensified, the boy's photogenic features became the ammunition in the custody battle, and Elian's Miami relatives had an inexhaustible supply. The little boy was brought out into the little garden for smiles and V-for-victory salutes each time the news cycle and the next day's front pages demanded it.

Now it is the other side's turn in the photo-war, and they are not letting the opportunity go to waste. Elian's father, Juan Miguel Gonzalez, now seems to have won his battle, but the happy-family pictures keep emanating from the office of his lawyer, Gregory Craig, like victory salvos targeted at a defeated enemy.

The pictures draw their potency from Elian's features - a testament to the visceral grip the face of a young child has on the emotions. The now famous picture of a federal agent in helmet and goggles, with his fearsome machine gun pointed in the general direction of the terrified child, triggered a wave of anxiety across the country and a tangible yearning for reassurance.

On seeing Saturday morning's gun picture, Dan Rather, the CBS network's avuncular news anchorman, declared that the American people "needed" another, more soothing, image so that they could feel better, as they went to their beds, about what had been done in their name.

The picture duly emerged in time for the Sunday press deadlines. A smiling family portrait was put out by Craig, showing Elian in his dad's arms, side by side with his stepmother, Nercy, and his baby half-brother, Hianny, together in their secluded temporary home at Andrews Air Force Base outside Washington.

Both images were instant symbols of two contrasting interpretations of Saturday's events - a brutal, militaristic raid, or a long-overdue father-and-son reunion - presenting editors around the world with a Rorschach test on where they stood. Most decided to stick with their normal news instincts, using the more dramatic and dynamic picture of the armed snatch as the main feature on their front page, tempered in some cases by a smaller inset photograph of the reunited family.

Some papers attempted to perch on the fence. Leo Wolinsky, of the Los Angeles Times, explained the decision to give each picture equal prominence by saying: "To have one in a less prominent position would have looked like we were taking sides." The New York Times put the picture from the raid on the front page in its first edition, which was incidentally the version which reached Miami, but buried it inside once the reunion photo became available.

The editors said they thought the gun picture had to be put in context, to clarify that the weapon was not actually pointing at the child, but down and to the side, and that the agent's finger was not actually on the trigger.

The choice resuscitated an interesting question underlying the photojournalist's trade: is a picture worth 1,000 words or does every picture require 1,000 words to put it in perspective? In Elian's case, each photograph and its use has been treated to pages of analysis. On the opinion page of the Washington Post, the right-wing commentator Charles Krauthammer lambasted the New York Times's decision as evidence that the newspaper was soft on Fidel Castro and communism, virtually accusing the editors of being fellow travellers.

While the conflicting pictures have been used as ammunition, they have also served as a sort of currency. The broader and more natural the smile on Elian's face, the higher the value of the picture. His Miami relatives clearly believed that the more pictures that flowed from their Little Havana home, showing Elian apparently bonding happily with his great uncle, Lazaro, and his cousin, Marisleysis, the more credit they would have in their account when the time came to go before the court of appeals in Atlanta and the court of public opinion nationwide.

When Juan Miguel's camp finally had the chance to mint some of their own currency, it was perhaps inevitable that the other side would denounce it as forgery. Marisleysis and Lazaro declared that Saturday's smiling family portrait must be a fake, as they claimed it showed Elian with longer hair than the crew-cut Marisleysis had given him a couple of days before the raid.

The photograph was scrutinised for signs of trickery with forensic care. Picture editors from Associated Press examined the negatives and declared them genuine. Elian's hair, they said, appeared darker and therefore thicker because of poor lighting and a cheap lens. Their conclusion, however, did not prevent the picture taking on a life of its own on a dozen websites devoted to conspiracy theories of various types.

The row over the photograph brought forward yet more, similar pictures of father and son happily eating together and exploring the parkland inside the perimeter of the air base. This latest volley seems to have settled the argument over photo-fraud for the time being, although each smile is still being pored over with a magnifying glass by supporters of the Miami clan.

Whoever else may be winners or losers in the Elian saga, still photography has clearly had a very good week. There must have been several million dollars worth of television equipment installed opposite the Gonzalez's Little Havana home, but the defining images were both stills.

In the days since, Craig has resisted demands of video-footage of father and son, no doubt recalling the shocking impact of the videotape issued by the relatives earlier in the battle, in which a clearly-coached Elian demanded to be allowed to stay in the US. It made him look like a hostage. The still photographs, by contrast, were more reminiscent of happy family snaps, evoking a time before Elian became a subject for the professionals.

fields.headline: Teachers told to stop whingeing
fields.standfirst: Puttnam tells union of need to change attitudesEducation Unlimited
fields.trailText: David Puttnam, the film producer and government adviser, yesterday warned teachers they would continue to be seen as "whingers not winners" unless they adopted a more enlightened approach towards improving their public image.
fields.body:
David Puttnam, the film producer and government adviser, yesterday warned teachers they would continue to be seen as "whingers not winners" unless they adopted a more enlightened approach towards improving their public image.

In a speech to members of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, Lord Puttnam appeared to urge them not to follow the "juvenile" behaviour of colleagues belonging to the National Union of Teachers, who at the weekend walked out during a speech by the school standards minister, Estelle Morris.

At the same time, the association's general secretary, Nigel de Gruchy, launched a counter-attack on Chris Woodhead, the chief inspector of schools, accusing him of triggering more bad publicity for the teaching profession by jumping on the anti-NUT bandwagon with comments on performance related pay.

Mr Woodhead had attacked the largest teaching union for using children "as pawns in a game" to fight the government's pay plans. But Mr de Gruchy said Mr Woodhead's intervention in a matter outside his remit was "gratuitous and unnecessary" and urged him to leave the NUT general secretary, Doug McAvoy, to fight his own battles.

Yesterday, Lord Puttnam tried to counter the fears of association delegates, at their annual conference in Llandudno, Gwynedd, about the role of the fledgling general teaching council, of which he is part-time chairman. He urged parents and teachers to work together to challenge the government, saying that he had noticed during visits to schools how highly parents regarded teachers.

But he added that a different picture also emerged of "teachers as whingers rather than winners, of long holidays rather than long hours and of Mr Chips rather than microchips". He said: "As a profession you have to develop a more enlightened attitude to the manner in which you are seen by the public. Once that broad public confidence has happened I am convinced that dealing with the government will be a lot easier".

He said parents and teachers working together had "the potential to be the greatest vote-wielding force in this country", but that the profession should be the architect of change.

Referring to the NUT's disruptive walkout over the weekend, he quoted from a Daily Mail leader yesterday which referred to "noisy, scruffy, chippy, boorish, truculent and self-pitying" teachers. It was regrettable, he said, that three million people were forced to read such "ludicrous misrepresentation" about the profession over their cornflakes.

Later, responding to Mr Woodhead's comments on performance-related pay, Mr de Gruchy said: "When will he realise that when it comes from him, there is a swing back in sympathy with the National Union of Teachers? This will completely undermine any attempts for a more constructive working relationship between the teaching profession and Ofsted."

Delegates at the conference expressed concern about the new general teaching council, which starts work in September. They said they were worried about the £20 annual subscription, which they dubbed an extra tax, as well as about the danger of overlap with existing union work and the amount of personal information the council would hold on all members.

A motion expressing concern about the council's role in taking over teacher disciplinary matters from employers was passed.

The conference also backed a motion calling for fair pensions for all teachers aged over 50, with full benefits for early retirement.

fields.headline: NUT presses Labour on section 28
fields.standfirst:
Education Unlimited
More about section 28
fields.trailText: Teachers' leaders yesterday demanded that the government stick by its pledge to repeal the section 28 law that bans local authorities from promoting homosexuality in schools.
fields.body:
Teachers' leaders yesterday demanded that the government stick by its pledge to repeal the section 28 law that bans local authorities from promoting homosexuality in schools.

Amid growing doubts over whether ministers have the stomach for a protracted battle over the issue with opponents in the House of Lords, the National Union of Teachers said repeal was essential to protect pupils from bullying and intimidation.

Its annual conference in Harrogate gave overwhelming support to a motion calling on the government to keep its manifesto promise and regret ting sex education guidelines from David Blunkett, the education secretary, that emphasise the importance of marriage. These would not assist teachers in responding to the needs of all pupils.

"It is the role of teachers to educate against prejudice and for tolerance. This involves valuing all forms of stable relationships from which children benefit," the motion said.

Delegates heard evidence that section 28 was contributing to distress in schools, including homophobic bullying.

George Wiskin, for the executive, said peers supporting section 28 "are not only morally wrong, but are aggravating conditions that have caused some vulnerable young people to be harassed, humiliated and even worse".

"We must stand up for pupils who are lesbian and gay, and ensure that the law no longer enshrines prejudice," he said.

John Burns, a Sutton teacher, said a survey of 1,000 schools showed there was homophobic name-calling in 80% and homophobic bullying in 25%, but only 6% had a specific policy to combat the problem. The union agreed to produce its own guidance on sex education.

A spokesman for the prime minister denied reports that the government would abandon repeal until after the election if peers persisted in blocking the measure when they vote on it again this summer.

fields.headline: UN calls for Chechnya inquiry
fields.standfirst: Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: The UN Commission on Human Rights yesterday passed a resolution calling on Russia to investigate alleged mass killings in the breakaway republic of Chechnya.
fields.body:
The UN Commission on Human Rights yesterday passed a resolution calling on Russia to investigate alleged mass killings in the breakaway republic of Chechnya.

The resolution, presented by the European Union, also urges UN special investigators to go on fact-finding missions to Chechnya. It was easily adopted despite dissenting votes by Russia and a handful of allies including China, Cuba and India. The US state department spokesman, James Rubin, said in Washington: "We think that this vote ... indicates that the Russians are severely isolated on this issue."

Activist groups, including the New York-based Human Rights Watch, also welcomed the vote.

Russia's ambassador Vasily Sidorov took the floor before the vote to denounce the western text as unbalanced, saying it ignored "terrorist" operations conducted by Chechen rebels. But he vowed that Moscow would look into all alleged abuses during its six-month campaign and would prosecute all culprits. Reuters, Geneva

fields.headline: Yugoslav airline boss shot dead
fields.trailText: The director of Yugoslavia's state airline was shot dead in Belgrade yesterday, witnesses and Belgrade's independent Studio B reported.
fields.body:
The director of Yugoslavia's state airline was shot dead in Belgrade yesterday, witnesses and Belgrade's independent Studio B reported.

Police showed reporters the body of Zika Petrovic, face down in a pool of blood, after he was reportedly shot in front of his house while walking his dog. The identity of his killers is not known.

Petrovic, the director of the Yugoslav Airlines (JAT), and an ally of the Yugoslav president, Slobodan Milosevic, was the latest victim of a series of killings in the Yugoslav capital of prominent figures.

In January, Serbia's notorious warlord Zeljko Raznatovic, also known as Arkan, was killed in a hotel. Weeks later, the defence minister, Pavle Bulatovic, was gunned down in a restaurant.

Petrovic, 62, was a member of the Yugoslav Left , the neo-communist party of Mr Milosevic's wife, Mira Markovic, and was known as a friend of the Milosevic family.

He had recently announced the privatisation of JAT, which has been in financial trouble for years because of international sanctions and flight bans imposed by western countries against it.
AP, Belgrade

fields.headline: Pinochet case in court today
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: On the eve of a crucial court session on whether General Augusto Pinochet should be immune from prosecution, the former dictator said through an aide yesterday that he had no hand in killings during his regime.
fields.body:
On the eve of a crucial court session on whether General Augusto Pinochet should be immune from prosecution, the former dictator said through an aide yesterday that he had no hand in killings during his regime.

Today the 21 judges of the Santiago Court of Appeals are to receive the report of an investigating judge who wants Gen Pinochet's congressional immunity lifted so that he can face trial.

According to a government report, 3,191 people were killed or disappeared during Gen Pinochet's 17 years in power. The outcome of the proceeding could decide whether he faces human rights charges stemming from his 1973-1990 regime.

Gen Pinochet has immunity as a senator-for-life, a post he created for himself in the constitution written before he left power.

On Tuesday, Gen Pinochet's associate General Luis Cortes said: "He told me: 'Please tell everybody that I never ordered anybody to be killed or tortured'."

Judge Juan Guzman is handling the 92 criminal complaints against Gen Pinochet - some from individuals, some from groups, including the Communist party and labour and teachers' groups.

Gen Pinochet's defence is expected to be first based on his declining health, and the general's lawyers pressed the court yesterday to order medical tests on him.
AP, Santiago

fields.headline: Telegraph group seeks merger
fields.standfirst: Conrad Black signals union with internet companies to revive Hollinger group's flagging share price
fields.trailText: Conrad Black signals union with internet companies to revive Hollinger group's flagging share price.
fields.body:
Conrad Black, the Canadian media baron who owns the Daily Telegraph, last night appeared to open the door for a merger of his Hollinger empire with one of the emergent internet businesses.

In a statement, he acknowledged that the group needs to move toward "the current trend to larger, consolidated, multi-media entities". A Hollinger spokesman said a wide range of options would be considered, including a Time Warner/America Online-style merger, which rewrote the rules of the media business at the beginning of the year.

Buyers have been invited for the company's many local newspapers and Hollinger said that it would be willing to explore individual alliances or mergers for its larger newspapers to leverage their content into new media - as long as the Canadian business retains majority control.

As well as the Telegraph, the Toronto-based Hollinger group owns the Chicago Sun-Times, the Jerusalem Post, Ottawa Citizen and the National Post.

The spokesman ruled out a straight sale of the Telegraph titles but said it would divest a part of the newspaper to a new media company in return for a stake in the buyer.

Mr Black said that the reshaping of the business was in response to Hollinger's continuing sluggish share price, which has suffered in comparison with the higher rated new media stocks. The price, which hovered between $13 and $15 for most of last year, has trickled down to less than $10 in recent months.

The proceeds from the sale of the group's local "community" newspapers will be used to reduce debt and buy back shares, a familiar method of breathing new life into flagging share prices.

"To unlock shareholder value, Hollinger International will make most of its operating assets available in one way or another," Mr Black said. The investment bank Morgan Stanley Dean Witter has been mandated to find potential buyers or merger partners.

webTitle: Police release TV film of Dando on day of murder

fields.headline: Police release TV film of Dando on day of murder
fields.standfirst: More on the Jill Dando case
fields.trailText: Detectives looking for the killer of Jill Dando have released closed circuit TV footage of the BBC presenter taken on the morning of her murder.
fields.body:
Detectives looking for the killer of Jill Dando have released closed circuit TV footage of the BBC presenter taken on the morning of her murder.

The film, taken from London stores and street cameras, shows Ms Dando shopping in the Hammersmith and Fulham areas. Officers trawled 191 videos of footage and the latest clips were released yes terday in the hope of jogging the public's memory.

Police also revealed that they identified at least 140 people who had an "unhealthy interest or obsession" with the presenter. Most of those suspects have been eliminated from the inquiry but some are still to be spoken to, a year to the day that Ms Dando was murdered on her doorstep, Scotland Yard said. Officers also set up a mobile police station near her home yesterday. They will spend three days in Gowan Avenue, Fulham, talking to residents and others.

Detectives are still examining information from a second Crimewatch appeal on television last week, including 200 names, 20 of them "relevant and interesting". Detective Chief Inspector Hamish Campbell said he was certain there were people in Gowan Avenue on the morning of the shooting who had not come forward.

A meter reader and a man collecting his daughter from school had been traced. "They felt they could not offer anything to the inquiry so did not come forward. My message to them and others like them is, we do need to speak to you." He also appealed for people to get in contact if they knew someone who fitted the "key elements" of the likely killer: a loner, known to be obsessive about Ms Dando or other women, interested in guns, fitting witness descriptions and capable of being in Gowan Avenue that morning and on the previous two Mondays.

webTitle: Tory core is racist says Norris team

fields.headline: Tory core is racist says Norris team
fields.standfirst:
Secret tape reveals candidate's 'detachment'The London mayor: special report
Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: The Tory candidate for London mayor Steve Norris believes the core of the Conservative Party is racist, sexist and homophobic, according to a secretly taped conversation. He also feels increasingly detached from the party's "rather unpleasant core".
fields.body:
The Tory candidate for London mayor Steve Norris believes the core of the Conservative Party is racist, sexist and homophobic, according to a secretly taped conversation. He also feels increasingly detached from the party's "rather unpleasant core".

The allegations, relayed by Mr Norris's most senior aide, come just over a week before polling day in both the London and local elections.

The remarks will infuriate Conservative central office with which Mr Norris has had an uneasy relationship throughout the campaign, and will reignite the political debate inside the the party over its handling of the asylum issue.

Mr Norris' views came from campaign aide Ceri Evans. In a conversation with a London-based Asian television company Zee TV, Mr Evans said: "His credentials on equality, the sexual agenda and race and everything are utterly impeccable. Not only are they utterly impeccable, they cost him dear amongst the rather unpleasant core of the party from which we feel increasingly detached."

Mr Evans was defending Mr Norris' refusal to join the other candidates in making a special broadcast for the company.

Mr Evans who used to work for Tory leader William Hague at central office has been Mr Norris's right-hand man since last summer.

Asked if he had indeed reflected Mr Norris's views on his party in this way, Mr Evans said: "I am not going to nickel and dime you on my form of words. I might well have said there is a core of the party from which he is increasingly detached. I might well have said it. Frankly, if I had a memory erasion and you asked me again now, I would say the same thing."

Mr Evans then adjusted his remarks to claim that Mr Norris only thought his agenda would distance himself from parts of the far right, or the periphery in his party.

He continued: "There are elements in all parts of the country, not just in London, who are not perhaps as tolerant as one might like."

He said Norris "does not just want people to tolerate diversity, he wanted them to celebrate the diversity of London. That does not happen the whole time".

Mr Norris was initially blocked from standing as the Conservative candidate by the 22-strong London executive on the grounds that he was a philanderer. The decision was overturned in December on the orders of Mr Hague, who had already lost his favoured candidate, the now disgraced Jeffrey Archer.

Mr Norris credentials on gender equality are publicly known. At the outset of the campaign, he opposed the party's call to keep Section 28 saying that the controversial clause in the Local Government Act fosters widespread homophobic bullying in schools.

He took a highly liberal view on race, opposing marriage bonds and the proposal from Ann Widdecombe, the shadow home secretary, to restrict immigration.

Mr Norris attacked as immoral and disgusting plans by Ms Widdecombe to bring back the primary purpose rule, the rule aimed at stopping immigration for marriage from the Indian subcontinent. The measure is designed to debar applicants if immigration officials believe the marriage is designed purely to get foreign nationals into Britain.

But Mr Norris subsequently disappointed the liberal wing of his party when he was reluctant to criticise Mr Hague's call for detention centres for all asylum seekers in Britain.

He has also disappointed liberals by refusing to change his hard line stance on abortion.

The embarrassing disclosure came as Frank Dobson, the Labour candidate, rounded on Mr Norris at the launch of his manifesto for London mayor.

Mr Dobson said that it would be a great mistake to vote for Mr Norris because he would privatise the tube.

"The Tories devastated the capital in their 18 years in power with crime escalating, unemployment soaring and public transport neglected," Mr Dobson said. "Let's not give them another chance to wreck London."

His attack shows how Labour has been jolted by Mr Norris's success in reaching out to non-Tory voters. In the most recent opinion poll, Mr Norris nudged ahead of Mr Dobson after 16% of electors said they would vote for him.

Labour has privately given up on a Dobson victory. Presuming a victory for the independent candidate, Ken Livingstone, Labour is embarking on a final round of frantic campaigning to avoid the humiliation of being beaten into second place by Mr Norris.

webTitle: EU high flyers take three-day jaunt to do three hours' work

fields.headline: EU high flyers take three-day jaunt to do three hours' work
fields.standfirst:
The European Commission: special report
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Spare a thought for a group of high-flying civil servants from across Europe who are having to slum it at a "budget committee" meeting this week.
fields.body:
Spare a thought for a group of high-flying civil servants from across Europe who are having to slum it at a "budget committee" meeting this week.

The hard-working civil servants are having to turn their minds to the future of the European Union's budget during a three-day meeting in Lisbon starting today.

Luckily, they need do only three hours work during their stay at the Hotel Tivoli, where suites cost £166 a night.

To ensure that they have recovered fully from their long journey to Portugal, the civil servants and their partners will be taken on a guided tour of Lisbon this afternoon. This will be followed by dinner in one of the city's smartest restaurants.

Alarm clocks will be set early for tomorrow morning, but this will not be for anything as trivial as a business meeting. At 9am sharp a bus will arrive to take the civil servants to the Parque Des Nacoes, followed by a tour of Lisbon's the Oceanarium.

In the afternoon they will have a chance to savour the Almendres stone circle, built in honour of a fertility goddess.

Any civil servant with a slight sense of guilt will feel better on Friday morning, when they all finally sit down for a three-hour meeting. They will discuss the EU's budget and "activity-based budgeting".

During the meeting their partners will be whisked off to a carpet factory.

The partners will not feel lonely because the business meeting will be called to an abrupt halt at 12.30pm for lunch, followed by a visit to a horse farm.

The Conservatives, who uncovered the itinerary for the jaunt, said last night that publicly funded trips around Lisbon did not fit with the prime minister's pledge to eliminate waste in the EU.

Francis Maude, shadow foreign secretary, said: "Labour said it would clean up the EU and end the freebie mentality, but the gravy train just keeps on rolling.

"Three hours' work over four days is a light schedule, even by EU standards. British families should not be paying taxes just so that EU bosses and their partners can have the red carpet rolled out to visit horse farms, expensive restaurants and stone circles dedicated to exotic Mediterranean goddesses."

The Treasury last night distanced itself from the Lisbon meeting. A source said: "This is a meeting which takes place twice a year and is hosted by the country which holds the EU presidency. The costs will be met by the host nation."

Britain will be sending an official to the meeting from UKREP, the British "embassy" to the EU.

webTitle: Attack at zoo prompts Clinton gun plea

fields.headline: Attack at zoo prompts Clinton gun plea
fields.trailText: The shooting of seven young people in Washington's National Zoo was a "senseless act" which proved the need for the United States to adopt tougher laws controlling children's access to guns, Bill Clinton said yesterday.
fields.body:
The shooting of seven young people in Washington's National Zoo was a "senseless act" which proved the need for the United States to adopt tougher laws controlling children's access to guns, Bill Clinton said yesterday.

The president led a stream of reform advocates who seized on the latest gun outrage to call on the Republican-controlled Congress to drop its opposition to a gun law reform bill which is currently stalled.

"Our country still has too much violence, too much crime," Mr Clinton said at the White House. "Whether it's random acts against children or a crime driven by hate, it should be obvious that we can do more and we must do more."

The calls came as Washington police said they were searching for a black teenager named Antoine in connection with Monday's incident, in which seven children and teenagers were wounded, one of them critically, after shots were fired during a running scuffle between two groups of youths in the zoo, one of the US capital's most popular attractions.

The most seriously injured victim, an 11-year-old boy, was alive yesterday afternoon - despite an announcement from a police spokesman yesterday morning that he was brain dead. The Children's National Medical Centre said that the boy's condition had improved and he was responding to care.

The shootings came late in a day in which thousands from Washington's black community had crowded the 163-acre site for the zoo's annual Easter Monday celebration of African-American families, a tradition which goes back to the late 19th century, when black families were excluded from the White House's annual Easter Monday egg-rolling event.

Witnesses said that the shootings came after groups of black teenagers - as many as 40 at a time - had spent much of the day taunting and challenging one another. The teenagers were standing by a zoo entrance on one of Washington's main thoroughfares, Connecticut Avenue, when a bottle was thrown at one group, apparently sparking the shooting.

"Everybody started grabbing their babies and running," said one witness, Kristyl Nelson.

Police said that they were only looking for one gunman, who was last seen running down the avenue, away from the zoo. The National Association for the Advancement of Coloured People offered a $25,000 (£16,000) reward.

The number of victims, whose ages ranged from 11 to 16, rose from six overnight when a seventh teenager checked in to a local hospital with a gunshot wound to the thumb.

The zoo, which is a part of the Smithsonian Institution, and which draws more than 3m visitors each year, remained closed yesterday as police searched for clues.

webTitle: BMW rejects extra time for new Rover bid

fields.headline: BMW rejects extra time for new Rover bid
fields.standfirst: Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: The car giant BMW yesterday said it was not prepared to risk losing a Rover deal with Alchemy by giving the Phoenix consortium extra time to prepare its offer.
fields.body:
The car giant BMW yesterday said it was not prepared to risk losing a Rover deal with Alchemy by giving the Phoenix consortium extra time to prepare its offer.

A spokesman for the German vehicle maker said it was close to finalising its deal to sell the bulk of Rover to Alchemy, the London-based venture capital firm. "If we wait for another bid which may fail and we cannot stick to the earlier deal with Alchemy, we would have the worst solution," he said. "This is what we would like to avoid."

Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, is thought to have been given short shrift by BMW when he asked yesterday for more time for Phoenix to prepare its counterbid. Last night, Mr Byers said Walter Samann, the BMW director who heads the Rover Group, had agreed to meet the head of the consortium today.

He also said that Alchemy had told him that its plans would involve about 3,000 job losses at Rover, a number significantly below its earlier estimates. Unions have forecast that up to 11,000 Rover jobs will go in the event of an Alchemy takeover.

Jon Moulton, Alchemy's managing partner, said he expected to complete the deal by Friday. Even union officials said there would have to be a dramatic change in events if the Alchemy deal were not to go ahead.

Phoenix, led by John Towers, former Rover chief executive, believes its plans for Rover could save thousands more motor industry jobs compared with Alchemy's proposals. But it has yet to complete bid arrangements.

Yesterday, BMW stressed that there was no deadline for its negotiations with Alchemy, but that once the final contract was prepared, BMW's options would be to sign it or wait for "a vague hope" of an appropriate offer from someone else. BMW had asked Phoenix to clarify its proposed bid.

The consortium's dilemma is that it cannot guarantee its financial backing until it has checked Rover's financial and trading details. This will take at least six weeks, which will be way beyond the date Alchemy hopes to complete its negotiations with BMW.

John Hemming, a member of Phoenix, said: "In practice, we are willing to accept the figures that BMW have, for the consortium's purposes, but the banks want due diligence and that can only start tomorrow and it needs to be completed by Friday." The West Midlands businessman suggested BMW could underwrite the figures until they were checked. He also claimed Rover's real loss last year was about £170m and not the £800m given by BMW.

Mr Moulton said that the actual losses could be more than £800m and that the proposed Phoenix offer had "the great benefit of being derived from a pretty great state of ignorance". He said: "We have spent six months working on this company, looking very hard at all the options, including the mass production route that Mr Towers's group seems to think is viable. Nobody at BMW, none of the experts we've been working with and not even the civil servants at the DTI believe that the mass production route is viable. That route requires a subsidy not less than £200,000 per man to keep it going for a year."

Some high-level Whitehall figures accused Mr Hemming of "playing politics" by floating a plan that stands little chance of succeeding.

Tom Watson, the AEEU's political officer and a member of the Rover taskforce, said: "We urge BMW to reconsider but it looks as if the Phoenix bid is dead. If it transpires the consortium had no chance of raising the money then they are guilty of giving false hope to thousands of families in the West Midlands."

Mr Moulton said that the actual losses could be more than £800m and that the proposed Phoenix offer had "the great benefit of being derived from a pretty great state of ignorance". He said: "We have spent six months working on this company, looking very hard at all the options, including the mass production route that Mr Towers's group seems to think is viable. Nobody at BMW, none of the experts we've been working with and not even the civil servants at the DTI believe that the mass production route is viable. That route requires a subsidy not less than £200,000 per man to keep it going for a year." Some high-level Whitehall figures accused Mr Hemming of "playing politics" by floating a plan that stands little chance of succeeding. Tom Watson, the AEEU's political officer and a member of the Rover taskforce, said: "We urge BMW to reconsider but it looks as if the Phoenix bid is dead. If it transpires the consortium had no chance of raising the money then they are guilty of giving false hope to thousands of families in the West Midlands."

fields.headline: Lockerbie trial delay sought
fields.standfirst: Libya and the Lockerbie trial: special report
fields.trailText: Prosecutors in the Lockerbie trial yesterday applied for postponement of the much-anticipated case amid claims that they had not been given sufficient access to lists of defence witnesses and defence evidence.
fields.body:
Prosecutors in the Lockerbie trial yesterday applied for postponement of the much-anticipated case amid claims that they had not been given sufficient access to lists of defence witnesses and defence evidence.

In an unexpected move, the lord advocate, Colin Boyd QC, took a first step to have the trial of the Libyan suspects - Abdelbaset Ali Mohmed Al Megrahi, and Al Amin Khalifa Fhimah - postponed for several weeks. The trial had been due to begin next week - following years of diplomatic manoeuvring and legal wrangles - but after notice was given by the defence on Thursday that they would be calling 119 witness, the crown decided yesterday to move to have the start date put back from May 3.

The prosecution claims it has not been provided with enough notice of the witness list, despite the defence being asked repeatedly to disclose it. A crown office spokesman said the prosecutor had also had no sight of the defence's physical evidence and so did not believe he could go to trial next Wednesday.

The application will be heard by the trial's presiding judge, Lord Sutherland, in the specially constructed court house at Camp Zeist, in the Netherlands, tomorrow. Mr Boyd is expected to argue that, given the number of witnesses and the fact that many of them live abroad, he will not have time to prepare properly for trial. Most of the defence witnesses are from Libya, but others are scattered across Malta, Sweden, Germany and the United States.

The trial, which is expected to last at least a year, will be immensely complicated. It has taken more than a decade since Pan Am flight 103 exploded over the town of Lockerbie, in Scotland, killing 270 people, for the prospect of legal proceedings to become a reality. The investigation and arrest of the Libyan suspects has spanned at least three continents and the prosecution witness list alone runs to more than 1,000 entries.

Shortly before Christmas last year the defence was granted a postponement to prepare the case. With such complexity in mind, the families of those who died said yesterday they were anxious for the trial to start, but only if fairness could be served.

Jim Swire, head of UK Families Flight 103, said that any further postponement would be unwelcome, but that if it improved the quality of the defence or prosecution, they would go along with the decision of the judges.

webTitle: Easter flop leaves Dome in cash crisis

fields.headline: Easter flop leaves Dome in cash crisis
fields.standfirst:
Millennium Experience
Department for Culture, Media and Sport
fields.trailText: Money from the sale of the Millennium Dome is expected to be used to pay off its multi-million pound losses, government insiders admitted yesterday.
fields.body:
Money from the sale of the Millennium Dome is expected to be used to pay off its multi-million pound losses, government insiders admitted yesterday.

After a disastrous Easter, when visitor numbers fell while other attractions had their busiest weekend of the year, few expect the dome to attract anywhere near the 10m visitors it needs to break even.

With only £5m left of the £60m overdraft it was given by the Millennium Commission in January, the attraction's chief executive, Pierre-Yves Gerbeau, denied that he was on the point of asking for another £20m to tide it over.

During Easter week, an average of 17,153 people a day visited the dome, less than half the 35,000 capacity that Mr Gerbeau created by bringing in longer opening hours. The dome now looks like it could fall 2m-3m visitors short of its target of 10m. That figure was itself revised down from 12m after appalling attendances in the dome's first month.

Yesterday, Mr Gerbeau was putting a brave face on the figures, blaming the weather and the 1.5m who took foreign holidays.

"The product is sparkling and has never been better," he said. "A lot of people decided to to go abroad this Easter. We expect really big crowds over the summer and there will be a rush at the end of the year."

Mr Gerbeau said foreign tourists might have been confused as to whether the dome's 14 zones were under cover. "We are going to do a little marketing push so that tourists know the sun is always shining in the dome."

But the Easter flop is a blow to the former operations director at Disneyland Paris. Shortly after taking over, he noted how crucial the holiday weekend was. "If we are not ready," he said, "we are going to miss the Easter vacations, and if we miss Easter we are going to miss the summer."

Geoffrey Thompson, owner of Blackpool Pleasure Beach, which had 65,000 visitors on Sunday alone, was more blunt about the weekend flop.

"If you can't do it at Easter, you'll never do it - it's the largest holiday weekend in the calender. It is no good saying people have gone abroad, because 1.5m go every year. We had our best weekend ever at Southport and nearly set a record here in Blackpool too.

"The problem is the dome. Gerbeau is a good man, but the place looks like it was designed by the ministry of blandness," he said.

But a spokesman for the New Millennium Experience Company, which runs the Dome, insisted it was on course for the 10m target, though that would mean attracting 34,500 visitors a day from now on - 7,000 more than the dome managed in the spring half-term.

He said there were "no plans" to ask for a further loans from the Millennium Commission, and it hoped to cover "hypothetical" losses on ticket sales with profits from merchandising and the "legacy from the sale of the site".

A government source last night confirmed that it expected part of the sale proceeds to go towards paying off the dome's losses.

English Partnerships, which is likely to be locked into a battle with the Millennium Commission as to who gets the lion's share, said the final decision rested with the government.

fields.headline: Silicon Systems plans flotation
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Ireland's booming economy is about to propel another fast-growing hi-tech firm on to the London stock market.
fields.body:
Ireland's booming economy is about to propel another fast-growing hi-tech firm on to the London stock market.

Silicon Systems, a Dublin-based intellectual property chip design company, plans to float on the London and Nasdaq stock exchanges with an expected value of around $700m (£443m).

A company statement said the exact timing of the flotation "will depend on specific market conditions and corporate factors".

Silicon, which is changing its name to Parthus Technologies, hopes to follow the success of fellow Irish firm Baltimore Technologies, which was one of the star performers on the London market last year and recently joined the main FTSE 100 index.

Silicon's co-founders Brian Long and Peter Mcmanamon are likely to see their shareholdings valued at several hundred million dollars. Other major shareholders include ST Microelectronics and Goldman Sachs, the float's co-ordinator, which owns 23%.

Silicon develops product platforms for wireless technology devices and licenses its designs to a range of component manufacturers.

The company's clients include Texas Instruments, ST Microelectronics and Creative Labs. It also has a licensing agreement with microchip designer ARM Holdings, whose technology is used in three quarters of mobile phones worldwide.

Mr Long set up Silicon in 1993, initially as contract developer of silicon intellectual property for large semiconductor manufacturers such as ST Microelectronics. Between 1993 and 1998 the company made a profit.

In 1998 Silicon took in Goldman Sachs as an investor and decided to invest heavily in research and development.

Last year its revenues, largely from licences, were $19m but it recorded an undisclosed loss.

Silicon is expected to raise around $100m from the flotation to finance research and development, acquisitions and sales and marketing expenditure.

webTitle: Indian drought: Government under attack for slow response to crisis

fields.headline: Indian drought: Government under attack for slow response to crisis
fields.trailText: The Indian government, under fire for a slow response to a drought overtaking its western states which is said to be the worst this century, has pledged to commit all its resources to averting a looming national crisis.
fields.body:
The Indian government, under fire for a slow response to a drought overtaking its western states which is said to be the worst this century, has pledged to commit all its resources to averting a looming national crisis.

The vow came at the end of a parliamentary debate in which MPs attacked the government for failing to tackle a crisis that has raised the spectre of famine and affects an estimated 50m people.

The agriculture minister, Sunderlal Patwa, said 23,406 villages in the desert state of Rajasthan and 9,421 villages in neighbouring Gujarat were affected by "conditions of scarcity". But he said newspaper reports of people fleeing the two states were wrong.

The prime minister, Atal Bihari Vajpayee, made a televised appeal at the weekend for Indians to provide financial help to the afflicted states. Yesterday he held an all-party meeting on the crisis.

The government said it had released 100,000 tonnes of wheat and rice each for Rajasthan and Gujarat which would be distributed in the drought-hit areas at subsidised prices, and Mr Vajpayee told parliament that trainloads of animal fodder were being rushed there.

Meanwhile his Bharatiya Janata party urged rival groups not to play politics with drought. "We appeal to all political parties to join in this endeavour and not politicise it, otherwise it would divert the nation's attention from the problem confronting the people," a BJP spokesman said.

The opposition Congress party accused the government of acting too late to help a rural population already hit by high debt, rising fertiliser prices and falling groundwater levels.

The drought is hitting Rajasthan and Gujarat because the annual monsoon rains have failed in some areas over the past two years. A downpour at the weekend brought only a brief respite.

Meanwhile, in the eastern state of Orissa, where 10,000 died and 1m were left homeless by a cyclone in October, there are fears that people living in flimsy temporary housing could begin dying of heatstroke as temperatures soar past 40C. Reuters

webTitle: Agencies back plans to make adoption easier

fields.headline: Agencies back plans to make adoption easier
fields.trailText: Adoption agencies last night welcomed the government's plans to introduce new laws to make adoption easier amid signs that ministers are planning to offer extra cash to couples who care for children.
fields.body:
Adoption agencies last night welcomed the government's plans to introduce new laws to make adoption easier amid signs that ministers are planning to offer extra cash to couples who care for children.

During a two-hour summit in Downing Street, the health minister John Hutton told the agencies that adoptions could be increased by 1,000 a year under the government's plans.

Ministers aim to streamline Britain's adoption system by introducing national standards which will end the anomaly of separate councils applying different criteria to hopeful parents. Mr Hutton, who indicated that ministers are planning to increase funding for adoptions, hinted that the government could make it easier for older couples to adopt.

Felicity Collier, the chief executive of the British agencies for adoption and fostering, was hopeful of an extra £50m for parents who adopt. She said: "Everybody recognised that adoption, especially of vulnerable, disabled or disturbed children, is not a cheap option."

Experts estimate that up to 5,000 children who are suitable for adoption are trapped in the care system because they cannot be matched with prospective parents, while hundreds of couples find themselves frustrated by the complex adoption procedures.

fields.headline: Colombia agrees deal with rebels
fields.trailText: The Colombian government has agreed to pull troops and police out of a northern region to enable peace talks with the country's second largest leftwing rebel group, the National Liberation Army, or ELN.
fields.body:
The Colombian government has agreed to pull troops and police out of a northern region to enable peace talks with the country's second largest leftwing rebel group, the National Liberation Army, or ELN.

In a communique released on Monday, the ELN commander Nicolas Rodriguez said that government security forces would withdraw from the area surrounding three towns on the Magdalena river, to allow a national peace convention.

"Civil authorities, the guerrilla forces of the ELN and the communities will live side by side ...This is a serious attempt to find a peaceful solution to the conflict," he said.

The president, Andres Pastrana, confirmed that the two sides had reached a "general framework of understanding", although he gave no details about the withdrawal.

The announcement comes 17 months after government forces pulled out of a larger region in southern Colombia as a condition for talks with the most powerful rebel group, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (Farc).

Since taking office in 1998, Mr Pastrana has concentrated on making peace with the 15,000-strong Farc, but talks have stalled and the group has refused to call a ceasefire.

Meanwhile, the 5,000-strong ELN has carried out a campaign of terrorism and economic sabotage in an attempt to force the government to the negotiating table.

Last year, ELN gunmen hijacked a domestic airliner, and abducted more than 100 worshippers from a church mass.

The group declared a week-long Easter truce to coincide with behind-the-scenes talks with the government, but while most Colombians welcomed a new peace process, few believe it will be simple.

Although the second demilitarised zone - about the size of Switzerland - will be much smaller than the territory ceded to the Farc, the region is a key economic and strategic corridor. Rich in oil, gold, and coca - the raw material for cocaine - the area straddles the Magdalena river, Colombia's main waterway, and road links to the Caribbean.

Once an ELN stronghold, the region has been convulsed with violence since incursions by rightwing paramilitaries.

In a letter to the government peace commissioner, Victor Ricardo, paramilitary commanders from the United Self-Defence Forces of Colombia, or AUC, rejected the planned withdrawal, and threatened to attack the ELN within their safe haven.

"You cannot return to the ELN territory which the AUC has recovered," it said. "The ELN must not use their demilitarised zone to launch terrorist attacks. If they do, we will not respect their refuge."

But Mr Rodriguez announced that Colombian and international monitoring groups will be allowed into the ELN's demilitarised zone. Talks with Farc were suspended for several months last year, when commanders rejected the president's demand to allow international observers into their territory in the Caguan region of southern Colombia.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.body:
Severed limbs case appeal
A man wanted in connection with the death of a teenager whose severed limbs were found 60 miles apart has appealed against extradition from Holland. Two weeks ago a court ruled William Beggs, 36, from Kilmarnock, should go back to Scotland to face charges of murdering and abducting Barry Wallace, 18, also of Kilmarnock.

Toddler's death: man in court
A 30-year-old man charged with the murder of a 14-month-old boy was remanded in custody for a week when he appeared in court in Nuneaton, Warwickshire, yesterday. Karl Ison, of Hinckley, Leicestershire, is also charged with assaulting the boy causing grievous bodily harm on a separate occasion.

Suntan appeal stays strong
Four out of 10 people still think it is important to get a suntan on holiday, despite the dangers of skin cancer, a survey suggested yesterday. A quarter of adults think the risks are exaggerated, according to the poll for the Imperial Cancer Research Fund.

Two held over fans' killing
Turkish police have detained two more men in connection with the murder of two Leeds United fans in Istanbul, the British consulate said yesterday. Four men have already been charged with murder.

Shell blows up waste plant
Two workers were taken to hospital yesterday after an undetected second world war shell went through an industrial crusher, blowing up a waste processing plant in St Leonards, East Sussex.

webTitle: New boss for BBC's Radio 5 Live

fields.headline: New boss for BBC's Radio 5 Live
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: The BBC ended its long search for a controller of Radio 5 Live yesterday, naming one of the rolling news and sport station's founders as its new head. Bob Shennan, head of BBC Sport, will take on the new role in July, eight months after the post fell vacant.
fields.body:
The BBC ended its long search for a controller of Radio 5 Live yesterday, naming one of the rolling news and sport station's founders as its new head. Bob Shennan, head of BBC Sport, will take on the new role in July, eight months after the post fell vacant.

Mr Shennan, 38, replaces Roger Mosey, who moved over to become head of TV news last November. Mr Shennan said yesterday: "This is a dream job for me - one I've always wanted to do. It's a privilege to be given responsibility for such a terrific and successful network."

Jenny Abramsky, the BBC's director of radio, said: "I am really pleased that someone who has nurtured Radio 5 Live will be taking the network into the future. Bob loves radio and his understanding of Radio 5 Live will ensure it goes from strength to strength."

Mr Shennan joined the BBC in 1987 as a trainee radio sport producer. He was made head of radio sport and outside broadcasts in 1994, and became involved in the development of Radio 5 Live.

fields.body:
ITV faced mounting pressure to bring back News at Ten yesterday when the regulator which signed the programme's death warrant accused it of failing to stem an unacceptable decline in ratings for the replacement news bulletins.

The independent television commission gave ITV three weeks to come up with a plan to reverse the slump. Next month, it will decide whether to order the return of the flagship bulletin, axed last year to make way for ratings-boosting drama and films.

If the commission bends to intense political pressure, including from Tony Blair and the culture secretary, Chris Smith, and attempts to force ITV to bring back the programme, it will meet serious resistance. ITV has made up to £70m in extra advertising income since the bulletin was scrapped. More than 1m extra viewers watch ITV at 10pm now than last year.

There is speculation that ITV may argue that the commission has no power to force News at Ten back.

Since ITV was allowed to shift its main evening news programme from 10pm to 6.30pm, and replace its "second" bulletin at 5.40pm with a late-night alternative at 11pm, the total number of viewers for the two programmes has fallen by 13.9%. The 11pm news's performance has been particularly disappointing. The commercial channel's regional news programmes have fared even worse: audiences have dropped by 22%. The BBC has benefited from ITV's woe.

Sir Robin Biggam, the commission's chairman, said that ITV had "failed to deliver" on commitments to maintain ratings for national and regional news. The impact on regional news programmes had been "unacceptable", although he conceded that the decline in this area had been stemmed.

Gerald Kaufman, the chairman of the Commons media select committee, said: "The only possible satisfactory outcome to this very serious statement by the chairman is that News At Ten be brought back - that's the only remedy."

The commission acknowledged that ITV had met a promise to increase the range and diversity of the programmes which replaced the News at Ten, and that the quality of the ITN news bulletins had not diminished.

ITV recognises that it has a problem. Its main challenge is to boost ratings for the 11pm bulletin. It has experimented with a number of new drama series in the run-up to the late-night news, such as Always and Everyone and Bad Girls. A new series, Metropolis, starts next week.

In a statement ITV said: "The decline in news audiences remains a concern and ... ITV is focusing on finding ways to improve the ratings performance of the main news programmes.

"However it is encouraging that average audiences for ITV's flagship evening news programme at 6.30pm were broadly comparable for the first year, at 5.4m, to average audiences for News At Ten for the previous year, at 5.7m. These figures vindicate that 6.30pm is an attractive time for viewers."

fields.headline: Philippines held to ransom
fields.standfirst: Army and navy step up hunt for 50 hostages held by separatists
fields.trailText: Rebel Islamic separatists from the Philippines suspected of kidnapping a party of foreign tourists from a Malaysian tropical diving resort yesterday taunted the Manila government over their demands.
fields.byline: Owen Bowcott  and agencies in Semporna, Malaysia
fields.body:
Rebel Islamic separatists from the Philippines suspected of kidnapping a party of foreign tourists from a Malaysian tropical diving resort yesterday taunted the Manila government over their demands.

The Abu Sayyaf movement, which is demanding the release of Muslim militants jailed in the US as well as an independent Islamic homeland on the island of Mindanao, is now thought to hold nearly 50 hostages - many of them Filipino schoolchildren.

Despite air force and naval searches of the Celebes sea, between Malaysia and the Philippines, the six masked gunmen, who carried AK-47s and a rocket launcher when they abducted 21 tourists and workers from the Malaysian island of Sipadan on Sunday evening, have not been found. The captured holidaymakers include three Germans, two French, two South Africans, two Finns and one Lebanese.

For the past month, Abu Sayyaf has been holding 27 Filipinos hostage, mostly children, on the Philippines island of Basilan in the face of a sustained ground offensive by the army. Last week the rebels announced that they had beheaded two male hostages.

Evidence of the group's involvement in the latest kidnap strengthened throughout the day. A marine photographer, Danny Chin, who hid from the gunmen while they were ransacking the resort on Sipadan told a local newspaper that they wrote the words "Abu Sayyaf" on a wall.

A report sourced to the Philippines police said the hostages had been taken to the Sulu archipelago at the southern tip of the country.

Earlier in the day an Abu Sayyaf spokesman, Abu Ahmad, boasted to a Philippine radio station: "Our group is behind the abduction of the foreigners [in Malaysia] and there are still a lot of surprises for the government if they won't listen to us".

Several hours later, however, in a second interview intended to exacerbate the authorities' discomfort, he added: "I'm not saying that we are the ones. I'm also not saying we are not the ones. Let's give the government a puzzle."

The organisation has previously demanded that the US should free three Islamists, including Ramzi Yousef, the mastermind of the 1993 bombing of the World Trade Centre in New York, and Sheik Omar Abdel-Rahman, who was convicted of conspiring to blow up New York city landmarks.

Sabah state police, in Malaysia, yesterday interrogated five people understood to include former employees of the Sipadan island resort, who were suspected of knowing some of the gunmen or aiding them in the kidnapping.

Earlier yesterday, a local Philippine radio station broadcast an appeal from a Catholic priest, held captive on Basilan by Abu Sayyaf along with the children, pleading for the military offensive to stop.

webTitle: Something rotten at the heart of an ailing country

fields.headline: Something rotten at the heart of an ailing country
fields.standfirst: As African profiteering goes it is small beer, but the consequences have proved disastrousZimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Despite calls for the investigation and freezing of Mugabe's personal assets held abroad, most observers believe that the teetotal president is more interested in clinging on to power than in lining his pocket.
fields.body:
The head of the armed forces in Zimbabwe is a director of a private company dealing in the mining and trading of gold and diamonds, ostensibly to finance the war effort in the north which is supplied by the general's transport firm.

Another director is the defence ministry permanent secretary whose other benefits include a lease on an 800,000-acre state farm for just over £1 a year.

The agriculture minister has been charged under the Prevention of Corruption Act with taking £3.5m from public funds and is out on bail. Two other permanent secretaries and the former head of the national oil company are under investigation for fraud.

The head of state's nephew represented a consortium which dubiously won the £1.5m contract to build the capital's new international airport.

His brother-in-law received a record £14,000 payout from the fund for war veterans which has been plundered by members of the ruling elite. A judicial commission alleged that many of the claims were fraudulent.

His young wife, a serious shopaholic, took £100,000 to build a mansion from a public housing scheme. Two years ago, without being lived in, it was put on the market for more than £400,000.

Welcome to Zimbabwe. In the scale of African profiteering, this is small beer, partly because the country does not have the sort of riches that encourage massive illegal expropriation. In Transparency International's index of perceived corruption, Zimbabawe ranks around the middle of 99 nations, along with Brazil, Morrocco and Malawi.

Despite calls for the investigation and freezing of Mugabe's personal assets held abroad, most observers believe that the teetotal and, even at 76, fitness-fanatic president is more interested in clinging on to power than in lining his pocket. He hasn't even been able to buy a presidential jet, though he can commandeer planes from the national airline.

While ordinary Zimbabweans are convinced that he has the mandatory Swiss bank account, most observers are convinced that he cannot match the cupidity of Nigeria's Abacha or Zaire's Mobutu.

The same cannot be said of those who surround him, though it would be an heroic senior civil servant or general in most African countries who denied himself the opportunities to get rich while in office.

The problem for Mugabe is the perception - in a highly literate population - that he has done very little about reining in the excesses of his family and party cronies.

John Makumbe, an academic critic at Harare University, says: "Experience has taught Zimbabweans that the (ruling) Zanu-PF government is very good at setting up all manner of schemes, funds and programmes to benefit the poor and the needy. But soon after gathering the money, it loots everything with impunity for the benefit of big chiefs."

After 20 years in power, it was only this month that the constitution was changed to provide for an anti-corruption commission and the fraud squad started to make some very high level arrests of officials and executives in key state organisations.

In a country that ranks 130 out of 174 in the United Nations human development index, and where life expectancy has dropped to an alarming 44 years - due to the Aids crisis - the flagrant abuse of state funds has become a critical election issue. Last July, Mugabe publicly recognised the problems with this admonition to his cabinet about the way contracts are awarded. "I know they are buying you for tenders and that some of you are accepting huge bribes, but can you have the courage to say to them you've lost the tender at the end of the day?"

The most serious scandal since independence in 1980 concerned the war veterans fund - compensation for the very people that Mugabe is now using as his political stormtroopers. General Vitalis Zvinavashe, the army commander now in private business in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) where 11,000 Zimbabwean troops are based, claimed 55% disability. Police commissioner Augustine Chihuri petitioned for 20% and his deputy Godwin Matanga for 92%.

The opposition MP Margaret Dongo said: "There are so many cabinet members, army officers and police officers who are claiming funds for serious disabilities, it is a wonder the government can function at all." Judge Chidyauysiku, who conducted an investigation into the scandal, just managed to keep his sense of humour. Confronted by a 92% disability claim from a former Zanu-PF MP of considerable girth, he remarked laconically: "I see here that one of your claims was for loss of appetite."

The ordinary veterans lost out, too, on the distribution of state-owned tenant and commercials farms. But Zimbabwe's democratic process, however skewed, does allow light to be shed on these matters. It was Mrs Dongo, the president of the Zimbabwe Union of Democrats, who asked for and was given a list of all farms leased out since 1990. Recipients of government munificence include the attorney general, the cabinet secretary, several civil servants and prominent business people.

Transparency does not exist, however, in Zimbabwe's 20-month involvement in the DRC in support of President Kabila against the Uganda and Rwanda-backed rebels. Mugabe's government has urged local business to take advantage of the economic opportunities in minerals-rich Congo, and his senior people have been enthusiastically showing the way to pay for a war costing up to £60,000 a day.

Besides General Zvinavashe's gold and diamond company, Olseg Private Limited, which is a joint venture with a company owned by the Congolese military, Zimbabwe also has an interest in the DRC's other main asset, the cobalt and copper mining enterprise, Gecamines.

For a year until last November, the chairman of Gecamines was the South African-based Zimbabwean entrepreneur Billy Rautenbach, introduced to Kabila by Mugabe's right-hand man and principal deal-maker, the justice minister Emerson Mnangagwa. For reasons that are still unclear, Kabila sacked Rautenbach last November just as he was placed under investigation in Johannesburg for fraud, tax evasion and alleged involvement with organised crime. Last September, the Zimbabwean magazine Legal Forum described the country as a "racketeering state" characterised by minimal economic development, stagnation leading to recession and unbridled greed by the ruling elite. Little wonder that President Mugabe and his friends are not keen to take a rest.
