webTitle: Jalopy man reaches out to zone 27

fields.headline: Jalopy man reaches out to zone 27
fields.standfirst: In the first of a series profiling the four main candidates, the Guardian finds a relaxed Steve Norris failing to follow the Conservative wayThe London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Among Steve Norris's manifesto commitments for the London mayoralty election is the following: "We will ensure a frequent, reliable bus service." He has not made a convincing start.
fields.body:
Among Steve Norris's manifesto commitments for the London mayoralty election is the following: "We will ensure a frequent, reliable bus service." He has not made a convincing start.

Mr Norris was supposedly travelling on his own campaign bus yesterday afternoon to the further reaches of east London: Fairlop and Barkingside. The bus never appeared. "I'm not happy with the lettering," said an aide. The candidate went in his chauffeur-driven Jag instead.

Not happy with the lettering! How would that have gone down in Barkingside had they known? How would they react if the 247 were cancelled for aesthetic reasons?

A bus did turn up, however, and it was not the 247 either. It was the Ken4London bus: open-topped in the old-fashioned seaside manner; supposedly purple (though it's actually lilac); and brimful of votaries in matching fleeces who were jiggling up and down in unison like devotees of an obscure religious cult.

The chances of two candidates turning up in this remote corner of the capital by chance were zero. And indeed, Ken himself was nowhere to be seen. It was a good-humoured ambush.

Not, however, one that was ever going to bother a candidate as skillful as Steve Norris. He shook the hand of the acting cult leader as though he were Stanley greeting the other Livingstone at Umjiji (a place far more accessible than Fairlop). "Have you seen our bus?" he was asked.

"Seen it? It's wonderful. The urban terrorism of it! I just love it. It's so Zone 1!" They shook hands and the lilacs moved on, having failed to dent the Norris composure for a second. Just another moment in the wackiest election since Eatanswill.

Adversity

London is choosing its first elected mayor on Thursday next week. But preliminary voting starts in some polling stations tomorrow, which may mean broadcast media scaling down their coverage and an end to the extraordinary round of debates, which have turned the candidates into companions in adversity. "We can all do each other's speeches now," says Norris.

The bookmakers are packing up because they reckon Ken Livingstone is already past the post. But the thing about this election is that nobody knows anything. Everything's novel: the early voting; the London-wide concept; the man without a party; the four-horse race; the second preferences; the pseudo-American feel of it all.

"I'm very, very confident," Mr Norris told a London radio station yesterday. That's a lie. But he does still think he has a chance.

He uses the Zone 1 jibe quite regularly: that Mr Livingstone is the candidate of the metropolitan sophisticates with nothing to say to Fairlop and Barkingside, which are somewhere around Zone 27. "The twilight zone," said someone. There are an awful lot of twilight zones that will be voting in this election.

"Ken's got no organisation in places like this," said Mr Norris. "Labour has the organisation but it's not doing anything. We are. All the way round outer London. Places like this. Upminster and Chingford. All the southern states from Bexley right round to Kingston. We've got the constituency parties and we've got the mechanisms to get the vote out."

The mechanisms belong to the Conservatives, and Steve Norris is the Conservative candidate. But not so as you'd notice. He is organising his own show from an obscure basement in Victoria with minimal interference from Central Office.

It's an informal kind of operation, and he is always Steve. Only Ken Clarke, among leading Conservatives, has ever had an office this relaxed in my experience. It is not the Conservative way. Billy Hague? I think not. Stan Baldwin? Tony Eden? Artie Balfour?

Popsy

The Norris posters show a florid-faced man, rather camp-looking: a 1930s art critic perhaps. Camp, however, is not his reputation. For those who may have been on Mars (or in Fairlop) until now, perhaps one should explain. But how? Let's just say he's a politician with whom the word "services" brings to mind not so much the buses as the activity commonly encouraged among pedigree bulls.

He does have a certain 1930s style, but it is very uncamp. Steve would have been taking his popsy down to the roadhouse in his jalopy at high speed, then mysteriously running out of petrol at a quiet and wooded spot halfway home.

It makes him at home in Barkingside, which was built around the same time, when the Central Line headed out towards the green fields of Ongar. It's a place with a settled, stable feel. Mr Norris was MP for Epping Forest nearby, and he works the high street as though he's known everyone his whole life: "How ARE you?" "Nice to SEE you!"

His manifesto is entitled Action Not Politics. This is bizarre. Is there any other profession which pretends it is not doing its job when it is? Action not Nursing? Action not Journalism? Action not Chartered Accountancy?

The mayoralty is going to be the most political job the British constitution has ever invented. The powers are so inchoate, so work-in-progress, that its success will depend hugely on the winner's ability to push the right buttons simultaneously with the boroughs, the new assembly, Whitehall, Westminster, Downing Street and the electorate.

He was discussing yesterday how the mayor will have responsibility for Trafalgar Square, but not Fleet Street or the Strand. It will be like a stalemated game of Monopoly in which deals have to be done or no one will ever build anything.

And Norris is an instinctive politician, who has spent his career making out that he has better things to do and yet keeps coming back for more, as though dragged reluctantly from his bed or his business. He has studied the US and French may oralty models, and has a clear idea of what he can and can't do.

"There's going to be a lot of power, though there'll be a lot more power to say no than to say yes. If the mayor chooses his issues, and they aren't Labour issues, they aren't Tory issues, and they aren't God-forsaken Livingstonian issues, but London issues, he can be very effective."

He agreed to say no to the racecourse planned for a park at Fairlop, which pleased the protesters he had come there to meet. He is saying an emphatic no to congestion charging too, which makes him different from the other candidates. He wants the jalopies to go faster, and he wants to keep the quiet wooded spots - hence his opposition to the racecourse. He talks about supporting the police but, without stopping for breath, sticks in a balancing clause about fighting homophobia and racism.

This is politics all right, but not as we know it. It is not Toryism as we know it either. The Norris theory is this: that he is now ahead of Frank Dobson and Susan Kramer, and the final choice will rest on the second preferences of their supporters.

Will any self-respecting loyal Labour or Liberal Democrat voter bring themselves to put down - three years after everyone ganged up to massacre the Conservatives - a TORY as their second choice? He's banking on it. If he's right, he may get the chance to make London safe for jalopy-drivers with popsies once again.

Popsy The Norris posters show a florid-faced man, rather camp-looking: a 1930s art critic perhaps. Camp, however, is not his reputation. For those who may have been on Mars (or in Fairlop) until now, perhaps one should explain. But how? Let's just say he's a politician with whom the word "services" brings to mind not so much the buses as the activity commonly encouraged among pedigree bulls. He does have a certain 1930s style, but it is very uncamp. Steve would have been taking his popsy down to the roadhouse in his jalopy at high speed, then mysteriously running out of petrol at a quiet and wooded spot halfway home. It makes him at home in Barkingside, which was built around the same time, when the Central Line headed out towards the green fields of Ongar. It's a place with a settled, stable feel. Mr Norris was MP for Epping Forest nearby, and he works the high street as though he's known everyone his whole life: "How ARE you?" "Nice to SEE you!" His manifesto is entitled Action Not Politics. This is bizarre. Is there any other profession which pretends it is not doing its job when it is? Action not Nursing? Action not Journalism? Action not Chartered Accountancy? The mayoralty is going to be the most political job the British constitution has ever invented. The powers are so inchoate, so work-in-progress, that its success will depend hugely on the winner's ability to push the right buttons simultaneously with the boroughs, the new assembly, Whitehall, Westminster, Downing Street and the electorate. He was discussing yesterday how the mayor will have responsibility for Trafalgar Square, but not Fleet Street or the Strand. It will be like a stalemated game of Monopoly in which deals have to be done or no one will ever build anything. And Norris is an instinctive politician, who has spent his career making out that he has better things to do and yet keeps coming back for more, as though dragged reluctantly from his bed or his business. He has studied the US and French may oralty models, and has a clear idea of what he can and can't do. "There's going to be a lot of power, though there'll be a lot more power to say no than to say yes. If the mayor chooses his issues, and they aren't Labour issues, they aren't Tory issues, and they aren't God-forsaken Livingstonian issues, but London issues, he can be very effective." He agreed to say no to the racecourse planned for a park at Fairlop, which pleased the protesters he had come there to meet. He is saying an emphatic no to congestion charging too, which makes him different from the other candidates. He wants the jalopies to go faster, and he wants to keep the quiet wooded spots - hence his opposition to the racecourse. He talks about supporting the police but, without stopping for breath, sticks in a balancing clause about fighting homophobia and racism. This is politics all right, but not as we know it. It is not Toryism as we know it either. The Norris theory is this: that he is now ahead of Frank Dobson and Susan Kramer, and the final choice will rest on the second preferences of their supporters. Will any self-respecting loyal Labour or Liberal Democrat voter bring themselves to put down - three years after everyone ganged up to massacre the Conservatives - a TORY as their second choice? He's banking on it. If he's right, he may get the chance to make London safe for jalopy-drivers with popsies once again.

fields.headline: Political killings inflame pre-poll tension
fields.standfirst: Most victims of violence are opposition party membersZimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: A wave of political repression continued to engulf Zimbabwe yesterday following the murder of three supporters of the opposition party, allegedly at the hands of activists from the ruling party.
fields.body:
A wave of political repression continued to engulf Zimbabwe yesterday following the murder of three supporters of the opposition party, allegedly at the hands of activists from the ruling party.

The killings mark a sharp escalation in political violence over the last few days as members of Robert Mugabe's Zanu-PF party switched the emphasis of their campaign of political intimidation away from white farmers to individual supporters of the opposition, the Movement for Democratic Change (MDC), ahead of next month's elections.

One MDC supporter was attacked with axes in Shamva, 55 miles north of Harare, on Monday night after attending a rally. He was approached by Zanu supporters and asked to produce the party card.

"He failed to do so and was beaten badly," said Moses Kufandiko, the MDC organising secretary for the area. David Mhaurwa died yesterday morning.

Another MDC supporter was killed on Monday night in the capital, Harare. He was working as a bouncer at a bar when two Zanu supporters approached and asked to come in. He refused them entry and when they noticed that he was wearing an MDC T-shirt they beat him to death with metal bars.

Another opposition organiser, Robert Mbuzi, died from gunshot wounds he suffered on Friday near Mhangura, 100 miles north-west of Harare.

Their murders bring the death toll to 12 in the past two months. Ten of the victims have been members of the MDC, which is posing a serious threat to the 20-year rule of president Robert Mugabe's party.

The other two were a farm foreman and a policeman who was killed because he was suspected of supporting the MDC. Two of the dead MDC members were also white farmers.

Police arrested five suspects for the murders yesterday - the first arrests since the most recent spate of killings and beatings began.

Morgan Tsvangirai, leader of the MDC, said political violence may be the price Zimbabwe has to pay to achieve democratic change. "This intimidation will continue," he said. "We believe violence against our supporters will not be scaled down until after the elections, whenever they are held. The MDC is aware of this burden and sacrifice. It will not deter our campaign. The elections are the real benchmark. They will determine where this country is headed. We shall pull through."

Mr Tsvangirai doubted whether a meeting in London later this week, between a Zimbabwe government delegation and the British government to discuss the land crisis, would offer a tangible solution.

"We believe the question is one of the future of Mugabe's government, and that cannot be settled by the London meeting. The violence at home has nothing to do with commercial farmers, it is a political equation," Mr Tsvangirai said.

With the scheduled time for the election fast approaching and the MDC maintaining a strong political presence, Mr Mugabe has stopped scapegoating white farmers and let the question of land reform take a back seat as his party's supporters have begun to target opposition party workers and the black labourers he fears will support them.

Many white farmers returned to their homes over the Easter weekend under local deals with squatters which ensured their safety, so long as they did not allow the MDC to organise on their property. Mr Mugabe's political opponents have accused him of attempting to stoke up racial hatred and revive the issue of land redistribution in order to divert the electorate's attention from the parlous state of the country and the unpopular war in the Congo. Inflation stands at more than 50%, unemployment is also high and foreign reserves have dwindled, while fuel shortages are widespread.

Mugabe is not due for re-election until 2002. But his hold on power has looked increasingly tenuous, particularly since he lost the referendum on constitutional change last month which would have allowed him to run for president for two more five-year terms.

webTitle: Leader's gaze falls on the ordinary Zimbabweans he betrayed

fields.headline: Leader's gaze falls on the ordinary Zimbabweans he betrayed
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Robert Mugabe looks down from almost every wall at the provincial hospital in Marondera. His mouth is stuck between a grimace and a wince; he wears a thin strand of moustache. In Ward One lies one of his victims.
fields.body:
Robert Mugabe looks down from almost every wall at the provincial hospital in Marondera. His mouth is stuck between a grimace and a wince; he wears a thin strand of moustache.

His eyes do not follow you around but are fixed in a glare which is too stern to be avuncular but not piercing enough to be sinister. Omnipresent and omniscient - there is no escaping the father of the nation.

In Ward One lies one of his victims. Florence Mutengiwa was badly burned when supporters of the ruling Zanu-PF party smashed the windows in her home, threw grass inside, poured petrol on it and set it alight while she and her husband Ishmael were sleeping.

The attackers locked the door from the outside, leaving Florence and her husband to burn. They were just two of the dozen or so black farmers on the Dean farm near Marondera, east of Harare, who were beaten and burned because they were sus pected of supporting the opposition Movement for Democratic Change.

They are now in the frontline of the power struggle in Zimbabwe as Mugabe supporters have switched their intimidatory tactics away from white farmers to their labourers - one of the most poorly paid and downtrodden sections of the nation's workforce.

The couple were transported to the hospital in Marondera in the truck of their employer, Craig White. Ishmael, a farm supervisor, escaped with only burns to his hands, others had their arms broken.

Florence was not so lucky. Her top lip, nose, cheeks and forehead are all charred and puffy. Her left eye is nothing but a squint; her head is horrifically misshapen. She is a young woman who did not so much lose her looks as have them brutally taken away from her - possibly forever. Her face is so swollen that she cannot speak.

Outside the ward young men in Zanu T-shirts roam the yard making sure that nobody else speaks either.

A small group of patients admitted yesterday with newly broken limbs shoo the Guardian away as one of the Zanu supporters approaches. A foreman who was killed nearby 10 days ago had his lips cut off and was paraded around the area as a warning to his peers to keep quiet.

Underneath a portrait of Mr Mugabe, the hospital administrator Dr Mojak sits in denial. As a government employee he is almost certainly a member of Zanu.

At the mention of Monday's attack at Dean farm he shuffles nervously and starts to stall. First he says Florence is not there; then that he has no knowledge of her being there; and finally that she is there but it is not possible to see her without first talking to the minister of health.

Because of an influx of patients with cholera and diarrhoea Florence's admission had completely slipped his mind, he insists. "You must go through the official channels," he says, "to protect her human rights."

webTitle: 'The killers must be tried - for the soul of the country'

fields.headline: 'The killers must be tried - for the soul of the country'
fields.standfirst: Whites ask not for revenge but the return of peace and orderZimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Maria Stevens tried to speak at the memorial service for her murdered husband David, but was overcome by emotion.
fields.body:
Maria Stevens tried to speak at the memorial service for her murdered husband David, but was overcome by emotion.

Attending with her four children, including two-year-old twins, she delivered her message in notes handed out to reporters.

"I hope for the sake of my husband that something good will come out of this dreadful and intimidating situation," the notes read, as Mrs Stevens held her crying baby. "I hope our beautiful country will return to its happy state and that it will get the change we deserve."

David Stevens, who was 47, was killed on April 15 by supporters of President Robert Mugabe who accused him of supporting the opposition Movement for Democratic Change (MDC). Stevens was one of at least nine people to die in two months of strife. Another white farmer, a black policeman, a farm foreman and at least five members of the MDC have also been killed in the land-grab campaign.

More than 1,000 members of the white farming community attended the memorial service yesterday in Harare, including John Osborne, who was abducted when he tried to rescue Stevens from war veterans and who was present when his friend was killed.

With his right eye still blackened and breathing with difficulty because of a collapsed lung from, he told reporters: "It's over and I'm fine."

Only a handful of blacks attended. All of the 300 workers on the Stevens farm had been intimidated. They said they were afraid of being ambushed.

"David Stevens had great compassion for his family and his workers. He had a sense of righteousness. These qualities got him killed," said Reverend Terje Bjerkholdt, who conducted the memorial service in Harare. The minister said that Stevens's black foreman, Julius Andoche, was also murdered, but his body was not discovered until a week later.

"These men were tortured and killed in the most gruesome manner," Pastor Bjerkholdt said. "The murderers must be caught and brought to trial, not for revenge, but for the soul of this country so it will be seen that justice has been done."

Burly farmers wiped their eyes and others wept when Stevens's favourite song, Have I told you lately that I love you, was played in the hall.

More than 50 white farming families neighbouring Stevens's farm evacuated the Macheke Virginia area, terrified by an armed gang of more than 100 marauders. The police offered no protection. Many returned to their farms on Monday, but others felt the situation was still too insecure. No arrests have been made for the killings of Stevens or Andoche, although several witnesses identified the perpetrators of the crimes.

Even as the memorial service was held, a campaign of state-sponsored violence and intimidation swept through rural Zimbabwe designed to cow the population into voting for Mr Mugabe's ruling Zanu-PF party in the parliamentary elections. The election date has yet to be announced.

Zimbabwe's vice-president, Simon Muzenda, said he was not sorry about the deaths of Stevens or his fellow white farmer Martin Olds. "Those two farmers who were killed had provoked the former fighters [who had invaded their farms] and it should not be regrettable," Mr Muzenda said. "We are calling on war veterans to remain on the farms and we warn farmers not to provoke them."

Hundreds of farm labourers suspected of supporting the opposition MDC have been beaten, tortured and threatened by Mr Mugabe's backers.

The wife of a white farmer who was beaten unconscious and later received a death threat said: "Our workers are very vulnerable. We get reports that they have been beaten and burned, that they have broken arms and legs. My husband cannot go back, but I have gone back to the farm to try to help them. Some have fled into the bush and the ones who stay are being beaten. It is terrible."

Death threats have been issued to several white farmers in the Wedza and Matabeleland areas. Death threats have also been issued in Harare to several leading members of the MDC, human rights activists, independent journalists and an Anglican priest who criticised the government.

Iden Wetherell, deputy editor of the Zimbabwe Independent, said: "With this campaign of violence and intimidation, Mugabe has reimposed his authority over the rural areas. It will be more difficult to intimidate the urban areas, but the rural areas are in terror. Now there is no question that free and fair elections can be held."

fields.headline: Rocky road to reconciliation
fields.standfirst: Saro-Wiwa execution in 1995 continues to haunt Shell
fields.trailText: Ken Saro-Wiwa, the Ogoni activist whose execution in 1995 brought opprobrium on the oil multinational Shell, received a symbolic funeral on Monday. But his body remains where it was buried by the Nigerian regime.
fields.body:
Ken Saro-Wiwa, the Ogoni activist whose execution in 1995 brought opprobrium on the oil multinational Shell, received a symbolic funeral on Monday. But his body remains where it was buried by the Nigerian regime.

In a move which typifies the confusion and infighting of this Niger delta region, this week' s funeral, which was organised by his younger brother did not include a reburial. That is still planned for the November anniversary of the execution, with other members of the family insisting on honouring his wishes for a private ceremony.

For the past two years Shell has been attempting to repair relations with the Ogoni. With the Methodist church acting as intermediary, a painfully slow reconciliation appeared to be healing the wounds caused by the company's refusal to intervene in the events that led to the execution of Saro-Wiwa and eight colleagues.

That has all fallen apart over the past few weeks, however. Violence has erupted again, resulting in several deaths. Ledum Mitee, Saro-Wiwa's successor as leader of the Movement for the Survival of the Ogoni People (Mosop), has been charged with attempted murder and arson. He is due to appear in court next week on the arson charges, ironically the day after Shell publishes its third annual report on its social and environmental performance.

The latest conflict endangers Shell's efforts to be seen as a "responsible" business. It also highlights the difficulties for companies attempting to work in accordance with the wishes of the communities where they operate.

The Ogoni affair in 1995, combined with the humiliating climbdown over plans to sink the Brent Spar oil platform, forced Shell to reassess its business approach and pursue what it dubbed "profits with principles". This includes opening its social and environmental performance to external scrutiny.

But despite years of careful diplomacy in Nigeria, Shell is accused once again of trampling local communities and bypassing Ogoni representatives. In an open letter to Shell chairman Mark Moody-Stuart, Mr Mitee wrote: "Shell risks sparking the worst crisis in relations since1995."

Mosop describes the recent violence as a rerun of 1994 - the events which led to the arrest and execution of the Mosop activists.

Speaking from his law chambers in Port Harcourt before his arrest, Mr Mitee said: "Shell has not actually changed over the past five years. There is nothing to show they want to match words to actions on the ground."

Mosop accuses the oil company of using sham consultations with local organisations in the Ogoni region to justify pushing ahead with road construction projects. It says local government leaders have been bribed to allow contractors into the area but local opposition has necessitated armed police protection. And the organisation claims documents supposedly showing Mr Mitee's support for the road projects are forgeries.

Rebuttal

Shell dismisses these accusations. Emeka Achebe, an adviser on Nigeria in the group's London headquarters, said the company has asked for evidence of bribery, which would justify instant dismissal, but none has been forthcoming. He says Shell is not interested in working under armed protection.

"We are committed to not working in areas where we are not welcome," Mr Achebe said. "The best security is good relationships. We would not encourage staff or contractors to do that. If armed protection is necessary, it is not worth being there."

The executive says Shell has worked hard to rebuild relationships with the Ogonis after the executions. Mr Achebe stressed the company's approach was not aimed at an early return to oil production, which ceased in 1993, and said that oil from Ogoniland provided less than 5% of production from the delta region.

He confirmed that Shell would eventually hope to start producing oil again in the area, but said the immediate aim was to repair relationships and rebuild communities.

This approach is based on the group's new philosophy, developed after the Saro-Wiwa affair, which places social and environmental objectives alongside shareholder value.

"There are three legs to our philosophy. We are not there directly for economic benefit. We have other responsibilities," he said.

The aim is to pursue priorities determined by the Ogoni people through a series of consultations involving independent participants such as the World Bank, the European Union and voluntary sector groups, as well as hundreds of Ogoni representatives.

Projects include youth training, power and water developments, as well as road schemes which have sparked the renewed hostility.

Mosop has criticised most of these as little more than window-dressing, but the main dispute is about how the projects are chosen and carried out.

Mr Mittee has dismissed the oil company's consultations, which he said were "phoney arrangements" aimed at winning the maximum propaganda effect.

"It is not for Shell to choose who they should talk to. It is for the people to choose who should talk," he said.

At a special congress recently, Mosop demanded a role in assessing the development projects which Shell is backing. But the company says the projects stem from a thorough and wide-ranging "stakeholder dialogue" with many community representatives and Mosop should not have a right of veto.

Divine intervention

In any case, Mr Achebe argues that Mosop has previously been invited to participate and has refused.

This is another claim which Mr Mitee does not accept, suggesting that the truth of what is happening on the ground may be being kept from Shell leaders in Europe.

But while the gap between the two sides seems irreconcilable, church leaders who have been brokering a peace remain optimistic. Bishop MK Stephen said recently: "As far as I am concerned we have made tremendous progress. The differences are not as great as has been suggested, not as tempestuous as people think. The situation is better under control now. We may be able to see the way forward very shortly."

Shell will certainly want firm evidence of responsible practices on the ground to back up its claims to have changed its spots.

But this episode demonstrates that corporate responsibility is more difficult than writing a new mission statement, and stakeholder dialogue, which lies at the heart of it, is not a simple matter of calling a meeting and getting everybody to agree.

And the organisation claims documents supposedly showing Mr Mitee's support for the road projects are forgeries. Rebuttal Shell dismisses these accusations. Emeka Achebe, an adviser on Nigeria in the group's London headquarters, said the company has asked for evidence of bribery, which would justify instant dismissal, but none has been forthcoming. He says Shell is not interested in working under armed protection. "We are committed to not working in areas where we are not welcome," Mr Achebe said. "The best security is good relationships. We would not encourage staff or contractors to do that. If armed protection is necessary, it is not worth being there." The executive says Shell has worked hard to rebuild relationships with the Ogonis after the executions. Mr Achebe stressed the company's approach was not aimed at an early return to oil production, which ceased in 1993, and said that oil from Ogoniland provided less than 5% of production from the delta region. He confirmed that Shell would eventually hope to start producing oil again in the area, but said the immediate aim was to repair relationships and rebuild communities. This approach is based on the group's new philosophy, developed after the Saro-Wiwa affair, which places social and environmental objectives alongside shareholder value. "There are three legs to our philosophy. We are not there directly for economic benefit. We have other responsibilities," he said. The aim is to pursue priorities determined by the Ogoni people through a series of consultations involving independent participants such as the World Bank, the European Union and voluntary sector groups, as well as hundreds of Ogoni representatives. Projects include youth training, power and water developments, as well as road schemes which have sparked the renewed hostility. Mosop has criticised most of these as little more than window-dressing, but the main dispute is about how the projects are chosen and carried out. Mr Mittee has dismissed the oil company's consultations, which he said were "phoney arrangements" aimed at winning the maximum propaganda effect. "It is not for Shell to choose who they should talk to. It is for the people to choose who should talk," he said. At a special congress recently, Mosop demanded a role in assessing the development projects which Shell is backing. But the company says the projects stem from a thorough and wide-ranging "stakeholder dialogue" with many community representatives and Mosop should not have a right of veto. Divine intervention In any case, Mr Achebe argues that Mosop has previously been invited to participate and has refused. This is another claim which Mr Mitee does not accept, suggesting that the truth of what is happening on the ground may be being kept from Shell leaders in Europe. But while the gap between the two sides seems irreconcilable, church leaders who have been brokering a peace remain optimistic. Bishop MK Stephen said recently: "As far as I am concerned we have made tremendous progress. The differences are not as great as has been suggested, not as tempestuous as people think. The situation is better under control now. We may be able to see the way forward very shortly." Shell will certainly want firm evidence of responsible practices on the ground to back up its claims to have changed its spots. But this episode demonstrates that corporate responsibility is more difficult than writing a new mission statement, and stakeholder dialogue, which lies at the heart of it, is not a simple matter of calling a meeting and getting everybody to agree.

webTitle: Patients at home in virtual hospital

fields.headline: Patients at home in virtual hospital
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Britain's first virtual hospital, where patients lie in bed at home and the consultant's ward round takes place on computer screens, has been given the go-ahead and may prove to be the prototype for the NHS of the future.
fields.body:
Britain's first virtual hospital, where patients lie in bed at home and the consultant's ward round takes place on computer screens, has been given the go-ahead and may prove to be the prototype for the NHS of the future.

The Treasury has agreed a £10m grant from the capital modernisation fund to the defence evaluation research agency (Dera) which expects to have 250 patients in hospital at home within two years.

Although the military has won the bid, this will not be an army hospital. The fund is intended for the modernisation of public services.

If the virtual hospital is a success, it is expected that health authorities up and down the country will be queuing up to enrol patients.

"It could prove a model for the future for the entire NHS," said Keith Smith of Dera yesterday.

Patients, who could be anywhere in the country, will be provided with equipment to suit their needs, which could include devices to take readings such as blood pressure, pulse, breathing rate and temperature and if they suffer from coronary heart disease, for instance, a cardiac monitor and weighing scales.

All of these would be linked up electronically through the telephone line to computers at a command and control centre, who would relay the information on to whichever specialist, in whichever hospital, was in charge of the patient's treatment.

The patient could be in Truro, but the most appropriate specialist for their needs might be in Edinburgh. Distance would no longer be a problem. If the monitors show up a difficulty, the local community nurse could be alerted to visit and sort it out. Patients would usually be supplied with computer terminals that would permit video links. The consultant's ward round would be replaced by virtual visits, as he or she tunes in to one patient after another throughout the UK.

Dera wants to keep the hospital simple in the early stages, so a limited number of conditions are envisaged, such as coronary heart disease, stroke, cancer treatment, home-based drug therapy and dialysis.

Mental health is also on the list. "Strangely enough, some people are more keen to speak to a specialist through the television interface than face to face," said Mr Smith.

Dera believes the virtual hospital will save the NHS a lot of money, through cutting the costs of hospital beds, saving consultants journeys from one hospital to another and allowing some medical and nursing staff to work from home if they want.

It also envisages that the project will be a money-earner for the UK "through deploying leading edge, shop window technology in the UK", said the bid document.

Dera has so far been talking to doctors in West Surrey, near its Farnborough base, Guy's and St Thomas' hospital in London and the John Radcliffe hospital in Oxford.

Its medical advisers believe that patients will recover much faster if they remain at home instead of spending days on hospital wards with the risk of cross-infections and the demoralisation of strange surroundings. Patients will be keen to take part, said Mr Smith.

"I don't think there is any doubt. Are they happy about spending five days in hospital where they see the consultant for five minutes a day? Of course not. We have had very positive feedback."

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: Whatever Easter resolutions London dealers may have made over the weekend, the determination to show independence of mind does not seem to have been among them. The market fell throughout the morning - because that is what Wall Street did on Monday - and rose in the afternoon because Wall Street did yesterday.
fields.body:
Whatever Easter resolutions London dealers may have made over the weekend, the determination to show independence of mind does not seem to have been among them. The market fell throughout the morning - because that is what Wall Street did on Monday - and rose in the afternoon because Wall Street did yesterday.

In fact with many traders and fund managers choosing to run this week's bank holiday into next week's, it could be that we have yet to see any new firmness of purpose take effect. Depending how history works out, this insouciance will go down either as the moment when the spring 2000 jitters faded or the most appalling example of establishment complacency since New York Fed governor Benjamin Strong's upbeat house party for central bankers in July 1927.

At the close the FTSE 100 was 41.8 points firmer at 6,283.0, below its afternoon peak at 6,313.8 but well above the early morning low of 6,155.7. One isle of British independence was the Techmark 100, which shed 16 points at 3,523.98 in spite of a Nasdaq bounce back.

Emap was a strong feature on the FTSE 100 leaders' board, ahead 75p to £11.93 thanks to the fresh speculation that the media group could soon be a bid target for US net group Yahoo! WPP was also in demand among media blue chips, up 20 at 958 ahead of its first quarter results, ignoring talk of difficulties in its talks to acquire Young & Rubicam of the US.

Centrica was active, adding 10.5p at 226.75p after confirming its plans to move into the telecoms arena.

British Airways gained 5.5p at 305.75p after confirming the appointment of Rod Eddington as its new chief executive from May 1. Elsewhere, BAE Systems took on 15.5p at 382.75p, helped by a reiteration of its "buy" stance from Warburg Dillon Read.

Tesco, up 3p at 215.25p, reflected a repeat by Goldman Sachs of its recommendation.

Oil majors benefited from strong results from US peers including Texaco and Exxon Mobil, with Shell ahead 26.25p at 50.25p.

Financials attracted support, with Abbey National up 42.5p at 780.5p, Lloyds TSB ahead 33.5p at 695p, L&G up 7.25p at 165.75p, and CGU ahead 46p at 930.5p; 3i Group jumped 59p to £11.80 after a press tip.

Many technology issues remained weak in spite of the Nasdaq bounce, with Nycomed Amersham down 29p at 511p, Colt Telecom off 128p at £26.81, ARM Holdings down 20.5p at 627p, and Freeserve off 16p at 379.5p. Dixons, down 19.75p at 253.25p, reflected in part the drop in Freeserve's value.

fields.headline: City's rhyme fits the times
fields.trailText: It has entered into City folklore - and with some justification, it seems. It is also one of the first initiation regimes for fresh-faced City traders, to chant the rhyme: "Sell in May and go away. Buy again on St Leger's day."
fields.body:
It has entered into City folklore - and with some justification, it seems. It is also one of the first initiation regimes for fresh-faced City traders, to chant the rhyme: "Sell in May and go away. Buy again on St Leger's day."

For most, working out when St Leger's day falls is the biggest problem, and for the record, it is a key day in the racing calendar and falls on the first or second Saturday in September.

But the next question is what is the point in learning such a childish mantra in the first place? According to research by Standard Life Investments there is every reason to remember the silly sounding rhyme.

By analysing equity prices over the past 27 years Standard Life concluded that equity markets appear to prefer the winter months.

The research showed that between 1973 and last year, stock prices around the world made their sharpest gains in December, January and April, and fell every month between - and including - May to September.

Just to be sure, the Standard Life fund managers broke down each period between equities markets in the US, Britain and Japan and also found consistency. They also split the 27-year period into three blocks - the 70s, 80s and 90s - and established that consistency remained, albeit with a slight weakening over the time.

Standard Life concludes that the established trend may be weakening because of changes in saving patterns among investors, who now put their money into the market on a monthly basis through savings schemes instead of waiting for year-end tax incentives before blitzing the market.

The research also makes the point that the reason prices rise so much at the start of the year might also be because companies, which sell stock to raise new money, tend to be less active in the early part of the year. This reduces supply when demand is going up, hence the simple demand and supply equation is in force. Standard Life notes that even though the mantra works over time, the market appears to have ignored it this year.

This might because the markets were so strong at the end of last year or, more worryingly, because they are about to to undergo a serious period of weakness.

Unsurprisingly, the fund managers conclude that the application of the mantra to this year's movements suggests the markets are on course for unseasonal summer strength.

fields.headline: Prestbury
fields.trailText: The late Sir James Goldsmith had a stock response to shareholder queries regarding the true value of whichever corporate vehicle he was heading: "Why don't we sell it and find out?" Maverick behaviour in the days when chairmen and directors were corporate bureaucrats, it is less so now.
fields.body:
The late Sir James Goldsmith had a stock response to shareholder queries regarding the true value of whichever corporate vehicle he was heading: "Why don't we sell it and find out?" Maverick behaviour in the days when chairmen and directors were corporate bureaucrats, it is less so now.

Yet yesterday's report and accounts from property group Prestbury - containing a stab at the company's liquidation value - still startles. Chairman Nick Leslau is quite prepared to break up Prestbury should the shares continue to trade at such a steep discount to "true value".

Best-known for Butlers Wharf, the mixed commercial and residential property on the south bank, Prestbury is, according to Mr Leslau and his colleagues, worth just over 64p a share, against last night's level of 57p. That the latter price itself marked a 0.5p drop on the day suggests the strategy of educating investors by being far more transparent than is usual in a property business has failed to strike a chord. But to take this view would be to miss the point.

Since at least the 1950s, the British property sector has been, in terms of reporting and shareholder information, a world leader in hyperbole, flim-flam and outright deceit, with capitalised interest, off-balance sheet borrowing and the best PR money can buy adding up to a smoke and mirrors show.

In sharp contrast, Mr Leslau offers the market not only a break-up value but a "doomsday" rent yield that assumes that all tenants break their leases as early as possible and that Prestbury cannot relet any of the vacant properties. In other words, shareholders are given the chance to imagine another 1990 or 1974 ahead of the fact.

There is method to this apparent madness, of course. Mr Leslau believes the opacity of traditional property reporting has contributed to investor aversion and there seems irritation that dot.com stocks are enjoying the uncritical treatment that property companies assumed was their right. But twice in living memory, the burst property bubble has dragged the economy into recession. If Mr Leslau can help avert a next time, he will be awesome indeed.

webTitle: Drug firms may halt UK research

fields.headline: Drug firms may halt UK research
fields.standfirst: Trade body warns over animal rights attacks repercussions
fields.trailText: Britain's drug companies could be forced to shift their research activities abroad to avoid an outbreak of "terrorist attacks" by animal rights groups, the industry's trade body warned yesterday.
fields.body:
Britain's drug companies could be forced to shift their research activities abroad to avoid an outbreak of "terrorist attacks" by animal rights groups, the industry's trade body warned yesterday.

The Association of the British Pharmaceuticals Industry said violent activism, a flood of cheap imports and the strong pound were all factors leading to "concerns about the UK environment".

Figures from the association yesterday showed that the industry's trade surplus slumped 16% last year - its biggest fall since 1945.

The ABPI's director-general, Trevor Jones, said: "These results confirm the industry's fears that the UK environment for pharmaceuticals is not as encouraging as it has been in the past."

Mr Jones claimed that a spate of high-profile attacks on animal research laboratories had been "compounded" by Labour Party policy prior to last the election, which he said favoured a reduction in the number of experiments on animals in the UK. He said: "It cannot be right for people to have their cars burned in their garages at night because they breed animals for testing.

"The recent rise in biophobia and animal extremism is of great concern."

Bill Fullagar, the association's president, added: "It cannot fail to have an effect on considerations about how and where we do research.

"Unless the climate changes, it will have an effect on where research is done."

The best known target of animal rights groups over the last year has been Huntingdon Life Sciences, which operates Europe's largest animal experimentation laboratory.

Activists have picketed private investors in the business, applying intense pressure on them to sell their shares. In its annual review of the industry, the ABPI said exports of drugs by British companies rose 7% to £6.33bn. However, imports increased at a much quicker rate, rising 24% to £4,27bn.

The organisation called for action to prevent "parallel trading" - whereby medicines produced elsewhere in Europe are shipped in to undercut British prices.

Most drugs produced by British companies are sold at uniform levels under an agreement between the industry and the NHS.

Mr Fullagar said: "Across Europe prices are being determined by governments, not by the industry.

"We would like governments to sit down together and decide what should be done about anomolies in pricing."

The ABPI also raised concerns about the National Institute for Clinical Excellence - the new NHS body which considers the "value for money" - or otherwise - of medical therapies. The association is concerned that Nice is a backdoor method of rationing expensive drugs.

webTitle: Renault gets green light for Korean takeover

fields.headline: Renault gets green light for Korean takeover
fields.standfirst: French group sheds truck subsidiary to focus on global expansion in car market
fields.trailText: Renault yesterday signalled the latest step in the rationalisation of the global automobile industry by selling off its truck subsidiary to Volvo in a $1.59bn (£1bn) deal.
fields.byline: Terry Macalister in London and  Paul Webster  in Paris
fields.body:
Renault yesterday signalled the latest step in the rationalisation of the global automobile industry by selling off its truck subsidiary to Volvo in a $1.59bn (£1bn) deal.

In a separate move, the French carmaker received the go-ahead from creditors of Samsung Motors to move ahead with its $560m takeover of the South Korean vehicle manufacturer.

Volvo will buy Renault's RVI truck division and its US subsidiary Mack Trucks in return for a 15% stake in the Swedish firm, which will make Renault the biggest shareholder in Volvo.

Renault will be given two seats on the board and will increase its holding to 20% by buying Volvo shares on the open market. The French firm must hold for at least three years the stake in the company, which will be number two in the world behind Mercedes Benz, owned by DaimlerChrysler.

Both sides were anxious to present the deal as a merger that would give the combined truck group the power to compete in a world of escalating costs and lower prices. But Renault, under its ambitious chairman, Louis Schweitzer, is seen by industry experts as keen to offload responsibility for trucks so that he can concentrate on global expansion in an even tougher car market.

The acquisition of Samsung through a 70% holding will build on the purchase of Dacia Automobile in Romania and a 36.8% stake in Japanese carmaker Nissan last year.

Renault will be the first foreign car producer to set up in South Korea, a notoriously inaccessible but lucrative market.

Volvo has been seeking a partner since the European Union's competition authorities last month blocked a proposed $6.9bn takeover of Swedish truck rival Scania.

The latest tie-up with Renault must still obtain EU regulatory and Volvo shareholder approval. The French carmaker tried a full merger with Volvo in 1993 but this was halted after a revolt by the Swedish company's shareholders.

Experts predicted there would be no such problem today when shareholders meet, especially when Renault has become a profitable concern after a period of mounting losses. Its 1999 operations showed a 15% rise in profits to €2.2bn (£1.28bn) after a series of cuts.

Mr Schweitzer said the Volvo deal would ensure his company "would get the full benefit of a period of growth". The 45,000 workers in France were assured that there would be no job losses.

Share dealings were suspended while the chairman said the operation would have a positive effect on profits within the first year. "We have a very good case, both on the financial and engineering sides.

"The two companies will remain intact and there will be no change in the conditions of work for the staff, nor will there be any industrial reconstruction," he said.

Volvo chairman Leif Johansson said the deal would help make the group the "most cost-competitive truckmaker there is".

The agreement is seen in France as vindication for the long-term strategy to increase the competitiveness of the Renault brothers factory.

Since 1990, with the staid family image of Renault's cars transformed by Formula One successes, Socialist and Gaullist governments have encouraged a market-led management strategy that was marked by two crucial events in 1992: the Billancourt production line was closed and Mr Schweitzer, a senior civil servant, was transferred from a financial advisory post to run a multinational that now employs more than 140,000 staff worldwide.

Renault will be the first foreign car producer to set up in South Korea, a notoriously inaccessible but lucrative market. Volvo has been seeking a partner since the European Union's competition authorities last month blocked a proposed $6.9bn takeover of Swedish truck rival Scania. The latest tie-up with Renault must still obtain EU regulatory and Volvo shareholder approval. The French carmaker tried a full merger with Volvo in 1993 but this was halted after a revolt by the Swedish company's shareholders. Experts predicted there would be no such problem today when shareholders meet, especially when Renault has become a profitable concern after a period of mounting losses. Its 1999 operations showed a 15% rise in profits to €2.2bn (£1.28bn) after a series of cuts. Mr Schweitzer said the Volvo deal would ensure his company "would get the full benefit of a period of growth". The 45,000 workers in France were assured that there would be no job losses. Share dealings were suspended while the chairman said the operation would have a positive effect on profits within the first year. "We have a very good case, both on the financial and engineering sides. "The two companies will remain intact and there will be no change in the conditions of work for the staff, nor will there be any industrial reconstruction," he said. Volvo chairman Leif Johansson said the deal would help make the group the "most cost-competitive truckmaker there is". The agreement is seen in France as vindication for the long-term strategy to increase the competitiveness of the Renault brothers factory. Since 1990, with the staid family image of Renault's cars transformed by Formula One successes, Socialist and Gaullist governments have encouraged a market-led management strategy that was marked by two crucial events in 1992: the Billancourt production line was closed and Mr Schweitzer, a senior civil servant, was transferred from a financial advisory post to run a multinational that now employs more than 140,000 staff worldwide.

webTitle: OECD delays crackdown on tax havens

fields.headline: OECD delays crackdown on tax havens
fields.trailText: A crackdown on tax havens by rich industrialised countries will be delayed by one year following signs that many jurisdictions are prepared to reform.
fields.body:
A crackdown on tax havens by rich industrialised countries will be delayed by one year following signs that many jurisdictions are prepared to reform.

The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, the Paris-based think tank which represents the worlds richest countries, is pressing ahead with plans to publish a list of jurisdictions which meet the technical criteria of harmful tax practices in June.

However, Frances Horner, head of the organisation's tax competition unit, said yesterday that the list would not form the basis of any sanctions to be applied.

Instead, the OECD would take another year to refine the list, excluding those jurisdictions which have agreed to cooperate with the OECD by opening their books to inspectors seeking to track down tax fraudsters.

Only those jurisdictions remaining would be threatened with so-called "defensive measures", which could include the scrapping of double taxation treaties with tax havens and reduced aid budgets.

Ms Horner conceded that the delay represented a change from previous plans but suggested that this was because the threat of sanctions was persuading many jurisdictions to cooperate with the OECD's efforts to stamp out tax poaching.

"Our goal is to promote change, not to apply sanctions," she said.

The OECD has identified 47 jurisdictions which it suspects of harmful tax practices, including Caribbean states and British territories, such as the Cayman Islands, Jersey and the Bahamas, and has been in negotiations with them for some time but is it also aiming to eradicate bad practice in member states.

Earlier this month, the organisation achieved a breakthrough when Switzerland and Luxembourg both agreed to sign a report committing OECD members to end the use of banking secrecy laws to hide fiscal crime.

The failure of the two countries to cooperate in the past represented a significant moral flaw in the OECD's argument with offshore centres, which had accused it of hypocrisy.

Now, offshore centres will find it harder to resist mounting pressure from the OECD for them to agree to more information sharing between national tax authorities, although it is acknowledged that certain hard cases are likely to refuse to cooperate, believing that it will erode their competitive advantage over industrialised countries.

webTitle: Prescott to back Gore on warming

fields.headline: Prescott to back Gore on warming
fields.standfirst: The weather: special report
fields.trailText: John Prescott is travelling to Washington to back Al Gore's stance on global warming and warn leading Republican senators that they pose a threat to an international agreement.
fields.body:
John Prescott is travelling to Washington to back Al Gore's stance on global warming and warn leading Republican senators that they pose a threat to an international agreement.

The deputy prime minister has forged a close relationship with Mr Gore, US vice-president and Democratic candidate for president, especially since the two spoke at the landmark UN climate change conference in Kyoto in 1997.

Mr Gore has been calling on the Senate, which has a Republican majority, to ratify the Kyoto agreement, but George W Bush, the Republican candidate, is opposed to ratification.

The Kyoto protocol called for a reduction in worldwide greenhouse gas emissions by a combined 5.2% by 2012. The US, by far the world's biggest polluter, would be required to cut its emissions by 7% below its 1990 levels.

Mr Prescott will meet Mr Gore tomorrow, as well as Republicans on Capitol Hill, such as Senator Joe Hagel, who is leading the drive to block ratification of the protocol.

Agreement on implementation, and enforcement, is still needed at a conference in the Hague in November, immediately after the US elections.

Mr Prescott is worried that the American opposition means that the hugely complex international negotiations are close to collapse. A meeting of environment ministers from the G8 industrialised countries broke up this month without agreement on a proposal to implement the protocol no later than 2002.

Many Americans claim that developing countries such as India and China are demanding a free ride by refusing to be bound to emission targets in this decade. Oil, motor and business interests have been lobbying against the agreement, or proposing loopholes.

Mr Prescott told the Guardian: "There has been a radical change in the US. Twelve months ago the car and energy industries were all against. They now recognise that there is a great potential for them, both through developing new technologies and improvement in their corporate image."

The leading anti-protocol lobbying organisation, the global climate coalition, has suffered a haemorrhage of support from leading companies such as Texaco, Ford and BP Amoco. The coalition has spread some of the most lurid projections of the cost to the US "four-wheel car" economy of meeting its Kyoto commitments.

Mr Prescott admitted that the problem was that "so many countries have got vetoes and could prevent agreement in the Hague. We have got to find consensus and work through the difficulties."

He would be "spending a lot of time between now and November trying to get the agreement again between the EU and others in the rich umbrella group: the US, Japanese, Canadians and Australians".

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Exchange deal shifts gear
fields.body:
Exchange deal shifts gear

Talks about a merger between the London and Frankfurt stock exchanges moved up a gear yesterday when the heads of the two institutions met in the German capital. With time running out before the German deadline of May 4 to agree to a deal, the exchanges are now expected to announce the terms of their tie-up as early as tomorrow. Progress has been made on the definition of the tie-up, which might also involve the US Nasdaq, to make it appear less like a takeover by Deutsche Börse of the London stock exchange. However, Gavin Casey, the chief executive of the London stock exchange, is said to be unlikely to retain that role in a merged exchange. That job is expected to go Werner Seifert, the German chief executive, with new London chairman Don Cruickshank retaining that role.

Prudential buys California bank

Britain's largest life assurance and pensions group, Prudential, which owns US life assurer Jackson National Life, said it would buy the small Californian bank Highland Bancorp for $120m (£76m) in cash.

Prudential said that Jackson National's banking unit, Jackson Federal Bank, would offer $25.45 per share for Highland Federal's shares in an agreed deal.

Highland Bancorp's Highland Federal Bank, which has seven retail branches in Southern California and assets of $667m, would be folded into Jackson Federal Bank, which would then have 14 branches in Southern California and assets of $1.1bn. Prudential said it is expected that the transaction would be completed this year.

Bupa woos hospital group

Bupa, the private healthcare provider, yesterday said it was "actively contemplating" a £220m cash offer for Community Hospitals, which operates 21 hospitals in Britain.

The move would be part of Bupa's strategy of becoming a one-stop "personal health service" rather than an insurer.

Community Hospitals said it was in talks with other potential bidders and advised shareholders to take no action. Its shares rose 244p to 552.5p.

Interbrew ready to float

Belgian beer group Interbrew, owner of Stella Artois, is to float as a public company by the end of the year in order to raise cash for acquisitions.The company said it might use the money for UK expansion.

Interbrew and Heineken have been tipped to pounce on Whitbread, which has said it wants to withdraw from brewing.

Interbrew announced that in the past year profits after tax increased 21% to £144m on increased net turnover of just over £2bn.

Centrica picks phone allies

Centrica, the parent company of British Gas, yesterday named Vodafone-AirTouch, Cable & Wireless Communications and Torch as partners in its planned assault on the telecoms market.

The company hopes to attract 1m customers to its fixed and mobile service by the end of next year.

Centrica intends to invest £150m in its telecoms business over the next three years, with the launch planned for September.

fields.headline: Asylum decisions at record rate
fields.standfirst: The issue explained: How to claim asylum
fields.trailText: A record 11,340 asylum claims were processed last month after hundreds of extra caseworkers were taken on to clear the huge backlog of cases, according to Home Office figures released yesterday.
fields.body:
A record 11,340 asylum claims were processed last month after hundreds of extra caseworkers were taken on to clear the huge backlog of cases, according to Home Office figures released yesterday.

The queue of asylum seekers waiting for a decision has fallen below 100,000 for the first time in four months and stands at 98,365 cases.

The official "recognition rate" of 19% of cases in March given full refugee status or exceptional leave to remain understates the real level of "genuine" asylum seekers, as it excludes the 1,955 given permission to stay last month in the special backlog clearance exercise. If they are included, the "recognition rate" shoots up to 36% of the cases on which a decision was made last month.

The 11,340 cases decided in March compares with 4,040 decisions in January and 7,865 in February. It was the highest monthly total ever recorded, said a Home Office spokesman.

The number of people seeking asylum in March was 6,680, up from 6,110 in February, suggesting that publicity about implementation on April 3 of the system of vouchers and dispersal did not have a deterrent effect.

Once again Yugoslavia - including Kosovo, Montenegro and Serbia - produced the most applicants, followed by Sri Lanka, China, Afghanistan and Somalia.

Ann Widdecombe, shadow home secretary, said she did not see the situation as improving. "It is still going to take years to clear the backlog of asylum applications, and in the meantime more and more applications come in."

Jack Straw, the home secretary, is expected today to highlight the effectiveness of his new £2,000 fines on lorry drivers who bring clandestine entrants into Britain.

fields.headline: Mack Robinson
fields.standfirst: Sprinting star overshadowed by his brother
fields.trailText: Mack Robinson, who has died aged 84, won the silver medal in the 200 metres at the 1936 Olympic Games in Berlin behind the legendary Jesse Owens, only to see his career ultimately overshadowed by his younger brother, Jackie Robinson, the first black American to play United States major league baseball.
fields.body:
Mack Robinson, who has died aged 84, won the silver medal in the 200 metres at the 1936 Olympic Games in Berlin behind the legendary Jesse Owens, only to see his career ultimately overshadowed by his younger brother, Jackie Robinson, the first black American to play United States major league baseball.

Mack Robinson was one of America's best sprinters of the 1930s, but originally he hardly seemed destined for great athletic feats. When he was in high school in Pasadena, wrote Olympic historian David Wallechinsky, "coaches did not consider him athletic material and made his mother sign a statement absolving them of blame if his heart was damaged".

Even when he showed formidable talents in junior college, it seemed that Robinson would not make it to the trials for the 1936 US Olympic team, and only made the trip to New York after a Pasadena businessman raised $150 to send him.

Robinson qualified for the Olympic team and, in Berlin, in the 200m where Owens broke the Olympic record, he came second in 21.1sec. Yet when he returned to Pasadena after the Olympics, he felt unappreciated. "If anybody in Pasadena was proud for me, other than my family and close friends," he said, "they never showed it. The only time I was noticed was when somebody asked me during an assembly at school if I'd race against a horse."

After the Olympics, Robinson starred on the University of Oregon track team, winning the National Collegiate Athletic Association 220-yard title and the American 200m championship in 1938. In that year, he was considered the best sprinter in the world. However, he was forced to quit both his studies and his athletics career to return home and support his family, including Jackie.

Back in Pasadena, wearing his Olympic sweatshirt with a big "USA" on the front, he pushed a broom sweeping downtown streets. But when a judge ordered public swimming pools in Pasadena to be opened to blacks, the city retaliated by firing all black workers, including Robinson.

He was not forgotten, however. In the opening ceremony of the 1984 Olympics, the giant Olympic flag was carried into the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum by six gold medal winners and three others - including Robinson.

Robinson's accomplishments came long before his brother Jackie broke baseball's colour code in 1947 when he turned out for the Brooklyn Dodgers. His affection for Jackie, his younger brother by four years, was strong and he took pride in his accomplishments.

"He always liked to say they had something in common: fighting the prejudice in the late 1930s and early 1940s," said George Beres, a friend who was Oregon sports information director from 1976-82. "They had more than just bloodlines and last name in common."

Yet Robinson also felt that his identity had been lost because of Jackie's achievements. "I am getting awfully tired of being referred to just as Jackie Robinson's brother," he once said. The brothers, natives of Cairo, Georgia, were honoured together by their adopted hometown in 1997 when the Pasadena Robinson Memorial was dedicated to them.

Mack Robinson is survived by his wife of 45 years, Delano, and their three sons and three daughters; and a son and a daughter from previous marriages.

fields.headline: The making of a mayor
fields.standfirst: The mayoral race has made local government sexy, and taught those involved a thing or two in the processThe London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: They think it's all over. The turf accountants have closed the book on Ken Livingstone; they will take no more odds on the 1-10 favourite - not, say William Hill, when a month has gone by since a punter put decent money on any of Ken's rivals. The game is up. Livingstone is so far out in front that, at the last count, his lead stood at a fat 33 points. The candidates of what we still, rather quaintly, call the "three main parties" are slugging it out for second place. The Green has already conceded defeat.
fields.body:
They think it's all over. The turf accountants have closed the book on Ken Livingstone; they will take no more odds on the 1-10 favourite - not, say William Hill, when a month has gone by since a punter put decent money on any of Ken's rivals. The game is up. Livingstone is so far out in front that, at the last count, his lead stood at a fat 33 points. The candidates of what we still, rather quaintly, call the "three main parties" are slugging it out for second place. The Green has already conceded defeat.

Ken's lead is so great, his stroll toward the London mayoralty such a cakewalk, that he has barely broken a sweat. His campaign has been meagre, saying little, doing little. Such is the prerogative of a candidate with a massive lead - his prime objective is to sit on it. When he has made news, it's usually been with an ill-chosen remark: he appeared to play down Hitler's crimes when he wanted to play up the cruelty of world debt. But these have been mere blips.

Instead, the campaign has become a victory march. The real battle, we now realise, was the internal contest for the Labour nomination: the action has dried up since then. In its place has come Red Ken's morphing from a politician into something larger. Behold, Ken Livingstone - cultural icon.

His face is deemed fashionable enough to wear: either as a Che Guevara-style portrait on a limited-edition T-shirt or multiply reproduced over a suit, as worn by Harry Enfield at the premiere last week of his new film. Like Gary Lineker before him, Livingstone even has his very own London play: Snogging Ken, complete with Warhol-style headshot on the programme cover. The play, a skit really, by Tariq Ali, Howard Brenton and Andy de la Tour, takes as its premise the sheer inevitability of the independent candidate. "What do the focus groups say?" asks Lola, an ultra-Blairite MP. "We dissolved them," replies the evil Pandora of Millbank. "They all wanted to vote for Ken."

The man is fast becoming a phenomenon. Very few politicians break out of politics and penetrate popular culture: Margaret Thatcher managed it (inspiring the now-forgotten song Stand Down, Margaret) so, for different reasons, did Richard Nixon (played by Antony Hopkins in the movie). But it's been a long time since a figure from British local government won a similar accolade.

Still, besides elevating Ken into the stratosphere of national celebrity, what has this mayor's race - now all but over - achieved? After consuming so much of the public oxygen for six months, has any good come of it?

The answer is an enthusiastic yes. The conventional wisdom may rule that the London contest has been a farce, a pantomime starring Ken, Frank (and earlier Jeffrey) which has given politics a bad name. But that's too po-faced, too bloodless a view of how democracy works. For the London circus has pulled off the previously unimaginable. It has taken the two most boring words in the English language - local government - and made them interesting. The dynamic of soap opera has hooked people who would otherwise have switched off. Indeed, it is the current lack of human drama that has made this final stretch of the campaign such a snoozathon.

The scolds say such emphasis on personalities is bad for politics: it freezes out discussion of policy. In fact, the reverse is true. The moment of hottest debate on the topic of greatest concern to Londoners - transport - came when the clash of personalities was at its most intense. Last November, when Labour demanded Livingstone recant his opposition to privatisation of the Underground, the issue was gnawed at in forensic detail. The fact that the conflict was personified simply meant more people paid attention. If the current battle of personalities was closer, the debate over policy would get hotter, too.

More specifically, this campaign has seen London reach an all but settled will on Tube privatisation: none of the main candidates now backs the government's proposed public-private partnership. Even Frank Dobson has said he will review it. Whatever the outcome next week, Labour cannot go ahead with its plans unchanged. This campaign has seen to that.

Labour has learned some other useful lessons, too. London has taught Tony Blair that devolution means letting go. When he apologised 10 days ago for getting it wrong in Wales, forcing Alun Michael on a reluctant nation, he knew that his remarks would resonate beyond Cardiff. For what put the PM on the road to enlightenment was the prospect of certain defeat in the capital. An episode future historians may call the London Revolt forced Mr Blair to learn the limits of his control.

The list of achievements attributable to the mayor's race does not end with Labour. The contest has also revealed a new kind of Toryism. Steve Norris, faced with the market forces of democracy, has had to tailor the Conservative product to appeal to the consumer. In London that has meant heading left on race and on sexuality, maintaining the Thatcherite emphasis on free markets, but ditching the Tebbitite harshness on social mores. Call it Nozzerism. It may not be enough to win, but it might just beat the Labour candidate in a Labour town - and show the Tories a way back.

The parties have changed and so has the party system. By asking people to vote for individuals, the London contest has broken the choke-hold of the party on British politics. An independent is set to win over the biggest direct electorate in the country. Because voters are allowed two preferences, millions of Londoners will break the tribal habit for the first time, and vote for another party - or for none. They each have a further two votes for the London assembly and here, too, the temptation will be to mix things up. The smart money says there will be a Green or two in the new body, perhaps even a Trotskyite such as Paul Foot or the perennial gadfly of gay rights, Peter Tatchell. The monotony of Westminster may give way to a noisier, more pluralistic politics. For as Scotland and especially Wales have shown, voters have not used devolution simply to repeat the votes they cast at the general election. Instead Britons are learning that they can vote in different ways for different jobs. London will prove it, by voting for Ken next week - and Labour next year.

It's not all good news. Last week's Guardian/ICM poll found that only 22% of Britons want to have a directly-elected mayor - down from 59% in February: London's antics seem to have put people off. But once the likes of Birmingham and Liverpool have their own candidates weighing in, it's a good bet that voters there will soon lose their reservations - and get caught up in the drama, just like Londoners before them.

No, the contest has been a worthy addition to our national, public life. Now, comes a tougher question: will the mayoralty deliver? Will it provide the improved governance London needs? Will the destination prove as valuable as the long march to get there?

fields.bodyText: They think it's all over. The turf accountants have closed the book on Ken Livingstone; they will take no more odds on the 1-10 favourite - not, say William Hill, when a month has gone by since a punter put decent money on any of Ken's rivals. The game is up. Livingstone is so far out in front that, at the last count, his lead stood at a fat 33 points. The candidates of what we still, rather quaintly, call the "three main parties" are slugging it out for second place. The Green has already conceded defeat. Such is the prerogative of a candidate with a massive lead - his prime objective is to sit on it. When he has made news, it's usually been with an ill-chosen remark: he appeared to play down Hitler's crimes when he wanted to play up the cruelty of world debt. But these have been mere blips. Instead, the campaign has become a victory march. The real battle, we now realise, was the internal contest for the Labour nomination: the action has dried up since then. In its place has come Red Ken's morphing from a politician into something larger. Behold, Ken Livingstone - cultural icon. His face is deemed fashionable enough to wear: either as a Che Guevara-style portrait on a limited-edition T-shirt or multiply reproduced over a suit, as worn by Harry Enfield at the premiere last week of his new film. Like Gary Lineker before him, Livingstone even has his very own London play: Snogging Ken, complete with Warhol-style headshot on the programme cover. The play, a skit really, by Tariq Ali, Howard Brenton and Andy de la Tour, takes as its premise the sheer inevitability of the independent candidate. After consuming so much of the public oxygen for six months, has any good come of it? The answer is an enthusiastic yes. It has taken the two most boring words in the English language - local government - and made them interesting. The dynamic of soap opera has hooked people who would otherwise have switched off. Indeed, it is the current lack of human drama that has made this final stretch of the campaign such a snoozathon. The scolds say such emphasis on personalities is bad for politics: it freezes out discussion of policy. In fact, the reverse is true.
