fields.headline: Trials of an unlikely eco-warrior
fields.standfirst:
Lord Melchett is no stranger to confrontation. But, in his first interview since being acquitted of theft, the head of Greenpeace says even Eton couldn't prepare him for his time in prison. By Emma Brockes
GM food: special report
fields.trailText: Lord Melchett is no stranger to confrontation. But, in his first interview since being acquitted of theft, the head of Greenpeace says even Eton couldn't prepare him for his time in prison.
fields.body:
Lord Melchett, executive director of Greenpeace, alumnus of Eton, Cambridge and the Callaghan government, was due to fly to Tanzania for a scuba diving holiday last July. The cases were packed and his family was waiting, but Melchett didn't show: he was banged up in a cell in Norwich Prison, hoping for clemency from the duty magistrate. Frazer Morrison, however, did not consider the peer's wish to see the marine life of the Indian Ocean sufficient cause for granting bail and kept Lord Melchett in for two nights and three days, an experience, he says, that not even public school had prepared him for.

Nine months later, Lord Peter Melchett is in his house in Kentish Town, freshly acquitted of theft and awaiting the verdict on whether he and 27 other Greenpeace activists will be retried for criminal damage. It was on a Monday morning last July that they wheeled a big mower into a field of GM maize near Norwich and tried to cut it down before it could pollinate neighbouring crops. It wasn't an act of vandalism, he says, but a genuine attempt to clear the field of pollution that would have worked, godammit, if they'd had an undisturbed hour and a half with the mower. "Greenpeace doesn't have a moral objection to GM foods. We don't believe it is something that religion wouldn't countenance, or that it's an interference with nature to which people would have ethical objection. We just think there is a danger in introducing something into the environment that you can't recall."

If Melchett is an unlikely eco-warrior, it is not for his poshness, but for his ambiguous relationship with the establishment. He looks like a hush puppy, with squashed features, luxurious hair and a way of bobbing up and down under the force of his own jollity. He is the fourth baron of a title created in 1928 by his great grandfather. "On paper, I suppose I look like a very establishment figure. But it wasn't quite like that. My family were German Jewish immigrants who possibly wouldn't have got into the country today. My great grandfather started ICI and was a Liberal politician. They were nouveau riche, I suppose. My mother never voted conservative. My father ran the steel industry under Harold Wilson and was seen as a traitor to conservative values. They weren't seen by the upper class to be particularly conventional."

Melchett was none the less sent to Eton, where he interpreted his masters' advice to engage in the national debate by going to hear Barbara Castle address a meeting in Slough. "It wasn't quite what they had in mind. But I thought she was brilliant." There followed a conventional path through Cambridge and the Lords, with occasional flashes of rebellion that would culminate in him leaving politics to take up the job at Greenpeace in 1979. Melchett chose to do an MA in criminology at Keele University, a discipline that the Cambridge law faculty thought of as intellectual heresy and could scarcely bare to speak of. (Melchett was given such unconventional assignments as being sent on the beat with Stoke-on-Trent police and, more usefully for his future career, observing prisoners at Grendon Underwood.)

There was a seminal moment with some dead partridges on the family farm in Norfolk. It has become more seminal in the retelling, says Melchett, but it was a profound boyhood experience: stumbling across two dead chicks that had been starved by the effects of pesticides. Having been brought up to applaud science, Melchett began for the first time to question it. "My father ran a big farming company in Norfolk, and cared a lot about the countryside. It never occurred to him that these modern, scientific sprays that he was using might be killing things he cared about. The idea that science proceeds in this rational, orderly way is bullshit. People have political and personal and financial agendas that they pursue with a level of viciousness."

Melchett worked in the environment ministry, the department of industry and was a minister of state in the Northern Ireland Office. In 1975 he acted on a working party on pop festivals. Then, when the Labour government lost to the Conservatives in 1979, he left. "It didn't appeal to me as a long-term career. The House of Lords is an appalling institution; it's really not something to base your life on. I find it embarrassing explaining to people from other countries how the House of Lords works."

His dislike of the Lords is such that Melchett has purposefully not married his partner and the mother of his son, to stop his title being passed down to the next generation. Disapproving of the hereditary peerage and taking to an airforce base perimeter fence with a pair of bolt cutters is quite a leap, but Melchett is laconic about his defection from lawmaker to lawbreaker, wrapping it up in terms of personal necessity. When he got involved in the anti-nuclear debate, the Chernobyl disaster had just happened and Melchett envis aged the 200-year-old beech trees of his native Norfolk as cinders on a charred landscape. He thought he'd be of more use to the environment outside of the political establishment, while using his experience within it. "There's an element of knowing how the other side behaves. It's like that dialogue in Yes Minister: 'Well, Sir Humphry, what happens if we get an independent scientific advisor and he says the wrong thing?' And Sir Humphry says, 'Don't worry minister, he's one of us.' And that's how it works."

Melchett doesn't shy away from confrontation, but he does prefer the behind-the-scenes wranglings that don't come with the threat of a prison sentence. One gets the feeling he enjoys revisiting his ministerial days by mixing and debating with politicians. One of his greatest triumphs, he says, was persuading Tim Yeo, then a junior minister at the department of environment, to install ozone-friendly fridges in his department's kitchens. "There was outrage in the refrigeration business because the government couldn't buy them in Britain and had to turn to Germany. It was a great moment."

Great moments, for Melchett, are not the demos and theatrical sit-ins, but those in which he successfully negotiates with a government to change its environment policy. "I don't think groups like Greenpeace should have the power to make decisions; of course we shouldn't, we shouldn't have the power to decide if GM crops are on the market. Ultimately, a democratically elected government must decide that, but they need the pressure."

Pressure is most effective when it comes from a variety of sources and it is variety that Melchett loves: the 27 activists in court with him included a Baptist minister, a beautician from Yorkshire, a biochemist from Cardiff University, a BBC researcher, a forester and a social worker. Even when he went to prison, an experience he found awful, he received a lot of support from fellow inmates. "When I went to get my food the first time, the prisoner dishing it out said, you can't eat this, it's not guaranteed GM free. I had a lot of encouragement to go on hunger strike." To Melchett, there could have been no higher compliment.

webTitle: English tunnels criticised for safety shortfalls

fields.headline: English tunnels criticised for safety shortfalls
fields.trailText: The mile-long tunnel which carries 32,000 vehicles a day under the river Tyne has been rated poor in a survey of safety standards of 25 tunnels in Europe published today. It was given a mark of 64%, with only three other tunnels achieving a lower score.
fields.body:
The mile-long tunnel which carries 32,000 vehicles a day under the river Tyne has been rated poor in a survey of safety standards of 25 tunnels in Europe published today. It was given a mark of 64%, with only three other tunnels achieving a lower score.

The survey was commissioned by European motoring organisations, including the AA, following the fire in the Mont Blanc tunnel which killed 33 people in March 1999. But investigators from a German firm of consultants were refused access to four Italian tunnels and to the Dartford tunnel, the busiest in Europe, which carries 150,000 vehicles under the Thames.

The Queensway tunnel between Liverpool and the Wirral was rated acceptable and the adjacent, newer Kingsway tunnel described as good.

But the consultants criticised all three British tunnels for failing to have automatic fire detectors, raised walkways accessible to all and emergency, sound-proofed phones. Potential problems with the smoke extraction systems in the Tyne and Queensway tunnels were also criticised. However, they praised the three British operators for having procedures to deal with emergencies and hazardous loads. They also praised fire services and systems for dealing with broken down vehicles.

No tunnel in Europe scored 90% or more, which would have earned a "very good" rating. Eight were rated as good, nine as acceptable and six as poor. The Alfonso XIII tunnel in Spain (at 39%) and the Fornaci tunnel in Italy (58%) were rated "very poor".

"What is clear from the survey is that the UK tunnels inspected are well-managed, but they haven't had the investment to keep them as safe as they could be," said the AA's policy director, John Dawson.

Brian Middleton, general manager of the Tyne tunnel, commented last night: "We acknowledge there are faults. It was designed 40 years ago when the traffic density was not so great and when these elements for which we are criticised were not catered for."

The Tyne tunnel, he said, relied on a closed circuit TV system for fire safety. "We have rapid response vehicles on continuous standby and they can be in the tunnel long before the emergency services arrive."

2 Italy: Fornaci tunnel, Savona, 58, very poor

fields.headline: When cheaper is worse
fields.standfirst:
Those who breastfeed are disadvantaged

More about welfare reform
fields.trailText: Is it believable, 50 years after the founding of the welfare state, that poor women who use milk powder to feed their babies get more valuable vouchers than those who breastfeed? It certainly sounds unbelievable - but for health campaigners familiar with the complexity of maternity benefits and the welfare food scheme, there is little that surprises any more.
fields.body:
Is it believable, 50 years after the founding of the welfare state, that poor women who use milk powder to feed their babies get more valuable vouchers than those who breastfeed? It certainly sounds unbelievable - but for health campaigners familiar with the complexity of maternity benefits and the welfare food scheme, there is little that surprises any more. Even a judge, in one recent case, wondered why this welfare world had become so complicated that to understand it required "a wet towel round the head". One reason for the complexity is the way that two separate systems - benefits and food - interlink. Another is the way in which amendments have been added to amendments to ensure the system complies with UK and European law.

The latest revelation has prompted reformers to insist that women who breastfeed should be entitled to the same vouchers as women who bottle-feed their babies. (Bottle-feeders get the equivalent of £7 a week in milk formula vouchers; breastfeeders get milk tokens worth only £2.10.) Their logic is impeccable. The benefits which babies gain from being breast fed have been set out in detail by medical researchers over the decades - better nutrition, an improved immune system, more protection against gastro-enteritis, ear and chest infections, eczema and childhood diabetes. Add to that the benefits which mothers obtain from breastfeeding: a lower risk of pre-menopausal breast cancer, ovarian cancer and hip fractures, plus a chance to get their figures back more quickly because the womb will contract faster. More important still are the social reasons for such a scheme: the much lower proportion of low income women who breastfeed. Only 50% of poor mothers begin breastfeeding, against almost 90% of high income women. Vouchers for breastfeeding should provide an incentive to raise that proportion.

But there needs to be one word of caution: remember the problem of tacking on minor changes instead of pursuing comprehensive change. There are two separate inquiries under way: one into the welfare food scheme, now 50 years old, and the other into maternity benefits introduced in 1975. There could be better ways than a mere voucher. British maternity benefits, for example, are among the lowest in Europe. No new voucher should be introduced before both inquiries have reported and a coherent plan has been drawn up.

webTitle: Why security is not always a safe option

fields.headline: Why security is not always a safe option
fields.standfirst: Regulation The £3bn-a-year private security industry has outgrown the police, but some firms employ criminals and use dubious methods
fields.trailText: For the police and the industry, the unacceptable face of the 1990s boom in private security arrived on the day posters appeared on walls in Bristol naming alleged "criminals", displaying their photographs and accusing them of everything from murder to drug dealing.
fields.body:
For the police and the industry, the unacceptable face of the 1990s boom in private security arrived on the day posters appeared on walls in Bristol naming alleged "criminals", displaying their photographs and accusing them of everything from murder to drug dealing.

They had been put up by a private security company, the SAS Patrol Group, in an exclusive residential area in west Bristol. Under the headline "Warning" they listed the names and addresses of 13 men, with details of their alleged crimes and hours of operation.

The Avon and Somerset police believed it could encourage vigilante action. "We have found in the past that this sort of information is based on supposition and rumour.

"Intelligence, and in particular details of previous convictions held by police, can only be released to certain outside agencies, which is controlled by legislation. This does not include people who are hired by a group of residents to patrol their streets."

The police are convinced many private security firms are owned and run by people with serious criminal records, and that in some parts of the country "bouncers" or "door supervisors" are a major source of drug dealing in clubs.

Although the private security industry has contracted slightly in the past few years, it is still worth about £3bn a year, and with 240,000 personnel has already outgrown the police service.

More than 8,000 companies are involved. Most of the industry is reputable but some are little more than "near protection rackets" operated by unregulated private companies who prey on the fears of vulnerable residents by offering local patrolling services at £1 a week per household.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, has acknowledged that once the private security industry has been cleaned up it may be used officially to supplement the activities of the police and meet the public's desire to see more uniformed patrol officers on the streets.

He has said: "It has been suggested recently that the private security industry might be able to assist the police by performing a form of complementary patrol service. The government is considering the issue and welcomes the constructive debate in this area."

An inquiry by a Commons home affairs select committee concluded that increasing public concern about standards in the industry had followed its rapid growth in the 1990s and the expansion of its role in areas previously the domain of the police. Attempts at voluntary regulation had failed because too many companies with low standards had not joined the system.

But the main impetus for regulation has come from the Association of Chief Police Officers and from the industry itself, including strong backing from companies such as Group 4 and Securicor.

Evidence given to MPs by chief constables highlighted the situation in Lancashire, where there are 3,200 police officers and 4,500 people employed in the private security industry. In a single year six police officers were found to have committed 10 crimes, while the private security firms accounted for 130 offenders and 249 separate crimes. A survey of the 476 known "door supervisors" in Lancashire found that 279 had previous criminal convictions, including 101 for assault, 18 for drug dealing and 25 for weapons offences. Three had been found guilty of murder or manslaughter.

The scale of the criminality stretches across the industry. In one case cited by the police the managing director of a company recommended an employee for a shotgun licence even though he had 15 previous convictions, including killing his wife. He also had a conviction for a burglary in which he used explosives.

The chief constables' casebook includes examples of night security guards who stole the stock, a security guard who stole a judge's handbag from her chambers, and a company of 26 staff, of whom 11 had previous convictions for more than 70 crimes, ranging from rape and threats to kill to assault and stealing cars.

In one case a private security company employed as a guard a man who was a convicted murderer and was on the run from prison.

fields.headline: Going home time
fields.standfirst:
The refugee issue is at the centre of the revolt against the Middle East peace process, and it is not just a case of return but of compensation

Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Peace talks between Israel and Palestinian leaders resume this week, under the aegis of the US, with a formal commitment by all to come to a "final agreement" before the autumn and the end of Bill Clinton's mandate as president. Negotiations focus on air and sea ports, safe passage routes between Gaza and the West Bank - and the existence of a Palestinian state as a kind of Bantustan.
fields.body:
Peace talks between Israel and Palestinian leaders resume this week, under the aegis of the US, with a formal commitment by all to come to a "final agreement" before the autumn and the end of Bill Clinton's mandate as president. Negotiations focus on air and sea ports, safe passage routes between Gaza and the West Bank - and the existence of a Palestinian state as a kind of Bantustan.

But the issue that was at the core of the "peace process" begun in Oslo will again be avoided. It is the 5m refugees whose right to return to their homes in Palestine and to be compensated for loss and property damage was recognised by UN resolution 194 of December 1948. This resolution has been reaffirmed more than 100 times but never implemented. In 1994, for the first time, the US voted against it in the general assembly - a warning that the UN is no longer a reference point for Washington.

Even third and fourth generation Palestinians maintain a strong identification with their original homes. They keep the keys to their houses and small children can describe in detail the family villages they and even their parents have never seen. The conditions in which most of them live should be an international scandal, but it suits the parties to the peace process to forget.

Lebanon has the worst record. The massacres by the Israelis and their Lebanese allies at the Sabra and Chatilla camps in 1982 are a wound that has never healed. The Lebanese political environment is hostile. All Beirut governments since 1948 have refused to grant Palestinians citizenship or integrate them into the local economy. State policy restricts Palestinians' housing, jobs and travel - aiming to encourage the emigration of these mainly Sunni Muslims who could upset Lebanon's tenuous sectarian balance. Some 75,000 Palestinians have in fact left in the last 10 years. In the camps 60% live below the poverty line, and there is 40% unemployment. Funding for the refugees has dwindled in recent years, leaving a gap UN officials call a "collective disaster".

Uniquely, Palestinian refugees do not come under the protection of the UN High Commissioner for Refugees, but have their own organisation, the UN Relief and Works Agency, in recognition of the fact that their problem was created by the UN itself with the attempted division of Palestine. In 1947 the UN proposed giving 56% of the territory of Palestine to a Jewish state and went ahead with the plan despite its rejection by the Palestinian leadership and some Zionist parties.

In 1948, 1967 and 1982 waves of ethnic cleansing virtually destroyed Palestinian society. Palestinians' profound sense of dispossession, and the discrimination against them where they now live, has made them a serious destabilising factor in the Middle East. With 70% of Palestinians being refugees, the issue cannot be kept off the agenda if the peace process, which began with the Madrid conference of 1991, is to have any chance of succeeding.

The refugee issue was obfuscated by Oslo. Those pushed out in 1948 when the state of Israel was created are excluded; only refugees from the 1967 war are to be considered. After Oslo the Palestine Liberation Organisation (PLO) leadership began cautiously to say the unthinkable, suggesting that the right of return was no longer practical, although the PLO's public position continued to ask for the right to return under resolution 194. In the refugee camps and among diaspora intellectuals, such as Edward Said, the shift was seen as a betrayal by PLO leaders. This has brought refugees to the centre of the growing revolt against the peace process. The Israelis say international aid should be used to settle the refugees in their host communities or elsewhere in the Arab world.

When Israel was established in 1948 Jews controlled 7-8% of the land and the British an additional 6-7%. Today the situation is reversed with 93% of the land held by Israeli Jews. The land was seized from Palestinian refugees now living outside Israel and from the 230,000 Palestinian Israeli citizens still inside.

Is it unrealistic, as the Israelis say, to imagine the refugees returning? Meticulous records of much of the 1948 land ownership were made by British land expert Frank Jarvis for the UN Palestine Conciliation Commission using data from the mandate records. Research done since by Dr Salman Abu Sitta shows the concentration of Jews today is largely in and around pre-1948 Jewish land and that Palestinian land is mainly empty. Dr Abu Sitta's proposes the return of refugees in the worst circumstances, from Lebanon and Gaza. Lebanon refugees could mostly return to their homes in Galilee, making little impact on the Jewish community. Gaza refugees could return to almost empty land in the southern part of Israel.

The US supports the return of stolen property to its rightful owners by backing the efforts of the Jewish restitution organisation. In Germany the first agreement between the government and Jewish organisations was in 1952 and $60bn was paid in compensation. German industry last year came under pressure from President Clinton and paid between $1bn and $2bn recompense for the suffering of Jewish slave workers under the Nazis. Hungary, Estonia, the Czech Republic, Poland and France have all passed or drafted laws for the restitution of Jewish property. Swiss banks, under pressure from the US, have paid back enormous sums to Jewish Holocaust survivors and their families.

No comparable pressure group exists to press for Palestinians, although there are stirrings among the diaspora and estimates of Palestinians' losses and compensation due have been made. Academics calculate material losses as between $147bn and $253bn. Another estimate includes non- material losses and amounts to $114,000 for each of 5m refugees.

Victoria Brittain is the Guardian's deputy foreign editor.

webTitle: Police team returns to Dando road

fields.headline: Police team returns to Dando road
fields.standfirst: More on the Jill Dando case
fields.trailText: Detectives looking for Jill Dando's killer set up a mobile police station near her home yesterday to try to jog still more memories.
fields.body:
Detectives looking for Jill Dando's killer set up a mobile police station near her home yesterday to try to jog still more memories.

Officers will spend three days in Gowan Avenue, Fulham, west London, talking to people who live or work in the area or even visit it. It was a year ago today at around 11.30am that the TV presenter was shot on her doorstep.

Scotland Yard said detectives were still trawling through information from a second Crimewatch appeal last week, which gave police 200 new names, 20 of them "relevant and interesting".

But Detective Chief Inspector Hamish Campbell said he was certain there were people in Gowan Avenue on the morning of the shooting who had not come forward.

A meter reader and a man collecting his daughter from school had been traced. "They felt they could not offer anything to the inquiry team so did not come forward," he said. "My message to them and others like them is: we do need to speak to you."

He also appealed for people to contact his team if they knew someone who fitted the "key elements" of the likely killer: a loner, known to be obsessive about Miss Dando or other women, interested in guns, fitting witnesses' descriptions and able to have been in Gowan Avenue that morning and on the previous two Mondays.

fields.headline: 50,000 extra Chernobyl cancers predicted
fields.trailText: The Chernobyl disaster will cause 50,000 new cases of thyroid cancer among young people living in the worst-affected region, World Health Organisation researchers say.
fields.body:
The Chernobyl disaster will cause 50,000 new cases of thyroid cancer among young people living in the worst-affected region, World Health Organisation researchers say.

The figures show that in Gomel, Belarus, 36.4% of children aged under four on April 26, 1986 - the day of the disaster - can expect to develop thyroid cancer.

This percentage is much higher than was originally expected, as well as being well above rates following previous exposures to nuclear fallout - for example among Pacific islanders exposed to American atmospheric tests.

Researchers believe that one explanation is that people in the region suffer from a deficiency of iodine, which is essential to the working of the thyroid gland. Young children exposed to radioactive iodine from Chernobyl fallout would have absorbed large quantities to make up the deficiency and as a result got a large concentrated dose in their thyroids.

A second, more general, report on the effects of Chernobyl released by the UN yes terday, predicted that that the worst was still to come for more than 7m people affected by the disaster.

"Chernobyl is a word we would all like to erase from our memory," said the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, in a foreword to the report.

But he added that "more than 7m of our fellow human beings do not have the luxury of forgetting. They are still suffering, every day, as a result of what happened."

Mr Annan said the exact number of victims may never be known, but that 3m children require treatment and "many will die prematurely".

The thyroid paper by Dr Elisabeth Cardis from the Lyon-based International Agency for Research on Cancer - part of the WHO - clearly shocked the 12 researchers involved. It is "very much hoped" they say, that their calculations are wrong, but add that the figures provide the best estimate at present.

The study says that whichever way the calculations are done, "if the current trends of risk continue, a considerable number of cases is to be expected among those exposed as very young children".

Based on a comparison with the number of thyroid cases among British children, the researchers found a dramatic rise in cancers among infants living in Gomel at the time of the accident.

In a population of 141,068 children under four, less than six cases would have been expected - in fact in the first 10 years there were 131. Over their lifetimes another 50,200 can expect to develop thyroid cancer, the researchers say.

They also predict that neighbouring areas can expect high figures. In Mogilev region 5% of the same age group can expect to suffer from the cancer - a total of 5,023 people. In the three regions of Russia most affected - Kaluga, Tula and Oryel - around 1% of children will be affected, causing 3,699 more cases.

The high numbers in the Gomel region need some extra explanation in addition to the one provided by the severity of the fall-out from the accident, the researchers believe. One possible cause is a genetic susceptibility of the ethnic group in the area, along with the moderate iodine deficiency.

The paper suggests further work to try to isolate the cause, but in the meantime suggests widespread screening of young people to try to catch the cancers early. The researchers also suggest iodine supplements are given to all children in the region, to prevent a further health catastrophe in the event of a second accident at Chernobyl.

Tobias Munchmeyer, a Greenpeace nuclear expert, said that Britain should reconsider its financial support for further nuclear reactors in Ukraine. Last week Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, pledged money to help Ukraine complete reactors un finished since the break-up of the Soviet Union.

Mr Munchmeyer said: "These are absolutely shocking figures, the result of very careful analysis by world experts, and they come out far worse than we could have believed.

"The remaining operating Chernobyl reactor, number 3, is acknowledged to be dangerous and we call on Ukraine to shut it immediately. We also call on the G7 countries not to fund new nuclear reactors in Ukraine, but instead spend the money on sustainable energy solutions."

fields.headline: National Roundup
fields.trailText: Beatles mementoes up for sale
fields.body:
Beatles mementoes up for sale

A handwritten letter from Paul McCartney and a Christmas card illustrated by John Lennon were unveiled yesterday among items documenting the life of the Beatles' manager Brian Epstein.

They are among 14 lots on sale at Christie's, South Kensington, on Thursday, nearly 33 years after Epstein died of a sleeping drug overdose. The collection is expected to sell for about £45,000.

The letter from McCartney to Epstein in 1966 or 1967 is signed The Reverend James Paul McKenzie, referring to the character in the song Eleanor Rigby.

The Christmas card, probably made in 1966, is inscribed "Happy Christian Brian from John", believed to be an ironic reference to Epstein's Jewish beliefs.

Epstein gave the collection to his chauffeur, Bryan Barrett. Mr Barrett, 70, said yesterday it would no longer hurt anyone to make them public, as Epstein's immediate family had died.

Death crash GP jailed for five years

A GP who killed an author in a car crash while three times above the drink-drive limit was yesterday jailed for five years. Passing sentence at the high court in Edinburgh, Lord Milligan also banned Elizabeth Crabbie from driving for 10 years.

Children's author Graeme Cook died instantly when Crabbie, who the court heard was driving on the wrong side of the main road between Perth and Forfar, ploughed into his car.

Crabbie, 54, was a senior partner at Comrie health centre in Perth and is married to Colin Crabbie, Tory councillor for Perth and Kinross. She had admitted causing death by dangerous driving at a previous hearing.

The court was told that on the eve of the crash a year ago yesterday the couple had been at a Conservative party function, where she had drunk a substantial quantity of alcohol. The following afternoon, after visiting her terminally ill father where she had also drunk wine and spirits, she was seen driving erratically on the A94.

She has lost her job and could be struck off the General Medical Council's register of doctors.

webTitle: New Labour may not like us but it needs our money

fields.headline: New Labour may not like us but it needs our money
fields.standfirst: Following the Thatcher dictum and dumping the unions is not an optionNew Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: It is almost 40 years since the then general secretary of the Trades Union Congress, the Ruskin and Balliol-educated George Woodcock, posed a disarmingly simple and obvious question to his colleagues on the TUC general council. "Why," he asked them, "are we here?"
fields.body:
It is almost 40 years since the then general secretary of the Trades Union Congress, the Ruskin and Balliol-educated George Woodcock, posed a disarmingly simple and obvious question to his colleagues on the TUC general council. "Why," he asked them, "are we here?"

He wanted to know what these great and good leaders of something like 14m paid-up members - almost double the present, post-Thatcher figure - actually believed the trades union movement was all about. Only when he had an answer to his simple question would it be possible, in his view, to move on to a discussion of the Woodcock pet project - the reform and restructuring of the entire trades union movement.

Alas, he got no satisfactory response from such panjandrums of the card vote as Frank Cousins of the Transport Workers and Bill Carron of the engineers. Woodcock saw himself as up to the armpits in high-pressure discussions with successive Conservative and Labour governments over the running of the economy. What he got back from the men (and they were men) round the table was that their job was to fatten the pay packets of their members at every opportunity - and not much else.

This extraordinary confrontation took place at a meeting of the economic committee of the TUC general council - the inner cabinet of the movement - in December 1962. The minutes of the meeting are reported in some detail in a timely new two-volume set of essays on the history of trades unionism in the post-war period up to the advent of Thatcherism*. The article on Woodcock and his failed crusade is written by Robert Taylor of the Financial Times, and it reveals just how far-sighted this difficult, and sometimes perverse, man really was.

In the course of a lengthy introductory speech, Woodcock clearly foresaw the coming of Thatcherism, the return of mass unemployment and even, to some extent, the acceptance of the monetarist approach to the economy by New Labour.

In a key passage, he told his colleagues: "The free-for-all cannot continue unabated. It will bring regulation, either by legislation or by unemployment. If this problem is not solved, the government will solve it for us by putting employers back into the position of having to be tough."

Alas, his analysis was not so much rejected as ignored. As Frank Cousins put it, if there is a free-for-all, then we must be part of the all. Woodcock never returned to the subject, though he soldiered on for another six years. It was one of the great lost opportunities, leading remorselessly to the winter of discontent of 1978/9, the fall of the Callaghan government and the arrival of Mrs Thatcher and her "ism", and resulting ultimately in New Labour's endorsement of the concept of a flexible labour market.

It all could - as Mr Taylor clearly believes - have been very different. But it did not happen, and the successors of Frank Cousins, Bill Carron, Hughie Scanlon and Jack Jones are now facing a situation in which vast swaths of the manufacturing industry on which they depend for their core membership is being destroyed.

So the impending withdrawal of BMW and Ford from mass car production in Britain could prove to be a turning point for the unions, in which they are forced, finally, to acknowledge just how little power they possess to carry out their primary function as the defenders of their members' livelihoods.

It is true that strike action has a certain muscular resonance, recalling the years of union militancy when shop stewards were the lords of creation and most managers cringed at the sight of a union card.

But few people inside the present day union bureaucracy, and even fewer in the boardrooms of BMW and Ford, can take the idea of a strike seriously, as an effective means of saving jobs rather than a means of letting off steam.

So the unions are effectively reduced to pleading with the government to do something - anything, they know not what - to prevent the remorseless process of cost-cutting at the expense of their members' livelihoods. But the government, beyond a few personal appeals from Mister Tony to the people he thought he had turned into his friends, is no better equipped with ideas for preventing the apparently inevitable. And ministers are well aware that their attachment to the flexible economy - a euphemism for making it easy to sack people - has helped to create the situation they now face.

It is at this point that many union members must be beginning to think not just about the sort of questions that exercised George Woodcock, but also about the hitherto taboo subject of the relationship between the trades unions and the Labour party.

For there is an obvious question which has hung over New Labour ever since its birth, and it is this: if we can't rely on the Labour government to protect our most vital interests - namely, the jobs of our members - why do we give them all that money?

Ironically, it was New Labour itself which first raised the question of whether this long-standing alliance had any further justification. Indeed, Mr Blair himself made it clear some time before he became party leader that it would be possible to do without union cash if the party set out to build a mass membership. Such a project was feasible, he argued, because he had achieved just that in his own constituency of Sedgefield. So convinced was he that he called me in for a wigging when I expressed scepticism in these pages.

Similar thoughts were expressed somewhat later by, as it happens, the very man the unions are now relying on in Dagenham and Longbridge: none other than Stephen Byers, the present industry secretary, was identified as the shadow minister who unwisely blurted out some "dump the unions" speculation to a couple of journalists in a Blackpool seafood restaurant.

But harsh reality, in the form of falling rather than rising membership, has since broken through. It is now well understood that New Labour's increasingly expensive election campaigns cannot be funded entirely by people like Bernie Ecclestone. Trade union money is still crucial to "the project".

But a "project" which includes high interest rates and a grossly over-valued pound is hardly one to appeal to union members who are suffering the consequences. So perhaps some of them will now revive George Woodcock's question, and I suspect that very few will reply: "We are here to pay the Labour party's bills." Perhaps the time has come to ask for something back.

Polly Toynbee is away.

fields.headline: Breaking news from the classroom
fields.trailText: Elaine Fisher (Letters, April 25) doubts whether newspaper personnel could stand the pace of the classroom. I have no such doubts - because I spent 17 years in newspapers before a degree and post-graduate training led me into teaching. Nothing in newspaper work prepared me for the intensity of the teaching schedule.
fields.body:
Elaine Fisher (Letters, April 25) doubts whether newspaper personnel could stand the pace of the classroom. I have no such doubts - because I spent 17 years in newspapers before a degree and post-graduate training led me into teaching. Nothing in newspaper work prepared me for the intensity of the teaching schedule and the meticulous attention which has to be paid to timing and personal organisation.

In the classroom you are entirely on your own. There is no team to handle 30 or so jostling, probing, agitated teenagers, just you and your skills. Your personality is tested every single second. It demands hawk-like awareness of every nuance of childish interaction and the sort of patience which few of my journalistic colleagues could have mustered, as demonstrated by their irritation when they had to "put up with" a couple of their own children during school holidays.

Add to this the clerical work which dwarfs the preparation and processing of similar face-to-face occupations like salesmanship and believe me, if you start out in life as a teacher, you could handle almost any other job you could think of.
Tony Vinicombe
Hove, East Sussex
ViniView@aol.com

 Like Pat Gibson (Letters, April 25), I am a late entrant to teaching, and have really enjoyed working with primary children since leaving the building industry. I have also been most impressed by the dedication of the vast majority of teachers I've worked with, but have noted the inexorable, but unnecessary, build-up of workload with the attendant increase of furrowed brows and groans as the "fun" is squeezed out of the school day. I shall not be applying to leap across the Blunkett threshold, for I believe that the whole of the school team, including the pupils, are responsible for learning achieved in school.
Bill Kitchen
Brightlingsea, Essex
bill_kitchen@hotmail.com>

 Surely Pat Gibson's split infinitive and infer/imply misuse indicates literacy attainment well below expectations and thus disqualifies her/him from even a sniff of PRP?
Brian Strauss
Basingstoke, Hampshire

 Teachers should be aware of one telling anagram of performance-related pay: mere end-of-year claptrap.
James Mackenzie
Edinburgh
james@mackenzie.nu

fields.headline: Proudhon's tabloid fate
fields.trailText: Proudhon's statement that "property is theft" was not a dictum (Anger as squatter sells up, April 25) but rhetorical analogy - an attempt to bring a sense of moral outrage to the problem of absentee landlords.
fields.body:
Proudhon's statement that "property is theft" was not a dictum (Anger as squatter sells up, April 25) but rhetorical analogy - an attempt to bring a sense of moral outrage to the problem of absentee landlords. He was saying that somebody who simply inherited land, but had nothing whatsoever to do with it, should not prosper at the expense of the farmers who worked it. One can be sure he would have felt equal contempt for south London squatters. Today Proudhon would be a Daily Mail reader.
Chris Jones
Luton

 As well as staying at Southport (Leader, April 25), Prince Louis Napoleon also passed some of his exile in Royal Leamington Spa. He rode with the Warwickshire Hunt and was a sought-after dinner guest. Could it be that the tree-lined boulevards of Paris were inspired, not by Southport, but by Leamington?
Robin Stott
Warwick
RSTOTT@warwickdc.gov.uk

fields.headline: Set back
fields.trailText: David Hart, general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers, is incorrect to assume 151 Pokemon cards make up the set (Pokemon cards 'exploit children', April 25). The situation is much worse.
fields.body:
David Hart, general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers, is incorrect to assume 151 Pokemon cards make up the set (Pokemon cards 'exploit children', April 25). The situation is much worse. There are 103 cards to collect for the base set, but the fun doesn't stop there. There are two additional sets, which have another 64 and 62 new cards respectively.

The first editions of cards have a special stamp on them to make them more valuable. There are also an unknown number of promo cards (approximately 15). We should, however, consider ourselves lucky. In America they have another two sets containing 130 and 83 more cards, and in Japan 15 different sets are available.
James Roberts
London

webTitle: The doctor will see you now - so don't ask questions

fields.headline: The doctor will see you now - so don't ask questions
fields.trailText: So Dr Theodore Dalrymple finds patients with written lists of questions intimidating and irritating (So, have you ever operated before?, April 25). It is not surprising that his patients appear not to understand what he tells them if his consultations are suffused with the arrogant and condescending attitude revealed in his article.
fields.body:
So Dr Theodore Dalrymple finds patients with written lists of questions intimidating and irritating (So, have you ever operated before?, April 25). It is not surprising that his patients appear not to understand what he tells them if his consultations are suffused with the arrogant and condescending attitude revealed in his article. As his basic message to patients seems to be just do what you're told and go away, it's far too complicated for you to understand and anyway you're bloody lucky to get to see a doctor at all, this is probably just as well.

Many doctors welcome patients who wish to understand more about their health, and encourage written lists of questions prepared away from the stress of the consulting room. Some even give written information in reply. Dr Dalrymple's article will be a useful teaching aide for demonstrating to medical students the sort of attitudes they should not adopt.

With regard to the "shortage" of orthopaedic surgeons, is it not strange that the same surgeon who will not see you for a year on the NHS could usually do your hip next week (and no doubt fully answer any questions you might have) in exchange for ready cash?

Messrs Blair and Milburn might say some scary things, but as long as we have doctors like Dalrymple, no one can argue that the medical profession doesn't need a bit of sorting out.
Dr John Main
Consultant nephrologist, South Cleveland Hospital
Middlesbrough

 I am one of those irritating and intimidating patients who comes to the doctor with written lists of questions. My recent experience in hospital suggests that, despite advances in medical training that focus on consultation skills, some doctors continue to see the medical encounter as one in which they dictate the actions and the patient gratefully and unquestioningly accepts.

I have multiple sclerosis, for which doctors can often do remarkably little but provide information. At a recent consultation, held after I had received a course of treatment, the doctor closed my file within a couple of minutes of my entering the room, ready to usher me out again. My typed list of questions - many of which should have been asked and answered prior to treatment if consent is to have any meaningful status - gave me the confidence to persist over the next 20 minutes in my search for answers, during which the doctor continually tried to close the consultation. I was searching for precisely that information which Dr Dalrymple feels we, as patients, cannot handle - an understanding of how my doctor makes decisions and manages treatment.

Patients are no longer prepared to feel disempowered by the lack of adequate information specific to their cases and the failure of personal interchanges and joint decision-making that would enable them to be partners in their own health care.
Janet Price
Liverpool
J.E.Price@liverpool.ac.uk

fields.headline: Bottom drawer
fields.trailText: I cannot let Joanna Moorhead's smug laziness go unanswered (It's a dirty job, April 25). My partner and I are working parents who use reusable nappies. I claim no particular organisational skills, nor do I have an unusually well-lined stomach. But it really is pretty easy!
fields.body:
I cannot let Joanna Moorhead's smug laziness go unanswered (It's a dirty job, April 25). My partner and I are working parents who use reusable nappies. I claim no particular organisational skills, nor do I have an unusually well-lined stomach. But for goodness sake, it really is pretty easy! Given that the alternative is to choke the landscape with crap-laden waste with a half-life to make the nuclear industry sit up and take notice, I feel my "sacrifice" is more than justified.

Ms Moorhead doesn't seem able to take the following, simple steps: organise her time and washing routines; buy enough reusables to avoid the no-clean-napples crisis scenario (you don't need that many); learn to love the natural, largely organic stuff that comes out of her child; tell her husband to shape up or ship out.
Duncan Mitchell
Bristol

 It's a shame that Joanne Moorhead hasn't read some of the information circulated during real nappy week. Terry nappies can be messy to use. But if, like most modern parents now turning to washable nappies, Cherie and Tony Blair buy some of the new fitted range of nappies rather than terries, they've nothing to fear.

New style nappies are fitted so leaks are a thing of the past. And not for them the task of "scraping poo" - flushable liners mean that the solid waste gets flushed away.

So well done Cherie for choosing washable nappies. They're better for the environment, better for your baby and they're more economical - Gordon should approve of that.
Eluned Rogers
Marketing director, Green Baby
greenbabyco@hotmail.com

webTitle: Dewar admitted to hospital for heart tests

fields.headline: Dewar admitted to hospital for heart tests
fields.standfirst: Devolution in Scotland: special report
fields.trailText: Donald Dewar, Scotland's first minister, was in a cardiac unit last night for investigation into heart irregularity.
fields.body:
Donald Dewar, Scotland's first minister, was in a cardiac unit last night for investigation into heart irregularity.

Mr Dewar, 62, was taken to Glasgow royal infirmary at 10.30 yesterday morning to undergo a pre-arranged procedure. It meant he missed yesterday's Scottish cabinet meeting and he is not expected to work for some days.

His spokesman played down the severity of the first minister's condition, saying a minor irregularity was spotted at a routine check-up a month ago and that yesterday's tests had been arranged to fit in with Mr Dewar's schedule.

News of the first minister's health problems, however, came as a shock to his cabinet colleagues. Most of the cabinet were not informed that he would be absent from yesterday's meeting - with his Liberal Democrat deputy, Jim Wallace, taking charge of the proceedings - until late on Monday night.

The spokesman refused to be drawn on the nature of the tests but said Mr Dewar had been feeling apprehensive about his hospital stay.

Mr Dewar, who is divorced with two children, is expected to be released from the hospital this morning, but it is unclear when he will return to work. Since becoming first minister, he has worked under a punishing schedule. Questions were raised yesterday as to why he had not taken treatment during the Scottish parliament's Easter recess, but the spokesman said Mr Dewar had a long-standing commitment to a trip to Japan and a speaking engagement at the Scottish TUC conference.

Even Mr Dewar's friends admit he has found it difficult to make the transition from Scottish secretary in the Westminster cabinet to Scottish first minister, where he takes the full brunt of criticism not just in the debating chamber but also from a resurgent Scottish political press.

Over the past few weeks, he has come under heavy fire over the escalating costs of the Scottish parliament and the executive's plans to repeal section 28, the local government law which bans schools from promoting the acceptability of homosexuality. Mr Dewar had been expected to take part in what will undoubtedly be a heated debate on section 28 tomorrow.

The first minister's duties will now be met by Mr Wallace until he returns to work, and any political matters will be dealt with by Labour cabinet ministers. But if Mr Dewar is off work for an extended period, a Labour minister will have to be appointed to take over his role. Mr Dewar, a bookish workaholic, has not had a full holiday since last summer, when he visited Orkney and Shetland.

Alex Salmond, leader of the the Scottish National party, said: "I'm sure that the whole parliament will join together in sending our best wishes to the first minister and I hope that these tests give him a clean bill of health."

fields.headline: Your party still needs you
fields.trailText: Peter Preston (Forget the party activists, April 24) repeats the "old orthodoxy" on local party campaign activity: that to the extent it takes place at all, it makes little or no difference to the outcome of an election. However, he is too quick to dismiss what is, in fact, an important part of the electoral process.
fields.body:
Peter Preston (Forget the party activists, April 24) repeats the "old orthodoxy" on local party campaign activity: that to the extent it takes place at all, it makes little or no difference to the outcome of an election. However, he is too quick to dismiss what is, in fact, an important part of the electoral process.

A growing body of research based on the systematic analysis of all constituency results demonstrates that the opposite is true. The constituency campaign still makes a difference. The harder a party campaigns in a constituency, other things being equal, the better it does there, and the worse its rivals do. This result has been verified by at least three independent research teams, each using different methodologies and different measures of campaign intensity, and each analysing several elections.

Furthermore, the parties themselves (or at least Labour and the Liberal Democrats) recognise the value of the local campaign and increasingly focus their local efforts in key marginal seats. An absence of canvassers locally might simply reflect living in a safe seat, where any canvassing activity for any party is a waste of resources. Targeted campaigning in key seats can yield impressive results (allowing the Liberal Democrats, for instance, to increase their parliamentary complement from 20 in 1992 to 46 in 1997, even though their vote share fell slightly).

The empirical evidence simply does not support the assertion that local political activism no longer matters. The constituency campaign only shifts a relatively few votes overall in national elections, clearly. But it can make the difference between winning and losing in particular seats. And in a close election, that can be the difference between forming a government and forming an opposition.
Dr Charles Pattie
University of Sheffield
c.pattie@sheffield.ac.uk

 Peter Preston's article is wishful thinking. He quotes David Butler saying that canvassing has a mere "slight effect", but that was from a different political age. The evidence from both the 1997 and 1992 general elections is that party activists make a major difference to election results, ensuring that the vote in marginal seats swings more impressively than in safe seats. Labour and the Lib Dems learned this lesson in 1992 and put motivated activists into marginal seats in 1997 with even more devastating results for the Tories than their low vote had already condemned them to.

For whatever reasons turnouts have been falling, so party activists will probably become more important. A personal example; voter turnout in my council ward last May was a depressing 23%, but among people canvassed it was 32% and among those canvassed who said they would vote for me, and therefore were "knocked up" on polling day, it was 40%. Perhaps that isn't conclusive evidence, but it is more than the "possiblity" of a "slight effect" Peter Preston wants to believe in.
Cllr John Culley
Yeovil, Somerset
jc@beaumonthouse.freeserve. co.uk

 Local activists who were depressed by Peter Preston's article shouldn't worry too much. A recent article in the Guardian by Paul Whitleley and Patrick Seyd (Grassroots gains, March 8) shows that Labour's majority at the last election would have been reduced by about 150 seats without local party activity.

Local campaigns don't convert voters, but they identify them and motivate them to vote. The London mayoral election is the exception that proves the rule. Ken Livingstone is likely to win without a party machine behind him but Frank Dobson is likely to lose without one. To all party activists of all the parties, don't lose heart - your party needs you more than ever.
Anthony Painter
London
ant1@islington.org.uk

fields.headline: The Max factor
fields.standfirst: Bruch first, Rachmaninov second. As usual
fields.trailText: Classic FM has announced the results of its annual Eastertide contest for the nation's favourite piece of classical music - the first of the new millennium. The winner was the violin concerto in G minor by Max Bruch. Runner-up was Rachmaninov's piano concerto no 2 in C minor. This is the same result as last year. And the year before.
fields.body:
Classic FM has announced the results of its annual Eastertide contest for the nation's favourite piece of classical music - the first of the new millennium. The winner was the violin concerto in G minor by Max Bruch. Runner-up was Rachmaninov's piano concerto no 2 in C minor. This is the same result as last year. And the year before. And the year before that. Also in 1996, when the exercise started. The only change at the top of the table has been at number three, where Beethoven's Pastoral symphony, which finished in this position in 1996 and 1997, was displaced by the Mozart clarinet concerto in 1998. And in 1999. And again this year.

The station is keen to point out that the margin by which Bruch beat off Rachmaninov was narrower this year than last. And lower down the table there are some encouraging signs of what psephologists call churning, with Vivaldi's inescapable Four Seasons, 11th in 1996, now sagging at 29th, while some nifty cornering at the chicane has swept Samuel Barber's equally omnipresent Adagio past it to sixth. Six composers - Les Six, as they may come to be known - enter the list for the first time this year: Jay Ungar, Arvo Pärt, John Barry, Richard (Warsaw concerto) Addinsell, Ludovico Einaudi, and Arthur Sullivan, who would no doubt wish to acknowledge the debt he owes to Mike Leigh's G&S biopic, Topsy-Turvey.

But as dwindling media coverage of its results demonstrates, Classic FM has a problem. Imagine how boring the public would find it if the same three horses finished ahead of the field in every Grand National. Yet perhaps that points to an answer. Racing, like golf, insures against foregone conclusions by a system of handicapping, designed to give also-rans more of a chance. By this time next year, Classic FM needs to dream up an equivalent method, bridling its Bruchs and restraining its Rachmaninovs while hoisting its Holsts and boosting its Bizets.

fields.headline: The peril persists
fields.standfirst:
Britain should set the pace in New York

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Have we forgotten Hiroshima? Through the bleak, paranoid decades of the cold war, the spectre of that murderous cloud served as a constant reminder of the vital importance of nuclear disarmament.
fields.body:
Have we forgotten Hiroshima? Through the bleak, paranoid decades of the cold war, the spectre of that murderous cloud served as a constant reminder of the vital importance of nuclear disarmament. While politicians spoke glibly of mutual assured destruction, and generals deployed their shiny new cruise and midgetmen missiles, millions marched in protest and a generation of children suffered nightmares of thermo-nuclear war. Mirv, ICBM, Salt, INF, and other ugly acronyms entered the vocabulary of a world teetering, it seemed at times, on the edge of an abyss. Fear of the bomb was universal; the next holocaust would be global, and the last. And then, the Berlin Wall fell, the "evil empire" of Ronald Reagan's imaginings dissolved, and the danger appeared to pass. The Hiroshima cloud had finally dispersed.

Except, of course, that it has not. The danger merely changed shape - which is the main reason why the conference called to review the nuclear non-proliferation treaty (NPT) in New York this week deserves very serious attention. The treaty, to which 187 countries (including the five acknowledged nuclear powers) adhere, is in trouble. In preparatory meetings, participants could not agree on the pace of the disarmament to which all in theory are pledged; the creation of new negotiations to curb the production of weapons-grade fissile material; or how to speed ratification of the comprehensive test ban treaty (CTBT).

What this disarray means in practice, for example, is that countries like India and Pakistan are less likely to feel obliged to end the rival nuclear tests which they began in 1998; that countries which are suspected of seeking to acquire nuclear capability, like Iran (and Iraq), may face no new obstacles to their ambitions; that Israel, which is already nuclear-armed, will be encouraged to continue its defiance of the NPT regime; and that countries which have forsworn the bomb, like South Africa, Canada, Egypt, Brazil, and members of the non-aligned movement, may come to reconsider their positions.

The US, the leading nuclear power, bears grave responsibility for this apparent impasse. It has failed to ratify the CTBT as it is honour-bound to do. It is developing a treaty-busting national anti-ballistic missile defence (NMD) which even cautious Kofi Annan describes as destabilising. It retains the right to "first use" of nuclear weapons. And it is reportedly upgrading and stockpiling warheads which it was expected to destroy under the Start negotiations with Russia. In vain does the US insist NMD is merely a defence against "rogue" states. Russia and China, to name but two opponents, simply do not believe it and would no doubt take counter- measures if it were deployed. Worse still, NMD undermines the concept of deterrence, substituting for it the dangerously foolish idea of "absolute security". The advent of NMD brings the prospect of a "limited" nuclear war closer.

Labour, in two minds about NMD but reluctant to challenge the Pentagon, claims credit meanwhile for reducing Britain's deployed nuclear arsenal. Like the US, the government is committed, ultimately, to complete nuclear disarmament. But this is simply not enough. Foreign Office minister Peter Hain missed his moment when he spoke in New York on Monday. To give a much-needed kickstart to these crucial talks, Britain should lead the way by proposing multilateral disarmament negotiations involving all the actual nuclear powers. Wait no longer for others to act. Build the trust that is so lacking. Put our weapons on the table. And remember Hiroshima.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: The Man In The Iron Mask | Solomon and Gaenor | Mafia! | Hamlet
fields.body:
The Man In The Iron Mask

(Randall Wallace, 1998)

8pm, Sky Premier

Wallace, scriptwriter of Braveheart, delivers an oddly muted, at times sombre version of the great Alexandre Dumas adventure. Golden boy Leonardo DiCaprio is touching as the naive and wronged man of the title, though less convincing as Louis XIV, the more worldly and cruel twin brother who incarcerated him. But the four musketeers ride again in a quartet to match even Dick Lester's crusty crew - Gabriel Byrne as D'Artagnan, John Malkovich (Athos) Gérard Depardieu (Porthos) and Jeremy Irons (Aramis).

Solomon and Gaenor

(Paul Morrison, 1999)

10pm, FilmFour

A touching tale of love across cultural barriers in pre-first world war Wales. Ioan Gruffudd - young Hornblower of the TV series - is Solomon, a door-to-door fabric salesman who hides his Jewish background when he falls for Gaenor (Nia Roberts), daughter of a chapel-going pit family.

It hardly mines deep seams of thought, but it's lyrical and beautifully shot, with fine, affecting performances from the two leads.

Mafia!

(Jim Abrahams, 1998)

10pm, Sky MovieMax

After joke-a-thons such as Airplane!, Top Secret! and the Naked Gun series, this effort targets the sitting duck of mob movies. But with little story to hang it all on, it mainly serves as a sad reminder of the halcyon Zucker-Abrahams-Zucker days. Abrahams didn't have the Zuckers by this stage, but he still wheels out the rest of the gear - wacky sight gags, politically dodgy sideswipes, dated references (the Macarena), film parodies (everything from Forrest Gump to Il Postino), and Lloyd Bridges - but it all looks pretty creaky.

Hamlet

(Kenneth Branagh, 1996)

1.35am, FilmFour

Or Branagh's Braveheart. Brave of him, anyway, to tackle the uncut tragedy, and he largely wins the day. The action is shifted to the later 19th century, the director hamming it up as the gloomy Dane, supported by Kate Winslet's no-nonsense Ophelia, Richard Briers's sly Polonius and Derek Jacobi's creepy Claudius.

fields.headline: Random Views
fields.standfirst: What students studying for finals are watching on TV
fields.trailText: What students studying for finals are watching on TV.
fields.body:
Jo Stella: "Now that I'm supposed to be revising, I watch a lot more television. I mean you can't work during Neighbours, can you? It's an institution. I watch it with my Mum. I'm also very fond of Hollyoaks. Do I think it's true to life? No not really, but I do like the way it contains improbably high numbers of very attractive men, ha ha ha."

Simon Norris: "I don't like watching telly. I've got better things to do with my time. What am I doing now? Actually I'm in the middle of revising the chemistry of the heavy transition metals. I do like Ali G. He's very funny, but I don't think he'll last much longer. People have wised up to him. Do I want to follow in his footsteps? No, I don't think so. Although I have always wanted to be a sort of screenwriter, director, producer of obscure independent films."

Naomi Davies: "I'm very into the Naked Chef. Why do I like him? Well, actually I used him as an example of the archetypal twenty-first-century man in this essay I'm doing on masculinity. So it's research really. Why do I think he's so representative? Well, it's because he likes to be seen as a bit of a lad. You know, one of the Loaded generation... a curry eater. But in fact he's really good in the kitchen and cooks for his girlfriend. It's all a media image of course, but that was my argument. I've also watched every single episode of Power Into Art on Channel Four about the Tate Modern. Actually, I sort of came up with the idea first - for the gallery I mean. My idea... well, to be honest, I'd rather not tell you in case somebody nicks it."

Adam Blendford: "Hmmm, I'm trying to write my dissertation at the moment so that takes up most of the day. In the evening I'll watch anything - I'm quite into the snooker. You can watch it with your brain switched off. I like Ground Force as well - it's a bit like Challenge Anneka. Only I don't fancy Charlie Dimmock. To be honest, if I really want to watch something, I go to the video shop. I don't trust the telly to entertain me."

 Clare Rudebeck spoke to students in Leeds, Nottingham and Cambridge

fields.headline: The path to power
fields.trailText: The Secret Life Of Michael Fry | Argi Bhaji | Under The Wire
fields.body:
TV writers seem to believe that setting a story in Wales automatically establishes an atmosphere of primitive mystery and existential isolation. As Michael Fry puts it in The Secret Life Of Michael Fry (C4), to Donna the prostitute as she explains how she'd returned from London to Llangrych, "I never heard of anyone fighting their way back here."

But to be fair to writer Paul Abbott and director Marc Munden, The Secret Life... squeezes full value from its rundown but characterful seaside locations, and benefits further from an excellent cast. Ewen Bremner takes the title role of the bemused council planning officer who discovers that his bosses are planning an implausible campaign to turn Llangrych into a magnet for international tourism, with the aid of lavish EU funding. The local internet-pornographer is played by an immensely sordid Michael Kitchen, while Rosie Marcel could almost convince you that Donna is different from the lamentable cliché of the tart-with-a-heart. As Mr Wentworth-Davies, the planning supremo, Robert Pugh rants and blusters like a clockwork Mussolini.

What Abbott's script is getting at is that a lust for power is meaningless without a sense of belonging and self-worth, and he uses the petty tyrannies of local government as a revealing satiric device. The council's lunatic pretensions are rendered extra-absurd by framing them inside a vast, echoing municipal building, as Fry looks on in goggle-eyed bewilderment. Bremner is especially good at evoking the cluelessness of a divorced single father. With Polish parents and a gay brother, he's already confused enough before he meets porno-queen Donna and finds his libido spinning off the dial. But all Donna wants is somebody to talk to...

Surveys reveal that chicken tikka marsala is now the most popular dish in Britain. Thirty-seven per cent of women prefer a curry and a video to a night of passion. Britain's curry industry is now bigger than coal-mining, shipbuilding and steel combined.

Regrettably, once you'd ticked off the statistics in Argi Bhaji (Cutting Edge, C4), there weren't many good reasons for watching the rest of the film. Although it was unusual to find a programme about food which didn't feature wine critics engaged in an idiocy contest or have a matching hardback book on sale in WH Smith, there seemed little point in tracking down living Mancunian stereotypes to prove yet again that curry-houses are packed with loutish lager-drinking men and shrieking women singing lewd songs.

But there were signs that the programme had started out with loftier ambitions than merely to make Curry Uncovered. It had been shot in Manchester's Rusholme district - a mecca, if you will, for curry addicts - around the time of the Muslim Eid festival, as if director Iain MacDonald had been planning an essay in multiculturalism, viewed through a digestion-blitzing prism of poppadoms and Carlsberg. In the end, though, the festival scenes were merely wallpaper in between the scenes of boorish drunks falling face-down into plates of aloo gobi, since most of the restaurant owners had decided there was no mileage in probing into the commerce-versus-religion debate. "You cannot mix religion with business, otherwise everybody would be bankrupt", declared the pragmatic Taz, manager of the Mughli.

The significant exception was Asif, from the Darbar restaurant, who succumbed to a soliloquy of self-loathing. He misses his family, and he hates Eid because it reminds him of his dead father. "I haven't been a good Muslim, I haven't been a good son", he lamented. On a brighter note, he had some tips for clearing obstreperous diners from his restaurant. A curt "sod off" is normally sufficient.

Under The Wire (Desperately Seeking EUtopia, BBC2) contrasted the way asylum-seekers are treated in southern Italy and Austria. In Italy, kindly priest Don Cesare hopes to convince them that "they can have a future in Italy and Europe". On Austria's Hungarian border, eager young patrolmen round up immigrants with the aid of radar and heat-seeking cameras and send them back. It wasn't hard to cast the Austrians as the bad guys, yet it remains to be seen how much trouble the Italian government's hands-off approach, which enables 80 per cent of asylum seekers to slip away into Germany, France and Britain, is going to cause.

fields.headline: Court circular
fields.standfirst: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.trailText: Who's up in front of the judge.
fields.body:
There's obviously something karmic in the air for porcine West Coast hip-hop guru Dr Dre, as his action against MP3 website Napster was followed (virtually by return of post) with a suit against him from Star Wars svengali George Lucas' production outfit Lucasfilm. According to the legal papers, filed in Northern California US District Court, Dre's unauthorised use of Lucas' patented sound effect "THX Deep Note" on his recent album 2001 constituted a clear case of copyright infringement; and, with George and co now seeking unspecified damages, it seems entirely plausible that whatever cash Dre does manage to finagle out of Napster will be heading straight into the coffers of Lucasfilm. You've got to laugh - haven't you?

Meanwhile, the grisly corpse of punk rock managed a small litigious wheeze this week, as erstwhile counter-cultural heroes the Dead Kennedys took each other to San Francisco Superior Court this week in a ruckus over unpaid royalties. Except, of course, it's very much the proverbial two-sided coin: while former band-members East Bay Ray, Klaus Flouride and DH Peligro are arguing ex-frontman Jello Biafra has diddled them out of "hundreds of thousands" in misappropriated album profits, Biafra claims the whole sorry business has erupted out of spite after he refused to allow the Kennedys' Holiday In Cambodia to be used in a Levi's advert. "I respect how much the Dead Kennedys' music and message means to people," he declared, "I can think of no worse way to stab our fans in the back than to sell out to Levi's." The help, however, say the aborted ad is merely a red herring proffered by Biafra to justify his retention of their money. "We think Biafra's acting like a capitalist in the worst sense of the word", commented Ray. "He may not be a corporation, but he certainly knows how to behave like one."

fields.headline: Born to run
fields.standfirst:
Logan's Run - the classic 70s sci-fi film about a hedonistic society where everybody is killed off on their 30th birthday - is being remade by Hollywood. About time too, says Maxton Walker (age 30)
Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: Logan's Run - the classic 70s sci-fi film about a hedonistic society where everybody is killed off on their 30th birthday - is being remade by Hollywood. About time too, says Maxton Walker (age 30).
fields.body:
Hollywood has a tendency to airbrush its more cringe-making moments from history. Take the 70s sci-fi camp classic, Logan's Run. Have you ever tried to get hold of it? The bloke in HMV just laughed at me when I tried to buy it at the weekend. And the woman in the rental shop went one better: she hadn't even heard of it.

But sometimes - just sometimes - tinseltown knows when to give a film a second chance. Which is why the action-movie producer Joel Silver, last week announced that he's planning a remake. And about time, too. If ever a film deserved another crack at greatness, this is it. A two-hour-long fashion disaster, it may be. But it remains (for my money, anyway) one of the most disturbing films ever made.

Logan's Run was originally a novel, published in 1967, and it spawned a number of potential screenplays. When the film finally did get greenlighted in the early 70s, the script was relatively faithful to the the novel: in the 23rd century an unnamed apocalypse has forced mankind to retreat to a sealed dome near Washington DC. However, to retain a population balance, everybody is executed on their 30th birthday. Logan is a policeman assigned to track down and kill "runners" who try to outstay their welcome. Until he too decides to make a break for freedom.

It was, and is, a superb premise for a film. And casting the impossibly beautiful Michael York as the policeman-assassin who turned rebel was inspired. But sadly, fate didn't see it that way. The makers could have won a shelf-full of awards for bad timing; red Spandex, disco music and shopping-mall sets may have seemed as visionary as it got in 1976. But the following year, Star Wars blasted onto cinema screens and sci-fi has never looked back. The dystopian visions of Logan, Soylent Green, The Omega Man and Planet Of The Apes were doomed forever to wander the cold outer reaches of late night TV. A small-screen Logan spin-off in 1978 staggered on for only 14 episodes before being cancelled.

But nobody who sees the original film ever forgets it. Which is why talk of a remake surfaces more often than rumours of a new Indiana Jones film. Last year, word had it that - surprise, surprise - Leonardo DiCaprio was ready to squeeze into Logan's cat-suit. The same story suggested that the termination age would be lowered to 21 - a potentially catastrophic decision. Make the cut-off point 20 or 40 and it just doesn't work. Thirty is a bizarre age; enough to have lived some sort of life. But not a full one. That's what gave the film its bite.

The film critic, Mark Cousins, once said everybody should make a point of watching Logan's Run on their 30th birthday. I'd go further. It's a film everybody should watch twice - once on each side of the big three-oh. Those who do tend to find two different films. I now find it far less disturbing that I had before turning 30. Twentysomethings see a nasty and brutish horror story. The rest of us can see it for what it is: a parable on the waste of not being allowed the dignity of growing old.

But as the film looks more and more dated, its message seems increasingly relevant. In 1976, a typical 30-year-old bloke would be married with kids and inching his way up some corporate ladder. Not any more. Thanks to rampant consumerism, adolescence now extends into our 20s and youth into our 30s. A marketing man's dream. More time to flog us CDs, exotic holidays and hi-fis before we start pumping money into pension plans, home extensions and children.

None of this could have occurred to the film-makers. They were taking a crack at the legacy of the 60s, or rather the twin devils of drugs and free love. The message was clear: if you're going to carry on this way, kids, what's the point of living beyond 30?

But it's the rise of e-commerce and the teenage multi-millionaires that's really changed the landscape. Now people really can have it all by their 20s. Once, only athletes and footballers were clapped out at 30. Nowadays, everybody out of their 20s has to look over their shoulder. Just how long until a millionaire teen-boss is going to walk through the door? Thirty really might be the the beginning of the end.

I can't wait for the remake. There's an entire audience of post thirtysomethings out there ready to be reminded that - despite what we're told every day - there's nothing wrong with growing older. And it's good to be reminded that the cult of youth - although exciting - is only that. A cult. Fifteen-year-old net entrepreneurs may not have realised it yet, but nobody can avoid the inevitable. If you're in your mid-20s, keep one eye on your local multiplex. You might wake up in couple of years to find it showing a movie that will really make you squirm in your seat.

The clock is always ticking.
