fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: The Reith Lectures | Night Waves
fields.body:
Sir John Browne, chief executive of the oil giant BP-Amoco, argues in the third of The Reith Lectures (8.0pm, Radio 4) that enlightened self-interest will dictate that industry actively safeguards the environment. Though large companies are neither democratic nor accountable, Sir John says they have to support sustainable development. Business is not about doing one-off, short-term deals. For their own survival, successful companies must interest themselves in the long-term future of the planet.

Though it is 27 years since it pulled out of the Vietnam War, America's 50,000 dead ensure that the conflict continues to pervade political and cultural life. Bill Clinton's draft-dodging was a persistent theme in his presidential campaigns, and George W Bush has had a hard time justifying his posting in the Texas National Guard. And, as Sarah Dunant ponders in Night Waves (9.30pm, Radio 3) there is the continuing flood of films and books about the war.

webTitle: Jerusalem: home to the invisible people

fields.headline: Jerusalem: home to the invisible people
fields.standfirst:
Thousands of Palestinians are being denied residency rights

Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Thousands of Palestinians are being denied residency rights
fields.body:
With his huge dark eyes and a smile full of mischief, five-year-old Faress Nasser is impossible to ignore as he plays in the family's living room. Officially, though, he does not exist.

When Faress was born in Jerusalem on April 15 1995, the hospital refused to issue a birth certificate, arguing that his mother, Dina Khoury, no longer had the right to reside in the city where she was born. The authorities in the West Bank, under Palestinian control, also refused to register Faress's birth, rendering him a non-person.

Faress's parents, Dina and Youssef Nasser - born in the West Bank but raised in San Francisco - married in 1984 after meeting in London. The couple returned to live in Jerusalem and in 1987 Ms Khoury applied to the Israeli authorities for her husband to live with her. As a US citizen, Mr Nasser could only stay in Jerusalem on tourist visas.

In the years that followed, Ms Khoury's encounters with bureaucracy included the deportation of her husband in 1990.

"Until now I joke that if I knew I would have been in this misery for 15 years, I do not know if I would marry Yousef," she says.

Ever since Israel occupied the eastern portion of Jerusalem after the 1967 war, Palestinian existence in the city has been a precarious affair.

Israeli historians say Israeli rule over Jerusalem has been guided by a demographic imperative, with Israel determined to maintain the balance that existed in 1967, when Jews accounted for 78% of the population.

To preserve that majority, the Israeli authorities initiated a range of restrictions on residency rights in the city.

The beginning of the peace process in 1993 only made matters worse. "This all became part of the battle of Jerusalem," says Barry Zinn, the human rights lawyer who is representing Ms Khoury.

A Jerusalem identity card carries tremendous advantages: medical insurance, family allowance, pensions and other social benefits.

Most important of all, it offers freedom. For example, Mr Nasser is legally bound to leave the city by 10pm each night, and if he should drive his wife's car, with yellow Israeli plates, it would be an offence under Israeli security regulations.

At the office of the ministry of interior in east Jerusalem, applicants line up from 2am each day. Places at the front of the line trade for $250. "People can kill for a Jerusalem ID card, you have so many advantages. There is not a single advantage to having a West Bank card," says Amir Cheshin, an author and former adviser to Jerusalem's mayor for nearly three decades, Teddy Kollek.

Human rights activists say many thousands of people lost their residency rights in Jerusalem unknowingly. Ms Khoury lost hers in 1996 in a response to multiple requests to have her husband, Yousef Nassar, join her.

"That day I cried because I thought I am 38 years old, and I don't exist," she says. "I still pay municipality bills, the phone bill is in my name. I felt like screaming: 'I do exist'."

Last month, the interior minister, Natan Sharansky, announced that Jerusalem residents stripped of their ID cards could apply for their restoration. The move is in response to a two-year court battle by an Israeli human rights organisation.

But it could still be many months before Dina and thousands of others win their rights back. Many may simply be afraid to come forward for fear of alerting the authorities to their twilight status.

"The fact that we have a major victory does not mean we should not lose sight of the fragile status of these people," said Eliahu Abram of HaMoked, which led the legal challenge. "They have a status that can evaporate overnight."

webTitle: Bruch still No 1 in classic hall of fame

fields.headline: Bruch still No 1 in classic hall of fame
fields.trailText: Bruch pipped Rachmaninov, with Beethoven breathing heavily down Mozart's neck ahead of a promising newcomer called The Mikado, in Classic FM's hall of fame yesterday.
fields.body:
Bruch pipped Rachmaninov, with Beethoven breathing heavily down Mozart's neck ahead of a promising newcomer called The Mikado, in Classic FM's hall of fame yesterday.

The station's now traditional Easter music marathon ended with Max Bruch's violin concerto beating another plangent masterpiece, Rachmaninov's piano concerto, for the fifth year running.

But the margin of listeners' votes is narrowing, with the Rachmaninov's supporters getting a boost with every television repeat of the film Brief Encounter, which his theme dominates.

Mozart's clarinet concerto was third in the top 2,000 for the third year running. Lower down the listings the impact of television and film exposure on the light classical electorate was stark.

The Ashokan Farewell, written by the little-known American folk musician and composer Jay Ungar, headed a list of 20 new entrants. Ungar made his debut in the poll in 100th place.

Classic FM believes this is because his melody was the Grammy award-winning soundtrack to the hit television series The American Civil War, which was shown in Britain at the end of last year.

A more veteran debut was by Sir Arthur Sullivan, whose operetta scores made him one of the richest and most famous composers in the world in the late 19th century.

Sullivan's The Mikado reached the top 2,000 for the first time at number 295. This was " thanks in no small part" - Classic FM said - to the Gilbert and Sullivan revival brought about by Mike Leigh's Oscar-winning film Topsy Turvy. His admirers mark the 100th anniversary of Sullivan's death later this year.

The impact of the Disney corporation's badly reviewed remake of the film Fantasia was also notable. It brought big rises for Shostakovich's piano concerto No 2 (up from 38 to 26) and Gershwin's Rhapsody in Blue, up from 76 to 49.

By contrast, the effects of a drop in high-profile exposure for a piece of music can be dramatic. John Tavener's Song for Athene, made famous at the funeral of Diana, Princess of Wales three years ago, has dropped 96 places from 123 to 219 since last year.

Beethoven hogged seventh, eighth and ninth place - as he does virtually every year with his Pastoral Symphony, Ode to Joy and Emperor Concerto. With 20 entries in the chart, he is closing the gap on the overall favourite composer, Mozart, who has 23 entries.

The less glamorous Bach, the composer whom Mozart called "father of classical music", has gained from publicity for this year's 250th anniversary of his death.

Bach's Goldberg Variations has risen 84 places from 271 to 187 and the St Matthew Passion has "jumped" - as Classic FM put it - by 52 places from 107 to 55.

Millennium top 20

1 Bruch Violin Concerto No. 1 in G minor Op.26

2 Rachmaninov Piano Concerto No. 2 in C minor

3 Mozart Clarinet Concerto in A

The station's now traditional Easter music marathon ended with Max Bruch's violin concerto beating another plangent masterpiece, Rachmaninov's piano concerto, for the fifth year running. But the margin of listeners' votes is narrowing, with the Rachmaninov's supporters getting a boost with every television repeat of the film Brief Encounter, which his theme dominates. Mozart's clarinet concerto was third in the top 2,000 for the third year running. Lower down the listings the impact of television and film exposure on the light classical electorate was stark. The Ashokan Farewell, written by the little-known American folk musician and composer Jay Ungar, headed a list of 20 new entrants. Ungar made his debut in the poll in 100th place. Classic FM believes this is because his melody was the Grammy award-winning soundtrack to the hit television series The American Civil War, which was shown in Britain at the end of last year. A more veteran debut was by Sir Arthur Sullivan, whose operetta scores made him one of the richest and most famous composers in the world in the late 19th century. Sullivan's The Mikado reached the top 2,000 for the first time at number 295. This was " thanks in no small part" - Classic FM said - to the Gilbert and Sullivan revival brought about by Mike Leigh's Oscar-winning film Topsy Turvy. His admirers mark the 100th anniversary of Sullivan's death later this year. The impact of the Disney corporation's badly reviewed remake of the film Fantasia was also notable. It brought big rises for Shostakovich's piano concerto No 2 (up from 38 to 26) and Gershwin's Rhapsody in Blue, up from 76 to 49. By contrast, the effects of a drop in high-profile exposure for a piece of music can be dramatic. John Tavener's Song for Athene, made famous at the funeral of Diana, Princess of Wales three years ago, has dropped 96 places from 123 to 219 since last year. Beethoven hogged seventh, eighth and ninth place - as he does virtually every year with his Pastoral Symphony, Ode to Joy and Emperor Concerto. With 20 entries in the chart, he is closing the gap on the overall favourite composer, Mozart, who has 23 entries. The less glamorous Bach, the composer whom Mozart called "father of classical music", has gained from publicity for this year's 250th anniversary of his death. webTitle: Fathers win equality in widow's benefits payout

fields.headline: Fathers win equality in widow's benefits payout
fields.trailText: Two fathers who fought for the benefits awarded to widowed mothers bringing up children alone have each won about £12,000 and the right to receive the benefits in future.
fields.body:
Two fathers who fought for the benefits awarded to widowed mothers bringing up children alone have each won about £12,000 and the right to receive the benefits in future.

David Cornwell and John Leary tried to claim the widowed mother's allowance, which is worth about £85 a week, and a one-off widow's payment of £1,000, when they were left to care for their young children after the death of their wives. But the benefits agency told them that the benefits were reserved for women whose husbands had died.

The two men took their case to the European court of human rights in Strasbourg, which announced yesterday that the UK government had agreed to a "friendly settlement" of their cases. The men will get the equivalent of the widow's payment and widowed mother's allowance backdated to when they claimed.

After a campaign by widowed fathers, the government agreed to alter the law in the Welfare Reform and Pensions Act 1999 to provide for a widowed parent's allowance payable to parents of either sex. That provision of the act will not come into force for at least another year, but the government has agreed to pay the men in the meantime.

The government has agreed to pay Mr Cornwell, from Cambridgeshire, who was left with an 18-month-old son when his wife died in 1989, £11,904.60, covering weekly payments backdated to February 1997. Mr Leary, of Hertfordshire, will receive £12,226.20, representing payments backdated to May 1997, when he claimed the benefits after his wife died aged 37, leaving daughters aged 10, seven and three.

Humphrey Woods, who set up the Campaign for Widowed Fathers' Benefits after his wife's death in 1990, said he and another father, Kevin Willis, who also have cases at the Strasbourg court, were holding out for the right to receive the equal of a widow's pension and other benefits. Mr Woods, from Bristol, has a daughter, Daisy, aged nine, whose mother, Lin, died of a heart attack six days after her birth. He is only now about to return to work after retraining as an educational support assistant. "I've received nothing at all. I've lost something like £30,000 to £35,000 over the last nine years," he said.

Mr Willis gave up work as a field service engineer to nurse his wife, Marlene, before she died of cancer in 1996, aged 38, and to look after his daughter, then aged seven, and son, then five. His wife had been the family's main breadwinner.

The widowed mother's allowance, which is not means-tested, dates back 50 years to a time when almost all women were supported by their husbands. But the wives of the men who took their cases to Strasbourg had paid years of national insurance contributions. The fathers claimed that the government had discriminated against them by failing, on the grounds of their sex, to guarantee their right to enjoy a family life.

fields.headline: Please, play something else
fields.standfirst: For the fifth year running, Max Bruch has topped Classic FM's Hall of Fame poll.  Andrew Clements can't stand it any more
fields.trailText: For the fifth year running, Max Bruch has topped Classic FM's Hall of Fame poll. Andrew Clements can't stand it any more.
fields.body:
Where does one start with Classic FM's Hall of Fame, already unveiled in a 45-hour radio marathon over Easter, and now sanctified in book form as A Buyer's Guide to the Best Classical CDs? Asking Classic FM's listeners to vote for their favourite pieces based upon the music that has been broadcast on the network over the past year is the kind of election process New Labour ought to admire. If you spoonfeed your audience a pappy diet of light classics and bite-sized chunks of larger works, all seasoned with the odd bit of cross-over, and then get them to vote for their favourites, the result is more or less a foregone conclusion. Pavlov couldn't have conditioned his salivating dogs any more effectively.

Without wishing to continue the suspense any longer, I can reveal that the winner this time, as it has been every year since the poll began in 1996, was Bruch's Violin Concerto No 1, with Rachmaninov's Second Piano Concerto as the runner-up. Both are undeniably fine works (though Bruch's Second Violin Concerto is actually a better piece than his first), with the right quota of big, succulent tunes to conform to the popular stereotype of "classical" music as heavily romantic and emotionally undemanding. It might relax you or stir you (see below) but it doesn't make you think. It is no surprise that 55 per cent of the 300 works honoured in this hall of fame come from the 19th century, for it is through this romantic lingua franca that the second half of the 20th century turned a debased form of classical music into a commodity, which is now exploited just as much by Classic FM as by the film and advertising industries.

Not content with its main list of winners - James Horner's score for Titanic is in at 75, Michael Nyman's music for The Piano at 291, just nosing ahead of Verdi's Otello - the guide reels off all manner of subsidiary lists. So we have the top conductors, the top pianists and even the top record labels; the top 20 "relaxing classics" (Bruch and Rachmaninov lead that category too), and top 20 "stirring classics" (Elgar takes the first two spots there, with the Cello Concerto and the Enigma Variations).

Bizet's The Pearl Fishers comes out as number one opera, closely followed by Mascagni's Cavalleria Rusticana and Verdi's Nabucco: in each case, surely, on the basis of one famous lollipop. Similarly because of its orchestral "Méditation" (more masturbation than meditation if you take a close look at the story), Massenet's Thaïs gets in at number six, one ahead of the Marriage of Figaro. All nothing to do with opera as such, and everything to do with sound-bite broadcasting.

It's the kind of nonsense that could charitably be dismissed as harmless if it were not for the fact that, like the classical Brit awards (also sponsored by Classic FM), there is something profoundly meretricious and self-serving about the whole thing. My real gripe isn't the fatuousness of it all - though that is pretty hard to stomach - but the fact that the whole exercise seems designed to confirm in-built prejudices rather than to extend anyone's horizons. If all the "classical music" someone knows is Bruch's First Violin Concerto and Rachmaninov's Second Piano Concerto, then they will be reassured to find that these, according to Classic FM, are the "best" works, and they won't be encouraged to explore any further.

As well as listing the "top" recorded versions for each of the 300 entries (some of those truly bizarre choices in themselves), the guide does contain recommendations of the "if- you-like-this-then-try" variety. But these appear to be so randomly selected that they aren't going to get anyone very far. If you like Beethoven's Pastoral Symphony, for instance, then you are encouraged to listen to Mendelssohn's Fourth Symphony, whereas admirers of Rachmaninov's Third Piano Concerto will be mystifyingly directed towards Shostakovich's Second.

Classic FM isn't all bad. Not everything it puts out is aimed as relentlessly at the lowest common denominator as this, which flatters its audience by canonising their tastes while doing little to develop them further - the "I know what I like and I like what I know" position dressed up as an aesthetic critique. Pierre Boulez was once asked why he insisted on conducting "difficult" music, instead of giving audiences what they wanted to hear. Only prostitutes, he replied, always give their clients what they want. Perhaps Classic FM should ponder on that.  A Buyer's Guide to the Best Classical CDs is published by Virgin on Thursday, priced £16.99.

webTitle: 'It's easier to bring a Belgian play to London than a Scottish one'

fields.headline: 'It's easier to bring a Belgian play to London than a Scottish one'
fields.standfirst: Playwright David Greig talks to  Brian Logan about the north-south divide
fields.trailText: Playwright David Greig talks to Brian Logan about the north-south divide.
fields.body:
How will David Greig play to English audiences? It should be a daft question. Greig has written a string of hit plays - Europe, The Architect, Cal-edonia Dreaming - for Scotland's most distinguished theatres and for the zeitgeisty experimental ensemble he co-runs, Suspect Culture. At 31, he is the most eye-catching of a mini-movement of fine young dramatists north of the border. He is the most productive, too, premiering seven new works in the last year, culminating in last month's tartan Oedipus for Glasgow's Tramway.

Greig, whose work is performed all over Europe, blames funding anomalies for his low profile in England. "It's easier to bring a Belgian production to London than a Scottish one," he says. When Victoria, his first play for the Royal Shakespeare Company, opens this week, southern audiences should be as approving as their Caledonian counterparts.

But wait - there's the mystery of The Speculator to consider. Greig's epic historical drama about the Scots banker and exile John Law, commissioned by and performed at last year's Edinburgh festival, provoked a veritable broadsheet Bannockburn, polarising critics along national lines. While the Scots praised it as "stunningly original" and "as absorbing as it is visionary", reviewers visiting from London (the Guardian's Michael Billington excepted) growlingly called it "ponderous, pretentious and shambolic" and "disastrously dull".

"It bamboozled me," says Greig, who talks to me an hour before the opening preview of his new play. "I would read the English papers calling The Speculator a flop, and yet my perception of it was that I'd never had a bigger hit. I was sold out at the biggest theatre in Edinburgh, I had peer-group approval from the Scottish theatre community, people coming up to me in the street..."

So what soured the Sassenachs? Unlike Irn Bru and The Proclaimers, Greig is not Scotland-specific: his work - dreamy but guttural conceptual dramas whose characters' lives insistently overlap - reflects his country's concerns, but not exclusively. (In a spirit of accessibility, he has just axed from Victoria a football quip about the 1978 World Cup that would have 'em rolling in the aisles north of Berwick). What is most likely is that the English critics of The Speculator had a festival-bashing agenda and the Scots a tub-thumping one: the production was neither as bad nor as grand as either claimed. Still, the play is undeniably a cracker. Like much of Greig's work, it offers up variations on a theme, teasing an idea - in this case, that capitalism, like love, depends on blind faith - into innumerable theatrical shapes.

Victoria, too, is an inquest into belief - or the absence of it. "I think by the end of the century, something had changed about the way we believed in things, certainly in the west," says Greig. "The question in my head was: what was the nature of that change?" This is surprising. The play - another epic, surveying life in a coastal village from 1936 through 1976 to 1996 - seems only peripherally concerned with the withering of ideology. True, it employs the Spanish civil war as a yardstick for an idealism that we have lost. But the politics are subsumed by a strong spirituality - familiar in Greig's work - rooted here in the omnipresence of history and in the indomitable Scottish landscape.

One character in Victoria, when asked, "Are you a communist?" replies, "I am, sort of." Greig seems to relish the obfuscation. I ask him the same question, and he too hums and hahs, before answering, circumspectly, "I'm definitely of the left." The dithering will hardly endear him to his critics, who have accused Greig, along with contemporaries Stephen Greenhorn and David Harrower, of diluting the Scottish stage's working-class tradition.

"The trouble with Scottish theatre," Greig sighs, "is that it's so small that two writers make a trend. It's quite an easy thing for Scots to define the working class solely as Scottish and the middle or upper class as British or English. But Edinburgh is a city with a large and extremely powerful middle class. That's engaged with in my theatre and I'd never apologise for that."

Bourgeois pride notwithstanding, Victoria toys with some of Scottish agitprop's favourite concerns - in its treatment of the 70s oil rush, it echoes John McGrath's bolshie classic The Cheviot, the Stag and the Black, Black Oil. More topically, the play - one of whose characters makes a mint quarrying a mountain - reflects the recent stramash surrounding the Highland toff who is trying to sell off the mighty Cuillins peaks on Skye, which he reckons he owns. It could only happen in Scotland - a land divvied into fiefdoms between fading rockers and loopy absentee lairds.

Greig is sensitive to the Scottish debate about ownership and conservation - though his take on the matter is ambivalent. "I like the idea that great chunks of Scotland are wilderness, I like to walk in those chunks, I believe that the nation should own that land, absolutely. But once you start writing and other voices come in to play, you start to question that... I was in the Basque country in Spain, and the landscape looks very like the Highlands, except that there were houses everywhere, there were people everywhere. You then have to question, is this a spoiled landscape or is it a populated landscape? Which is more important: people or hills?" In Greig's reading, the 20th century represents a journey from communitarianism through individualism to environmentalism, a creed that has "gone beyond the individual, to a point where humans themselves are regarded as problematic".

Victoria weaves these ideas deftly into a story of three generations' attraction to and repulsion from one stretch of Scottish coast. As in so much of the nation's literature, emigration is the great panacea. "The advantage of being Scottish," Greig wrote in The Speculator, "is that there's always somewhere better to go." It is tempting to attribute this recurring motif to Greig's biography: he grew up in Nigeria, studied in Bristol, and speaks without a Scots accent. "I certainly feel that if you live in Scotland but speak like I do, if you live in Scotland and work in theatre, you can't help but be ambivalent about it. To be honest, I think if you live in Scotland at all you can't help but be ambivalent."

Greig could easily leave. He is under commission to the National and the Royal Court. Recognition in England - even from its critics - seems on its way. But Scotland pulls him back, because he is helping to create something new in the national culture. "If you exclude entertainment and music hall and talk just about the writing of plays, we are at a very young stage in that tradition. There's an excitement about that," says Greig - an excitement reflected in the current proposals for a Scottish national theatre. He dreams of the day Scotland has a repertoire of classic plays to call its own - indeed, it is a day he seems determined to precipitate, single-handedly. The ambition accords with what Greig describes as Victoria's preoccupation: "My plays resonate very strongly with the belief," he says, "that we can become more than we feel that we are."

 Victoria is at the Pit, the Barbican, London EC1 (020-7638 8891) till May 13.

Recognition in England - even from its critics - seems on its way. But Scotland pulls him back, because he is helping to create something new in the national culture. "If you exclude entertainment and music hall and talk just about the writing of plays, we are at a very young stage in that tradition. There's an excitement about that," says Greig - an excitement reflected in the current proposals for a Scottish national theatre. He dreams of the day Scotland has a repertoire of classic plays to call its own - indeed, it is a day he seems determined to precipitate, single-handedly. The ambition accords with what Greig describes as Victoria's preoccupation: "My plays resonate very strongly with the belief," he says, "that we can become more than we feel that we are."  Victoria is at the Pit, the Barbican, London EC1 (020-7638 8891) till May 13.

fields.headline: Naked, but not revealed
fields.trailText: Directed by Gough Lewis, Sex: The Annabel Chong Story purports to investigate the life and personality of Singapore-born Grace Quek, best known to her public as porn star Annabel Chong. But it tells us next to nothing about the LA porn industry, or about the mercurial Grace/Annabel.
fields.body:
Even after 87 minutes' close observation, I know next to nothing about Grace Quek - and that's after seeing her arguing with her mother, debating at the Cambridge Union, slashing her arm and having sex with 251 men. How intimate does a documentary portrait have to be before it actually succeeds in revealing its subject?

Directed by Gough Lewis, Sex: The Annabel Chong Story purports to investigate the life and personality of Singapore-born Grace Quek, best known to her public as porn star Annabel Chong. At best it lays out a confused jigsaw of TV clips, footage of Quek's daily round, interviews with her friends, family and associates, and glimpses of her 251-man porn shoot. But it tells us next to nothing about the LA porn industry, or about the mercurial Grace/Annabel - except that she is intelligent, articulate but hugely troubled, and that she has a whole arsenal of wigs under which to hide her true identity.

Quek's refusal to cohere as a subject is contingent on the fact that there's apparently no one looking at her: director Lewis is curiously absent, as either a character or as an invisible shaping intelligence. But he apparently was a character in her story: in interviews, Quek has denounced him for failing to reveal that he was her lover for a year during the making of Sex, something the film never even implies. That omission contributes to making the film incomplete, if not actually dishonest. But there are other ways in which Lewis's participation as film-maker remains unclear.

He is apparently present in a concrete sense: that is presumably him behind the camera in the Quek family kitchen in Singapore, during a heart-rending row between Grace and her conservative mother, who has only just learned about the existence of Annabel. If the scene feels intrusive, that's because Lewis has failed to establish the conditions which would make it watchable. In theory, we can stand to watch practically anything in documentary, as long as we have an implicit understanding of what sort of contract is implied between film-maker and subject on one hand, and film-maker and audience on the other.

Sometimes, the very fact that a camera crew is present justifies the footage. The subjects clearly understand that they are being filmed and will eventually be watched by strangers. But the fact that a documentary can now be shot by a single-person crew transforms the traditional authority of the form. In Sex, we feel that the Quek family row is being witnessed not by the public eye, but by some private guy - someone who has simply blundered into the kitchen with his camcorder.

But whatever the machinery, the pact behind an intimate docu- portraits is often very simple - the film-maker wants to make the film, the subject wants to be seen. This implied contract makes it legitimate for the film-maker to delve into areas that might otherwise seem off-limits, and it holds whether a film is dealing with exhibitionists or recluses. The camera's presence in Kirby Dick's film Sick gives the exuberant, and slowly dying, S&M performance artist Bob Flanagan a shot at posterity: it lets him show the world his fight against cystic fibrosis, not to mention his alarming nail-through-penis performance. Terry Zwigoff's film Crumb gives artist Robert Crumb and his disturbed brothers an opportunity for group psychotherapy, something they may never have attempted before there was a camera present to watch it.

Here's the paradox: if a film works, then its underlying contract is clearly understood, even if it is never explicitly stated; and if its contract is understood, then the film works. That's the trouble with Sex - if only Gough Lewis were a more accomplished storyteller, then we would have a clearer sense of what's going on between him as a film-maker and Grace Quek as a subject. As it is, we can't quite understand how either of them benefits from the investigation, and we are left piecing together the disparate bits of the Annabel Chong puzzle, wondering just what the deal really is.

 Sex: The Annabel Chong Story is on release.

fields.headline: David Jones
fields.standfirst: British car designer who created the classic 1950s Bedford van
fields.trailText: The car designer David Jones, who has died aged 90, entered the motor industry at the moment when the "engineered" appearance of the motor car was giving way to the more intuitive "styling" approach. He was Vauxhall's director of styling from 1934-71, the longest-ever occupation of the design executive's chair in the motor industry.
fields.body:
The car designer David Jones, who has died aged 90, entered the motor industry at the moment when the "engineered" appearance of the motor car was giving way to the more intuitive "styling" approach. He was Vauxhall's director of styling from 1934-71, the longest-ever occupation of the design executive's chair in the motor industry.

It was the beginning of industrial design in the service of the postwar competitive market and the production of motor cars for mass consumption. Its luminaries included General Motors' Harley Earl in Detroit, and it was with Earl that Jones served his apprenticeship in 1937. His training as a sculptor informed the appearance of the Vauxhalls of the 1950s, mostly remembered now through the retrospective lens of pop art - notably their spacecraft imagery, tail fins, wrap-around windscreens and the grinning chromium-plated teeth of the Cresta and the Wyvern. However, Jones' most lasting contribution was the Bedford van, later customised into the Dormobile. This is the vehicle which appears in Alan Bennett's The Lady in the Van, a testament to the good taste of his character, Miss Shepherd, and to Jones' talent.

Jones was born in Birmingham; his father was a manufacturer of agricultural machine tools and his mother a schoolteacher. He was educated privately and at Birmingham Art School, where he met his future wife, Marjorie Derricourt, who was studying painting. A talented illustrator, in 1928 Jones was awarded a scholarship to the Royal College of Art in London, where he studied illustration and sculpture and came under the influence of Henry Moore, who was teaching there.

On graduation, Jones worked briefly as an apprentice to the sculptor Barry Hart before joining Vauxhall in 1932. After the retirement of Eric Kennington, he was appointed director of styling, but his career was interrupted by the war. He was commissioned in the Royal Engineers with the rank of captain in the camouflage section, and divided his time between camouflaging airfields and working on troop carrier design at Vauxhall.

During and immediately after the war he came under the spell of Gurdjieff, his movement and John Bennett. With his reluctant family, he attended the "Movement" at Bennett's house, Combe Springs in Kingston, most weekends, with trips to Paris to visit Gurdjieff. He became briefly a spokesman for the "Movement".

The decade of the 1950s was Jones' most creative period at Vauxhall. In retrospect, there is a clear connection between the streamlined forms of motor car styling and the work of sculptors such as Moore and Hepworth. This might be seen as his particular English contribution to what was essentially an American initiative.

His design department at Luton was more like a traditional artist's studio than present-day design offices. Here cars were modelled full-size in clay. The staff wore smocks and used large wooden sweeps to shape the material. The connection with Harley Earl and the Tech Centre in Detroit, where he was a frequent visitor, was also influential: Vauxhall is GM's British subsidiary.

In commercial vehicle design, Jones made a lasting contribution. The snub-nosed Bedford vans, with their innovative sliding doors, and the dropped front three-quarter window Bedford trucks were two of his inventions.

Publicly, Jones was an attractive and humorous man; privately he was more introspective and withdrawn. Following a near-fatal car accident in 1967, he retired prematurely and lived quietly in Hertfordshire until his death. He became a Fellow of the Royal Society in 1953, and his work for Vauxhall was exhibited in the Festival of Britain in 1951.

His wife predeceased him in 1995, and he is survived by his daughter, Sonia, and his son, Edward.

fields.headline: Alexander Cohen
fields.standfirst: The New York theatre producer who brought Beyond the Fringe to Broadway
fields.trailText: Alexander H Cohen, who has died aged 79, was a Broadway producer of the old school: he knew when to quit. When he fielded Angela Lansbury as a mental institution inmate in a musical titled Prettybelle, which featured songs like When I'm Drunk I'm Beautiful, he realised it was too wacky even for 1970s New York audiences and closed it in Boston.
fields.body:
Alexander H Cohen, who has died aged 79, was a Broadway producer of the old school: he knew when to quit. When he fielded Angela Lansbury as a mental institution inmate in a musical titled Prettybelle, which featured songs like When I'm Drunk I'm Beautiful, he realised it was too wacky even for 1970s New York audiences and closed it in Boston. When Jerry Lewis got out of hand in the 1977 Hellzapoppin, he put an end to that show, also in Boston.

Yet retrenchment was never the result: at the time of his death, he was planning a comedy about euthanasia titled Sweet Deliverance with an unlikely star, TV comedienne Fran Dresher. He is currently represented on Broadway by the first New York production of Noël Coward's Waiting on the Wings, starring Lauren Bacall and Rosemary Harris.

"I can owe a million, and I have," he once said, "but when I put my head on the pillow at night, it's 'Goodbye Charlie'. I get up the next morning and start all over again. I like it. Besides, I don't know how to do anything else."

Like many producers, he came into the profession with money, the son of a businessman who died when he was four and a mother who later married a banker. Known in his early years as Broadway's "millionaire boy angel", he indulged his fascination with theatre - cultivated by his uncle - by spending his family inheritance on shows, losing much until the 1941 play, Angel Street, which starred Vincent Price and became the film Gaslight.

Since Cohen's track record did nothing to disprove the long-held notion that no more than a third of Broadway shows make money, he sensibly hung on to his "day job", which was director of advertising and publicity for the Bulova watch company. As his producing life gathered momentum, he went beyond plays, originating the annual spring Tony Award telecast in 1967, which has become a significant factor in the nationalisation of Broadway-style entertainment.

He also produced numerous TV specials in collaboration with his wife, the writer/actress Hildy Parks. His 101 theatre productions included a number of West End efforts, such as Arthur Miller's The Price, Neil Simon's Plaza Suite and Terence Rattigan's Man and Boy. Back home, he tried to raise the brow of Broadway with Hamlet, starring Richard Burton under the direction of John Gielgud, King Lear directed by John Houseman, Beyond the Fringe with Jonathan Miller and, more recently, The Herbal Bed, a British import which didn't repeat the success in New York that it experienced in London.

Cohen's hit musicals were unorthodox: Peter Brook's La Tragédie de Carmen (1983), Richard Rodgers' last musical I Remember Mama (1979) and the Tommy Tune confection A Day in Hollywood/A Night in the Ukraine (1980). He also accumulated a high-toned list of enemies, including Lewis, his ruthless fellow producer David Merrick and Marlene Dietrich, whose concerts he produced.

A few things he could never live down: bad Broadway musicals come and mostly go, but he had a hand in the building and running of one of the most charmless and problematic venues in North America, Toronto's O'Keefe Center, which opened in 1960 with the famous but troubled musical Camelot. (The show's agonised gestation was made worse by the auditorium's teething problems.)

In more recent years, Cohen could claim responsibility for Stamford, Connecticut's Rich Forum, which proved to be infinitely more congenial. He also turned down a chance to invest in Cats and refused to have any of his theatre posters sold in the Disney store on 42nd Street.

Thanks to his colourful personality, he occasionally stepped out from behind the scenes: he played a theatre producer in Woody Allen's The Purple Rose of Cairo, and performed Star Billing, a one-man show - albeit off-Broadway - of his reminiscences two years ago. His memoirs, Sold Out!, were published in 1993.

He is survived by his wife, two sons, and a daughter.

fields.headline: Joe Kayll
fields.standfirst: Fighter ace and POW escaper
fields.trailText: The Royal Air Force fighter pilot Joe Kayll, who has died aged 85, led a fighting retreat from northern France during the British withdrawal in spring 1940, flew in the Battle of Britain, and as a prisoner of war helped organise the "wooden horse" breakout.
fields.body:
The Royal Air Force fighter pilot Joe Kayll, who has died aged 85, led a fighting retreat from northern France during the British withdrawal in spring 1940, flew in the Battle of Britain, and as a prisoner of war helped organise the "wooden horse" breakout.

Born in Sunderland and educated at Aysgarth and Stowe, he entered the family timber business but, inspired by flying, he joined the Royal Auxiliary Air Force in 1934. Commissioned, he learned to fly with 607 "County of Durham" Squadron, using Wapiti and Hart biplanes. By early 1939, Kayll was a Flight-Commander in 607 Squadron, which now flew Gladiator biplane fighters.

In November 1939, Kayll's squadron was posted to France. The following March, he became commander of 615 "County of Surrey" Squadron flying obsolete Gladiators. On May 10, the German offensive against the low countries and France began, and 615 Squadron, caught re-equipping with Hurricane 1 fighters, was involved in the intensive air fighting.

Kayll nourished 615's fighting spirit by flying up to seven sorties a day from improvised airfields with a mixture of Hurricanes and Gladiators. The squadron inflicted heavy losses on the Luftwaffe while the German army continually overran the squadron's forward airfields. On May 15, Kayll, flying a Hurricane, shot down two Messerschmidt Bf 110 twin-engined fighters, and on May 20 destroyed a Heinkel 111 bomber. The next day, 615's surviving pilots flew back to Kenley, south of London. By mid-June, 615 had regrouped, and it resumed operations against Luftwaffe-occupied airfields in France.

Kayll was awarded the DSO and DFC, and during the Battle of Britain he shot down a Messerschmidt Bf 109E fighter and Do 17 and He 111 bombers. This was in a ferocious seven-day period, which started on August 18.

In late September, the exhausted 615 Squadron was moved to Prestwick to regroup. It was credited with 97 German aircraft destroyed. Kayll's score was seven and one shared destroyed, seven unconfirmed destroyed and six damaged. In October, 615 returned to defend London against German fighter-bomber attacks.

In June 1941, after six months at Fighter Command HQ, Kayll returned to operations as a wing-commander flying with the famous Hornchurch Wing, operating three Spitfire squadrons. Fighter Command was mounting numerous sweeps over France and he flew in several "Circus" operations, which involved a small number of bombers, heavily escorted by fighters, to draw the Luftwaffe into battle.

On June 25, Kayll, while flying with his section near St Omer, was shot down, captured and sent first to Spangenberg Castle POW camp, and later to Wartburg, from which he escaped during the great breakout of September 1942.

He was recaptured and sent to Stalag Luft III at Sargan, Silesia, location of the "wooden horse" escape. Other short-term escapes followed until the Great Escape of March 1944. But after the Gestapo shot 50 allied airmen, all escape plans ceased.

Kayll was awarded an OBE for his escape activities, and was demobilised in 1946. He rejoined the Royal Auxiliary Air Force, commanding 607 Squadron, and also re-entered the family business, which he later ran with his two sons.

Kayll had strong county loyalties and served both as deputy lieutenant of Durham and as a JP. He founded Sunderland Yacht Club, and was a president of the Wear Boating Association.

He leaves a wife, Annette, and two sons.

fields.headline: No: 1623
fields.standfirst: Boy George
fields.trailText: Boy George.
fields.body:
Age: Fast approaching 40, a distinguished age to get involved in politics. Just look at Glenda Jackson and Martin Bell.

That's all very well, but aren't we talking about Boy George here: Culture Club frontman, one-time heroin addict and cross-dresser? The very same. The popstar turned DJ has been booked as a panellist on the BBC's Question Time, a slot more usually reserved for political big wigs and the like.

So when did the karma chameleon start cultivating an interest in politics? Early on in his career he was christened Lieutenant Lush by Malcolm McLaren, pop svengali and sometime political activist, and then there was that War is Stupid song.

A bit tenuous. There's no other reason he's on the show? Well, he's been quite outspoken against Clause 28. Which reminds me, Brian Souter, Stagecoach millionaire and vehement pro-Clause 28 campaigner will be a guest on the same show.

That's more like it. Do I detect a little stirring on the part of the BBC? Apparently it's sheer coincidence - Souter couldn't make an earlier date.

Why the sudden influx of celebs? Perhaps David Dimbleby sees himself as another Parky. Critics have accused the show's producers of dumbing it down and the Tory culture spokesman, Peter Ainsworth, has accused Question Time of suffering from an identity crisis.

So how will Souter cope with sharing the stage with a gay icon? Shouldn't be too much of a problem. Boy George spent most of the 80s playing down his homosexuality. This reached its zenith when he appeared on the late Russell Harty's chat show and said he'd prefer to have a nice cup of tea than sex.

Don't say: War is Stupid is the stupidest song I've ever heard.

That's all very well, but aren't we talking about Boy George here: Culture Club frontman, one-time heroin addict and cross-dresser? The very same. The popstar turned DJ has been booked as a panellist on the BBC's Question Time, a slot more usually reserved for political big wigs and the like. So when did the karma chameleon start cultivating an interest in politics? Early on in his career he was christened Lieutenant Lush by Malcolm McLaren, pop svengali and sometime political activist, and then there was that War is Stupid song. A bit tenuous. Which reminds me, Brian Souter, Stagecoach millionaire and vehement pro-Clause 28 campaigner will be a guest on the same show. That's more like it. Perhaps David Dimbleby sees himself as another Parky. fields.headline: BT gets the number wrong
fields.trailText: BT was embarrassed to discover yesterday that one of its services was still giving out old numbers after code and number changes were introduced over the Easter weekend - despite a £20m, three-year campaign to ensure a smooth changeover.
fields.body:
BT was embarrassed to discover yesterday that one of its services was still giving out old numbers after code and number changes were introduced over the Easter weekend - despite a £20m, three-year campaign to ensure a smooth changeover.

Customers using the 1471 caller identity service, which provides the number of the most recent incoming call, found they were still being given old codes and numbers.

The changes saw new three-digit codes and eight-figure numbers introduced in London, Cardiff, Coventry, Ports mouth, Southampton and Northern Ireland, affecting 11.5m customers.

London numbers given on the 1471 service were still being identified with the old codes - 0171 or 0181 - rather than the new 020 7 or 020 8 prefixes. Callers to mobile phones were also identified by their old numbers.

Other major telephone operators, including Cable & Wireless and Vodafone, had similar problems.

A BT spokesman blamed technical difficulties. Each telephone has a calling line identity (CLI), and these can only be changed exchange by exchange and line by line. Engineers would work on changing the CLIs at night, and BT hoped to have the problem solved within 12 weeks.

There was little sign of chaos as people returned to work after the long weekend. Chambers of commerce in Cardiff, Portsmouth, Coventry and London said they had not received a single call complaining of problems from any member.

Customers will be able to use the old codes and numbers until the beginning of August, when they will be phased out. After October 14 only the new numbers will work.

webTitle: British tourist killed by performing elephant

fields.headline: British tourist killed by performing elephant
fields.standfirst: Nurse gored to death and family injured in Thailand
fields.trailText: A British trainee nurse has been gored to death by a performing elephant in Thailand after it charged at tourists during an obedience display at an animal park.
fields.body:
A British trainee nurse has been gored to death by a performing elephant in Thailand after it charged at tourists during an obedience display at an animal park.

Friends and neighbours of Andrea Taylor said yesterday they were devastated by the loss of a "lovely, friendly girl". Ms Smith, 23, from Wigan, Greater Manchester, was on holiday with her father Geoffrey, 53, and her sister Helen, a 20-year-old technical manager.

The family were sitting in the front row of an obedience display in the Suan Nongnuch animal park at the resort of Pattaya, 90 miles south-east of Bangkok, on Monday when the bull elephant attacked.

The Foreign Office said the animal grabbed the trainer riding the elephant with its trunk and hurled him to the ground before charging at tourists in the small stone arena.

Mr Taylor, whose leg was injured in the attack, tried to shield Andrea but discovered yesterday that she had died from internal injuries in Pattaya hospital.

Several local people were also injured as they tried to bring the elephant under control and considerable damage was done to vehicles and property.

It is believed that Helen, who suffered abdominal injuries when the elephant trampled on her, has not been told of her sister's death. Both Helen and her father are said to be in a stable condition.

Neighbour and family friend Arthur Fairhurst, 72, said: "It is a terrible shock that this should happen on what was meant to be a happy family holiday.

"Geoffrey has been to Thailand three times before and this time he decided to take the girls with him."

Ms Smith was training to be a nurse in Huddersfield and her ambition was to work as a midwife in Canada. Her sister worked in Halifax and used to drive her home to Wigan at weekends. She was a keen musician and played the trombone in local brass bands.

Animal experts suggested yesterday that the elephant may have been in musth (ready to mate). Nick Ellerton, curator at Knowsley safari park, Merseyside, said: "I would liken an elephant in musth to a drunk at a disco - it allows bulls to win fights with other elephants because they are so high on testosterone they aren't scared of getting hurt.

"It's a very sad story. What has probably happened here is that either an inexperienced trainer has not realised when the animal was coming into musth, or one has decided to ignore it to make money."

According to reports, the organisers of the show have been charged by police with the reckless endangerment of life. Last month the park paid a Russian tourist 150,000 baht (£2,500) in compensation after a puma injured her arm.

Helen's housemate Michelle Barrow, a 26-year-old primary teacher, said: "Andrea was looking forward to going on holiday the most. She had never been to Thailand and I think it was the first time they had been away as a family since their mum Jacky died five years ago.

"Helen must be devastated at losing Andrea. She is going to take this very hard. They are a very close family. We all go and watch the Saints [St Helens] rugby team and Helen even rang me on Saturday to find out the score.

"Helen is an outgoing bubbly person. Andrea was a bit quieter but still a good laugh."

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: •Every so often a website of artfully simple charm created by someone prepared to share every detail of their life with an eager world catches on and becomes all the global rage. But must it inevitably be a spotty adolescent from Des moines, Iowa or a confused spinster from Tomsk?
fields.body:
Every so often a website of artfully simple charm created by someone prepared to share every detail of their life with an eager world catches on and becomes all the global rage. But must it inevitably be a spotty adolescent from Des moines, Iowa or a confused spinster from Tomsk?

No. Why shouldn't it be Ruth Gledhill, religion correspondent of the Times? My attention is drawn to www.ruthgledhill.com and it is an absolute joy.

Everything you always wanted to know about Ruth, from her ballroom dancing career with husband Andrew to a picture captioned "Ruth jumps a five-bar gate at Uttoxeter racecourse on her chestnut mare, Sadie" is here.

Of the 11 sections listed on the home page, a particular favourite is "about us and the family" which has details of the Rev Peter Gledhill, "Ruth's cousin Basil Rathbone", and "Ruth's beloved grandmother Sybil".

The miracle about this, the inaugural Diary Website of the Month, is that, although it has existed for months, I am only the 7055th visitor. But we can change that. Let's see if word of mouth and the power of email cannot make a global cult out of www.ruthgledhill.com .

It may not be much of a thank you for filling the Millennium Dome over the school holidays when the tickets were given away with a voucher for six Big Macs and a free fortnight in the Canaries, but it seems the government has done something at last for the genius responsible. A press release announces that the international Indian film awards will be held at the dome on June 24. "Speaking about the awards," reads the document from Wizcraft public relations, "Lord Pierre-Yves Gerbeau, CEO of the Millennium Dome, said ..."

Arguably his lordship's greatest achievement is making it such tremendous fun to hold a senior executive post at the dome. Some days, you even get to wave goodbye to the punters! Lord Gerbeau has instituted a Disney technique whereby senior bods line up at closing time and by the exits and thank people for coming with a cheery "Hope you had a good day!" Appearance is by rota (Lord G takes his turn, of course) and among those due to appear later this week to bid the departing a heartfelt "missing you already" are marketing chief Sholto Douglas Home and Gez Sagar, once John Prescott's spokesman. Marvellous. We all love sycophantic gimmicks lifted from third rate management training courses in Sacramento, so hats off.

With eight days to the poll, we have sold out of Oooh You Amaze Me! T-shirts (although there are a pair in my desk for Diamond brothers Andrew and Matthew, if they care to get in touch) but by way of a late mayoral election challenge, there is a special one-off cash prize of £150 for the first person who has him or herself pictured in a T-shirt while standing next to Frank Dobson, preferably with arm round the old boy. Any picture must reach us by next Wednesday, for inclusion on polling day.

Finding space in his Mail on Sunday column for a refreshing anti-EU item, Norman Tebbit mentions "Blair's favourite minister, Mandy Mandelson . . ." One hates to be proprietorial about nicknames, of course, and it's a delight to see plain "Mandy" in such widespread usage . . . but there is a point at which engaging chutzpah crosses the border into outright impertinence, and lifting the full "Mandy Mandelson" (always until now an appellation unique to this column) is it. Watch yourself, Norman, boy. You are asking for a slap.

Thanks again to BMW for the splendid car (whatever the model was, it was very quick and comfortable) they lent for a trip to northern France. If they'd simply put the summonses from courts in Calais, Boulogne, Le Touquet and Abbeville in the bin when they arrive, I'd be obliged. Next stop, Ferrari.

fields.headline: 100 Falun Gong protesters held
fields.standfirst:
Introduction to Falun Gong
Falun Dafa
fields.trailText: Chinese police detained around a hundred followers of the banned Falun Gong sect in Beijing's Tiananmen Square yesterday after they staged silent protests to mark the first anniversary of the group's protests outside government headquarters last April.
fields.body:
Chinese police detained around a hundred followers of the banned Falun Gong sect in Beijing's Tiananmen Square yesterday after they staged silent protests to mark the first anniversary of the group's protests outside government headquarters last April.

The symbolic heart of the Chinese capital was thrown into confusion soon after its morning opening, as scores of Falun Gong members - who follow a meditation-based, Buddhist-influenced exercise regime - emerged from among tourist crowds and began a sit-in.

Some assumed the lotus position, trademark of the group, while others tried to raise yellow banners bearing its name.

Plain-clothes and uniformed police then sprinted across the square and bundled protesters into waiting vans. Some of the those arrested, who included men and women of all ages and at least one child, were shoved and punched.

A number of foreign journalists were detained by police and ordered to hand over their press cards, and films and videotapes were confiscated from reporters and tourists. Occasional scattered protests continued for several hours.

An official at the Tiananmen Square office said only: "It's just been a normal day in the square."

That may not be so far from the truth. Last week a senior Chinese official acknowledged that protests had taken place in the square on an almost daily basis since last summer when the government banned the Falun Gong and began a nationwide crackdown against its supporters.

The banning of the movement was provoked by last April's protest, when some 10,000 Falun Gong practitioners surrounded government headquarters for more than 12 hours, in protest against being labelled superstitious by an official publication.

Chinese leaders became alarmed that an apparently obscure movement could mobilise thousands in the tightly controlled capital without the authorities finding out.

It also numbered among its followers - estimated by some officials at tens of millions - government advisers and functionaries at various levels, including a senior official in the police ministry itself.

The government decided to stamp out what it labelled an evil cult. One of its main targets was Li Hongzhi, the Falun Gong's New York-based leader, whose personal popularity was seen as a threat by Chinese leaders. He claimed to possess healing powers and special talents such as the ability to walk through locked windows.

The authorities accused him of causing more than 1,500 deaths by urging his followers not to take medicine. A propaganda war and the jailing of hundreds of followers have led many to give up the practice.

Sun Yuxi, a spokesman for the Chinese foreign ministry, said yesterday that "98% of Falun Gong followers have now seen through the movement and broken away".

But some followers simply refuse to give up. Observers in Beijing say the government has been shocked by the persistence of the Falun Gong loyalists, whose continuing defiance in the face of a massive official campaign is almost unprecedented in contemporary China.

And western diplomats say the tough action by the authorities has risked alienating ordinary people who may have been disillusioned with changes in Chinese society, but were more concerned about improving their health and avoiding China's fast-rising medical costs, than with any kind of outright opposition to the government.

webTitle: Heads it's murder and Tails it's not

fields.headline: Heads it's murder and Tails it's not
fields.trailText: The members of the jury were certain about one thing: Phillip Givens was guilty of something. But exactly what that something was eluded them - even after nine hours of deliberation.
fields.body:
The members of the jury were certain about one thing: Phillip Givens was guilty of something. But exactly what that something was eluded them - even after nine hours of deliberation.

So they decided the fate of the 28-year-old man accused of killing his girlfriend by the only means they could think of to break the deadlock. They flipped a coin to find him guilty of murder rather than the alternative charge of manslaughter.

Not just any old coin, mind you, but a silver dollar.

"Realistically, I didn't think we had anything to lose," said jury foreman David Melton. "We were going to be hung without it."

Mr Melton, 45, said the 12 jury members believed that it was acceptable to make a decision on the basis of tossing the coin because they had all agreed to the legal tie-breaking device.

"It kind of blows your mind," said Mark Chandler, a lawyer for Givens, who is facing a maximum sentence of life imprisonment. "I think they had a lapse of judgment and I'd like to think it doesn't go on very often. They didn't have to resort to this."

The jury of five men and seven women considered the matter for nine hours over two days and concluded that a conviction was required. Ten members were prepared to compromise but one was adamant that the killing of Monica Briggs, 29, was murder and another insisted that it was manslaughter.

When word of how they made up their minds finally got back to Judge Kenneth Conliffe, he brought the jurors back to the court in Jefferson county, Louisville, Kentucky.

"It has come to the attention of the court that - with the great difficulty that the jury had - that you all got to the point where you were in essence almost hung, and that you may have resolved the issue by the flip of the coin," he said. He said there would now be a new trial to go ahead in September.

Court official and lawyers said that they had never heard of justice on the toss of a coin, but noted that jury deliberations are supposd to be secret.

"I don't think it's widespread," said Cedric Powell , an assistant law professor at the University of Louisville.

"But I think the system breaks down sometimes. There are imperfections in the system but it doesn't shake my faith in it."

webTitle: The battle that broke two nations' hearts

fields.headline: The battle that broke two nations' hearts
fields.standfirst: 85 years on, thousands gather before dawn to pay tribute to the thousands of Anzac troops who died fighting on the Gallipoli peninsula
fields.trailText: Before the first pale streaks of dawn appeared in the sky, a piper from the New Zealand Defence Force played a lament. Behind him, waves lapped around the small bay where another generation of young Australasians stormed ashore 85 years ago.
fields.body:
Before the first pale streaks of dawn appeared in the sky, a piper from the New Zealand Defence Force played a lament. Behind him, waves lapped around the small bay where another generation of young Australasians stormed ashore 85 years ago.

Thousands of people had gathered in the darkness in what has become an annual pilgrimage to pay tribute to the Anzac troops who fought and died on this rugged peninsula in western Turkey.

In a sombre atmosphere, the prime ministers of Australia and New Zealand inaugurated a memorial site. "Gallipoli was the battle which broke our hearts" said New Zealand's prime minister, Helen Clark.

It was on the beaches around this bay, just before dawn on April 25 1915, that the first allied troops landed on the Gallipoli peninsula. They made initial progress but soon met with ferocious resistance from the Ottoman Turkish defenders on the clifftops above.

Fighting was grim. Trenches were only yards apart, and combat was often hand to hand. Allied leaders were determined to take Gallipoli to break the defences of Istanbul, but it was not to be. The Gallipoli campaign was a devastating, if heroic, failure. Eight months after the first landings the allies retreated. Tens of thousands of people had lost their lives on both sides.

The majority of casualties were Turkish. There were also thousands of deaths among British and French forces. They were all remembered in yesterday's ceremony, but it is the spirit of the Anzacs which has taken on almost mythical status, that endures. For most Australians, Anzac day is a more important national holiday than Australia Day.

Australia's prime minister, John Howard, promised that although members of the Gallipoli generation - "as wild and free as the land they loved" - are almost gone, they will never be forgotten.

"The shadows gather on a time and a world in which our nation's spirit was born", said Mr Howard. "Soon the story of Anzac, which forever joined the people of Australia and New Zealand, will pass gently from memory into history."

The Turkish authorities are helping to keep that history alive. The peninsula has been declared a peace park, where military monuments and graveyards will be preserved side by side with the outstanding natural beauty of the rugged scrub-covered cliffs.

Among the Turkish commanders who rose to prominence defending the peninsula was Mustafa Kemal, who later took the name Ataturk as the first president of the modern Turkish republic.

Yesterday, his thoughts were quoted during a service of remembrance: "You, the mothers, who sent their sons from far away countries, wipe away your tears ... after having lost their lives on this land they have become our sons as well."

It was a sentiment which captured the mood of the thousands who listened to the Last Post yesterday.
fields.bodyText: Before the first pale streaks of dawn appeared in the sky, a piper from the New Zealand Defence Force played a lament. Behind him, waves lapped around the small bay where another generation of young Australasians stormed ashore 85 years ago. Thousands of people had gathered in the darkness in what has become an annual pilgrimage to pay tribute to the Anzac troops who fought and died on this rugged peninsula in western Turkey. In a sombre atmosphere, the prime ministers of Australia and New Zealand inaugurated a memorial site. "Gallipoli was the battle which broke our hearts" said New Zealand's prime minister, Helen Clark. It was on the beaches around this bay, just before dawn on April 25 1915, that the first allied troops landed on the Gallipoli peninsula. They made initial progress but soon met with ferocious resistance from the Ottoman Turkish defenders on the clifftops above. Fighting was grim. Trenches were only yards apart, and combat was often hand to hand. Allied leaders were determined to take Gallipoli to break the defences of Istanbul, but it was not to be. The Gallipoli campaign was a devastating, if heroic, failure. Eight months after the first landings the allies retreated. Tens of thousands of people had lost their lives on both sides. The majority of casualties were Turkish. There were also thousands of deaths among British and French forces. They were all remembered in yesterday's ceremony, but it is the spirit of the Anzacs which has taken on almost mythical status, that endures. For most Australians, Anzac day is a more important national holiday than Australia Day. Australia's prime minister, John Howard, promised that although members of the Gallipoli generation - "as wild and free as the land they loved" - are almost gone, they will never be forgotten. "The shadows gather on a time and a world in which our nation's spirit was born", said Mr Howard. "Soon the story of Anzac, which forever joined the people of Australia and New Zealand, will pass gently from memory into history." The Turkish authorities are helping to keep that history alive. The peninsula has been declared a peace park, where military monuments and graveyards will be preserved side by side with the outstanding natural beauty of the rugged scrub-covered cliffs. Among the Turkish commanders who rose to prominence defending the peninsula was Mustafa Kemal, who later took the name Ataturk as the first president of the modern Turkish republic. Yesterday, his thoughts were quoted during a service of remembrance: "You, the mothers, who sent their sons from far away countries, wipe away your tears ... after having lost their lives on this land they have become our sons as well." It was a sentiment which captured the mood of the thousands who listened to the Last Post yesterday.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Landmines kill 30 in Angola
Thirty people were killed and at least 17 injured when two trucks hit anti-tank mines in rural Angola at the weekend, aid workers said yesterday.
fields.body:
Landmines kill 30 in Angola
Thirty people were killed and at least 17 injured when two trucks hit anti-tank mines in rural Angola at the weekend, aid workers said yesterday.

Twelve people died at the scene on Saturday and 18 more in hospital near Negage, 160 miles north of the capital, Luanda. Aid workers have said Unita rebels, fighting a 25-year civil war, have changed tactics by using landmines rather than conventional assaults.
Reuters, Luanda

Russian tycoon faces charges
Prosecutors have formally charged the Russian tycoon Anatoly Bykov with ordering a murder and money-laundering in Krasnoyarsk, western Siberia, but a trial could be more than a year away, the ITAR-Tass news agency reported yesterday.

The two charges carry a maximum sentence of 22 years Mr Bykov has denied wrongdoing and said the case is politically motivated.
AP, Moscow

US bombs Iraq in no-fly zone
US warplanes bombed Iraq's air defence system yesterday in the northern no-fly zone, the US military said.

Iraqi forces fired anti-aircraft artillery at allied planes near Bashiqah, 250 miles north of Baghdad, a statement from the US European Command said. The jets responded by bombing Iraqi air defence sites. An Iraqi military spokesman told the official Iraqi News Agency that a water tanker driver died in the attack.
Reuters, Istanbul

Belgium hands over general
The former head of the Rwandan gendarmerie has been extradited by Belgium to face charges of organising the 1994 genocide in Rwanda.

General Augustin Ndindi-liyimana will stand trial at the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda, which is taking place in Arusha, Tanzania. He was chief of staff of Rwanda's paramilitary police in the years before and including the 1994 genocide in which at least 500,000 Tutsis and moderate Hutus died.
AP, Arusha, Tanzania

ETA targets journalist
A Spanish newspaper, noted for its bitter criticism of the Basque separatist group ETA, received a letter bomb yesterday, officials said.

The device, deactivated before it went off, was addressed to the ETA expert at the newspaper La Razon. Last month a letter bomb was sent to a state radio journalist.
Reuters, Madrid

fields.headline: The best Talking Heads scene
fields.standfirst: American Psycho
fields.trailText: American Psycho.
fields.body:
New York. The late 1980s. Patrick Bateman (Christian Bale) reclines in the back of a stretch limousine, his life partner Evelyn (Reese Witherspoon) beside him on their way to a dinner date. Evelyn rattles off a list of possible guests and themes for their imminent wedding; Patrick sits listening to his Walkman. Hissing tinnily through his headphones, we can hear Talking Heads' Wild Wild Life. Patrick comments in voiceover.

"I'm trying to listen to the new Talking Heads tape, but Evelyn, my so-called fiancée, keeps buzzing in my ear."

Evelyn appears to be talking to herself as much as Patrick.

"Photographer? Annie Leibowitz. We'll get Annie Leibowitz."

She nods to herself.

"Patrick, we should do it."

Irritated, Patrick slowly takes off his headphones, turning to Evelyn.

"Do what ?"

"Get married. Have a wedding."

"No. I can't take the time off work."

"When has anyone at that company done anything nice for you?"

"I don't want to talk about it."

"I hate that job anyway. I don't know why you don't just quit."

Patrick speaks very slowly, as if addressing a child.

"Because... I... Want... To... Fit... In."

He looks at her in disgust, turning back to stare out of the tinted window. He puts his headphones back on.The conversation is over.

See also: Stop Making Sense, True Stories, Wall Street

Don't see also: Look Who's Talking

Pointless trivia: American Psycho star, Christian Bale, trained for 10 weeks in dancing and martial arts for his 1992 roles in Newsies and Swing Kids.

fields.headline: The student finance guide
fields.standfirst: Debt is rising, grants have been abolished, fees introduced - well, no one said being a student would be easy on the pocket. Ian Wylie tells you what you need to know to keep your head above water
fields.trailText: After the initial excitement of getting your A-level results and gaining entry to university or college, you'll need to start thinking about your money.
fields.body:
After the initial excitement of getting your A-level results and gaining entry to university or college, you'll need to start thinking about your money.

Government grants have now been abolished for new undergraduates, although existing students who are already receiving a grant will carry on getting the money until they graduate.

Your first priority will be to pay your tuition fees. Universities will usually stop people graduating if fees are unpaid. However, the maximum tuition fee contribution expected from students in 2000/2001 is £1,050, and around a third of all students - those whose family income is below £17,805 - will not be required to pay tuition fees.

There are also courses, or certain years of some courses, where your college will charge fees of £520 instead of £1,050. And if you are a student on a full-time or part-time course of initial teacher training (other than a first degree course), you should receive free tuition whatever your and your family's income.

In any case, however, most students are entitled to a grant towards their fees. This grant is based on an assessment by your local education authority (LEA) of your income and that of your family.

Your LEA will want details of your parents' residual income. It does this by taking their gross income, for income tax purposes, and subtracting certain allowances. Then the LEA decides the parental contribution according to the following calculation:

 no contribution if their income is less than £17,805;

 £45 if their residual income is at least £17,805, plus £1 for every £13 of residual income between £17,806 and £22,754; plus £1 for every £9.20 between £22,755 and £33,449; plus £1 for every £7.50 for £33,450 and over. The maximum contribution is £6,437.

However, the actual parental contribution cannot be more than the maximum fee contribution of £1,050. Different rules also apply if you have a brother or sister who is also receiving student support from the LEA. Your parents' total contribution will be worked out before it is shared between yourself and your brother and sister. In normal circumstances, it will be shared out equally.

But for all your other expenditure - rent, books, food, going out - you'll need to consider alternative sources of finance.

A student loan

The maximum amount of loan that you can get depends on where you live and study; which course you study; which year of your course you are on; how much you and your family are expected to contribute; and the length of your academic year.

Three-quarters of the maximum loan available does not depend on your or your family's income. For the 2000/2001 academic year, all students should qualify for a loan of £2,795 (£3,445 in London) per annum. Some, from less well-off backgrounds, will be eligible for the maximum loan of £3,725 (£4,590 in London). If you're intending to live at home with your parents, you will be eligible for a loan of £2,215 to £2,950 depending on income.

You don't have to borrow to take the full entitlement, but most students so as you cannot apply for a top-up later. The loan can be paid either in three equal instalments or in one lump sum. The latter course is suitable for students with will-power as they can earn interest on the sum advanced until it is needed. Those who cannot resist the urge to spend, are best advised to receive an equal portion of their entitlement each term.

Your parents

Tell your parents to dig deep. Calculations from the National Union of Students (NUS) suggest that students will typically face a shortfall of more than £3,000 in each undergraduate year.

Some parents are better prepared than others. The most prudent will have been setting money aside for five years and more in a Tessa, Pep, Isa or endowment policy. Parents with less than a few months to prepare will have little option but to divert money from funds saved for retirement or to borrow.

Revolving credit or 'draw-down' loans secured on a home are a cheaper and more flexible form of borrowing than personal loans or overdrafts, allowing parents to draw down cash each term. Parents should also remember that most banks offer preferential rates to students - some parents may have reservations about letting their children loose with an interest-free overdraft, but it makes sound financial sense to take advantage of cheap credit where available

A job

Students are increasingly likely to take part-time jobs, though universities - and the NUS - tend to advise against it. The job market depends on the area, of course, but several sources of student earnings are not taken into consideration by your LEA when calculating grants. Wages from casual or part-time vacation and term- time jobs, the first £820 of unearned income, £1,000 of any scholarship and £1,855 of any trust income are all ignored. Sums above these figures reduce the student's support £1 for £1.

Hardship money

Access funds and hardship loans are available to help students who are in financial difficulty. They can be used to help with living expenses and course costs including childcare costs, travel, accommodation costs, household expenses, books and course equipment. You will usually need to wait until you have started your course before you can apply for either a hardship loan or an access funds payment. However, if you think you may need additional financial help to complete your course, you should talk to your college before you start the course, about how these two schemes might be able to help you.

Colleges decide which students will receive payments and how much each payment will be. Student support or student services staff at your college will be able to advise you which scheme will best suit your needs.They will tell you how to apply. In some cases you may be able to have an access fund payment and a hardship loan at the same time.

Educational charities

There are many charitable trusts and organisations which can assist students. Many of the payments may be small, to help assist with the purchase of books and equipment, others can be quite substantial. Schools or libraries should have details of local educational trusts and charities. The Educational Grants Advisory Service, part of the Family Welfare Association, also has a comprehensive database of charities and trusts.

&#149 Details of the scales, allowances and additional payments can be found in the Department for Education and Employment's booklet Financial Support for Higher Education Students in 2000/2001. To obtain a copy telephone 0800 731 9133.

Money Unlimited's student finance guide
